Perrier Is Planning Expansion in U.S.
LEAD: The French mineral water group Source Perrier plans a substantial expansion in the United States in the next few years after several recent acquisitions, its chairman, Gustave Leven, said at the company's annual meeting at its headquarters in southeastern France.


Dry Forecast Drives Up Farm Futures
LEAD: Soybean, grain, sugar and cotton prices rebounded yesterday as forecasters warned that the Midwest faced a new siege of hot and dry weather.


Hoover Institution Chief to Resist Order to Retire
LEAD: W. Glenn Campbell, conservative Republican, friend of Ronald Reagan and builder of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, relishes a good fight, and a difficult few weeks have given him an occasion for one.


A Homeric Opera
LEAD: ''The Golden Apple,'' an aopera by Jerome Moross, is to be presented by the Kurt P. Reimann Opera Studio of New York University, at the University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street, tonight at 8 o'clock.
The work, which was composed in 1954, is based on sections of ''The Odyssey'' and ''The Iliad,'' but the action has been moved to Washington state, circa 1900.


...But East Germans Are Intent on Staying As Is
LEAD: Although the East German press reported fully on the keynote speech by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the Soviet party conference, East Germany's conservative leader has repeatedly made clear he has no immediate intention of importing any of the Soviet leader's program of change.


Isaac Molho, 83, Founded French Bookstore
LEAD: Isaac E. Molho, the co-founder of the Librairie de France in Rockefeller Center, died of heart failure Monday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Debt Sales Climb in Quarter But Stock Offerings Slump
LEAD: Corporations continued to find the bond market a rich field for raising money in the second quarter, but investor apprehension limited their ability to find new equity capital.


Iran Said to Fortify Key Strait
LEAD: Iran has nearly completed an underground bunker that will put its Chinese-built Silkworm missiles within range of any ship passing through the Strait of Hormuz and conceal the weapons from American reconnaissance, a top American military official said today.

Reviews/Music; Cerebral Solos And Standards On Saxophone
LEAD: Anthony Braxton started his late set of alto saxophone solos at the Knitting Factory last Friday night with music that sounded like a sheaf of music crumpled and shredded -gentle melody phrases, assertive lines, trills, sputters, honks, juxtaposed every which way.
Then, for the rest of the set, he put the individual pieces back together again.


AT THE BAR
LEAD: Alton H. Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason are arguably the two lawyers New Yorkers most love to hate, largely because of their unorthodox and unsettling manner of proceeding in highly visible, racially sensitive cases.


John Cage Is Focus Of Outdoor Concerts
LEAD: The Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, at the Museum of Modern Art, is for many people a kind of spiritual haven within the city: a place one can spend a few contemplative hours among the trees and reflecting pools, surrounded by works of Rodin, Moore, Picasso and Matisse, without leaving midtown.

LEAD: Three developers are creating houses on a nine-acre tract that, for as long as most Staten Island residents can remember, was the home of the Franz Reb Stables.

LEAD: ''All four persons named in this document are delegates to the conference.''


Cenith Makes Bid For Rest of Ionics
LEAD: A Boston-based partnership, Cenith Partners L.P., has offered to acquire all the shares of Ionics Inc. that it does not already control for a package of cash and securities that it valued at $25 a share, or an estimated $80 million.
Ionics is a maker of water and chemical processing and pollution abatement equipment based in Watertown, Mass.


3 Convicted of Setting Fire To Home for Foster Babies
LEAD: Three Queens homeowners were convicted yesterday evening of setting fire to an unoccupied house on their block to keep New York City from using it to shelter foster-care infants.

LEAD: LaMarr Hoyt, winner of 24 games and the Cy Young Award with the Chicago White Sox in 1983, will serve the rest of his one-year prison term for violating probation on a cocaine conviction in a South Carolina halfway house, starting this weekend.

Diana feels vaguely alienated.

Re: Shaping the Court; Reagan Is Not the First President Thwarted By Unpredictability of Issues, and Minds
LEAD: ''Packing the Supreme Court simply can't be done,'' said President Harry Truman, who had seen two of his four appointees join a 1952 decision striking down his broad claim of executive authority to seize the steel mills. ''I've tried it and it won't work.''


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 440 money market mutual funds decreased $1.93 billion, to $264.36 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 122 institutional funds decreased $851.3 million, to $70.10 billion.
Assets of the 220 general purpose funds were down $390.0 million, to $81.44 billion.

Mets on Power Surge; Yanks Near Lead; Yankees 5, White Sox 3
LEAD: Tommy John still shakes his head when he is asked how long he can continue to pitch this way.
He is unsure, knowing that he has seen the end of his career before but that now, at the age of 45, he is still able to win baseball games.


Drought Revives Fight for Great Lakes Water
LEAD: A proposal by Gov.
James R. Thompson of Illinois to divert water from Lake Michigan to replenish the Mississippi River has renewed an emotional, 80-year debate among the states and Canadian provinces that share the Great Lakes basin.


A Bit of Burton's Legacy
Richard Burton had a weakness for troubled clerics.
From the high drama of ''Becket'' to the wonderfully trashy romance of ''The Sandpiper,'' he really knew how to wrangle with his conscience.
Whether he was playing the archbishop or the adulterous minister, his eyes grew piercing, his voice projected from deep in the diaphragm.
But he never learned when it was time to parody himself.
How could he play ''Exorcist II: The Heretic'' with a straight face?
And what did he see in ''Absolution''?
Here he tackled the hopeless role of Father Goddard, a teacher in a Roman Catholic boys' school, who is psychologically tortured when his favorite student confesses to murder.


MAN IN THE NEWS: Marcel Lefebvre; A Devotion To the Past
LEAD: To some, particularly among American Catholics, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre is primarily a defender of the Latin Mass and the precise question-and-answer catechisms they knew in the years before the Second Vatican Council.


Third World Bank Aid
LEAD: Commercial banks must do more to help highly indebted middle-income countries by mixing new money with debt-reduction plans, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today.


McClease Freed on Bail; Tape Issue Unclear
LEAD: Samuel M. McClease, who claimed he had tapes of Tawana Brawley's advisers privately expressing doubts about the case, was released on bail yesterday after signing a sworn statement declaring that he was ''presently unable'' to produce the recordings.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Top-Ranking Executive Returning to Thompson
LEAD: Bertram Metter, the J. Walter Thompson executive who resigned under its old management, is returning to his old title of chairman of the domestic company.


Louis Novins, 79, Pay TV Advocate, Dies
LEAD: Louis A. Novins, a motion picture executive who tried unsuccessfully to introduce pay television in the 1950's, died after a heart attack Wednesday at George Washington University Medical Center in Washington.
He was 79 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

LEAD: Supporters of gun control won a victory today when the House Judiciary Committee approved an amendment to require a national seven-day waiting period in sales of pistols.

LEAD: Three young men were convicted yesterday of the shotgun slaying of a Queens grand jury witness in a case that raised public fears about the security of witnesses.

770 Jobs to Be Cut By Union Pacific
LEAD: The Union Pacific Railroad said it would close its repair shops in Omaha and move their operations to the railroad's newer shops in North Little Rock, Ark.
Railroad officials told the 770 workers at the Omaha locomotive and car shops that they would lose their jobs beginning in 90 days.

Jazz Festival; Celebrating French Jazz
LEAD: The JVC Jazz Festival's Salute to Jazz in France at Town Hall on Wednesday was a bit like a wine tasting - it offered little sips implying larger things.


Review/Recital; Young Violinist From China
LEAD: Qian Zhou is a very young violinist from China who has been studying at the Peabody Institute and who last year won the Marguerite Long-Jacques Thibaud Competition in Paris.
Miss Zhou's evening at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday radiated good health.
There is muscle and weight to her sound and the right musical values seem to be in place.


Two Plead Guilty to Bank Fraud
LEAD: A former officer of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and a former vice president at the Penn Square Bank pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court to bank fraud charges in a plea-bargaining agreement.

LEAD: George P. Rutland, who resigned from Calfed Inc. in May when he was passed over for the top post at the big California savings and loan institution, will head a smaller savings unit based in Connecticut.

U.S. 'Debtor' Status Grows  The stake held by foreigners in the United States has risen sharply.
The trend could eventually hurt Americans' standard of living.


Angolan Rebel Chief Meets Reagan
LEAD: Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader, met with President Reagan today and said afterward that the President had agreed with a plan he presented to bring peace and reconciliation to Angola.


Reviews/Music; David Murray's New Precision On Saxophone
LEAD: The saxophonist David Murray's first set at the Knitting Factory on Sunday night could barely contain all his playing.
Mr.
Murray, who is a member of a generation located between the 1960's avant-gardists and today's young neo-conservatives, is changing his style, and he seems to be flaunting the fact by playing better than ever.


Belfast Shipyard Plan
LEAD: The British Government confirmed today that it planned to sell the troubled Northern Ireland shipyard Harland &amp; Wolff and said Ravi Tikoo, an India-born shipping entrepreneur, might be the buyer.
Mr.
Tikoo wants to build the world's biggest luxury cruise liner in the Belfast yard, which has 4,000 workers.


A.M.A. Urges Breach of Privacy To Warn Potential AIDS Victims
LEAD: The American Medical Association, breaking with the centuries-old tradition of confidentiality, today strongly urged physicians to warn the sexual partners of patients found to carry the AIDS virus if there was no other way to alert them to the danger.


J.A.L. Orders 15 More of Boeing's 747-400's
LEAD: Japan Air Lines has decided to buy 15 more Boeing 747's for a total of about $2 billion, a spokesman for the carrier said yesterday.


Mayor Received Help In Plot, F.B.I. Charges
LEAD: An extortion plot against a housing developer in Wayne, N.J., involved a second person besides Mayor Louis V. Messercola, an F.B.I. complaint charged yesterday.


2d Leak on Phone Bid Is Reported
LEAD: Officials of the General Services Administration said yesterday that secret bid information for a second Government telephone contract might have been leaked to competitors and that the agency had suspended bidding on the contract.


Robert O. Fishel, 74, A Baseball Executive
LEAD: Robert O. Fishel, a major league baseball executive for more than 40 years and a Yankee official for 20 years, died yesterday afternoon, after collapsing outside his apartment in Manhattan.
He was 74 years old and had been suffering from a respiratory ailment.


MEXICANS REJECT CRITICISM FROM U.S.
LEAD: Responding to unusually heated American protests, the Mexican Foreign Minister has declared that his Government's refusal to extradite a Puerto Rican to the United States on terrorism charges ''was in strict compliance with Mexican law'' and should not be construed as a deliberate anti-American act.


Teen-Ager Convicted of Manslaughter in Fatal Fire
LEAD: A 14-year-old who admitted setting fire to an abandoned car in Brooklyn last November, fatally burning a man inside, was acquitted of murder but convicted of the lesser charge of second-degree manslaughter by a jury that deliberated for an hour yesterday.


Investor Group Buying S. Carolina Resort Island
LEAD: Charles S. Way Jr. and his associates have bought themselves some choice real estate: a sparkling South Carolina sea island that had been in the hands of Kuwaiti investors.


At Least 14 People Wounded In Downtown Pretoria Blast
LEAD: A bomb exploded in a busy shopping center in downtown Pretoria today where the air force has its headquarters, and at least 14 people were wounded, the police said.

Mr.

Machito had arrived from Cuba in 1937 and sung around New York with Xavier Cugat and other bandleaders, but in 1940 he was ready for his own group.

Terms were not announced. . . .
Larry Van Eman, an assistant at Oregon State the last eight years and a coaching disciple of Ralph Miller, was appointed to the staff of Jimmy Rodgers, the new Boston Celtic coach.


White House Will Start Drug Tests For Employees of Executive Office
LEAD: Hours after the disclosure today that three White House guards had been suspended for suspected off-duty use of cocaine, the White House announced a random drug-testing program for employees of the Executive Office of the President.


Mozart Operas
LEAD: Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' and ''Cost Fan Tutte'' are to be performed this weekend by the opera department of the Brooklyn Conservatory at the South Street Theater, 10th Avenue at 42d Street.
The performances, featuring student casts, are to be sung in English under the direction of Thomas Schilling.


Fiddles, Fireworks And Shakespeare For the Fourth
LEAD: THANKS to the fortuitous timing of the Declaration of Independence 212 years ago, the United States celebrates its birthday at a time when warm weather turns most people's thoughts to the great outdoors.
Even in New York City, where the outdoors is all too often assumed to be a crowded intersection or a forest of tall buildings, that more gentle and natural outdoors - of parks, rivers and beaches - will be the stage on which dozens of festive dramas will be played this holiday weekend.

Rose Bowl Shifts to ABC
LEAD: The Rose Bowl will be televised by ABC, beginning next January and continuing through 1997, ending the game's long affiliation with NBC, officials of ABC Sports and the Tournament of Roses Association announced yesterday.


Agent Orange Fund Is Backed
LEAD: The Supreme Court today removed the last legal obstacle to a $240 million settlement between Vietnam veterans and manufacturers of the herbicide Agent Orange.


Police Corruption Trial Under Way in Boston
LEAD: At a trial in Federal District Court here today, the Government outlined its case against seven present and former Boston police detectives accused of systematically extorting money and favors from the owners of some of this city's most popular restaurants and nightclubs.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz reaffirmed United States support for El Salvador and Honduras today as he met with leaders of the two nations to devise a common course of diplomatic action against the Nicaraguan Government.


Harlem Dance Theater
LEAD: The Dance Theater of Harlem and the Universal Symphony Orchestra, directed by Gail Hightower, are to perform Borodin's ''Polovetsian Dances,'' Stravinsky's ''Firebird Suite,'' and Alex North's ''Streetcar Named Desire'' at City Center, 131 West 55th, tonight at 8.
The program will be repeated tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M., and a second program, which includes works by Copland and Tchaikovsky, will be offred on Sunday at 3 P.M..

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, asked for an extension of the deadline of next Tuesday for seeking an indictment of John F. Mulheren, a takeover stock speculator who is suspected of engaging in a stock parking scheme, people close to the investigation said yesterday.

Restaurants
LEAD: The Russian Tea Room remains a special place, if not necessarily a special restaurant.
Where else can you have Christmas in July: pine-green walls, bright red banquettes, tinsel-draped chandeliers decorated with gleaming Christmas-tree balls; ''Russian'' waiters named Salvador and Bob decked out in festive red tunics, and stargazing and Stolichnaya in abundance?


Review/Dance; Platel Dances 'Swan Lake'
LEAD: The Paris Opera Ballet is blessed with extraordinary dancers.
That is certainly clear from the company's ''Swan Lake.'' Rudolf Nureyev's staging may be lugubrious, yet there have been memorable performances of its leading roles.

Review/Art; Haunting Heads From Abakanowicz
LEAD: In a corner of a group show at the Marlborough Gallery is a cluster of eight recent sculptures by Magdalena Abakanowicz that may catch even her supporters by surprise.
Her earlier sculptures in the show are more typical. ''Androgyn IV'' is a burlap torso perched on a wooden support like an idol, or like a figure awaiting execution.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Kelso Depot Journal; Fighting for a Desert Railroad Station
LEAD: Standing under the graceful loggia of the shuttered Union Pacific Railroad depot here, staring into the vast void that fills the desert between the lonely station and the stark Granite Mountains to the southwest, it is difficult to imagine that nearly 2,000 people lived here in World War II, mining iron ore.


Our Towns; At Cooperstown, So Many Greats, So Little Time
LEAD: Nine-year-old Timmy Brophy knew the Baseball Hall of Fame was going to be pretty great, but he didn't think it would be this great. ''Ma, look,'' he said. ''Babe Ruth's bowling ball!'' It was breathtaking.


Wisdom Made Easy
LEAD: To the Editor:


Organ-Music Sampler; Organ-Music Sampler
LEAD: Nicolas Kynaston, who served as organist at Westminster Cathedral in London between 1961 and 1971 and has worked since as a concert artist, closed Donald Joyce's venturesome Monday night organ recital series at the Church of St.
John the Evangelist.


TV Weekend; The Synergism of Linked Repeats
LEAD: How do you get more mileage out of summer reruns?
Public television's ''Great Performances'' has hit on the neat idea of linking repeats, in varying degrees, to current performances.


ICH Offer Rejected
LEAD: The board of the First Executive Corporation rejected an offer by the ICH Corporation to buy 6.3 million of its shares for $12 a share.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, First Executive, an insurance holding company based in Los Angeles, said its board would take no other action.


It's Debut Season At the Bronx Zoo
LEAD: This year's additions to the Bronx Zoo include white-handed gibbons, left, Przewalski horses, above, and flamingo chicks.


Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Gains 19.73
LEAD: Stock prices staged a broad advance yesterday on sharply higher volume.


White House Presentation
LEAD: Pat Riley, Lakers' coach, giving a warm-up jacket to President Reagan yesterday at the White House.
The jacket was autographed by members of the team.
At center is Christine Riley, the coach's wife. (AP)


The Cost of Glasses, Wrongly Magnified
LEAD: In 49 states, you can buy reading glasses without a prescription.
Why not in New York?
Because optometrists and opticians don't want the competition, and have successfully disguised their self-interest as medical prudence.
This may be the year, however, when a majority in the Legislature is finally brought to serve the interest of the general public.


2 S.I. Men Accused Of Sodomizing Boys In Major Abuse Case
LEAD: Two Staten Island men surrendered yesterday to face charges of sodomizing and sexually abusing boys in what the Staten Island District Attorney described as a major investigation of child abuse in the borough.


Mets on Power Surge; Yanks Near Lead; Mets 12, Astros 6
LEAD: The Mets played last night as if they were still soaring from the two-out home run that Howard Johnson launched in the ninth inning in Pittsburgh Wednesday night.
The home run tied the score, and the Mets won two innings later.


Japanese Buy U.S. Ski Area
LEAD: Victoria Company Ltd., a Tokyo sporting goods retailer, said today that it had acquired the 1,500-acre Breckenridge ski area in Colorado from a Chicago partnership that includes the Denver investor Marvin Davis.
No terms were disclosed, but real estate brokers estimated the purchase price to be near $65 million.


Brazil Inflation Rate Up
LEAD: Prices in Brazil shot up by 167 percent in the first half of this year, according to official figures.
Inflation in June hit 19.53 percent, the biggest monthly increase since June 1987, when prices rose a record 26.06 percent.
The new figures, which were released Wednesday, brought inflation since the start of the year to 167.74 percent, while prices rose 336.09 percent in the last 12 months.


A Suit Against Borg-Warner
LEAD: The California Insurance Commissioner, Roxani M. Gillespie, has filed suit against the Borg-Warner Corporation seeking up to $80 million in damages as a result of the failure of Centaur Insurance, a wholly owned Borg-Warner subsidiary, to satisfy its reinsurance obligations to Mission Insurance.


Cavities and Communists
LEAD: There are few Americans over 20 for whom a childhood trip to the dentist didn't mean a cavity count.
But now, the National Institute of Dental Research reports that half the nation's children have no tooth decay whatsoever.
The reason: fluoride, once the paranoid's favorite target.


Jazz Festival; Gil Evans Tribute
LEAD: Most big bands are modeled on machines, with gleaming, interlocking parts meshed in efficient arrangements.
The Gil Evans Orchestra, until the death of its leader this year, was something else - a hive, perhaps, or a commune.
Instead of a blueprinted clarity, there's a fertile murk from which solos rise while colleagues toss in dissonances and the rhythm eddies below; arrangements seem to tumble together and later dissolve, like a jam session in which the horn players just happen to come up with fully harmonized ensembles.


Mutual Fund Sales Decline
LEAD: Monthly mutual fund sales fell to $7.1 billion in May, compared with $9 billion in April and $13.5 billion in May 1987, the Investment Company Institute said today.

World of Drugs Has A Death Penalty Now
LEAD: To the Editor:


Review/Theater; A Murder Most Foul, And Its Aftermath
LEAD: In April 1966 French railway officials found a piece of a female human torso in a freight train.
Within days other parts of the same body were found in boxcars across France.
The only thing missing was the victim's head.
The police, working with rail schedules, finally pinpointed a bridge under which all the trains carrying parts of the woman's body had passed.


Holiday Events Throughout the Region
LEAD:  New Jersey


Review/Theater; A Romantic Interlude
LEAD: Bob Morris's explorations of a gay man's place in a heterosexual world are becoming wittier. ''A Circle,'' his new play, being presented at the Theater for the New City as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, twists the familiar boy-meets-girl story into a funny adventure in self-discovery.


No Headline
LEAD:  GOLF  Three Share Lead: Morris Hatalsky one-putted 12 times yesterday as he scrambled to a 66 and a share of the first-round lead in the $900,000 Western Open in Oak Brook, Ill.
Hatalsky, who won the Kemper Open earlier this month, shared the top spot with Mark Hayes and Brian Mogg.
All cut six shots off par at the Butler National Golf Club.


Archdiocese to Sponsor Mass for Homosexuals
LEAD: The Seattle Archdiocese will assume sponsorship of a mass for homosexuals, Archbishop Raymond G. Hundhausen announced today, but the group that had sponsored the weekly church service is divided over whether to accept the change or move elsewhere.

LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts.
Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

LEAD: The judge in the Wedtech racketeering case ruled yesterday that if Representative Mario Biaggi takes the stand in his defense, prosecutors will be allowed to explore his conviction for accepting illegal gratuities and obstruction of justice, as well as other controversies in his past.

LEAD: This was the 78th meeting in their rivalry, one that began when Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova were the child stars of women's tennis, only beginning to make their presence felt.

Study Links Crash Dieting to Slower Weight Loss
LEAD: Athletes who repeatedly gain and lose weight may end up with slower metabolism, burning calories more slowly than normal, according to a new study.
The findings lend support to the disputed theory that crash dieting causes slower metabolism, making it easier to gain weight and harder to diet in the future.

LEAD: The Pacific Stock Exchange, which operates trading floors here and in San Francisco, said today that it had reached an agreement that it hopes will lead to the creation of another exchange in Honolulu.

LEAD: Fidelity Brokerage Services, a discount brokerage subsidiary of Fidelity Investments, Boston, has taken its $2 million print account to Tarlow Advertising.

LEAD: An incentive plan to keep the Chicago White Sox from moving to Florida was approved tonight by the Illinois Legislature after one of the plan's sponsors warned that ''We're about to turn the lights out in Comiskey Park.''


Acquittals in Egyptian Trial
LEAD: A criminal court today acquitted 44 police officers charged with torturung Moslem fundamentalists held in a case linked to the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.
The officers, ranging in rank up to brigadier, held posts in the Interior Ministry's Prisons Administration and the State Security Service.

Economic Scene; Still Wanted: A Budget Plan
LEAD: THE connection between a nation's internal and external deficits is clear: If a nation invests more than it saves and consumes more than it produces - as the United States has been doing - the excess must be covered by an inflow of foreign capital.
The greater the internal budget deficit, the lower the rate of national savings and the greater the dependence on foreign capital.

How Coca-Cola Obtains Its Coca
LEAD: For years people have speculated about the secret formula of Coca-Cola, and the ingredients its contains.

'We Are Talking About Our Future'
LEAD: Well, at last.
Along comes a new proposal for national drug action that is clear, sensible, comprehensive, entirely doable.
It is based on solid thinking about what the problems are, makes choices about priorities, sets goals and outlines organization.
It could finally, finally give the country a known plan and a rational strategy for fighting narcotics.

LEAD: College-bound only a week ago, two Bronx youths were arraigned last night on attempted murder and other charges in what the police called a 45-minute crime spree by five prep-school classmates that ended in the death of one and possibly ruined lives for the others.

On Stage
LEAD:  A Robbins Retrospective


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  The Economy


NOW Renews Equal Rights Battle
LEAD: At noon yesterday, Molly C. Yard, the president of the National Organization for Women, carried to the steps of the nation's Capitol petitions bearing 100,000 signatures calling for passage of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.


All Sides in Nicaragua Get Plea From Bishops
LEAD: Nicaragua's Roman Catholic bishops today called on the Sandinista Government, opposition political parties and contra leaders to renew their political discussions and reach agreements that guarantee ''an irreversible democratization and pacification of the country.''


Holiday Events Throughout the Region
LEAD:  Hudson Valley


Bonds and Notes Up in Slow Day
LEAD: The prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher in very quiet end-of-quarter trading yesterday, given a push by a drop in crude oil prices.


REview/Music; In a Park, Show Tunes
LEAD: It's getting hard to tell the festivals apart without a scorecard, and sometimes they intersect.
On Tuesday evening at Damrosch Park, in Lincoln Center, Martin Josman led the National Chorale in a free concert that the group's schedule listed as the opening performance of the New York Festival of American Music Theater - a run of 16 performances in New York and Westchester parks, through Aug.


Reviews/Music; High-Volume Statement From Yugoslavia
LEAD: Laibach, the Yugoslav rock band that performed last Friday and Saturday at the Kitchen, is either an ugly phenomenon or a didactic joke - and a loud one either way.
Named after the word used by the German occupation forces in World War II for the Slovenian capital city of Ljubljana, Laibach arrives with songs and manifestoes espousing ''totalitarianism,'' giving up individuality to accomplish collective goals.


Builders Weigh Major Project For Brooklyn
LEAD: An 8 million-square-foot redevelopment project in downtown Brooklyn is being considered by the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian builder, and the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, the largest American builder of shopping centers, the heads of the companies said yesterday.


Fannie Mae Offer
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, plans to announce on Wednesday the interest rate for a $500 million offering of indexed sinking-fund debentures due in 1993.
The offering will be made through 25 dealers selected by Fannie Mae.


Most of Eastern Bloc Follows Moscow's Call for Change Intently . . .
LEAD: The Soviet Union's closest Eastern European allies are following the Moscow party conference intently, evidently convinced that as the cards are dealt there, their own hands may be shaped in future political and economic decisions.


Edward Sulzberger Is Dead at 80; President of Real Estate Concern
LEAD: Edward Sulzberger, a patriarch of the New York real estate industry who was chairman of the board and former president of Sulzberger-Rolfe, died last night at his home in Manhattan.
He was 80 years old.


Iraq Says U.S. Supplied Iran With Data on Planned Raid
LEAD: Iraq has accused the United States of supplying intelligence information to Iran that disclosed details of Baghdad's military plans to mount its successful attack on an Iranian-held oilfield last weekend.


When Teen-Agers Kill
LEAD: The Supreme Court's 5-to-3 decision spares the life of a condemned killer who, though he committed an atrocious crime, was only 15 years old when he did so.
But this particular ruling still leaves the Court without a principle by which to decide who is too young to be executed.


Management Buyout Is Approved at Payless
LEAD: Payless Cashways Inc.'s board of directors today approved a sweetened offer of $909 million from senior management to take the building-supplies company private in a leveraged buyout.


Mauling the Mallers at Manassas
LEAD: More than 60,000 spectators recently gathered at Gettysburg, Pa., for a partial re-enactment of the great battles of July 1-3, 1863.
That's a crowd about two-thirds the size of the Army of Northern Virginia that Robert E. Lee led into the crucial struggle of the Civil War, 125 years ago today.


Review/Recital; Handling Bach With Affection
LEAD: It's nice to come across a musician with both a heart and the technique to make its feelings clear.
We seldom do.
Mostly it is one or the other - as it was with the piano program by Joseph E. Fields at Weill Recital Hall on the evening of June 23.


Holiday Events Throughout the Region
LEAD:  Westchester County


Reunion of Old Champions
LEAD: SHE stood at the baseline, hoping for some kind of intervention, divine or otherwise, to prolong her match against her old rival.
Even when she saw the linesman at the opposite end of the court extend his hand, she wanted to grasp the moment and hang out a little longer at Centre Court.


Mexico Given Ban in Soccer
LEAD: Mexico was banned from all international soccer competition today, including the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea.

Risking Double Defeat: No Arms Treaty and Bad Arms
LEAD: ''Democracies usually do the right thing - after exhausting all the other alternatives,'' Abba Eban tells us.
Nowhere is this more true than in the United States' efforts to modernize its land-based ICBM force, which after 12 long years seem still in the ''exhausting'' phase.


Recipe for a Novel
LEAD: Nan and Ivan Lyons, authors of ''Someone Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe,'' came to Washington this week to do a little test tasting of a concoction in their new novel, ''The President Is Coming to Lunch.''


REBEL ARCHBISHOP ANOINTS 4 BISHOPS
LEAD: In a ceremony filled with cornet flourishes and angry sermons, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre brought about the first major schism in the Roman Catholic Church in more than a century today when he consecrated four bishops in defiance of the Pope's orders.

Surgery for Allison
LEAD: Bobby Allison, the race car driver who was severely injured in an accident June 19 at the Nascar Miller 500 at Long Pond, Pa., underwent surgery yesterday to install a steel rod in his fractured left leg.
Allison, 50 years old, broke two bones in his lower left leg, his left ribs, his femur and suffered a concussion.

BUSH SAYS RIVALS OFFER ONLY GLOOM
LEAD: Vice President Bush yesterday portrayed the Presidential election as a choice between two economic visions: Republican optimism and undue Democratic pessimism.


Murder Defendant Is Beaten
LEAD: A man accused of murdering two of six kidnapped women he imprisoned in a basement ''house of horrors'' was attacked by two inmates Wednesday while a jury deliberated the charges against him, officials said.
The defendant, Gary Heidnik, 44 years old, suffered only bruises in the attack, which occurred in a holding cell one floor above where the jury was meeting.


European Bank Idea Rebuffed
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that monetary union in the European Community would be difficult and that progress toward such integration would not necessarily involve a common European central bank.


Ford Will Convert Plant for Engines
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company will spend $780 million to convert a former tractor plant into a modern engine plant.
The action is a departure from recent practice by the Big Three auto makers, which have been buying engines from cheaper foreign sources, primarily in Mexico and South America.


L. W. Beilenson, 89; Helped to Form Unions
LEAD: Laurence W. Beilenson, a lawyer who helped establish the Screen Actors Guild and other Hollywood unions in the 1930's, died Monday of a stroke.
He was 89 and lived in Los Angeles.


Book on Greek Leader Stirs Diplomatic Dispute
LEAD: It started out last year as a harmless sounding project: a book by American and Greek authors about the administration of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece, edited and published by Greek-Americans.
But now, two months before publication, the project has created a stir involving the State Department, the Greek Embassy and others associated with it.


James and Thoreau To Be in Poets' Corner
LEAD: Memorial stones for Henry James and Henry David Thoreau will be placed in the American Poets' Corner at the cnclusion of vespers on Oct. 23 at 7 P.M. at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

Tale Behind Search Warrant: Pentagon Data Believed Sold
LEAD: Federal investigators asserted that they had overheard a Navy procurement official read bid information from contractors to a private consultant, according to Federal court documents unsealed today.


Company News; Management Science Sought
LEAD: Computer Associates International Inc. said it was still eager to buy Management Science America Inc. and might raise its offer for the Atlanta-based software concern.
On Monday, Management Science disclosed that it had received and rejected a $191 million offer from Computer Associates, the nation's largest independent software vendor.


OIL PRICE SLIDE KEEPS GASOLINE COST STABLE
LEAD: Oil prices fell below $15 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the first time since late 1986.
The drop reflected traders' worries about a price war among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday about the Pentagon procurement inquiry misidentified a company named in court documents.
It is the C-Cubed Corporation, not C3 Inc.


CAR MAKERS FIGHT BACK ON LEMON LAWS
LEAD: Propelled by decades of frustration over unrepairable cars and unresponsive auto makers, state legislatures have rolled out one law after another to help owners exercise warranty rights.
The auto industry, which has lost battles in 46 states since 1982, is now petitioning the Government for a law that would override some tough new state regulations.


Patents; A Contraceptive Based On Fetal Tissue Protein
LEAD: A pediatric surgeon has patented a new contraceptive based on a protein found in fetal tissue.
The patent also covers a method for enhancing female fertility, based on antibodies to the same substance.


About New York; Hsu's Potpourri: From Fireworks To Fortunetellers
LEAD: From time to time it is helpful, to say nothing of illuminating, to look in on Hwa-Min Hsu, attorney at law, Canal Street, Chinatown, U.S.A.
You know Canal Street.
That's the one where, these days, there's someone every 15 feet hollering, ''Fireworks!
Fireworks!
Fireworks!''


Iraq Acknowledges Its Use of Gas But Says Iran Introduced It in War
LEAD: The Iraqi Foreign Minister acknowledged today that his country had used chemical weapons in its war against Iran, but said Iran had used them first.


Patents; Microorganisms Used As an Insecticide
LEAD: Plant Genetics Inc. of Davis, Calif., received a patent this week on a way to use microorganisms called nemotodes as an insecticide.


Company News; G.M. Engine Plan
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would invest $80 million in a project to build a new line of engines at its plant in Tonawanda, N.Y.
The Mark V engine, a V-8 that is designed for use in pickup trucks, motor homes and boats, is to be introduced in the 1991 model year.
The Tonawanda plant employs 4,300 and produced 1.4 million engines in 1987.


Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: Bo Jackson, the outfielder-running back who suffered a severely torn left hamstring May 31, may be activated any day by the Kansas City Royals. . . .
Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos, who coached his team to the last two Super Bowls, underwent surgery for the removal of a kidney stone Thursday in Denver.


LENDL TRAILS BECKER AS PLAY IS HALTED
LEAD: In true soap-opera style, Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker walked off Centre Court this evening with the outcome of their semifinal match very much in doubt.
Will Lendl, No. 1 in the world but frustrated time and again in his attempt to win Wimbledon, overcome what was a two-set deficit to reach a third consecutive final?


'DESIGNER' DOG FOODS COMPETE FOR SALES
LEAD: Is your dog overweight?
There's a new ''light'' dog food.
Is he a little run-down?
Maybe high-protein food would pick him up.
How's his breath?
A mint-flavored dog biscuit might make him better company.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 46.


A Shadowy Kremlin Rivalry Moves Into the Public Glare
LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin came to the final session of the Communist Party conference today a prophet without honor in his own party, asking hoarsely for his honor back.


Fairness for Foster Care
LEAD: Reforms of New York City's overworked foster care system have awaited the outcome of a 15-year-old lawsuit aimed at curbing the influence of sectarian agencies.
Now a Federal appeals court has cleared the way, giving responsibility for reform to the city and the private agencies that provide the services under contract.


20 Indicted in Pornography Case
LEAD: Pornography dealers who the authorities say are responsible for mailing most sexually explict material in the country were charged today in Federal indictments with distributing obscene material through the mail.


Alajarvi Journal; Boys of Summer in the Midnight Sun
LEAD: It is the time of year when night in much of Finland means the sun lowers itself onto the horizon and perches there until morning, when you can read on a park bench at midnight and when this northern nation's boys of summer thrill their countrymen in contests of pesapallo, or Finnish baseball.


Company News; Morrison Knudsen Stake Purchased
LEAD: Edward F. Heil, an Illinois investor, has purchased a 6.2 percent stake in the Morrison Knudsen Corporation and said he was considering seeking one or more seats on the board of the construction and engineering concern, based in Boise, Idaho.


Freedom From Health Fear
LEAD: The catastrophic health care bill that President Reagan signed yesterday offers a historic expansion of Medicare - and an equally welcome advance in political maturity.


G.M. Extends Incentives
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet, Buick and Oldsmobile divisions today extended through Sept. 28 buyer incentive programs that were scheduled to expire on Tuesday.
Many of the Chevrolet rebates will be leaner, but Buick rebates will be unchanged except for those on the LeSabre, a spokeswoman said.


Criminal Libel Charges Dropped in S. Carolina
LEAD: A prosecutor dropped criminal libel charges against a weekly newspaper editor today at the request of two legislators who said the case was giving the poor, rural area bad publicity.


Tension Reported High In Burma After Clashes
LEAD: Western diplomats said today that an outward calm had returned to Burma after clashes between demonstrators and the police and military 10 days ago, but that tension remained unusally high.


BILL ROBERTS, EARLY REAGAN ADVISER, IS DEAD AT 63
LEAD: Bill Roberts, a founder of political consulting and the manager of Ronald Reagan's entry into politics in 1966, died of heart failure Thursday in California after a long battle with diabetes.
He was 63 years old.


Rebuting the Myths Around Mozart
LEAD:  1791  Mozart's Last Year  By H. C. Robbins Landon  Illustrated. 240 pages.
Schirmer Books. $19.95.


Minimizing the Damage
LEAD: To the Editor:


Your Money; Direct Purchases Of Municipals
LEAD: THE purest play in the municipal bond market is direct investment.
Some people prefer to choose their bonds directly and structure their own portfolios, rather than relying on mutual funds or unit investment trusts.
But direct investing requires sizable amounts of money and the time for active portfolio management - as well as some expertise.


MIDRED GILLARS, 87, OF NAZI RADIO, AXIS SALLY TO AN ALLIED AUDIENCE
LEAD: Mildred E. Gillars, nicknamed Axis Sally by American soldiers in World War II for her Nazi propaganda radio broadcasts, died of cancer of the colon last Saturday at Grant Medical Center in Columbus, Ohio.
She was 87 years old and lived in Columbus.


1 Dead and 42 Hurt in Lebanon
LEAD: One person was killed and at least 42 were wounded today when cars rigged with explosives blew up near a Syrian Army checkpoint in West Beirut and near a Syrian military camp in the Bekaa region of Lebanon, officials said.


Let the Gypsies Alone
LEAD: To the Editor:


Panel Censures New York Judge as Using His Influence Improperly
LEAD: A State Supreme Court Justice, Bruce Wright, has been censured by the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct for writing letters on court stationery on behalf of a woman with whom he was acquainted, and for not disqualifying himself when legal motions involving the woman came before him.


Crash Kills Spanish Official
LEAD: Rescue workers today found the bodies of five people, including a senior Spanish transportation official, after the official's helicopter crashed in a storm north of Madrid.
A Civil Guard spokesman said the bodies of the chief of highway traffic, Rosa de Lima Manzano, and four men were found near the wreckage on a 4,800-foot-high peak near La Cabrera, a town 45 miles north of Madrid.


Canada to End Paper $1
LEAD: Canada's one-dollar coin will completely replace the paper dollar bill within two years, the Government has announced.
The coin was introduced last year under a plan to save taxpayers $175 million (Canadian) over 20 years because coins have a longer circulation life than paper bills.
Public acceptance of the gold-colored 11-sided coin has been limited, but the Government has said that production of dollar bills will end on June 30, 1989, and that the bills will cease to be legal tender about a year later.


Bomb Site Cleanup Is Put at Billions
LEAD: Cleaning up the radioactive and chemical pollution caused by the manufacture of nuclear bombs will cost $40 billion to $110 billion, a report by the Department of Energy said yesterday.


Dow Loses 10.13 on Holiday Selling
LEAD: Stock prices declined moderately yesterday in brisk trading before the Fourth of July holiday weekend.


Jazz Festival; McKenna's Austere Pianism
LEAD: Even in the conservative wing of jazz, where undue ostentation is frowned upon, the pianist Dave McKenna represents an unusually staid presence.
Mr.
McKenna, who gave a solo performance at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday afternoon as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, is a dogged melodist who eschews fancy pyrotechnics, rarely wastes a note and, having established a tempo, holds to it with a metronomic accuracy.


DUKAKIS FAULTED ON DEFICIT
LEAD: A Massachusetts Republican leader has criticized Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis for campaigning for President outside the state on the day the state's fiscal year ended with a deficit of nearly $400 million.


COPING: WITH BURGLAR-ALARM INSTALLATION
LEAD: Time was when a moat and a drawbridge were the preferred home security devices.
Things improved, and for a while the residents of many towns could boast that they never needed to lock their doors.
That too has changed in recent years, and with more than three million burglaries reported annually in the United States, burglar alarms are becoming a staple of domestic life.


Company News; Greyhound Sells Its Last U.S. Lines
LEAD: The Greyhound Corporation, once the nation's largest intercity bus company, completed its withdrawal from that business with the sale of two regional lines.
Greyhound said it had sold the Vermont Transit Company and Texas, New Mexico and Oklahoma Coaches Inc. to the GLI Holding Company of Dallas, the company that bought Greyhound Lines Inc.


Sports People; Daly Glad to Stay
LEAD: Chuck Daly, the most successful coach in the 31-year history of the Detroit Pistons, acknowledged yesterday that he had agreed to a multiyear contract with the team, which he led into the championship round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.


Company News; CSX Reports Loss; 25% of Staff to Be Cut
LEAD: The CSX Corporation, the large shipping, railroad and energy company, took a $778 million charge today against its second-quarter earnings to lay off nearly 25 percent of its work force, and it reported a loss of $160 million for the quarter.


Holiday on Monday
LEAD: The Independence Day holiday will be observed on Monday.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Fireworks: East River, 9:20 P.M., between East 23d and East 46th Streets.
Government offices: Closed.
Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.


ASTROS RALLY IN 13TH TO SPLIT WITH METS
LEAD: The Mets turned into July last night with seven hours of baseball that carried them from peak to valley and from Friday to Saturday as they split a 22-inning doubleheader with the Houston Astros.


Razing Rumania
LEAD: Even as Stalinism's disastrous legacies come under attack in Moscow, the old tyrannical style flourishes in Rumania.
Nicolae Ceausescu's harsh 20-year rule has turned one of Europe's traditional breadbaskets into a land of legendary deprivation.
He has razed acres of ancient houses and churches in Bucharest, its once-elegant capital, to make a parade ground.


SWEEPING POLITICAL REVISION OF SOVIET SYSTEM APPROVED IN STORMY MEETING OF PARTY
LEAD: Delegates to a Communist Party conference today approved a major overhaul of the Soviet political system in a stormy final session that included the first openly divided votes since the early years of the Soviet state.


Settlement Reached in Crash Of Church Bus in Kentucky
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has reached out-of-court settlements with the families of almost all the victims of a fiery crash in May of a church bus in which 27 people were killed, lawyers said today.


Brazil-U.S. Pact On Securities
LEAD: United States and Brazilian securities regulators signed a far-reaching mutual assistance pact today to cooperate in enforcing securities laws of the two countries.


British Bid For M.T.M.
LEAD: M.T.M.
Entertainment Inc., the highly successful television production company co-founded by the actress Mary Tyler Moore, has agreed to be acquired by a British production company, published reports say.


Tharp and Six Dancers To Join Ballet Theater
LEAD: Twyla Tharp will join American Ballet Theater as artistic associate, a position that will make her a resident choreographer with the company.
Several members of Miss Tharp's own dance troupe will join Ballet Theater in what Miss Tharp called a merger rather than a dissolution of her own troupe.


FIXING THE UNFIXABLE
LEAD: Clarence M. Ditlow 3d, director of the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer organization in Washington, provided the following recommendations for owners of new vehicles with persistent problems.
The offices of state attorneys general can provide additional details.

Paul Riesman, Anthropology Professor, 50
LEAD: Paul Riesman, former chairman of the anthropology department at Carlton College in Northfield, Minn., died of an aneurysm Wednesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital, near his summer home in West Cornwall, Conn.
He was 50 years old and lived in Northfield.

Patents; Electromagnetic Gun
LEAD: The Army has patented a portable electromagnetic rail gun.
The device, which propels a bullet by applying an intense electromagnetic pulse, is similar to weapons under research for use in space against missiles.
The Army said the gun could fire a bullet four times as fast as an M-16, and rip apart a steel plate.


Seven Entries for Oaks
LEAD: Seven 3-year-old fillies, led by Goodbye Halo, have been entered in the Coaching Club American Oaks tomorrow at Belmont Park, the final leg of the New York filly triple crown series.


First Blacks Moving to Boston Project
LEAD: Two black families will make history this month just by moving into a public housing project in South Boston.


Increase in Rates Is Sought
LEAD: The Connecticut Light and Power Co. filed formal applications today with the State Department of Public Utility Control to raise its natural gas and electricity rates a combined total of almost $116 million a year.
The company had notified the department in May that it would file the applications seeking its first increase in rates since 1983.


Business Digest: Saturday July 2, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Coca-Cola Company misstated the company's public stance, in some editions, on its use of a non-narcotic derivative of the coca plant.
Coca-Cola has previously acknowledged that coca is an ingredient in its cola.


Maureen Mara Weds Douglas Allen Brown
LEAD: Maureen Elizabeth Mara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Wellington T. Mara of Rye, N.Y., and Douglas Allen Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Curtis E. Brown of Southborough, Mass., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.
The Rev.
John McCarthy performed the ceremony.


White Sox Are Safe at Home
LEAD: The Chicago White Sox, whose existence on this city's South Side appeared doomed as midnight approached Thursday, were given new life early today.

Reviews/Pop; 2 Saxophonists' Idiomatic Way With a Band
LEAD: Clarence (C) Sharpe and Billy Harper, two unjustly overlooked saxophonists, came to the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night as part of its jazz festival and performed wonderfully.


Company News; Santa Fe in Switch On Property Sale
LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said it would retain certain West Coast properties it had previously planned to sell as part of a corporate restructuring.
The decision is expected to increase the company's real estate assets by nearly $1 billion in the next five years, Santa Fe said.


Sports People; Olympic Withdrawals
LEAD: Rex Chapman and Shelton Jones, who played with the United States Select Team on its recent European tour, have decided to withdraw from the United States Olympic basketball trials.
Tom McGrath, associate executive director of the Amateur Basketball Association of the United States, said attorneys for both players notified Coach John


DUKAKIS HOLDS AUDITIONS FOR NO. 2 SPOT ON TICKET
LEAD: The political imagery seemed promising: the successful son of immigrants and the square-jawed astronaut from the Midwest, two complementary emblems of the American dream.


Construction Spending Rose 1.1% in May After April Dip
LEAD: Construction spending advanced 1.1 percent in May as strength in office and factory construction offset weakness in other areas.


NEC Sets U.S. Research
LEAD: The NEC Corporation, a leading Japanese electronics maker, said this week that it would set up an institute in Princeton, N.J., to conduct computer and communications research.
The institute will start work next May, NEC said.


Trying to Stage a Convention With Flair but Without Glitz
LEAD: ''We want a convention just like our candidate: organized, orderly and short.''


10-Minute Happy Hour Heads Down the Track
LEAD: ''The shufflers are here,'' someone yelled out, and all the regulars at Lagoda's Saloon looked up to see the end of an era.


World Bank Reserve Plan
LEAD: Recognizing that a growing number of poor countries are seriously behind on loan payments, the World Bank said today that its board was expected to increase provisions for loan losses to $500 million from the current $100 million.


No Eastern Shuttle Sale
LEAD: In a major retreat by its chairman, Frank Lorenzo, the Texas Air Corporation announced yesterday that it was canceling the sale of its Eastern Airlines shuttle to a new subsidiary.

Help for Addicts
LEAD: To the Editor:


Review/Dance; Fokine Infuses a Program by the Harlem Troupe
LEAD: The spirit of Michel Fokine presided over the performance that Dance Theater of Harlem offered Thursday night at the City Center as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts.
One of the three works was by Fokine himself, another was a new version of a work created by him and the third might never have existed if it had not been for precedents set by this great balletic reformer.


Court Protects Hiring Lawyer of Choice
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled 8 to 4 yesterday that the Government could not prevent defendants from hiring the lawyers of their choice by freezing and seizing the defendants' assets.


L. W. BEILENSON, UNION FOUNDER
LEAD: Laurence W. Beilenson, a lawyer who helped establish the Screen Actors Guild and other Hollywood unions in the 1930's, died of a stroke Monday.
He was 89 years old and lived in Los Angeles.


Killer Denied Parole in a Scarsdale Murder
LEAD: Richard Herrin, convicted in 1978 of killing his ex-girlfriend with a hammer while she slept in her Scarsdale home, has been denied parole for a second time because of the ''extreme gravity of the present offense,'' a state official said today.


Company News; Semiconductor In Stock Buyback
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it would buy back the National common stock and warrants it gave Schlumberger Ltd. for the purchase of Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation last fall.
The buyback, in effect, is a decision by National to pay Schlumberger in cash instead of in stock for the acquisition.

LEAD:  International 2-7  The Communist Party conference ended.
Delegates approved a major overhaul of the Soviet political system, including a partial transfer of power from the party to popularly elected legislatures.

WRITERS PLAN NEW OFFER TO THE INDEPENDENTS
LEAD: As a strike by 9,000 movie and television writers drags into its 18th week, it has become more than ever a psychological war.


Medicare Expanded for First Time Since '65
LEAD: President Reagan with members of Congress after signing the Medicare bill yesterday outside the White House.
The measure provides the elderly with insurance against major illnesses. (The New York Times/Jose R. Lopez)


CONTRACT FREEZE DIFFICULT FOR PENTAGON
LEAD: The Defense Department's decision to freeze nine military equipment programs today because of reported contracting irregularities caught Pentagon managers completely by surprise, and left them wondering how they would put Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci's order into effect.


EDBERG, DOWN 2 SETS, SCRAMBLES PAST MERCIR TO FINAL
LEAD: In a sport of overnight sensations and phenoms too young to attend R-rated movies, Stefan Edberg of Sweden was not progressing fast enough to suit his critics.
He is No. 3 in the world and a two-time winner of the Australian Open, but is characterized as lacking determination, perhaps courage, when it really matters.


Sports People; Suns Release Bailey
LEAD: James Bailey and Jeff Cook became unrestricted free agents when the Phoenix Suns decided not to offer them contracts.
Cook, 31 years old, a 6-foot-10-inch forward-center, played in 33 games last season, averaging 1.5 points and 3.2 rebounds.
Bailey, also 31, averaged 4.4 points and 3.2 rebounds in 65 games.


PRETORIA PRESENTS PLAN TO BUTTRESS SEGREGATION LAW
LEAD: Apparently bowing to pressure from the political right wing, the South African Government today proposed legislation that would lead to stricter enforcement of residential segregation and harsher penalties for offenders.


ROUGH-EDGED ADS SELL 'REALITY'
LEAD: With its out-of-focus close-ups, drifting camera and grainy shots of teen-agers spraying one another with soda and sashaying between cans, the current television commercial for Sprite looks like a home movie -which is no accident.


Consultant Seeks Affidavit
LEAD: Melvyn Paisley, a military consultant, went to court today in a bid to obtain the affidavit secretly filed by Government investigators to search his office for evidence in the Pentagon fraud and bribery investigation.


Hermann Volk, Cardinal, 84
LEAD: Hermann Cardinal Volk, the former Roman Catholic Bishop of Mainz and an advocate of ecumenism, died today after a lengthy illness, his press office said.
He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Although noting that the prospects are ''bleak'' for any immediate relief from the drought gripping much of the Farm Belt, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said today that it was premature to consider Federal aid or other cash payments to assist farmers.


Have the Brawley Lawyers Broken the Law?
LEAD: Like agile mystery writers, Tawana Brawley's lawyers have kept prosecutors hanging in suspense over proof of their charge that white law-enforcement agents abducted and sexually abused the upstate black teen-ager last fall.
But because Alton H. Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason are not mystery writers but lawyers, responsible for real lives not invented ones, their tactics are highly questionable.

LEAD: Two clerks at an all-night grocery were shot to death in Brooklyn early yesterday during an $800 robbery, the police said.

LEAD: Five firefighters battling flames inside an automobile dealership in downtown Hackensack, N.J., were killed in a cataract of burning timbers yesterday when the roof of the blazing building collapsed on them, fire officials said.

LEAD: ''A reasonable mistake in judgment'' was the most probable cause of a collision of two Army helicopters that killed 17 soldiers during night training here in March, a report by Army investigators said today.

Sports of The Times; The Foregone Conclusion
LEAD: THIS was as close to a sure thing as there is in tennis.
Even though Martina Navratilova and Steffi Graf had been in three tournaments this year without crossing paths, everyone knew they would finally meet on Centre Court at Wimbledon in the final.
According to London bookmakers, people bet so heavily on the likelihood of this happening that there was no second choice worth mentioning.

Summer Laundry Tips
LEAD: In warm weather, dry-cleaning bills can soar.
But for some garments, laundering can save money and even time, since you don't have to rely on a cleaner's schedule.
Knowing what you can wash also makes vacation packing easier.
Don't rush to the suds with everything you own.
Constructed garments with sewn-in shoulder pads or fused facings must be professionally cleaned; so must silk organdy, taffeta and chiffon.

U.S. Stops Payments on Programs Believed Tainted in Fraud Inquiry
LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci today halted payments to all contractors involved in nine military programs valued at nearly $1.7 billion because of evidence in court affidavits suggesting that competition for the contracts had been tainted by fraud.

LEAD: Several small biotechnology companies are developing ways to administer drugs by encapsulating them in tiny organic spheres called liposomes.
Proponents believe this approach will improve the ability of doctors to aim medications more precisely and control the speed of their release.

Company News; Tesoro Tax Pact
LEAD: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it had reached a tentative $20.6 million settlement with the Internal Revenue Service to resolve all pending income tax issues for the company's 1981 through 1985 fiscal years.
The settlement calls for San Antonio-based Tesoro to pay $10.6 million in additional taxes and $10 million in interest, Tesoro said.

LEAD: A jury today convicted a 44-year-old man of murdering two of six women he had abducted and kept shackled in the basement of his North Philadelphia home.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Health page on Thursday about screening for breast cancer gave an incorrect percentage for women over 40 who said they had a mammogram in the last year; the correct figure was 17 percent.
The article also imprecisely paraphrased a Federal recommendation for women between the ages of 40 and 50; they are urged to have mammograms every one or two years.

LEAD: PAINTBRUSHES and roller covers (the woolly sleeves that fit onto the roller and spread the paint) seldom receive the care they need.

National League; Wild Pitch Allows Giants to Tame Pirates
LEAD: With only five hits in two games, the San Francisco Giants needed help today.
And the Pittsburgh Pirates obliged.
With the bases loaded and one out in the bottom of the eighth, the Pittsburgh reliever Barry Jones threw a wild pitch that bounced high in the air, enabling two runs to score as the Giants won, 2-1.

How High the Dollar?
LEAD: Since last month's economic summit conference in Toronto, the dollar has risen against all major currencies.
The dollar is now stronger against the West German mark and the yen, than at any time since the Oct. 19 stock market collapse.
With the exception of West Germany, the central banks of the major trading nations are doing little to support their currencies against the dollar.

LEAD: THE CREW TENSES AS SIRENS WAIL AND warning lights wink on.
All but one of the space shuttle's three main engines have mysteriously failed minutes after takeoff, leaving the ship crippled dozens of miles above the choppy Atlantic.
Previously, the only option would have been a potentially deadly controlled crash in the water.

Mr.
Lobe, who lives in New York, spent the summer of 1985 living and working at Chesterwood, French's estate, in the popular 19th-century artist's former studio.

Innocence Abroad
LEAD: To the Editor: Sound the hurrahs for Ruth Wolff's paean to the unhurried and unregimented traveler (''Innocence Abroad,'' Travel, May 1).
With the proliferation of guidebooks and ultraspecialized tours, it is a wonder that any traveler can just be left alone to savor wandering among streets, dropping in on unsuspecting shopkeepers, meandering to the point of even getting lost in quaint streets and parks, looking at sights for the sheer beauty of their ''being'' rather than of their attested place in history.

The Dollar Rises, Despite Opposition
LEAD: The rally in the dollar grew stronger, defying efforts by some central banks to check its rise.
During the week the dollar rose as high as 133.9 yen and 1.82 marks.
In mid-June, the dollar was worth only about 126 yen and 1.75 marks.
The West Germans appeared most anxious to temper the dollar's comeback, with the Bundesbank raising its discount rate to 3 percent, from 2.5 percent, in hopes that higher interest rates would draw support to the mark.

Question Of the Week; Should The Yankees Have Fired Billy Martin?
LEAD: Certainly not.
Because with Billy Martin gone (for now) we fans will have to be fed a steady diet of real baseball news: like hits, runs and errors.
Besides, Billy looked so happy as he watched from the dugout.
Always smiling.
That's our Billy.
But all this hardly matters, for some time during the next six months, Martin will be named manager again.

Making Brushes Last
LEAD: PAINTBRUSHES and roller covers (the woolly sleeves that fit onto the roller and spread the paint) seldom receive the care they need.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article about Afghanistan in The Week in review on June 19 described American aid to Pakistan, incorrectly.
Since 1981, the United States had spent or authorized more than $7 billion in aid to Pakistan.
None of it has been covert.


Making Brushes Last
LEAD: PAINTBRUSHES and roller covers (the woolly sleeves that fit onto the roller and spread the paint) seldom receive the care they need.
But even inexpensive brushes and covers will last a long time if they are used properly and cleaned thoroughly after each use, and protected when put away for long periods.

If not quite warm and lovable, at least it's handsome and businesslike.

Question Of the Week; Should The Yankees Have Fired Billy Martin?
LEAD: No way.
Ever since Billy Martin came to New York he brought a unique style of managing that made the game much more exciting to watch.
Billy Ball consists of suicide squeezes, double steals, and hit and runs just to name a few.
It's a shame he had to be let go because of people second-guessing him and trying to create stories that aren't true.

In a topsy-turvy world (there's one now!), one needs to feel solid ground under foot (another one!).

Corrections
LEAD: A Travel Advisory chart on June 12 gave an incorrect telephone number for information on automatic teller machines that provide local currency to Visa cardholders overseas.
Holders of Visa gold cards may get information by calling 800-336-3386 or, in Alaska and Hawaii, 800-336-3379.
A holder of a regular card may ask the issuing bank for a list of overseas cash machines.

Soviet Union
LEAD: To the Editor: I beg to differ with the assessment of hotels in the Soviet Union.
Traveling two years ago this spring, staying over in seven cities -Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev, Yalta, Tashkent, Samarkand and Bukhara - I felt spoiled by the superlative quarters providing good-size beds, spruced-up furnishings and, with one exception, clean and up-to-the-minute bathrooms.

The Where and Ware of Hagi
LEAD: JAPANESE connoisseurs have an old saying: ''One, Raku; two, Hagi; three, Karatsu.'' They have long ranked the most precious ceramic wares made for the tea ceremony in this order.
The charms of Hagi ware's rough clay and rich, pockmarked surfaces, laced with cracks in the glaze, take on character and deeper tones with age and use.

LEAD: In the Pacific Northwest the barbecue season doesn't have as much to do with the weather as it does with the salmon run.

Old House in Sea Cliff Is Even Older
LEAD: You had an interesting account of Sea Cliff's Victorian houses  [ ''Sea Cliff Adjusts to Historic Listing,'' June 12 ] .
But I would like to tell you what I told the Landmarks Association.
It is a well-established fact that 112 Sea Cliff Avenue was built in 1884.
The date of 1887 is wrong.
In 1888 the tower wing was added, and of course the tower is the most conspicuous feature of the house.

LEAD: FOR the first time in a major league career that began in 1966, Don Sutton, a 324-game winner, has been placed on the disabled list.

Sutton, 43 years old, did not get a decision in his last start, a 4-3 loss to Houston Tuesday night, and complained afterward of a sore right elbow.

The Voices You Hear Are Inimitably Their Own

Jazz Festival; Sarah Vaughan, at Carnegie, Shows Grace in Adversity
LEAD: Sarah Vaughan was understandably miffed during her Carnegie Hall concert on Thursday evening.
The hall's unreliable sound system made it difficult for the singer to hear the members of her own backup trio.
And the thin, watery sound that emanated from the stage left Andrew Simpkins's bass semi-audible and George Gaffney's piano an ineffectual tinkle.

A Brave Old World in Eastern Europe
LEAD: I ONCE took a train from Warsaw to Athens, passing through every Eastern European country but East Germany, and watched with wonder as storybook towns passed my view and ancient laborers crowded my compartment.
Winding through the Transylvanian Alps at dawn, we came upon horse-drawn sleighs in the snow and whole villages built of timber, the houses tall and balconied and painted in the pastel shades of butter mints.


Not a Drop to Drink
LEAD: CONSIDER A DROP IN THE ocean.
This is what they're doing, on a rather grand scale, at the California Academy of Sciences, the 138-year-old museum in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park.
Part of a massive new exhibit entitled Wild California that is scheduled to open Oct. 9 and intended to illustrate the diversity of habitats and ecosystems within the state, the Sea Meadow diorama will represent life forms extant in a random squirt of coastal sea water -magnified 200 times.

Results Plus
LEAD:  Auto Racing  Elliott Wins by Inches: Bill Elliott held off Rick Wilson yesterday to win the Firecracker 400 Nascar race at Daytona International Speedway in Florida.
Elliott, who started 38th in the 42-car field, did not lead until 23 laps from the end of the 400-mile, 160-lap race.
Once he got his Ford Thunderbird in front, however, he kept it there, beating Wilson's Oldsmobile Cutlass by less than the length of his hood.

Industry Deals With the Drought
LEAD: THE paper plant that squats on the Pigeon River in Canton, N. C., never stops if it can help it.
Every day, it turns out milk and orange juice cartons and envelope paper.
But it needs the cooperation of the skies.
Some 44 million gallons of water swish through the plant every day, washing wood, helping to bleach the pulp.


Soviet Union
LEAD: To the Editor: The Beriozkas in Moscow do indeed have a tempting variety of artistic items as Esther Fein said, but visitors should take with them heavy-duty capacious plastic sacks with sturdy handles or all they will bring home will be regrets over the beautiful things left behind because the flimsy paper bags supplied in the dollar shops can't make it to the airport in Moscow, and purchases made in Russia may not be shipped no matter how bulky they might be or how costly.


Canada Catches a Cold War Chill
LEAD: WHEN Pierre Elliott Trudeau stepped down after 15 years as Canada's Prime Minister in 1984, he told a friend that he had not realized before taking the job how limited its powers would turn out to be.
Rarely did he have any real choices, he complained; almost everything was hemmed in by the ''realities'' imposed by previous governments, the powers of the provinces, the country's membership in the Western alliance and, above all, its proximity to the United States.

In Switzerland, Mountaineering For Everyone
LEAD: TO stand on the roof of the world is an experience that most of us believe we'll never have.
To know what it's like to climb a major mountain and gain an eagle's-eye view, we have to be armchair mountaineers, relying on books or films.
But a cable car line in Zermatt allows a reasonably fit person with no climbing experience to make such a climb, safely accompanied by a licensed mountain guide, and taste the thrill of true mountaineering - a brief membership in one of the world's most exclusive clubs.

Headliners; On the Run
LEAD: After he began managing other people's money six years ago at the age of 31, Roberto C. Polo apparently came to consider his own comfort to be a good investment for his clients.

Polo had homes, offices and art collections in New York, Paris and Geneva.
But eyebrows rose as the former mid-level bank officer began to consume more conspicuously than his clients.


A Tour of the Psyche In 'Some Golden States'
LEAD: Tim Miller's ''Some Golden States,'' presented at the downstairs theater of Performance Space 122 on Friday night, is a geographical and psychological tour that promises much.
Autobiographical stage journeys can be fascinating, and this autobiography focuses on the coming-of-age of a young homosexual in the late 1970's and early 1980's - a time marked by the killing of Harvey Milk, a San Francisco city supervisor who was one of the country's first publicly avowed gay politicans, and by the first awareness of AIDS and its apparent singling out of homosexuals.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD: MOMENTUM: Women in American Politics Now.
By Ronna Romney and Beppie Harrison. (Crown, $18.95.) In 1973, there were 16 women in the House of Representatives.
Fifteen years later, there are 23.
That barely qualifies as progress, let alone the ''momentum'' of the title of this breezy, upbeat account of the current status of women in American political life.

Soviet Union
LEAD: To the Editor: In the guide to Moscow's subway system and the palatial stations, the incredibly low fare of 5 kopecks or 1/20 of a ruble retained for their use is cited.
But how does one arrive at the U.S. equivalent of ''about 3 cents''?
According to the official rate imposed on tourists, whereby the ruble is worth almost as much as the British pound, 5 kopecks would equal about 8 U.S.

The Race to a More Elaborate Arms Race
LEAD: IRAN, Iraq and 46 other countries have anti-ship cruise missiles.
Nineteen countries, including Argentina and India, own diesel-attack submarines.
And 21 nations have naval mines, which, like the other two weapons, are capable of sinking large ships.

Sports of the Times; Anybody Seen a Boat?
LEAD: OUR friend was a coxswain at Keble College of Oxford a few years back.
We were a bit disappointed on Saturday when he did not wear his old rowing cap as he drove out to Henley.
You'll see plenty of caps, he promised.
He left the motorway just past Windsor Castle and maneuvered the back roads toward Henley-on-Thames, the same route he has taken on the first weekend in July since 1955.

LEAD: ''Latin Jazz Jam: A Tribute to Machito,'' at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, was a dismal affair for the most part.

LEAD: State Department officials said today that the shooting down of an Iranian passenger plane by a United States Navy warship would not lead to any fundamental change of American policy in the Persian Gulf.


Johann Baptist Gradl, German Politician, 84
LEAD: Johann Baptist Gradl, a former minister in the West German Government who had worked for German reunification, died here Friday after a long illness, city officials said.
He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Nancy C. Widmann, who was recently named the president of the CBS Radio division, attributes her success in the radio business to her hard work, the high quality of her staff and her willingness to take risks.


Man Wants to Keep Money Left by His Aunt, a Suicide
LEAD: A man has asked a court whether he can keep $160,200 in $100 bills that his aunt wrapped as a Christmas gift and gave to him before killing herself.

LEAD: Jammed rush-hour traffic, once the bane of the big city, has become a pervasive part of daily life in the suburbs around New York City.


Outdoors: Fly Fishing for Bass
LEAD: MOST saltwater fly fishermen learn the basics of the sport on stream or lake.
Fascinated with the challenge of taking trout or black bass on an artificial fly, they eventually succumb to the urge to try for striped bass or bluefish, bonefish or tarpon.

LEAD: To the Editor:


In New York, the Cultural Season Is Beginning to Have No Seasons
LEAD: Gone are the lazy summer days when the Muses fled New York City to pitch their tents at bosky summer festivals and the only sign of life at Carnegie Hall was a graduation exercise.


Review/Rock; Wire's Deadpan Songs
LEAD: Wire started out in the late 1970's as an extremist band, playing distilled, flinty post-punk rock.
Since its 1984 reunion, the band has turned to another extreme - steady-state rock that encases pop-song structures in deadpan repetitions.
At the Ritz on Saturday night, Robert Gotobed dispensed unswerving, nearly uninflected rhythm patterns on a drum kit that included only a bass drum, a snare and a hi-hat cymbal.


Sports News Briefs; Age Limit is Set For Games Soccer
LEAD: The ruling body of world soccer today set an age limit of 23 years for all players competing on Olympic soccer teams.


Miriam I. Fredman, Clothes Merchant, 63
LEAD: Miriam I. Fredman, the wife of Samuel Fredman, chairman of the board of trustees of the State University of New York at Purchase, died in an automobile accident Wednesday in Horsholm, Denmark, where she was attending a conference with her husband.
She was 63 years old and lived in White Plains.


Sports World Specials; Wings Above Maine
LEAD: If they look up into the sky and see a World War I vintage biplane droning overhead, vacationers near Rockland, Me., today may shake their heads and wonder if they have been transported back 70 years in time.
Under a canvas flying helmet and pair of goggles the craggy-faced pilot of the spindly olive-green machine is Jack Gardiner, a retired airline executive.


Richard S. Morse, 76, an Inventor Of Orange Juice Concentrate, Dies
LEAD: Richard Stetson Morse, a scientist and inventor with a knack for turning inventions into commercial successes, including high-vacuum machines and frozen orange juice concentrate, died Friday of a heart attack at his summer home in Falmouth, Mass.
He was 76 years old and a resident of Wellesley, Mass.

LEAD: Since Gail Temple and Gary Lattanzi have been supervising parolees with AIDS, they have found themselves teaching grown men how to use condoms and sending others, who probably have only a few more months to live, back to jail.
