Global Briefs
LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States between January and May shrank by 15.5 percent from the period last year, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported.
The decline, to $3.16 billion, from $3.65 billion, came as growth of Korean imports from the United States outpaced the growth of Korean exports to the United States.

Women Protest in Pakistan
LEAD: About 400 women demonstrated here Saturday against the implementation of Islamic law by President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.
It was the second such protest in two weeks.
Many women fear that the new code will negate 1961 laws that gave them the right to file for divorce or to demand the right to register marriages and divorces.

LEAD: Risen Star, who became racing's newest hero with a popular victory in the Preakness Stakes and an electrifying runaway in the Belmont Stakes last month, may now be retired to stud by the end of this month, his trainer said last night.

This week's column, though, is confined to the interesting and sometimes preposterous answers submitted by readers in response to a question answered last month.
It inspired such an unusual number and range of responses that they are worth sharing.

On Your Own: Fitness; You Might Climb the Walls After This Unusual Workout
LEAD: IT'S time to celebrate the fourth-floor walk-up.
It's not the apartment we're interested in, but the stairs.
The typical fourth-floor walk-up should have about 50 steps, providing about 40 feet of vertical rise.
Moving your body up and down the stairs is work, and work equals exercise.

Sequoyah''s primary business is uranium conversion at its eastern Oklahoma plant.

Critic's Notebook; Blur of the Biennale: Art in Its Context and Aching Feet
LEAD: A large international show like the 43d Venice Biennale is as much carnival and theater as it is an art exhibition.
For as long as the art community is in attendance, which is usually for the three or four days just prior to the official opening, the show generates a kind of subculture, a world unto itself, with a rich cast of clowns, acrobats, ringmasters and strongmen.

On Your Own; To Run Safely, Run Wisely
LEAD: ONE day last March I was running north on York Avenue, engrossed in conversation with a training partner, when, at a busy intersection, a car came screeching toward me.
I had no time to dart away.
In an instant I was sprawled out on the car's hood, in shock, lucky I had not been killed.

New Techniques Enable Scientists To Study Rapid Changes in Proteins
LEAD: USING a new particle accelerator, scientists at Cornell University have taken a snapshot of protein molecules with what amounts to a shutter speed of a billionth of a second.
The scientists now hope to be able to capture changes that occur as often a million times a second as proteins perform crucial functions in the body.

LEAD: An asteroid about a third of a mile in diameter that crashed into the southeast Pacific Ocean about 2.3 million years ago sent so much water vapor into the atmosphere that it could conceivably have helped trigger an ice age, according to a report in the journal Science.

Sports People; Sprinter Ends Feud
LEAD: Ben Johnson, the world record-holder in the 100 meters, and his coach have mended their differences and will soon resume training together, according to an official with the sprinter's local track club.
Earl Ross, a teacher who 25 years ago founded the Optimists Track Club, said yesterday that he met with Johnson and his coach, Charlie Francis, late last week and ''we sat down and said, 'What are the problems?

F.B.I. AGENT ADMITS HARASSING BLACK
LEAD: A Chicago-based agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has acknowledged that he and other white colleagues planned a campaign of ''retribution'' against a black agent, Donald Rochon, whose case has prompted a national debate over racism in the bureau.

LEAD: Shortly after the Atlanta Hawks lost in seven games to the Boston Celtics in the second round of the National Basketball Association playoffs, Stan Kasten, president of the Hawks, was asked if he planned to pursue the free-agent market.
He said that he would prefer to stay away from free agency, ''unless you're one player away, and this is the player who puts you over the top.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain today expressed understanding of an American warship's downing of an Iranian airliner on Sunday, while most other European allies and Japan expressed deep regret about the military action.

Minerals Are Linked to Sleep Difficulties
LEAD: TRACE elements in the diet can influence the quality of sleep, according to by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The research, conducted at the department's Human Nutrition Research Center in Grand Forks, N.D., revealed that women with shortages in their diets and blood of either of two essential minerals, copper and iron, were more likely to have trouble sleeping.


QUESTIONS PERSIST ON AIRBUS DISASTER
LEAD: More than a day after an Iranian airliner was downed by an American warship, critical questions about the shooting in the Persian Gulf remain unanswered.

LEAD: Vice President Bush may be narrowly trailing Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis in the opinion polls, but he is far ahead according to another indicator of Presidential prospects: the ''royalty factor.''


Hanoi Is Said to Crack Down on Literary Dissent
LEAD: Vietnam has sentenced five writers and journalists to jail terms of up to nine years, apparently as a warning that there are limits to literary dissent, according to Asia Watch, a Washington-based human rights group.

Merc Trading Soared in June
LEAD: Bolstered by the rising dollar's effect on currency futures and options, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange reported record volume in June.
Trading was up 31.7 percent over May volume and up 14 percent from June 1987, the exchange said.


On Horse Racing; Risen Star: The Plot Thickens
LEAD: The drama surrounding Risen Star these days is a familiar one, a set piece played in four acts: Horse gets good.
Horse gets syndicated.
Horse gets hurt.
Horse gets retired.


American Standard
LEAD: Finmeccanica Societa Finanziaria Meccanica S.p.A. said a subsidiary, Ansaldo S.p.A., had agreed to acquire the railway signaling operations of American Standard Inc.
Terms were not disclosed.
Finmeccanica, a unit of the state holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, said in a statement that Ansaldo would acquire the Union Switch and Signal division in the United States and American Standard's Italian-based Wabco Westinghouse operations.


TV Producers Discover New Path to Prime Time
LEAD: A television series based on the ''Friday the 13th'' horror films has surprised everyone and become a success in first-run syndication.
Originally scheduled to air late at night, Paramount Pictures' hourlong series about an antique shop filled with cursed objects is now being shown in prime time on some stations.


A Killing Inflames Mexican Campaign
LEAD: A senior aide to the leading opposition candidate in the presidential election Wednesday was shot dead this weekend, hours after Mexico's most contentious presidential campaign in nearly half a century came to its formal close.


Prospects for Lower Rates Brighten
LEAD: As the second half of the year begins, the prospects for lower interest rates over the next six months seem far brighter than most analysts said was possible even a month ago.


The Arts Festival; A Japanese Composer's Avant-Garde Concerns
LEAD: When the music of Toru Takemitsu came drifting over the Pacific in the 1960's, the freshness of its language took many Westerners by surprise.
Like many works composed in Europe and the United States at the time, his scores were couched in a modern idiom that used clouds of dissonance, orchestral timbres twisted in unusual ways and elements of randomness.


Houghton Plans Sequel To 'Cultural Literacy'
LEAD: In books as in motion pictures and television, the next best thing to an original hit is a successful sequel, or something that can be spun off from the original.


Downing of Jet Raises Question on Schedules
LEAD: The Iran Air jet shot down by an American warship was flying the only international airline route listed out of Bandar Abbas, Iran, on Sundays, according to the Official Airline Guide providing worldwide schedules.


A Serenade in the Park
LEAD: A theater company from Tokyo serenading visitors yesterday at Strawberry Fields in Central Park during an outdoor performance.
Twenty shamisen players took part in the performance. (NYT/Dith Pran)

Market Place; Analysts Size Up Discount Chains
LEAD: DISCOUNT retailers are normally able to weather sales turndowns better than more traditional retailers, but so far this year the discounters have found their normal pricing edge blunted by competition.


Pregnant Women and Hepatitis B: New Policy Reflects Fears
LEAD: AN important Federal recommendation last month to test all pregnant women for the hepatitis B virus reflected new evidence that many more infants are threatened by the virus than previously believed.
The policy change also reflected evidence that many doctors were not being diligent enough in ordering hepatitis tests for pregnant women known to be at high risk of the liver disease.


U.S. Awarded '94 World Cup Tourney in Soccer
LEAD: The United States today was awarded the 1994 World Cup, soccer's quadrennial international tournament, which is regarded in some countries as the world's premier sports event.

LEAD: Marc N. Weiss, a documentary film maker, had an idea for public television.
Instead of running independent documentaries on a scattershot basis, why not take advantage of the so-called summer doldrums to present a national package of strong nonfiction programming with helpful introductions and aggressive promotion.

LEAD: THE Soviet Union, bidding for leadership in Mars exploration, plans to launch a pair of spacecraft this week and next on seven-month journeys to orbit the planet and dispatch landing vehicles to Phobos, a tiny gray moon believed to be an asteroid trapped by Martian gravity.

Key Parts of Soviet Plan for Change
LEAD: Following are key sections of the resolution on perestroika, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's term for economic and political restructuring, approved by the extraordinary Communist Party conference last week and published today for the first time.
The resolution and five others on such topics as legal reform and changing the bureaucracy, were distributed in translation by the official press agency Tass.

York International Accepts Buyout Offer
LEAD: The board of the York International Corporation accepted an offer of $57.50 a share in cash and securities, or about $750 million, from a management group led by Citicorp's venture capital unit.
The board rejected a $59-a-share, or $767 million, cash takeover offer from an unidentified third party.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.Why don't people who take nitroglycerin for a heart condition explode?
A.Nitroglycerin, the highly explosive compound of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and oxygen developed in the 19th century, acts on directly on the walls of the blood vessels.

Housing for the Poor and Poor Housing
LEAD: ''Locked Out of the American Dream'' begins with the gloomy observation that ''the story of public housing in America is a story of high hopes and failed policies'' and ends with glimmers of promise that the nation can do better.
This sober documentary, on Channel 13 tonight at 10 o'clock, recalls the way low-income neighborhoods have been bulldozed out of existence by highways, gentrification and expanding institutions.


Fast Trains: Germany Expects U.S. Prize
LEAD: Hoping to win a big United States order, West Germany is making a determined attempt to beat Japan in a high-technology race to produce the world's first high-speed magnetic levitation train.
The revolutionary train uses magnets to propel it above a steel track at speeds up to 310 miles per hour.


Credit-Card Tie to Nonprofit Groups
LEAD: A few weeks ago, about 100,000 people on the Museum of American Folk Art's mailing list were asked to sign up for a Mastercard or Visa credit card in an arrangement that will benefit the museum every time the card is used.
The offer came through Maryland Bank N.A., which like other banks sees the program as a way to gain accounts.

LEAD: Over the last year, the United States has become increasingly entangled in the Persian Gulf through a series of isolated, incremental decisions with no systematic definition of strategy or policy, according to Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress.

China Starts New Airline
LEAD: China's largest airline, Air China, was established last week as part of a plan to reorganize the Civil Aviation Administration of China, an agency that has been criticized for mismanagement and inefficiency.
Air China will be the nation's major international carrier, operating 32 overseas routes to 31 cities in 24 countries.

Car Lynching
LEAD: Revenge seems to help relieve the pain when police refuse to enter a locked parked car and turn off the burglar alarm that endlessly pierces the night.
Such car alarms are mandated by law to shut off after 15 minutes.
Too many of them don't.
The police usually shrug off their responsibility to provide relief, for reasons the Department's legal adviser cannot explain.

His effectiveness was just not what it had been, for whatever reason.

Critic's Notebook; Biography and the Aim of Art
LEAD: ''Life is very nice, but it lacks form,'' Jean Anouilh once observed. ''It's the aim of art to give it some.'' It has been the aim of many recent biographies to identify the autobiographical sources lurking beneath those forms imposed by craft and imagination - an impulse with both rewards and hazards.


Bridge
LEAD: If one had to select a ''1987 Man of the Year'' based on performance in American National Championships, it would not be an American.
It would be Jaggy Shivdasani of Bombay, India, who achieved a remarkable double.
In his first American appearance, in Baltimore last July, he won the Spingold Knockout Team title with a pickup foursome.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan has wisely struck down the Government's attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization mission to the United Nations.
In so doing, Judge Edmund Palmieri vindicates the sanctity of America's treaty obligations and the right of the U.N. to extend its diplomatic hospitality as it sees fit.

LEAD: ''Pleasure Life,'' presented Sunday night by the Japanese experimentalist group Dumb Type at Performance Space 122, is a mad yet endearingly ingenuous enterprise involving miniature searchlights, four small television monitors, sleek Rube Goldberg sculptures that produce sound when they turn and ranks of shoulder-high platforms made of steel rods.

LEAD: More than 100 vials containing blood washed ashore from Newark Bay and were turned over to the New Jersey Department of Health, the police said today.

Q: Which Books to Take? A: Nearly All.
LEAD: Moving day.
You can't put it off any longer.
The mover's at the door, armed with cardboard boxes and one of life's fundamental questions: Which books do you keep?
And why?
With no visible medical credentials, he is asking you to perform nothing less than an autopsy on your life.

LEAD: The Koppers Company has signed a letter of intent to sell its chemical division for $660 million to an investor group that includes some Koppers managers, Beazer P.L.C. said.
Beazer agreed to acquire Koppers on June 1 for about $1.81 billion.
The sale, which had been expected, would leave Koppers with its construction-materials business, which accounted for 60 percent of its revenue in 1987.

What cause can justify the risk of so appalling an accident?
It surely occasions a reexamination of the Navy's activities in the Persian Gulf and the goals of American policy.


Fritz Wiessner, 88; Career as a Climber Spanned 8 Decades
LEAD: Fritz Wiessner, a mountain climber whose active career spanned eight decades and who led difficult ascents until he was nearly 87 years old, died on Sunday from complications after a stroke at his home home in Stowe, Vt.
He was 88 years old.


Medserv Chief Returns From Russia With Deal
LEAD: Dennis A. Sokol arrived from the Soviet Union via London on the Concorde yesterday morning and complained, ''I'm tired.'' But Mr.
Sokol had two agreements in his pocket to provide health care services to the Russians.


The Editorial Notebook; For Addicts: A Death Penalty
LEAD: Few people would advocate solving the drug problem by killing addicts.
Yet that's the effect of the drug policy now pursued by Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo.
By resisting measures to halt transmission of the AIDS virus among addicts, they are letting the infection spread.
That does not eliminate drug abuse, only drug abusers.

LEAD: The X-ray machines at the doors are gone, and the tense atmosphere that reigned at Unesco's headquarters at Place de Fontenoy has visibly relaxed.
It is possible now for employees to be seen talking to American diplomats without fear of censure or ostracism.

LEAD: In a round straw hat and an off-green jeans outfit, Patricia Harris of Washington was a nervous spectator today as the second of her sons to fight in the United States Olympic Trials started toward the ring.


About New York; The Insolvent Find a Tradition Is Dwindling
LEAD: It is midday at Gem Pawnbrokers, the self-proclaimed ''Money Stop'' at 608 Eighth Avenue.
A man shuffles in with a duffle bag and proceeds to extract a conga drum, displaying it as if it were pure gold.
He hints he might condescend to pawn it for $75.
Bill Galindez, who owns the place, squints and says $35.


A Circuit of Festivals Showcases the Blues
LEAD: These are busy times for Mark Naftalin, a musician and a producer of blues shows.
The posters from his just-completed Marin County Blues Festival are stacked high on a living room piano bench, and the phone rings repeatedly with calls from helpers.

LEAD: Even amid an unfolding international crisis, there has been room at the White House for gentility.

LEAD: ON Jones Beach, this is the summer of the young men in the long suits and the longish hair.
As they move along the boardwalk in these sleek black spandex pants, the breeze lifts tufts of hair at the napes of their necks and the sunlight glints on the heavy gold chains that dangle horn-shaped charms.

LEAD: Robert H. Morosky, the former president of Allied Stores, is negotiating to buy the Gold Circle discount department store chain from Federated Department Stores, according to people in the retailing business.
Gold Circle is one of the remaining Federated store divisions still to be sold by the Campeau Corporation, owners of both Federated and Allied Stores.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday introduced its Multifamily Guarantor Program, whereby the corporation will buy three types of fixed-rate multifamily mortgages from lenders for a like amount of multifamily mortgage participation certificates.
Included will be both conventional and Federal Housing Administration mortgages.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary on June 22 about Bobby Dodd, the former Georgia Tech football coach, misstated his birth date.
It was Nov. 11, 1908.

LEAD: Richard D. Burritt, for more than 40 years a reporter, editor and news administrator with The New York Times, died of Alzheimer's disease Friday at St.
Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, Conn.
He was 84 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

Sports of The Times; The 1994 World Cup
LEAD: AT the moment he had been waiting for all his life, Peter Sommo fell to his knees in front of the television set, held his head in his hands and shouted a quick prayer of thanksgiving.
And every so often later that Sunday in 1982 as he hurried about the Knickerbocker Country Club, where he has been a waiter for more than a decade, he suddenly shed a tear and suddenly sang a song under his breath, occasionally at the same time.


Dispute Resolved
LEAD: Ronnie Lamarque, co-owner of Risen Star, showed a $100,000 check at a news conference in New Orleans a yesterday and said it would go to the jockey, Eddie Delahoussaye, resolving his dispute with the colt's owners.
Delahoussaye had complained that he had not received a 10 percent share of a $1 million bonus paid to Risen Star in recognition of the colt's performance in the Triple Crown races.


Mr. Meese Judges Mr. Meese
LEAD: Satisfied that he will not be indicted, Edwin Meese has decided to resign as Attorney General.
Even though he hasn't seen the just-completed report of the independent counsel who investigated him for a year, Mr.
Meese said yesterday that he is certain of vindication.
He thus clings to the wrong standard even as he rightly declines to cling to office until the bitter end.


Mexicans Will Vote Today, Calling Ballot a Watershed
LEAD: After the most competitive and contentious presidential campaign in nearly half a century, Mexicans are to vote Wednesday in an election being described here as a watershed in modern Mexican history.


Car Sales Up in Japan
LEAD: Japanese bought a record 2.5 million vehicles in the first six months of the year, a 16.9 percent increase from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today.
Hisashi Kawagishi, an official with the trade group, said the increase reflected steady consumer spending and strong sales campaigns.

LEAD: The last of four prep school classmates sought in connection with a crime spree that left one of their friends dead surrendered in the Bronx yesterday and was charged with hindering prosecution.

LEAD: The governing bodies of Anglican churches meeting on both sides of the Atlantic were struggling yesterday for ways to open religious offices to women without splintering their denominations.

Marguerite Belleri, Singer, 64
LEAD: Marguerite Belleri, a member of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus for 57 years, died of heart failure Saturday evening at Hempstead (L.I.) Hospital.
She was 93 years old.
Mrs.
Belleri, born Gretl Maerkl in Traunstein, Bavaria, was engaged for the Met in 1910 when still a Munich schoolgirl.
During her tenure with the company she worked with many of the great conductors and singers of the century.


Soon You'll 'Print' a Copy of That Bedsheet Pattern
LEAD: A shopper in a department store scans a computer display of different bedsheet patterns, presses several buttons and walks to the checkout counter.
Instantly, an electrostatic printing system begins ''printing'' the chosen pattern on the sheets.
By the time the customer's credit card is checked and the purchase is completed, the machine has produced a custom-printed set of sheets - with matching pillow cases.

He owes no money and buys generic grocery products.

LEAD: ''Short Circuit 2,'' a sequel to the 1985 comedy that became a best seller as a video cassette, is about the mechanically cute robot, now named Johnny Five, and his adventures in a big unnamed city that is, in fact, Toronto.
It opens today at the Criterion and other theaters.


Judge Schedules Start of Agent Orange Payments
LEAD: Totally disabled Vietnam veterans who were exposed to the highly toxic herbicide Agent Orange will begin receiving payments early next year from a $240 million settlement of a suit against the chemical's makers, a Federal judge said yesterday.


Foster Injured
LEAD: The two-time world champion high hurdler, Greg Foster, said yesterday that he would try to make the United States Olympic team despite a broken left arm that required surgery and medical opinion that the goal may be impossible.
Foster, 29, broke his left forearm when he tripped on a hurdle in practice Monday at Cal Poly Pomona.

LEAD: Japan and the United States today signed a farm-trade agreement reached last month that would eventually dismantle Tokyo's quotas on imports of beef, oranges and orange juice.
The Japanese Ambassador, Nobuo Matsunaga, and the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, exchanged letters to put the accord into effect, ending a 20-year dispute.

Economic Scene; On Guaranteeing Child Support
LEAD: FOR the political pros eager to untangle the welfare maze, three of the prettiest words in the English language are ''make dad pay.'' Requiring absent fathers to support their children would make a dent in the cost of supporting chronic welfare dependents, as well as saving newly separated and suddenly poor mothers from a first visit to the welfare office.

LEAD: A Federal judge has struck down as unconstitutional the Reagan Administration policy of withholding foreign aid from private groups that perform abortions or that promote the procedure as a method of birth control.

LEAD: Rebels in northern Uganda have released seven kidnapped priests and nuns after the Roman Catholic Church met their demands for medical supplies, the Rev.
Agostoni Tarcis, secretary of the church's Justice and Peace Commission, said today.
The abductions occurred Saturday at Amuru Mission, near the provincial capital of Gulu, after an unsuccessful raid by the group, the Holy Spirit Movement, on another mission hospital for drugs.

Citicorp Auction
LEAD: Interest rates were mixed to nearly unchanged yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.
The bank holding company said it sold $50 million worth of 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.567 percent, down from 7.589 percent last week.
It also sold $50 million worth of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.5943 percent, almost unchanged from the 7.594 percent it received last week.

Egypt Back in Arab Group
LEAD: Egypt has been reinstated in the Arab League Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization, effective next December, the organization announced today.
Egypt was suspended in 1979 after signing the peace treaty with Israel.
The organization works closely with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and with the Arab League, which also suspended Egypt in 1979 and has not reinstated it.

LEAD: THOSE who watch ''The Today Show,'' ''All My Children,'' ''Facts of Life'' and ''L.A.
Law'' may already be familiar with Corelli's ''Suite for Strings,'' the signature musical segue into television commercials for K Mart featuring the entertaining maven Martha Stewart.


Study Faults U.S. Plan to Trade Alaska Land
LEAD: A Congressional study says a Reagan Administration proposal to trade away potentially valuable oil rights in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is not in the public interest and should be abandoned.


Spanish-Language TV Grows Up
LEAD: Helped by the deep pockets of new corporate owners and growing interest from advertisers, Spanish-language television in the United States is shedding its status as the stepchild of the broadcasting industry and maturing into a more professional and competitive business.


Progressive Is as Legitimate as Conservative
LEAD: To the Editor:


Baseball; Viola Beats Red Sox for 14th
LEAD: Frank Viola won his league-leading 14th game tonight, pitching a three-hitter as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8-1.
The Twins moved within three and a half games of Oakland in the American League West.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about a patent dispute involving a British company misidentified the former director of research at Molins P.L.C.
He is David T. N. Williamson.


Armenians Cite Deaths But Soviets Deny Clash
LEAD: Armenian militants said today that Soviet Army paratroopers had fired on protesters trying to shut down Yerevan's airport and had killed as many as five people.
A Soviet official denied there had been any clashes or deaths.


South Korean Chief, in a Switch, Seeks Wide New Ties With North
LEAD: Announcing an important change in policy toward North Korea, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea said today that he would allow trade, family visits and student exchanges with the North.


Sports People; Page Named Coach
LEAD: Pierre Page, who has spent the last eight years with the Calgary Flames' organization, the last three as an assistant coach, was named coach of the Minnesota North Stars yesterday.
Page, 40 years old, succeeds Herb Brooks, who, with the entire staff of coaches and scouts, was dismissed June 14.
That day, Jack Ferreira was hired as general manager for the North Stars, whose 19-48-13 record last season was the worst in the National Hockey

Perini Investment Bid Is Increased
LEAD: An investment group led by the Beverly Hills investor Robert N. Goodman has raised its offer to acquire Perini Investment Properties Inc. to $21.50 a share, or $84.3 million, from its earlier $19-a-share proposal.


Shultz Begins 18-Day Visit to 7 Asian Lands and Hong Kong
LEAD: In a final effort to strengthen relationships and resolve longstanding problems in Asia before the end of the Reagan Administration, Secretary of State George P. Shultz began an 18-day visit today to seven East Asian countries and Hong Kong.


Review/Music; A Night of Japanese Music With a Western Tilt
LEAD: The very notion of a ''Sound Space Ark'' conjures up some hippie vision of musical transcendence.
The reality is somewhat more prosaic, if still interesting.
This is the name - its derivation seems lost in mystical conceptualizing and group discussion - assumed by a Tokyo new-music ensemble founded in 1972.


Oil Trader a Big Winner In Atlantic Sale to Sun
LEAD: John Deuss, the Dutch oil trader whose attempt to corner the January market for North Sea Brent crude cost him $200 million, will more than make up for his loss with the planned sale of his Philadelphia refinery to the Sun Company.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency Grabs Agency: This Book Tells the Tale
LEAD: Recent fans of the ad game and old participants as well will find interesting reading in ''Emperors of Adland,'' a new book by Nancy Millman, advertising columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times.
It is a readable guide to, and background study of, the merger mania that has infected the industry worldwide.

LEAD: The Prime Minister's office said today that it is investigating an allegation that officers of the Israeli internal security service disguised themselves as ABC News reporters and cameramen to arrest a Palestinian last month.

LEAD: The Iranian F-14 fighter that the warship Vincennes thought it had detected in an attack pattern over the Persian Gulf on Sunday would have posed a limited threat to the ship, aerospace industry and military officials said today.

LEAD: More than 15 miles of ocean beach on Long Island, including Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Parks, were closed today when a mysterious wave of sewage, syringes, blood vials and infectious hospital waste washed ashore.

It's like occupying a permanently suspended helicopter.

Gabriel Dell, 68, a Dead End Kid On Broadway and in Many Films
LEAD: Gabriel Dell, who began acting on Broadway as one of the Dead End Kids and went on to a wide-ranging stage and film career, died of leukemia Sunday at his home in North Hollywood, Calif.
He was 68 years old.


Putting Son on Display as Pig Brings a Child Abuse Charge
LEAD: A woman who dressed her 7-year-old son as a pig, tied his hands behind his back and placed him on the front porch where neighbors could view the crying child pleaded not guilty today to a child abuse charge.


Heyman's Transformation of GAF
LEAD: Six years ago, a Connecticut real estate developer unknown on Wall Street bought a tiny block of stock in the GAF Corporation and threatened to throw out the directors unless they sold the company.


Fatal Fire Is Ruled Arson
LEAD: A fire that killed five people has been ruled arson, Fire Chief Charles J. Bunyan said today.
Investigators have traced the origin of the blaze to the enclosed porch of the victims' duplex, he said.
Killed in the fire Monday were Jack Blose, 35 years old, his wife, Deborah, 31, and their children, Jack Jr., 12, Rachel, 5, and Lacey, 4.


Big Board's Priority Plan Wins Praise
LEAD: A proposal by the New York Stock Exchange to give priority to individual investors' orders received favorable reactions yesterday from portfolio managers and other market professionals, while their reactions to a plan to drop a post-crash reform on the Big Board were mixed.


Britain and Iran Settle Case
LEAD: Britain and Iran have agreed to exchange compensation for damage to each other's embassies in incidents about eight years ago, the Foreign Office announced today.
Iran will come out ahead by nearly $2 million in the deal, which Foreign Office officials and Mohammed Besti, the Iranian charge d'affaires in London, completed Tuesday after three weeks of negotiations, a Foreign Office spokesman said.


Indicted GAF Executive Is a Student of Chess
LEAD: In describing why he loved the game of chess so much, James T. Sherwin told a reporter last year: ''You can engage in diversionary tactics.
You can try to fool your opponent into thinking you can do one thing and you're really doing something else.''

LEAD: Ozzie Smith, the Wizard of Oz shortstop for the St.
Louis Cardinals, stood No. 1 in the big leagues in votes last night when the final tally was made in the annual election by fans for baseball's All-Star Game.

Sports People; Malone Dispensable
LEAD: The Washington Bullets indicated yesterday that they would make no attempt to re-sign Moses Malone, the 33-year-old center who has been an All-Star 10 times.


72 Tons of Marijuana Seized
LEAD: The Coast Guard has seized a Panamanian-registered ship with more than 72 tons of marijuana, after firing on it 600 miles from shore.
Officials said the converted oil-supply ship Encounter Bay, which was towed into port here today, refused orders to stop on Friday.
The cutter Boutwell, with permission from the Panamanian Embassy to board her, fired 60 rounds from machine guns, then threatened cannon fire before the crew surrendered.


Sports People; Jets Sign Safety
LEAD: The Jets have agreed to terms with the free safety Erik McMillan, a No. 3 draft pick, and a defensive tackle, Albert Goss, their No. 12 pick.
The Jets have signed 6 of their 12 draft picks.

2 Labs Licensed for New AIDS Test
LEAD: A biotechnology company that developed a test to detect the AIDS virus, even if it is hidden in cells, announced yesterday that the test was now available commercially.


Review/Recital; Soviet Pianist, Busoni Winner, Makes Debut
LEAD: A superior pianistic talent was disclosed by Lilia Zilberstein, the young Moscow-born winner of the 1987 Busoni competition, at her local debut in Weill Recital Hall Tuesday evening.
The program - a part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts - was all Russian, and the style corresponded, but Miss Zilberstein moderates the harsh excesses that have been associated with Soviet piano playing in recent decades, and brings a fluid lyricism, a free swing of tempo and a sense of color to much of her playing.


Reviving a Comforter
LEAD: AT this point, you have probably forgotten (if you care at all) that last winter your down comforter was getting flat and lumpy and was losing its warmth.
But now is the season to have it reconditioned.

Wahlstrom also has offices in Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

LEAD: Despite an asphalt company president's testimony that he conspired with executives of three other companies to fix prices of asphalt used on state and local roads in Orange County, a jury on Tuesday acquitted the other three of violating Federal antitrust laws.

LEAD: BOTH the weigh-in officials and the fish will benefit from the new regulations governing the American Bluefish Tournament out of Margate, N.J., July 16.


It's Not Just Recess
LEAD: The House majority leader, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, tried to brief reporters yesterday morning about the legislative agenda now that Congressmen were back in town from their five-day break for the Fourth of July.
But he had barely uttered the words ''Independence Day District Work Period,'' the official name for the break, when he as well as the reporters dissolved in giggles.


Board Backs Building New Military Reactor
LEAD: An Energy Department advisory board today recommended building a nuclear reactor in South Carolina to provide raw materials for the nation's atomic weapons arsenal.

LEAD: John Reilly, who served for two decades as Chicago's director of special events, died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
He was 89 years old.


Market Place; Fund Managers Regain the Lead
LEAD: AT the beginning of the year, some market analysts boldly stated that this would be the year that investment managers began beating the Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index, and it appears that they were correct.
After lagging behind the index for four of the last five years, the average independent investment management firm has been outpacing the once seemingly unbeatable index -and by a fairly wide margin.


The Pucker Factor
LEAD: In armed services slang, ''the pucker factor'' is the stress that afflicts human beings on full alert.
If the factor is missing, the person reacts like a robot, numb to sensitizing tension; if the factor is too high, the person crumples or ''puckers'' in panic.


Sports People; Sabonis at Risk
LEAD: The team physician of the Portland Trail Blazers has said the Soviet basketball star Arvydas Sabonis would risk a career-threatening injury if he plays in the Olympic Games this year.


North Sea Oil Rig Blast Kills 1 and Injures 25
LEAD: An explosion and fire on a North Sea oil rig killed one worker and injured at least 25 others Wednesday night.
Many of the injured were severely burned.

LEAD: Texaco Inc.'s plan to sell Saudi Arabia a half-interest in three United States refineries and associated marketing properties can go forward without the approval of the Federal committee that reviews foreigners' purchases of American companies, a Treasury Department official said yesterday.

Making Feet Burn in Moscow
LEAD: His economic reforms sputtering, Mikhail Gorbachev decided to wrest at least the promise of real political change from last week's Communist Party conference.
He got it.
Conferees agreed to slash the party's role in decision-making and management and to turn the Government into a president-and-parliament system.


ACID RAIN IMPERILS ADIRONDACKS FISH
LEAD: Over a quarter of the lakes and ponds in the Adirondack Mountains are so acidic that the vast majority of them can no longer support fish, a three-year study by New York's state environmental agency has found.
An additional one-fifth of the lakes in the region are so acidic they are considered ''endangered,'' according to the study.


Leading Japan Politicians Implicated in a Stock Deal
LEAD: Leading Japanese politicians, including aides to Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita and to former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, were implicated today in a deal in which they reaped huge profits on the sale of the stock of a fast-growing Japanese company.

LEAD: Acacio da Silva of Portugual edged Steven Rooks of the Netherlands in a photo finish today of the fourth stage of the Tour de France.
Another Dutchman, Teun Van Vliet, kept the overall lead.


Safety Agreement at Eastern
LEAD: Eastern Air Lines and unions representing its pilots, flight attendants, mechanics and other employees have agreed to work together to make sure that their longstanding labor dispute does not jeopardize safe operation of the airline, Federal officials announced yesterday.

LEAD: A Bronx preparatory school student pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of hindering prosecution after telling a judge that he had helped wash away blood and burn up clothes in an effort to conceal a friend's death during a crime spree late last month.


Health; Personal Health
LEAD: There is hope for cigarette smokers who feel increasingly victimized, misunderstood or at the mercy of their tobacco habit.
Health professionals and nonsmokers are being urged to see smokers in a more sympathetic and constructive light in the wake of the Surgeon General's recent report declaring nicotine to be an addictive drug that quickly turns most users into abusers.

LEAD: A bomber's incompetence probably saved this small southern Indiana town from explosions that could have damaged six bridges as well as offices and businesses, the authorities say.


Health: Behavior; New Research Identifies Disorders That Disrupt Sleep With Violence
LEAD: One night five years ago, Donald Dorff woke up in the middle of the night with a gash on his forehead.
The 67-year-old retired grocer from Minneapolis had been dreaming that he was a football star in pads and a uniform, charging an opponent.
In fact, he was wearing pajamas and he had charged into his bedroom dresser.


More Funds for Training Programs
LEAD: New York State now requires all welfare recipients capable of working, including mothers with children over age 6, to take part in job training, educational programs, organized job searches or, as a last resort, mandatory work programs.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell further yesterday, pushed lower by a drop in the value of the dollar and a big jump in many commodity prices.

LEAD: For months Michael S. Dukakis waved off any questions about his choice of a running mate with a breezy, ''There's plenty of time.'' Now, with 12 days left before the Democratic National Convention begins in Atlanta, Mr.
Dukakis is on the brink of a decision, but he is giving very few clues about what it will be.


A GARDENER'S WORLD A Touch of Gray Brings Harmony To Diverse Plants
LEAD: AS more and more gray creeps into my hair, the same thing is happening in my garden.
I don't know if there's any connection, except that the passage of time always brings its changes, many of them predictable.
The longer people garden, the more their taste in plants tends to run toward those with gray foliage.

The Editorial Notebook; Why the Palestinians Left
LEAD: An Israeli journalist, Benny Morris, has written a careful and timely book about the origins of Israel's endless conflict with Palestinian refugees.
It addresses two questions.
Were Arabs expelled from Israel as part of a predetermined Zionist plan?
Or did Palestinians flee voluntarily, as instructed, in the expectation that they would return after invading Arabs had driven Jews into the sea?

LEAD: A 27-year-old Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday to murdering a crime witness and gave a graphic and chilling account of how he and another man had executed her.

U.S.-Soviet Theater Conference Plans Exchanges
LEAD: A meeting of Soviet and American theater people opened here Tuesday at Eugene O'Neill's boyhood home, and, were he alive, the playwright might have been jarred to hear talk that was more reminiscent of box office than of ideological ferment.
The script for the sessions, which are to end Friday, calls for practical cultural exchange unimpeded by governmental staging and moralistic declamation.

Leak Closes Nuclear Plant
LEAD: The Consolidated Edison Company's Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant was taken out of service at 4 A.M. today when a leak of slightly radioactive water was discovered, a spokesman said.
The spokesman, Dan Walden, said a pin-sized hole in a tube in one of four steam generators in the containment building was discovered through normal monitoring procedures.


Money Fund Assets Rise
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 441 money market mutual funds increased $468.8 million, to $264.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 122 institutional funds decreased $458.8 million, to $69.64 billion.
Assets of the 220 general purpose funds were up $316.4 million, to $81.76 billion.


Apollo's Troubles Stun Wall St.
LEAD: In a surprise for both Wall Street and the computer industry, Apollo Computer Inc., a maker of computer work stations, said yesterday that it expected to report a second-quarter loss of between $5 million and $8 million because of lower demand for its machines in the United States and Europe.


Campaign Finance; How an Ecology PAC Chooses Its Candidates
LEAD: Officers of the League of Conservation Voters' political action committee admitted that they knew very little about the environmental views of Wayne Cryts, a Missouri farmer who is running for Congress.


USG Is Offering $600 Million Issue
LEAD: The USG Corporation, the nation's largest gypsum producer, is offering to the public a $600 million issue of senior subordinated debentures due in 2000 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
Originally the corporation planned a $550 million financing.


TAX PROPOSAL STIRS DISPUTE IN GERMANY
LEAD: The West German Government, which is struggling to contain a soaring deficit, announced its 1989 budget today amid heated controversy over planned tax increases.
There is a widespread belief among economists that the increases will largely neutralize the reductions in personal income taxes that go into effect in 1990.


72 Tons of Marijuana Seized
LEAD: The Coast Guard has seized a Panamanian-registered ship with more than 72 tons of marijuana, after firing on it 600 miles from shore.


Grimes Ordered to Resume Testimony in Attack Trial
LEAD: A victim of the Howard Beach racial attack who erupted emotionally on the witness stand Wednesday will have to continue testifying at the second trial in the case despite his mental and emotional problems, the judge ruled yesterday.

LEAD: Bobby Allison left his room at Lehigh Valley Hospital Center in Allentown, Pa., in a wheelchair yesterday for the first time since his racing accident June 19.
Ed Gossage, spokesman for Allison's sponsor, Miller Racing, said Allison remained in guarded condition.
Allison, 51, suffered a concussion and several broken bones in the accident in the Nascar Miller 500 at Pocono International Raceway.


Company News; Qantas Jet Order
LEAD: Australia's international carrier Qantas Airways Ltd. has placed an order for three additional jetliners from the Boeing Company. ''The acquisitions, which will build the Qantas fleet to 43 aircraft, are needed to meet traffic demand,'' Jim Leslie, Qantas's chairman, said in a statement.
He said the planes, two 747-400's and a 767-300ER, would lift the airline's order list to 11 new planes at a total cost of $2.06 billion.

LEAD:  Jazz With J. J. Johnson J. J. Johnson, Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South, near 11th Street (255-4037).
J.
J.
Johnson's appearance at the Village Vanguard last year had the club packed not only with jazz fans, but also with trombonists, most of whom were slack-jawed in amazement.
Mr.
Johnson, the first be-bop trombonist, set the rules for most trombonists who followed him, not only in his unadorned, graceful swing, but in his tone and perfect intonation as well.

Against an eclectic polyrhythmic score by Marc Ream, the images transform and dissolve like a grandly designed Rorschach test.

LEAD: H. Ross Perot's $500,000 consulting contract with the Postal Service was suspended yesterday by the General Services Administration because his company had refused to supply documents to the G.S.A.'s Board of Contract Appeals.


Review/Art; Portraitist's Faces of Early America
LEAD: The early-19th-century portraits by Joshua Johnson, now on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center, come to life slowly.
Johnson, one of the first known black artists in the United States, was active as a portraitist in Baltimore between 1795 and 1825, and the considerable strengths of his art emerge from behind a screen of social propriety, artistic awkwardness and pictorial convention.


Iran Sought Talks in April, U.S. Says
LEAD: Iran apparently expressed interest in a face-to-face meeting with American officials last April, but hopes for a meeting were dashed after the United States sank six Iranian gunboats in the wake of the mining of the frigate Samuel B. Roberts, several senior Administration officials said today.


Lucas May Try To Buy Elstree
LEAD: George Lucas, the maker of ''Star Wars'' and ''Willow,'' said today that he might buy Britain's Elstree film studios, which were recently sold to a property group.


U.N. Agencies to Meet in Oslo On Third World Environment
LEAD: Heads of the major international development agencies are likely to agree at a meeting here to place greater emphasis on protecting the environment to insure that economic growth becomes sustainable in the third world, the Norwegian Prime Minister said today.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the Senate vote on a plant-closing bill misstated the vote of Senator Bob Dole in some editions.
He voted against the legislation.


Richest Person Found in Japan
LEAD: Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, the head of Japan's Seibu railway group, remains the richest person in the world, Forbes magazine said yesterday.


Senate Blocks Reagan On Kuwait Arms Sale
LEAD: The Senate tonight agreed by voice vote to block President Reagan's request to sell Kuwait 300 Maverick air-to-surface missiles.
The action comes just days before Kuwait's ruler arrives in Washington.

Sports People; Challenging the Rules
LEAD: Even though National Collegiate Athletic Association rules have apparently disqualified Tony Mandarich of Michigan State from competition this season, Coach George Perles insisted yesterday that his lineman will play this fall.


Business People; Bank Names New Officers
LEAD: The Greater New York Savings Bank, moving to fill a vacancy caused by the death of its top executive, yesterday named Charles J. Ohlig chairman and chief executive and Gerard C. Keegan president and chief operating officer.


Socker, Anyone?
LEAD: The selection of the United States to host the 1994 World Cup raises the question of why Americans call the sport soccer when it's football everywhere else.
A well-traveled friend explains that the name evolved when the game came over from England, which has two sports called football - rugby football and association football.


Sterling A. Callisen Art Historian, 89
LEAD: Dr.
Sterling A. Callisen, an art historian and former president of the Parsons School of Design, died of pneumonia last Saturday at his home in Andover, Mass.
He was 89 years old.


Afrikaner Church Questions South Africa's Angola Role
LEAD: In the first sign of dissent within the Afrikaner establishment over Pretoria's military presence in Angola, the main Afrikaner church has publicly questioned South Africa's role there.

Avon Books Picks Chief
LEAD: Carolyn Reidy, the publisher of Anchor Books, yesterday was named president and publisher of Avon Books, the mass-marketing division of the Hearst Trade Book Group.
Ms.
Reidy will replace Rena Wolner, who announced her retirement from book publishing.
Ms.
Reidy was director of subsidiary rights at William Morrow from 1983 to 1985.


Review/Film; Rocks and Hard Places
LEAD: Harry Hook's subdued and powerful first film is a coming-of-age story loaded with history.
Mwangi, a 12-year-old boy of the Kikuyu tribe, is a clear metaphor for Kenya's political development.
Set in 1950, at the start of the struggle that would lead to independence from British rule 13 years later, ''The Kitchen Toto'' suggests how blacks such as Mwangi were doubly oppressed - by the white colonists and by the Mau Mau, the terrorist group that forced other Kikuyus to swear allegiance to them.


SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  'Paris' at the Algonquin Liliane Montevecchi: ''Souvenir de Paris,'' the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street (840-6800).
Liliane Montevecchi and her musical director, Joel Silberman, have skillfully adapted her recent one-woman show, ''On the Boulevard,'' into a cabaret act.
The dancer and singer shares her memories of working in the chorus of the Folies-Bergeres and Parisian-inspired songs that include Cole Porter's wistful ''You Don't Know Paree'' and ''I Love Paris,'' as well as a French ''Night and Day.


Diner's Journal
LEAD:  A Neighborhood Haunt New York City is filled with unassuming little neighborhood haunts that rarely if ever get press attention, and they get along just fine without it.


Company News; CJI Will Acquire Triangle Industries
LEAD: Triangle Industries, the world's largest consumer packaging concern, said its shareholders had approved the acquisition of Triangle by a subsidiary, CJI Industries.
The company will still be called Triangle, officials said.
The acquisition increases to 82 percent the combined voting shares of Nelson Peltz, Triangle's chairman, and Peter W.


Review/Music; Evening of 20th-Century Music With the London Sinfonietta
LEAD: The London Sinfonietta, now in its 20th season, showed at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening why it is in the upper echelon of the world's new-music groups.
A concert of 20th-century works led by Esa-Pekka Salonen, a young Finnish conductor whose sympathy for contemporary music is obviously strong, was a marvel of ensemble synchronization and technical fluency.


DOLLAR DRIFTS ON RUMORS; TRADE GAP FIGURE AWAITED
LEAD: The dollar drifted again yesterday, but some currency traders said they were still confident that the two-week rally would be revived.


House to Vote On Trade Bill
LEAD: The House will vote next Wednesday on a revised bill to overhaul United States trade policy and on a related measure requiring large United States companies to give advance notice before closing a plant, House Speaker Jim Wright said today.


A Joint Jewish-Arab Peace Movement Needed; Education Goes On
LEAD: To the Editor:


Europe Jobless Data
LEAD: The number of people out of work in the European Community fell by 400,000 in May, but the seasonally adjusted rate remained unchanged at 10.3 percent, according to figures released today.
The statistics office said the number of jobless in the 12 member states stood at 15.5 million in May - 1.6 percent lower than in May 1987 and down 2.5 percent from April.


Company News; Drexel Said To Expect Charges
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert is stepping up its campaign to brace employees and major customers to the likelihood that it faces impending charges of securities law violations, several customers of the firm said yesterday.

LEAD: William S. Paley, the 86-year-old founder and chairman of CBS, yesterday unveiled a model of his new $45 million Museum of Broadcasting before a gathering at the Plaza Hotel.


Proxy Vote Held Valid In Irving Bank Battle
LEAD: A ballot cast by the Heine Securities Corporation for Bank of New York during its campaign to unseat the board of Irving Bank should never have been revoked, a court-appointed referee concluded yesterday.


2 EXCHANGES BACK A PLAN FOR HALTS IN THEIR TRADING
LEAD: In an effort to reduce the chances of a market collapse like last October's, the boards of the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have approved a proposal under which trading in both markets could be halted before such a plunge.


Jersey Recommends Measles Revaccination
LEAD: The New Jersey Health Commissioner today recommended the revaccination of certain groups of children in Burlington and Ocean Counties because of an outbreak of measles that began in May.


Euro Disneyland Financing Gains
LEAD: Euro Disneyland, a unit of the Walt Disney Company, said it had completed two major hurdles in the initial financing of its theme park to be built near Marne-la-Vallee, east of Paris.
The park, which may turn out to be Europe's largest entertainment complex, will be built on a 5,000-acre site and is expected to open in 1992.

The Electoral College's Cold Calculus
LEAD: Americans have long hankered for formulas to predict elections.
Some formulas work better than others.
After the Roosevelt landslide of 1936, James J. Farley suggested dryly that the old cliche, ''As Maine goes, so goes the Nation,'' be updated to read, ''As Maine goes, so goes Vermont.'' Yet the inhabitants of Crook County, Oregon, have unerringly picked 26 consecutive winners, from Grover Cleveland through Ronald


Business Digest: Friday July 8, 1988
LEAD:  Markets


STIFF SETBACK SEEN FOR RULING PARTY IN MEXICAN VOTING
LEAD: The Mexican Government today failed to release all but the most fragmentary results from the presidential election Wednesday, an action immediately interpreted here as indicating that the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and its candidate had been rejected by a larger proportion of the electorate than at any other time in the party's 59-year history.


Limited National Impact Seen If Drought Lasts Only a Year
LEAD: A summer-long drought would inflict numerous hardships on farmers and others who depend on agriculture for a living, but the national economy as a whole will not be hurt if the drought is only a one-year phenomenon, many economists believe.


Struggling Carter Makes No Apology
LEAD: Gary Carter was accepting congratulations yesterday for making the All-Star team for the eighth straight year as the starting catcher for the National League.
And he was still accepting condolences for not hitting a home run in 52 days.

Higher Chance for Big Quake
LEAD: A new scientific report issued today estimated that there is a 60 percent chance of a major earthquake in Southern California in the next 30 years, and a 50 percent chance of a similar quake near San Francisco.

JUNE RETAIL SALES SHOW AN INCREASE
LEAD: Retail sales, stalled by cold and rain in April and May, improved with the weather in June, the nation's largest general retailers reported yesterday.
But industry analysts remained generally cautious about the outlook for consumer spending.


Reviews/Art; Juxtapositions: From Robert to Manet to Pollock
LEAD: Among the paintings Manet chose to exhibit in the 1873 Salon, a portrait of Berthe Morisot particularly rankled the Parisian critics. ''Le Repos'' depicts its subject reclining awkwardly on an overstuffed couch.
Manet displays her left hand draped elegantly across the cushioned seat, but the other hand looks bizarre - a claw painted in loose, flat brushstrokes.

Danger on the North Sea
LEAD:  1980: 123 crewmen on the accommodation platform Alexander L. Kielland died when the oil rig capsized in storms in the Norwegian Ekofisk area.
December 1965: 13 men died when the Sea Gem rig collapsed and sank.  1975: Three men were killed when a pipeline ruptured on the Alexander L. Kielland.
November 1965: Three people died and 11 were injured when an explosion ripped the bottom out of a drilling barge at Teesport near Middlesbrough in northeast England.

LEAD: The chairman of Alitalia, Umberto Nordio, was asked to resign today by Italy's state-owned holding company, Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, a major shareholder in the airline.
Last week Italian newspapers told of a dispute between the holding company's chairman, Romano Prodi, and Mr.
Nordio about how the airline was being run.


Real Benefits From Rail Profits
LEAD: Yes, railroads gouge shippers who lack a transport alternative.
An isolated coal mine in Kentucky is sure to pay a lot more than an auto parts manufacturer in Illinois that has railroads and truckers bidding for its business.

LEAD: A Federal jury today awarded $22.6 million to the estate of the defunct E.S.M.
Government Securities Inc., ruling against the financier Marvin L. Warner, who the firm claimed had unjustly profited from its 1985 failure.

LEAD: In an admission that it had significantly underestimated the problems in the savings and loan industry, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today more than doubled its projection of the cost of shutting down or merging more than 100 insolvent savings and loan associations in Texas.

He was 57 years old.

LEAD: An Energy Department advisory group has recommended that the department build a new reactor in South Carolina to produce fuel for the nation's nuclear weapons instead of converting a mothballed commercial reactor in the state of Washington.

LEAD: It's hard to remember now, but the Peace Corps used to be a favorite propaganda target of Radio Peking and other Communist outlets.
That was hardly surprising.

Khrushchev's missionaries  [ who were ]  pouring forth from Moscow to advance the cause of world Communism.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Media Business page on Monday about corporate name changes misstated the role of Landor Associates on behalf of British Airways.
Landor helped to redesign British Airways' logotype and aircraft in 1984.
The name change, from B.O.A.C., was made by the company itself, in 1972, after it was formed through the merger of the British Overseas Airways Corporation and British European Airways.


Review/Dance; Another Look at 'The Nutcracker'
LEAD: Experience and artistic maturity do make a difference in ballet, despite the physical advantages of extreme youth.
That was the message of two performances of ''The Nutcracker,'' performed by the Paris Opera Ballet on Tuesday night and Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.


Music From Villages Of the Soviet Union
LEAD: UNTIL now, an American listener would have had to traverse the length and breadth of the Soviet Union - to the borders of Mongolia, Iran, Poland and Turkey, to Siberia, the Gulf of Finland and the Black Sea -to hear the musicians appearing tomorrow at Symphony Space.
For the first time in New York, 34 musicians from the villages of the Soviet


Cocoa Panel Will Meet
LEAD: A panel of industry experts has scheduled a meeting next week to try to resolve a dispute between world cocoa producers and consumers over support prices, International Cocoa Organization officials said today.
The dispute over support prices has paralyzed the group's operations since March.
The organization, which tries to stabilize prices by buying and selling from a buffer stock, cannot intervene in the cocoa market until the two sides agree on what price range the pact should defend.


Bartok's Remains Are Reburied in His Native Hungary
LEAD: Bela Bartok Jr., left, and Peter Bartok, right, sons of the composer Bela Bartok, with an unidentified woman at a funeral ceremony yesterday in Budapest before the composer's remains were buried.
Bartok, who left Hungary in 1940 and died of leukemia in New York in 1945, had been buried in Hartsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorporation said today that it would acquire Montclair Savings Bank in a transaction valued at about $80 million.
Montclair, which has eight offices in New Jersey, will operate under its own name as a separate subsidiary of First Fidelity, the bank said.

LEAD: Anxious oil traders briefly pushed the price of oil up by nearly a dollar a barrel in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange early yesterday after news of an explosion and fire on a North Sea oil platform.
New figures showing high demand for gasoline also bolstered prices.

Arthur (Dudley Moore) still drinks too much, though now it's beginning to show.
He looks vaguely unhealthy and is no longer funny.

Economic Scene; The Revolution By Gorbachev
LEAD: THE Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, gained support for his proposals to reorganize his nation's economic and political system from last week's conference of the Communist Party.
But what is striking about the resolutions adopted is the admission of the failings of the Soviet system and the painfully slow progress made thus far in overcoming them.


Misadventures On the Way To Munich
''Loose Connections,'' the 1983 English film that opens today at the Public Theater, is of main interest for having been directed by Richard Eyre, the director of the good, strong, politically provoking ''Ploughman's Lunch'' (1984), written by Ian McEwan.
''Loose Connections'' is a politically aware romantic comedy about a pretty, committed feminist named Sally (Lindsay Duncan), a representative of the middle class, and her adventures on the European road with Harry (Stephen Rea), a rough, young male chauvinist out of Liverpool's working class.

15 Officers Wounded by Inmates in Attack at Jersey Prison
LEAD: Inmates wounded 15 corrections officers at Trenton State Prison today in what prison officials said was a planned attack.
None of the officers were seriously hurt.


Separating Facts From Hyperbole In Reports of Hospital Waste on L.I.
LEAD: Shortly after noon on Wednesday, bathers at Lido Beach in Nassau County plucked two empty vials, syringes and other suspicious material from the surf.
Almost immediately, worried lifeguards, following standing orders, ordered hundreds of bathers out of the water.

This was an imaginative grouping of three contemporary practitioners of extended vocal techniques, none well known to the general public.

LEAD: The USG Corporation's shareholders overwhelmingly approved a restructuring plan that will increase the company's debt to $3.1 billion from $800 million.
The restructuring was the legacy of its costly victory in a takeover battle with Desert Partners L.P.

AIDS Carriers Win a Court Ruling
LEAD: A Federal court in California has issued the most definitive ruling yet that a Federal law barring discrimination against the handicapped protects healthy carriers of the AIDS virus as well as those who have actually developed the deadly disease.


Reviews/Music; Sibelius Quartet, From Finland, In a New Work
LEAD: Vladimir Agopov, a Ukrainian composer who teaches in Finland, recently delivered a new string quartet to his colleagues of the Sibelius Academy Quartet.
They in turn brought the piece - Mr.
Agopov's second in the genre - to listeners at the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night.


CBS Revises Fall Schedule To Counter Effects of Strike
LEAD: CBS announced yesterday a reworked schedule for the fall that emphasizes movies, mini-series and special programming by the network's sports and entertainment divisions.
The move represents CBS's strategy for filling in gaps in its schedule left by the strike of the Writers Guild of America.


Counting Dropouts, Keeping Students
LEAD: What proportion of students drop out of New York City high schools?
According to a recent study by the Board of Education, the figure is 26.3 percent, an improvement from the 27.9 percent calculated a year ago.
But by another, more sophisticated calculation that tracks students through all four years, the rate is 22.4 percent, up from 21.8.


Postal Agency Plans Partial Restoration Of Reduced Services
LEAD: Window service at the nation's post offices, reduced last February to save money, will be returned to normal levels in September, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank announced today.

LEAD: In a modern industrial complex on the outskirts of Santiago, Chilean technicians are meticulously reconstructing a French-built Mirage 50 fighter plane that crashed two and a half years ago.


Massachusetts Plans to Pay to Send Boston Pupils to Suburbs
LEAD: Massachusetts lawmakers have added to the 1989 budget a $1 million plan under which the state would pay suburban public schools to accept students who live in Boston and neighboring Worcester.

LEAD: Mayor Koch said the other day that the ''daughter of Westway has more than seven veils.'' He was probably too discreet to say that the veils are rapidly slipping off.
As they reveal her blemishes, the danger increases that Westway's ''daughter'' will turn into another Westway fiasco.

Larizza Industries
LEAD: Larizza Industries said it had provided certain information to a number of parties who might be interested in possible acquisition of the company or a portion of the company's assets.
Larizza manufactures plastic products, electronic components and valve and pipe fittings.
Larizza said none of the parties had made an offer and there were no negotiations under way with such parties.

LEAD: Four out of every five flights into the nation's 27 busiest airports arrived on time in May, with airports in cities in the West and South showing the best records, the Transportation Department said Thursday.

LEAD: Britain is engaged in a bitter debate over oil-rig safety after the explosion of a North Sea rig in which officials say 166 workers died.

LEAD: The defense in the Howard Beach racial-attack trial sought to show yesterday that the prosecution had improperly coached a victim so that he would later identify a defendant as one of his assailants.


Coping: With Hobby Collections
LEAD: Hobbyists take holidays too, in the summer's heat and haze.
There are fewer hobby shows and fewer opportunities to buy, sell and trade.
So this is a good time to put a collection in order.
You will get more enjoyment from your hobby when activity resumes in the autumn, and if your collection ends up in someone else's hands, he or she will thank you.

LEAD: More than 100 people were killed today when a train derailed while crossing a bridge in southern India, plunging the engine and nine cars packed with passengers into a lake.

LEAD: Today is the 50th anniversary of the death of Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court, a remarkable figure who still has much to say to us about the way judges should decide cases.

Bergen Brunswig
LEAD: The founders of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation said they had revised a recapitalization plan to liquidate their holdings and temporarily ward off a potential takeover.
Still to be worked out is the premium the company will pay for the founder's controlling stake and the restrictions on reselling new shares to be issued as part of the recapitalization.


Durham Corp. Tie
LEAD: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a Hong Kong affiliate of New Zealand's largest investment concern, has purchased a 12.7 percent stake in the Durham Corporation, an insurance and broadcasting company in Raleigh, N.C.
It will seek permission from regulators to raise its stake as high as 50 percent.


Review/Pop; Leonard Cohen Reflects Darkly On the World
LEAD: Leonard Cohen occupies a special niche in the roster of composer-performers who achieved prominence in the late 1960's.
The singer, poet and guitarist, who played at the Ritz on Tuesday and moved to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, writes authentically poetic songs whose quasi-Biblical lyrics transform personal experience into the language of sacred myth.


Florida Steel
LEAD: The Florida Steel Corporation said that its senior management was considering a leveraged buyout that would involve cash and securities valued in the ''mid-to-high 40's'' a share.
The company's shares jumped $3.625 today, to $47, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company has about 6,100,000 shares outstanding.

LEAD: A police officer was hit by a car and seriously injured and a passing motorist was inadvertently shot by another officer on Route 22 in Mountainside, N.J. yesterday in a bizarre chain of events that was set off by the report of a stolen car and that included a chase of several other cars stolen in separate incidents, the authorities said.

LEAD: Amid reports of medical waste washing ashore for a third day, 15 more miles of ocean beaches in New York City and on Long Island were closed to swimming yesterday, and it appeared likely that they would remain closed for part of the weekend.

LEAD: Dr.
John D. Clark, a chemist who specialized in storable liquid rocket fuels, died Wednesday at St.
Clare's Hospital in Denville, N.J., after a long illness.
He was 80 years old and lived in Newfoundland, N.J.


Iranian Plays Down Revenge
LEAD: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that his nation would ''not push for any revenge'' against the United States for shooting down a civilian jet carrying 290 people last Sunday.


Bus Depot Tightens Security
LEAD: In an effort to increase security at the Port Authority bus terminal in Manhattan, only passengers with tickets are now allowed in the building between 1 A.M. and 6 A.M., a spokeswoman said yesterday.
The move, which has been coming since the authority began closing off sections of the building during late-night hours two years ago, will leave many homeless people without a place to sleep.

LEAD: A week after Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci ordered a freeze imposed on nine contracts under investigation in the Federal inquiry into Pentagon procurement fraud, Navy officials have not yet figured out how to carry out the order.

LEAD:  Boxing  Curry Wins Title: Donald Curry captured the World Boxing Council junior-middleweight title yesterday when a bleeding and battered Gianfranco Rosi failed to answer the bell for the 10th round in San Remo, Italy.

Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, learned arithmetic in its airy, high-ceiled classrooms.
David Halberstam, the writer, played football on the dewy green grass behind the building.

Bridge
LEAD: Humor is not usually an element in card play, but there is an occasional opportunity for a sly technical joke.

Mexico Shatters a Monolith
LEAD: A race far closer than even the opposition expected has left real doubt over who the next Mexican president will be.

Treasury Prices Tumble on Jobless Report
LEAD: A report of a steep decline in the nation's unemployment rate in June sent prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbling and yields soaring yesterday.
The discount rates on Treasury bills also soared as this latest sign of economic growth heightened fears that the Federal Reserve would tighten credit to prevent a resurgence of inflation.

Bonn Tax Bill Passed
LEAD: The West German Government's tax revision legislation was finally passed today after 18 months of often bitter debate.
From 1990, taxes will be cut by 37.2 billion marks (about $20 billion) a year.
But Bonn will gain 18.1 billion marks (about $10 billion) by cutting tax concessions and imposing a withholding tax on investment earnings.

On Thursday evening at the New York State Theater, the company offered the first performance in this season's run.

GUIDEPOST: The Long View
LEAD: Binoculars come out in summer, for nature watching, sporting events and outdoor festivals.
When shopping for a pair - through a catalogue or at a specialty store - consider not just the magnification power, but also the angle of view and the size of the front and rear glass elements.
The wider the angle, the easier it is to track moving subjects.

Where Two Worlds Meet in China
LEAD: SOMETIMES, as dawn's first purple splotches ooze through the folds of mist that swaddle the steep hills here, the rattle of firecrackers echoes from a not too distant treeless slope as a group of Miao people bury one of their dead.
Though burials are officially banned in China in favor of cremation, the coffin-maker on the main street was busy the day before, planing and sanding long white planks in a trade that has all but disappeared from this country.

Burmese Curfew Is Lifted
LEAD: The authorities today lifted a dusk-to-dawn curfew imposed in Rangoon after thousands of students rioted in the streets June 21, the state radio said.

According to the Government, six policemen and three civilians were killed in the rioting.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  HEARTS OF LIONS: The History of American Bicycle Racing.
By Peter Nye. (Norton, $19.95.) Peter Nye has written a sumptuously detailed account of American bicycle racing, emphasizing the early years when cycling was a big-money sport.
Drawing principally on newspaper accounts, Mr.
Nye chronicles the amazing feats of competitors such as Charles (Mile-a-Minute) Murphy, who in 1899 covered a mile in 57.8 seconds riding through the slipstream of a Long Island Rail Road locomotive.

Recycle water for ornamentals, container gardens, window boxes and seedlings.
Finish pruning overgrown hedges.

Jittery Times for Pilots and Air Controllers in Gulf
LEAD: ''Sure, I'm nervous about flying through the gulf, and I have been for a long time,'' said Capt.
Harold Ewing, a commercial pilot who regularly flies Boeing 747 airliners into Dubai. ''Everybody is.'' Commercial airline pilots and air traffic controllers in the southern Persian Gulf are among the most eager to hear the conclusions of investigators looking into the downing Sunday of an Iranian airliner by a United States warship.

Fisk have a nice summer.'' The lazy, hazy summer hasn't started yet, but my sophomores are busy taking exams, and I'm running back and forth to the bookroom returning American lit texts and counting ripped covers.
It's that wonderful quiet time between the end of the school year and the beginning of vacation and it's a time of taking inventory both literally and figuratively.

Practical Traveler; Dear Tourist Bureau: Can You Help Plan a Trip?
LEAD: IF you want free maps and information from a state travel bureau in the busy season, do not wait until the last week before vacation to ask.
To find out how long it took for a response to such a request, identical letters were sent to 50 state travel organizations and the District of Columbia asking for a map, a schedule of events and sources of further information.

The Battle of the Books
LEAD: As a junior at Yale, majoring in literature, I found James Atlas's article interesting.
The movement to widen the academic canon is not just an effort by junior faculty ''to define themselves and to validate their own identities.'' It is also an attempt by students to establish a curriculum which reflects the variety of cultures in the nation and world we live in.

But in the summer I sometimes like to serve salad and a fish or meat dish together.

LEAD: A power failure in the East River tunnel leading to Pennsylvania Station brought Long Island Rail Road service to a halt for over an hour yesterday and delayed service for several hours in the late afternoon.

In the U.S.S.R., Just Getting Food to the Table Is a Struggle
LEAD: THE state meat store on Malaya Kolkhoznaya Ploshchad offered a typical selection the other day - baloney, salami and baloney.
In the fish store a few doors down a sales clerk was pounding a block of frozen ocean perch with a sledgehammer to break off pieces for a long line of impatient customers.
At the fresh produce shop next door, beets, cabbage and a mound of soggy squash were the vegetables of the day.

The Light and Dark Tones Add Drama
LEAD: JUST what is it that puts zip into our photographs?
To some minds, the magic ingredient is contrast.
What's meant here by ''contrast'' is the amount of separation between bright tones and dark tones in a picture, although there are plenty of other contrasts to be found in most images.

Search Continues for Victims of Roof Collapse
LEAD: Rescue workers loading debris into a scoop yesterday as they continued to dig through the rubble of the store that collapsed Thursday in Brownsville, Tex.
The volunteers have reached the first floor of the three-story building.
One body was removed yesterday and is thought to be the last victim.
At least 14 people were killed and 47 injured in the disaster.

A Film Adaptation Of Waugh Tests the Limits Of Moving Books To the Screen
LEAD: Evelyn Waugh's novel ''A Handful of Dust'' is the work of a man who had been deeply wounded by the failure of his first marriage: lurking at the heart of it are a cry of pain and an act of revenge.
It is true that by the time Waugh's feelings reached the printed page, they had been transmuted into comedy - he was far too much of an artist to serve them up raw.

One Hurt in Amtrak Accident
LEAD: One car of an Amtrak train derailed near here early today, injuring a passenger and delaying the Miami-to-New York run by about four hours, a spokesman for the railroad said.
The accident occurred when an axle broke, the official said.
The passenger's injuries were not believed to be serious, the spokesman said.
