LEAD: The University of South Carolina basketball coach, George Felton, has gone out of the country to recruit basketball players for the first time, announcing the signing of Brad Ignajatovic, a 6-foot-10-inch center and Bojan Popovic, a 6-2 guard.

John Cage's First Opera, Written by the Numbers
LEAD: What do the following operas have in common: ''Carmen,'' ''Tristan und Isolde,'' ''Marriage of Figaro,'' ''Dido and Aeneas,'' ''Norma,'' ''Mignon,'' ''The Magic Flute,'' ''Parsifal,'' ''La Gioconda,'' ''Cenerentola'' and ''Die Walkure''?
All of them - or, rather, parts of them - appear in some form as parts of yet another opera, John Cage's first, titled ''Europera,'' which will have its American premiere Thursday (with repeats on Saturday and next Sunday) at the PepsiCo Summerfare in Purchase, N.Y.

LEAD: IT IS 10 A.M.
ON A MONDAY, and the Surgeon General is already at war.
C.
Everett Koop is addressing a room choked with reporters at the Department of Health and Human Services.
As he stands with Amish severity in his Navy uniform, jabbing his pointer at poster-sized graphs and charts, Koop looks less like a spokesman for national health than a commodore outlining his battle plans.

GENERATIONS OF TORMENT
LEAD: ''In no way, can or will the Provisional Irish Republican Army ever be defeated militarily.'' - Sir James M. Glover, former general officer commanding, British Army, Northern Ireland, Feb. 21, 1988.


Glancing Back to '42 On Gentle Guadalcanal
LEAD: THE name Guadalcanal generates feelings that still stir the American soul.
Here, in 1942, United States marines were very nearly abandoned on a toehold of beach and jungle.
Then, after six months of grisly fighting, they brought the Japanese onslaught to deadly and permanent halt.
The story of that fighting, at places with names engraved in the American memory - Red Beach and the Tenaru River, Matanikau, Lunga Point and Bloody Ridge overlooking Henderson Field - was written by a correspondent who slogged the ridge and jungle with men of the First Marine Division.

Significant steps are being taken to make this development a reality.

NEW YORKERS, Etc.
LEAD: NED SCHNURMAN knows what he should do when he returns to New York after a vacation.
He should, as he put it, ''go home, unpack, go into the office the next day with presents for everybody and be a nice guy.'' He does none of those things.
He times his return so that he can go directly to the office, luggage and all.

Headliners; Answering Prayers
LEAD: When Sister Rose Philippine Duchesne worked among the Potawatomi Indians of Kansas in the 1840's, she was called ''Quah-kah-ka-num-ad,'' the woman who always prays.
Last week she officially became a woman to be prayed to - Pope John Paul II canonized her as the fourth American to attain sainthood.

LEAD: WHAT would Michael H. Mescon, dean of Georgia State College of Business Administration, do to keep Donald Ratajczak at the school? ''His windows, his laundry, anything,'' Mr.
Mescon said.
Over the past decade, Mr.
Ratajczak, an economist, has propelled himself and Georgia State to national prominence by becoming the best forecaster of the Consumer Price Index, the most closely watched barometer of inflation.


Paris in a Bottle
LEAD: A MARVELOUS THING ABOUT THE great explorers, Columbus and all that lot, was not the distances they traveled or even the remarkable places they found - but the fact that they did it all without guidebooks.


Quality Quandary
LEAD: To the Editor:


TASTING THE WATERS
LEAD: COOKING OUT OVER WEST LAKE from the Louwailou Restaurant across a shimmer of water embraced by tea-green hills, I bit into my first freshwater shrimp bathed in Dragon Well tea and knew why Hangzhou has been for the last six centuries China's No.1 pleasure spot.


Good Buildings That Make Respectful Neighbors
LEAD: ''The street is a room by agreement,'' the great architect Louis Kahn said many years ago.
In his characteristically poetic manner, Kahn was stating perhaps the most important truth about the design of cities: that there is a kind of social contract involved in the making of a well-designed city, a tacit understanding that buildings be placed so as to make a coherent whole.


Rutgers and Legislators Split on Development
LEAD: A PROPOSAL by Rutgers University to lease 80 acres on the edge of an ecological preserve for housing development has inspired passage of a bill by the Legislature that could redefine the relationship between the university and state government.


The Battle of the Books
LEAD: As a longstanding adversary critic of the literary establishment, I would like to offer some observations on James Atlas's article, ''On Campus: The Battle of the Books'' (June 5).


Region's Flood of Federal Taxes Trickle Back
LEAD: New Yorkers paid $14.5 billion more in taxes to the Federal Government last year than they got back in aid and programs from Washington, according to a report issued this week by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.


COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Trimming Office Space; Corporations Find Cutting Back Takes Time and Money
LEAD: A COMPANY can trim its staff overnight, but the task of trimming office space is rarely as fast or simple.
Like a jigsaw puzzle with missing pieces, a company that dismisses employees and perhaps eliminates a weak department rarely fits back together easily in a new compact form.


Reviews/Music; Pop With Le Jazz Hot, By Giordano and Vignola
LEAD: The simultaneous booking of Vince Giordano's 10-piece band, the Nighthawks, and Frank Vignola's string quartet, the Hot Club of France, for a four-week engagement at Michael's Pub that began on Tuesday, suggests that the restaurant at 211 East 55th Street is offering a double bill.
In a sense it is, but the quartet has been enfolded within the big band to form a large ensemble in which the groups sometimes play separately and at times are combined.

Pace of Building Abandonment Tumbles
LEAD: HOUSING abandonment, once the scourge of New York City neighborhoods, has declined sharply over the last few years.
Even so, city officials are preparing to assume ownership of a few thousand more parcels of real estate on which owners have fallen behind in their property taxes.

LEAD: Vice President Bush rules out paying reparations to Iran's Government but says the Reagan Administration is considering compensating families of the 290 people killed when the Navy shot down an Iranian jetliner.
Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis said ''some form of humanitarian assistance would probably be appropriate.


Correction
LEAD: A chart last week about water consumption gave incorrect figures for fresh-water use in the United States.
Daily residential use was 25.4 billion gallons in 1980 and 28.4 billion gallons in 1985.
Daily industrial and commercial use was 51 billion gallons in 1980 and 37.9 billion gallons in 1985.


Poland: From Independence to Communism
LEAD: George Bernard Shaw once claimed that there were three tragic nations: the Jews, the Irish and the Poles.
Of these it is the Poles whose history, passions and culture are least known by other nations.
For a thousand years they have straddled a civilizational fault line where the influence of Rome gives way to Byzantium.

Loan vs. Loan

Present at Stereo's Birth
LEAD: This year is replete with audio anniversaries.
The centennial of the phonograph record, as distinct from Edison's cylinder, was celebrated in May.
This fall will see the fifth birthday of digital disks, and right about now - as far as anyone can fix the date - is the 30th birthday of stereo.

We face new threats from terrorism and other forms of unconventional warfare.

'The Sound is Under Seige'
LEAD: TERRY BACKER, 34 years old, of Norwalk, the new appointed Soundkeeper, is charged with protecting the marine resources of Long Island Sound.
He is also president of the 300-member Connecticut Coastal Fishermen's Association, which set up the Long Island Soundkeeper Fund after receiving a $176,000 settlement in its lawsuit against the City of Norwalk for dumping sewage into Norwalk Harbor.

A Secret Collection Goes Public
LEAD: One of the finest art Deco collections formed in recent years has just come on the market.
The holdings of Michael Chow, the restaurateur, have been bought by Anthony DeLorenzo, a New York dealer who specializes in 20th-century decorative arts.
The sale puts on public view one of the most important collections of Art Deco ever assembled, and one that was put together in almost utter secrecy.


THE REGION: Airport Gridlock; 'Plane City' Grows, With No End in Sight And No Room to Move
LEAD: ''LOTS of times,'' said the veteran airline pilot, ''you push back from the gate at LaGuardia, you look out that cockpit window, and it's full - tails and wings all over.
You don't go anywhere for 20 or 30 minutes because there's nowhere to move.
It's Plane City.
So you haven't started your engines yet, and already you're a half hour late.

The Battle of the Books
LEAD: James Atlas's article stresses canon revision as reapportionment - expansion of the tradition to include writers hitherto ignored or devalued.
But equally important is the reformulation of the canon from inside.
For example, feminist critics and new historicists agree that Shakespeare's work cannot be treated as esthetically autonomous or historically transcendent.

Refuting Usual Seafood Cliches
LEAD: CLOSE your eyes.
Think Clam Diggers Restaurant.
What do you see: a rustic fish house, shore dinners, steamers, paper plates?
Now, open your eyes and look at Shelter Island's Clam Diggers Restaurant: a bright yellow Victorian house with hanging baskets of fuchsias and outdoor dining porches.
Inside, it is white lace curtains, tablecloths, cut flowers, candlelight, floral paintings, antiques, towering vases of flowering branches and strains of progressive jazz in the background.


FICTION
LEAD:  PEOPLE LIKE US.
By Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Plunging into this densely populated roman a clef by the author of ''The Two Mrs.
Grenvilles'' is like coming late to a cocktail party where the socially prominent guests are already in full cry.
Although the faces are familiar, there are too many to sort out; at first it's hard to catch the tune, but give it time.

The young Soviet musician won first prize in the Paganini Competition three years ago at the age of 16.

LEAD: The main question to ask about the Georges Braque exhibition at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is not whether it is good or bad but whether it should be taking place at all.

LEAD: I'm sure my colleagues at Duke University are more sensible than Mr.

Difficulties in Choosing Diskettes
LEAD: WHICH brand of floppy diskettes do you buy?
The question is not a trivial one, especially for those companies that buy thousands of diskettes a year.
Prices for standard double-density floppy diskettes range from $1 to $5 for a 3.5-inch diskette and 30 cents to $1.50 for a 5.25-inch model.
The price range on other types of diskettes is even wider.

Correction
LEAD: An article on June 26 about plans to build a new theater in Stamford incorrectly described the status of a closed theater on the property.
The theater, at 307 Atlantic Street, has been partly torn down.

SIBERIA TAUGHT HIM A FEW THINGS: AN 'ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE' RETURNS
LEAD: In June 1956, the most senior representatives of the Yugoslav and Soviet Governments -Tito and Khrushchev, accompanied by their chiefs of staff - sit in one of the parlor cars of the special train that shuttles between Moscow and Kiev.
There is no need for an interpreter.
Since their schedule is overburdened (the meeting's purpose is to smooth out the numerous ideological differences that had accumulated during the Yugoslav ''schism''), little time remains for ancillary matters.

Becken is back at the plant in a business of his own.

Along the Vecht River By Auto or Bike or Foot
LEAD: LESS than an hour's drive south of Amsterdam is a region that seems a microcosm of the Dutch countryside.
Enfolding the River Vecht in its north-south course between Vreeland and Maarssen, the region consists of centuries-old villages, expanses of flat and watery pasture land punctuated by windmills, castles and dozens of mansions built by Amsterdam merchants as weekend retreats during the 17th and 18th centuries.

LEAD: The Army and Air Force have ordered commanding officers to tell soldiers or airmen who tests indicate are carriers of the AIDS virus that they face discharge or prosecution unless they inform all sex partners of their condition and use condoms.

The Battle of the Books

THE SILVER LINING IN DISASTER
LEAD: Demographers tell us that human fecundity increases in time of war and other catastrophe.
A sort of population thermostat apparently kicks in, as if nature were programmed to counteract the death count.
Some cultural historians have suggested in a similarly mystical vein that artistic creativity tends to decline in relatively calm periods, but to flourish when society is convulsed.

LEAD: A gun club must pay a woman $100 in damages for denying her membership application in 1980 and admit her, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled Tuesday.

Mom Says Goodbye to Nursery School
LEAD: The other evening my son and a dozen or so classmates pped up to his teacher and received an official-looking diploma, complete with ribbon.
It was the annual picnic of the cooperative nursery school where Sam had spent two years of his young life and from which he was now graduating.
My husband and I, bleary-eyed and reeling from the round of wholesome family activities that mark the end of every school year, looked on, slightly stunned, feeling as if we were watching a movie.

THE FRENCH REVOLUTION: RIGHT OR WRONG?
LEAD: History has never been easy for the French.
It has, for them, probably more than for any other European people, produced a mix of exultation and anguish.
Ninety-nine years ago, the French celebrated the 100th anniversary of the beginning of their great Revolution of 1789, and, by a rather extraordinary coincidence, they did so only a couple of years after inaugurating for the first time a permanently republican form of government, finishing a century-long alternation between monarchy and anarchy.

International Report; Duty on Japan Printers
LEAD: The European Community announced on Friday a provisional dumping duty on Japanese daisy-wheel computer printers.
The action follows the decision in late May to place a similar duty on the makers of dot matrix computer printers.
The commission said a duty of 43.2 percent would be imposed on the daisy-wheel printers made by all companies except the Tokyo Electric Company and the Tokyo Juki Industrial Company, whose printers will be taxed at a lower rate of 12.4 percent.

LEAD: In a fiscal sleight of hand, the Federal Government has begun delaying payment of Medicare bills by 10 days as a means of stretching out payments and cutting $815 million from this year's budget deficit.

LEAD: Ten weeks after the nation's corn crop was sown, heat and drought are disrupting the plants at the crucial, delicate stage when they develop flowers, achieve pollination and form kernels.

LEAD: In six weeks, the staff at the Basic Trust Infant-Toddler Center will pack up the highchairs, the blocks, the goldfish, the cribs and the cots and move out of Public School 166 in Manhattan to new quarters five blocks away.

Sports People; 8-1 Favorites
LEAD: The British bookies have made Sandy Lyle of Scotland and Seve Ballesteros of Spain betting favorites for the British Open, which starts Thursday at Royal Lytham-St.
Annes in Lytham, England.
Lyle and Ballesteros were made 8-1 choices, and American golfers were put down as longshots. ''Maybe they know something I don't,'' said Lyle, winner of the Masters earlier this year and the leading money-winner on the PGA Tour.

LEAD: A member of a peace group was arrested for the second time in three days today when trucks laden with food and medical supplies bound for Nicaragua tried to cross a bridge into Mexico, the officials said.

LEAD: Interest rates at the weekly auction of Treasury bills rose modestly yesterday, and now stand at the highest level since the middle of last October,when rising interest rates were one factor blamed for the sharp drop in stock prices.

LEAD: The method of electing Texas district judges was challenged today in a Federal lawsuit that charges that the at-large system makes it more difficult for Mexican-Americans and blacks to be elected.

Heinz Crop Losses
LEAD: The H.J.
Heinz Company said it expected to lose much of its Midwestern tomato and cucumber crops to the drought, despite recent scattered showers in growing regions.
The food processor said it expected to harvest about 60 percent of its cucumber crop and 75 percent of its tomatoes in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana.

The 53-year-old Soviet grandmaster, a former world championship candidate, topped an almost-all-grandmaster field with an 8-3 score.

Review/Dance; Explosions Of Sounds And Steps
LEAD: Choreographers like to work with Harry de Wit.
And it is easy to see why.
The Dutch composer's music certainly doesn't take a back seat to the dancing, providing an easily complementary aural backdrop.
Instead, he collaborates with an aggressiveness and sense of invention that lend extra energy to the dance.


Coffee Curbs Predicted
LEAD: London coffee dealers predicted today that the International Coffee Organization would soon cut coffee producers' export quotas because of low prices, removing 1.5 million 60-kilo bags of coffee from the total of 54.5 million bags that members may now export.
But forecasts of cold weather in Brazil, lifting prices today, may postpone the quota cut.

Pullman Holdings Increases Offer
LEAD: The Pullman Company said that Pullman Holdings Inc. had increased the amount it would pay for all of the Pullman Company's stock to $7.75 a share in cash and debt securities, from $7.50 a share.
Under the agreement, Pullman Holdings would pay $232.5 million in cash for 30 million common shares.


Northwest Cuts Fares
LEAD: Northwest Airlines, a subsidiary of NWA Inc., today cut its lowest discount fares in more than 500 markets, with reductions ranging from $6 to $150 for round-trip tickets.
Northwest also said adult passengers who begin their trips in Louisville, Ky.; Buffalo, and the Wisconsin cities of Green Bay and Madison would be eligible for children's excursion fares on tickets bought in July for travel during off-peak periods.

Microscope Innovation
LEAD: The ability of a microscope to reveal fine detail in a sample illuminated by ordinary light is ultimately limited by the wavelength of the light itself.
If an object is smaller than a single wave of the light striking it, no lens, however powerful, can form an image of the object.

LEAD: * Alan Neadle was promoted to executive vice president at Princeton Partners.


Love-Bead Alert: The Hippie Look Flowers Again
LEAD: Jeans have holes again.
Love beads are back.
Short and tight is in.
Tie-dyed shirts and hosiery are selling.
It is not quite the dawning of a new age of Aquarius, but hippie fashions are making a comeback in the twilight of the 1980's.
For example, at Bentley's, a dance club for fashion victims with a sense of humor, they are bringing back everything but free love.

Donal M. Billig, were aired in court today at a hearing to determine when and how an investigation of the allegations will proceed.


5 Are Dead and 1 Is Missing As Texas Rivers Rise Quickly
LEAD: Five people were drowned, one person was missing and others were stranded as heavy rain sent creeks and rivers raging out of their banks in western and central Texas, the authorities said today.


Steel Production Rises
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.841 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.834 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 86.3 percent of capacity in the week, compared with 86 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: As relatives of some of the victims charged that safety warnings had been ignored, the British Government today began an investigation of the North Sea oil-rig explosion that left 166 workers dead.


King Athelstan's Justice
LEAD: About 10 centuries ago, the Anglo-Saxon King Athelstan -an advanced law-giver for his time - sent word to an archbishop that ''it seemed too cruel to him that a man should be killed so young  [ at age 12 ] , or for so small an offence. . . .
He said then that it seemed to him and to those with whom he had discussed it, that no man younger than fifteen should be killed unless he tried to defend himself or fled.


Mets to Sign McClure
LEAD: The Mets will sign the left-hander Bob McClure today to replace the right-hander Rick Aguilera, who will undergo surgery tomorrow and be placed on the disabled list, Jay Horwitz, the Mets' spokesman, said last night.

Supernova Is Linked To Creation Of Fluorine
LEAD: APPLYING complex equations to data from the last major stellar explosion observed from Earth, two West Coast physicists have devised the first plausible theory to explain the origin of the element fluorine.

LEAD: The Imperial Sugar Company of Sugar Land, Tex., which acquired the Holly Sugar Corporation of Colorado Springs, has changed its name to the Imperial Holly Corporation but will continue to market the brands separately.


Discount Retailer To Close 35 Stores
LEAD: Heck's Inc., the financially troubled retailer, said it would close 35 of its 120 discount department stores as part of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization plan.
The affected stores are in West Virginia, Virginia, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Ohio and Pennsylvania, the company said.
About 700 to 1,000 jobs will be eliminated.

LEAD: Three children left alone in their Harlem apartment were killed yesterday in a fire after a candle apparently set fire to a living-room sofa, a Fire Department spokesman said.

LEAD: As showers that began Saturday continued to fall on parts of the parched Midwest and South, the chairmen of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees told President Reagan today that there was widespread support in both parties for legislation that would provide billions of dollars in relief to farmers whose crops have been damaged.

LEAD: CPC International Inc., the large corn refining and food company, said today that its second-quarter net income rose 45 percent and it predicted that its earnings per share for the year would rise at least 30 percent.

The attackers escaped in a waiting speedboat.

931 Name Changes in '88
LEAD: A record number of American corporations changed their names during the first six months of 1988, with financial institutions and manufacturing companies heading the list, according to a survey.
Of the 931 name changes, 53 percent were because of mergers and acquisitions, the survey, by Anspach Grossman Portugal Inc., found.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on July 2 about the Defense Secretary's suspension of payments to military contractors, and a related article in Business Day, misstated an aspect of the action.
The Bell Atlantic Corporation was not among the Pentagon contractors working on programs affected by the move.
Further developments in the case are reported today on page A1.

Timing Is Everything
LEAD: So you want to hold a news conference, and you want a big turnout.
What should you do?
Well, assuming that timing is everything, schedule it for a Wednesday.
That's what most people do.
And make it at 10 A.M.
By that time, the reasoning goes, most reporters are awake, but not yet hankering for lunch.

U.S. Oil Rigs Increase
LEAD: The number of rotary rigs working in the United States rose by 5 rigs, to 926, for the week ended last Friday, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
A year earlier, there were 891 working rigs, the company said.
The count of rigs working offshore rose by 2, to 130, while the number of rigs working in shallow inland waters was unchanged at 28, Baker Hughes said.


Transplant Patient Dies
LEAD: Clinton House, who survived 14 months with a donated heart and lungs he received after donating his own healthy heart in the nation's first domino donor transplant, died today, Johns Hopkins Hospital said.


Carpenter Sues Leona Helmsley Over a Job
LEAD: Lawyers for a carpenter who built elaborate television cabinets for Leona and Harry Helmsley's Greenwich, Conn., estate in 1985 filed a $250,000 civil lawsuit against Mrs.
Helmsley in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, charging breach of contract.

Ex-Im Bank in Aid to Brazil
LEAD: The Export-Import Bank said today that it would resume lending money to Brazil to finance American exports.
The move underlined Brazil's improving ties with its foreign creditors.


Postal Service Loses Appeal on Perot
LEAD: An appeals board of the General Services Administration yesterday denied the United States Postal Service's request for reinstatement of its contract with the Texas entrepreneur H. Ross Perot.


A Fair and Practical Plant-Closings Bill
LEAD: The House is scheduled to vote this week on the controversial plant-closings bill, which would require businesses to give 60 days' notice when planning large layoffs or a complete shutdown.
The Senate passed it by a surprisingly large 72-to-23 margin, but the bill needs veto-proof House approval, too.


Sports People; Dugout Discontent
LEAD: The Chicago Cubs' shortstop, Shawon Dunston, reportedly challenged Manager Don Zimmer to a fight in the dugout Sunday during a game with the San Diego Padres in San Diego.
Zimmer chastised Dunston for missing three hit-and-run signs in the fifth inning of the game, which the Cubs won, 4-2.
When the shortstop challenged Zimmer to fight, Andre Dawson stepped in and pulled the two apart, The Chicago Sun-Times reported yesterday.

LEAD: The decisions by delegates to next week's Democratic National Convention will be forwarded to the chair and the American public by an electronic voting system that is said to be the fastest and most sophisticated ever used at a Presidential nomination convention.

LEAD: FAT calories appear to count more to the human body than do calories from carbohydrates, according to careful analysis of the diets and body fat content of 155 sedentary obese men.

Now, at 9 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, we are given an opportunity to see how television might have covered the ratification of the Constitution 200 years ago.

LEAD: Should New York stiffen its penalties for hate crimes?
Should there be a permanent special state prosecutor for such crimes?

LEAD: A helicopter plucked three inmates from a state prison yard amid of gunfire today.
The helicopter was later ambushed by state police and forced down here after an aerial chase, state officials said.


Solar Energy Will Prove Itself Cheaper
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bush Vows to Help Farmers Expand Market for Exports
LEAD: Vice President Bush vowed today to make the expansion of domestic and foreign markets for farm products his top agriculture priority if he is elected President.


Abraham S. Jacobson; Doctor and Editor, 75
LEAD: Abraham S. Jacobson, editor in chief of Medical Tribune and a professor of clinical medicine and pathology at Cornell Medical School, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at New York Hospital, where he was an attending physician.
He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.


William R. Hamcke, Banker, 63
LEAD: William R. Hamcke, former senior executive vice president and chief financial officer of Irving Trust Company, died of a heart attack Saturday at Stamford Hospital.
He was 63 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Potter Advances: Third-seeded Barbara Potter of Woodbury, Conn., defeated unseeded Betsy Nagelsen of Kapalua Bay, Hawaii, 7-6, 7-5, yesterday in the first round of the $200,000 Virginia Slims of Newport tournament in Rhode Island.
Three other seeded players advanced to the second round.

LEAD:  New Rules for Banks  The United States and 11 other nations will require banks to keep more capital on hand, forcing some to raise billions of dollars.

Gorbachev in Poland  Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in Warsaw, urged a meeting of European leaders to seek a breakthrough on cutting conventional arms.


Sports People; Nilan Signs
LEAD: The Rangers have re-signed the right wing Chris Nilan.
Nilan, 30, was acquired from the Montreal Canadiens in January in exchange for draft considerations.
He had 7 goals and 5 assists in 50 games with the Canadiens.
After joining the Rangers, he had 3 goals and 5 assists in 22 games.
Terms of the new contract were not disclosed.(


Food Vendors Unite in Protest Over Koch Order
LEAD: Vendors carrying their umbrellas as they marched at Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street.
They were protesting an order to enforce a law that limits the time and the location they may operate.
Page B1. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


Apollo Is Optimistic Despite Loss Forecast
LEAD: Apollo Computer Inc. said today that it had slightly exceeded its forecast for its unit volume shipments in the second quarter, even though the computer work station maker will report a loss for the period.


S.E.C. Bid For Change
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission sent to Congress today the final and most controversial portion of its legislative recommendations for changes in the financial markets.


The Big Eight: Still a Male Bastion
LEAD: A young woman who is a certified public accountant was asked recently to comment on the advancement of women to the top of that profession.
Peering out from her work area into the partners' glass-walled offices, she saw nothing but a sea of male faces.


Summations in Howard Beach Case Attack Trial Strategies
LEAD: Defense lawyers at the second Howard Beach racial-attack trial, summing up their cases, argued yesterday that their clients were the innocent targets of a prosecution case built on the willfully distorted testimony of key witnesses.


Control Data Subsidiary Plan
LEAD: The Control Data Corporation has told its employees that it plans to make its computer disk drive group a wholly owned subsidiary.


Advanced Micro Net Soars
LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said its net income for the second quarter rose sharply from a year earlier.
Earnings in the quarter totaled $23.5 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share.
Revenue rose 22.8 percent, to $308.1 million, from $250.8 million.


An Ode to the Danube
LEAD: Among the projects of the last, extraordinarily fertile decade of Leos Janacek's life was an attempted symphony on the subject of the Danube River.
He set it aside without ever considering the work finished, but after his death in 1928 it was found that the sketches represented self-contained, continuous music.

LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-13  The United States will compensate the families of the 290 people killed when an Iranian airliner was shot down by a Navy warship, the White House announced.
The amount has not been decided.

What's In a Name? Often Confusion
LEAD: PICTURE the scene: A team of doctors has just identified a strange and apparently new form of arthritis that showed up in Lyme, Conn., and they want to name it appropriately.
They decide to call it ''Lyme arthritis,'' and thereby unwittingly manage to insure a certain measure of confusion about that disease for years.

LEAD: Watching ''The Struggles for Poland,'' the absorbing new public broadcasting series on that unlucky nation's efforts to find independence, you may wonder how anybody ever came up with the notion of a Polish joke.

LEAD: Steve Bauer of Canada retained his slim lead in the overall standings of the Tour de France today as Jerome Simon of France won the ninth stage.

LEAD: Word has it that Dennis Ross, who handles Middle Eastern affairs at the National Security Council, is going to the Bush campaign as a top foreign policy adviser.


Dollar Rises Despite Moves By European Central Banks
LEAD: The dollar continued to climb against several major currencies yesterday despite concerted intervention by central banks.


Passenger Traffic Down at Eastern
LEAD: Eastern Airlines Inc. has reported a 15.7 percent decline in passenger traffic in June and said it reflected its continued ''downsizing.'' Revenue passenger miles, the number of miles flown by paying passengers, fell 18.6 percent for the first six months of 1988, compared with the first half of 1987.

LEAD: The CNW Corporation, a major railroad company whose chief executive, James R. Wolfe, is ailing, announced yesterday that it had named Robert W. Schmiege president and chief operating officer in a move to ease the burden on Mr.
Wolfe.


Business and Health; A Company Tests H.M.O. Approach
LEAD: A YEAR after becoming one of the first major companies to try a health plan that makes a network of health maintenance organizations the primary provider of medical care, the Southwestern Bell Corporation has significantly reduced the growth of its medical costs.
It has also changed the way many employees receive care, which pleases some workers and disturbs others.

LEAD: Citibank, the nation's largest bank, will triple, to $3,000, the average minimum monthly balance it requires for customers to avoid fees for checking accounts and the use of automatic teller machines.

Boeing Test on Plane Feature Is Focus of Accident Hearing
LEAD: Two months before a Boeing 737 jetliner was ripped open on a flight in Hawaii in April, the manufacturer told the Government that special tests had verified the effectiveness of a design feature to prevent explosive decompression.
Other experts had warned that this design might be inadequate.

Harry is still the sort of guy who believes that if you spare the rod you spoil the psychopath.
When in doubt, shoot.


Sports People; Houston Investigated
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has formally notified officials at the University of Houston by letter of its investigation into allegations of recruiting violations and charges that coaches frequently gave cash to football players.
The school has until Oct. 17 to respond to the letter.


Despite Serious Wrist Injury, Vanbiesbrouck Stays Upbeat
LEAD: Every day the baby can do something new.
It isn't always dramatic, often amounting simply to an added subtlety in a smile or a firmness in a grip.
For John Vanbiesbrouck, whose first child was born on June 18, these have been days of wonder for him and his wife, Rosalinde.
They have also brought wonderfully useful lessons for him.

LEAD: The most twisted, hair-raising and scream-inducing landmark in New York City was created yesterday when the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island was given official status by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

LEAD: IF the last-minute revision of earnings estimates by securities analysts is any indication, companies in basic industries like steel, aluminum, forest products, chemicals, paper and packaging may be giving investors a pleasant surprise in coming weeks.
And the same goes for New York City banks, according to Benjamin Zacks, executive vice president of Zacks Investment Research, a Chicago-based firm that tracks earnings estimates at more than 100 brokerage firms.

LEAD: In addition to being a writer for People magazine, Fred A. Bernstein is involved with an organization called The Princeton Review, which tutors students for the Scholastic Aptitude Test.
It was at that organization that he realized there was a paucity of advertising media to reach such people.


International Paper
LEAD: The International Paper Company said today that it would appeal a ruling that could cost it $25 million in back pay to workers locked out of its Mobile mill.
The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that it was illegal for the company to permanently replace 280 maintenance employees at the mill.


Two Dukakis Decisions
LEAD: In sweltering Faneuil Hall yesterday, Michael Dukakis announced what he called his first Presidential-caliber decision, his choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas to run with him.
It's a shrewd, audacious decision, likely to advance the Democrats' chances.


Big Board Seat $700,000
LEAD: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $700,000, down $100,000 from the last such sale on May 20, the exchange said.
The market for the seats is now $675,000 bid, and $825,000 offered, the exchange said.


Eating Well
LEAD: FROM time to time articles crop up in newspapers noting the recall of ceramic ware because of high levels of lead.


Research Tax Credit
LEAD: The Reagan Administration favors a permanent tax credit for research and experimentation, Dennis Ross, Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary, told a Senate finance subcommittee today.
The current 20 percent tax credit for research expires at the end of 1988.
The House Ways and Means Committee approved a two-year extension but the Senate panel is considering a permanent extension.


Crude Oil Extends Decline, But Unleaded Gasoline Rises
LEAD: Crude oil prices weakened further yesterday in volatile New York trading, but unleaded gasoline strengthened because of tight supplies and conjecture about higher United States demand.

LEAD: The Harvard Business School is expected to announce shortly that it will require entering M.B.A. students to take a three-week course on business ethics.

Sports People; No Sideline Coaching
LEAD: Bela Karolyi, who on Saturday resigned as head of the United States women's gymnastics delegation to the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, said yesterday he would not attempt to tutor his pupils from the sidelines in future Olympics the way he assisted Mary Lou Retton in 1984. ''This is an even greater problem than we had in 1984,'' said Karoly.


Asset Move Attempted, S.E.C. Says
LEAD: An investor from Taiwan accused of insider trading illegally tried to transfer several million dollars to Hong Kong last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission asserted yesterday.


Illinois Legislature Moves to Give Parents Control of the Chicago Schools
LEAD: The Illinois Legislature, responding to criticism of Chicago public schools as the nation's worst, has passed a bill to completely restructure the system and shift power for running the schools largely to parents.

LEAD: The television networks, faced with a possible shortage of fresh entertainment shows because of a writers' strike, are looking to their news divisions to help fill the programming void.

His mentor is his mother.

LEAD: Alfred Harvey Wheeler, a social studies teacher in the New York City public school system for 42 years, died yesterday at his home in Huntington, L.I., after a long illness.
He was 83 years old.


Lotus Program
LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation said it had begun shipping Agenda, a software program designed to store and retrieve free-form information such as personal notes, outlines, messages and other data.
The program was originally to be released in April.
The company, however, said it had extensively redesigned the appearance of the program based on suggestions of its test users.

House Votes Bill That Could Bring Shutdown of 20 U.S. Bases in '89
LEAD: The House of Representatives, tackling one of the most politically sensitive issues in Congress, approved legislation today to expedite the process for closing obsolete military bases.


New Procedure Clears a Vessel Totally Blocked
LEAD: Balloon angioplasty, the medical procedure in which a tiny balloon is inflated inside a blood vessel to clear a blockage, is growing in popularity among doctors as an alternative to coronary bypass surgery.
A thin tube, or catheter, is inserted into a blood vessel and the balloon inflated so that it pushes the blockage, called plaque, back against the vessel walls.


Heinz Joseph Wittig, Pediatrician, 67
LEAD: Dr.
Heinz Joseph Wittig, a pediatrician and head of the allergy division at the Ochsner Clinic, died at his home here Sunday after a long illness.
He was 67 years old.


The Silver Lining in Mexico's Election
LEAD: The problem with holding competitive elections in which the outcome is predetermined is that credibility and legitimacy suffer dearly.
That is the moral of last week's elections in Mexico, and that is one of the burdens that Mexico's next president will carry into office.


Corn Harvest Will Fall 29%, Report Says
LEAD: The Agriculture Department, in a long-awaited report, estimated today that the drought would cut the nation's corn harvest to 5.2 billion bushels, 2.1 billion less than was expected when the crop was planted.


About New York; Tasting History Through Papers That Age Well
LEAD: Come with us to a vault deep in the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 40 Wall Street.
Sit down at a table with a wise old man, Ernest Chambre.
Watch as Mr.
Chambre sifts through the fraying contents of four heavy boxes.
As he skips across the centuries, the story coalescing in front of your eyes is the story of America.

LEAD: More than a thousand New York City food vendors, chanting anti-Koch slogans, marched on City Hall yesterday to protest the Mayor's ban on food vendors in congested areas of Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

Economic Scene; Sky Isn't Falling, At Least Not Yet
LEAD: CHICKEN LITTLE, meet Roger Rabbit.
With the United States trade deficit down and most industrialized economies growing at a healthy clip, long-fashionable gloom has given way to a celebration of the resilience of the international financial system.


Bentsen to Run Two Races
LEAD: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, selected by Michael S. Dukakis to be his running mate, will continue his bid for a fourth term in the Senate, a dual campaign made legal in Texas in 1959 to let Lyndon B. Johnson run two races.
If Mr.
Bentsen wins both races this year, his Senate seat would become vacant in January.


American Passage: A Niche Marketer
LEAD: Among the things that American Passage, a Chicago advertising company, has been doing is representing military and college newspapers to national advertisers.
It has also been selling ad space on college newspaper racks.

LEAD: As Julia Ramashamola sees it, the almost unbearable agony of being the mother of a woman facing execution for a political crime is made even worse because she is black.

LEAD: In its first important rebuilding steps, Braniff Inc. announced yesterday that it was buying 12 Fokker 100 jets and would build a major hub at Kansas City, Mo.


Beijing Criticizes Rating by Moody's
LEAD: China complained yesterday that Moody's Investors Service assigned too low a rating when the nation issued its first international bonds last October.


A Needless Detour on 42d Street
LEAD: Claire Shulman, Borough President of Queens, is asking the Board of Estimate to reconsider its earlier approval of the 42d Street redevelopment project.
She argues that the project has changed significantly since it received the original go-ahead.
In particular, she objects to the fact that the project's proposed merchandise mart will be occupied mainly by manufacturers and sellers of furniture and fixtures used in interior decorating.


Real Estate; Looks Count At Suburban Shop Strips
LEAD: WHEN strip shopping centers first appeared on the suburban landscape in the 1950's and 1960's, they typically were no-frills structures consisting of little more than long flat-roofed buildings with little visual appeal.


In Soviet Union, a Small but Growing Nutrition Movement
LEAD: WHILE many Soviet citizens stand in interminable queues to buy meat, Arthur Stepanyan and his wife, Olga, don't bother.
They eat almost no meat at all and serve it to their children only once or twice a week.
They don't think meat is healthful.

This leads inevitably to a requirement for typewriter ribbons.
Cat's-paw that I am to these Olympian sadists, I had bought three typewriter ribbons scarcely 10 minutes before the Monday mail arrived with news that they would have to be amortized.

Greece Issues Photos of Suspects in Ship Siege
LEAD: Greece said today that it had obtained the photographs of four suspects in the terrorist attack aboard an excursion ship in the Saronic Gulf on Monday and that it had identified two of them.
The Government said it did not know the whereabouts of the attackers.


Two Tied for Lead In New York Open
LEAD: Dave Carazo, the 43-year-old head pro at Tuxedo in Orange County, shared the lead and the credit after the first round of the Michelob New York State Open golf tournament today.


Reviews/Film; Bunraku Puppets in Natural Settings
LEAD: ''The Love Suicides at Sonezaki'' (1981), opening today at Film Forum 1, is an adaptation of Monzaemon Chikamatsu's 18th-century bunraku puppet drama, filmed not in a bunraku theater but in realistic settings that are at odds with this most highly stylized theatrical form.


TEXAN ADDS CONSERVATIVE VOICE TO TICKET; A REGIONAL BALANCE
LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis reached for regional and ideological balance today and selected Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas as his running mate, counting on the conservative Democrat to strike at the heart of Vice President Bush's Southern base.


Cullum Gets Buyout Offer
LEAD: The Cullum Companies, the dominant supermarket chain in North Texas, said today that a group including its top management and a private investment fund headed by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company had offered to buy Cullum for $360.8 million in cash.


Minute Maid Drops Disputed Phrase
LEAD: The latest battle in the orange juice wars ended yesterday when the Coca-Cola Company, which had begun promoting its new Minute Maid Premium Choice orange juice as ''straight from the orange,'' agreed to drop those words from its packaging.


Bank Capital Rule Expected To Slow the Pace of Lending
LEAD: The new capital guidelines approved Monday by the world's leading central bankers may not read like a best seller, but they will surely have a far-reaching effect on banks, their borrowers and the economy at large.


Allegheny Deal Set
LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. said it intends to sell its semiconductor equipment business to Silicon Valley Group Inc. for undisclosed terms.
The parties signed a letter of intent and will try to negotiate a definitive agreement and win the approval of both boards, Government regulators and the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing Allegheny International's Chapter 11 reorganization.


Shultz and Aquino Call Agreement Near On Philippine Bases
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Corazon C. Aquino said today that they were confident that Washington and Manila would conclude an interim agreement for two American military bases in the Philippines by the end of the month.


Britain Savors Boon From Saudi Sale
LEAD: For Britain, the huge arms sale to Saudi Arabia announced last week represents both a strategic and an economic coup for the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, bolstering Britain's influence in the Persian Gulf and guaranteeing jobs at home.

Polaroid To Market New Films
LEAD: In an acknowledgment of the declining popularity of the instant photography market that it pioneered, the Polaroid Corporation said yesterday that it would take on the Eastman Kodak Company and the Fuji Photo Film Company in the $7 billion world market for conventional color film.


Joshua Logan, Stage and Screen Director, Dies at 79
LEAD: Joshua L. Logan, the director of some of Broadway's most enduring and prestigious hits, among them ''South Pacific,'' which won the Pulitzer Prize, and ''Mister Roberts,'' died yesterday afternoon at his Manhattan home.
He was 79 years old and had suffered for many years from supranuclear palsy, a debilitating disease.

Mudslide Kills 35 in China
LEAD: A mudslide killed 35 workers at a power station in southwestern China, where flooding after heavy rains had already claimed 76 lives, the official New China News Agency reported today.
The slide also injured 10 workers when it swept through an electric generating plant in Sichuan on Sunday evening, the agency reported.

LEAD: Soviet and Afghan attacks on positions captured by Afghan insurgents have recently stalled and in some areas reversed the guerrilla campaign to topple the Kabul Government, Western diplomats said today.

LEAD: All the municipal beaches on Staten Island and in Brooklyn were closed yesterday when sewage gushed into New York Harbor after a power failure at a sewage-treatment plant, adding new concerns for beachgoers and health officials already alarmed by recent deposits of medical waste on the local shoreline.

LEAD: When the White House announced Monday that the United States would compensate the families of the 290 people who died on Iran Air Flight 655, only the circumstances were new.

Book Notes
LEAD:  History in the Family


Testing of Blood For AIDS Virus
LEAD: The AIDS-related tests used on blood samples from beach debris detect antibodies to the AIDS virus, substances the body produces in response to the virus.
Their presence in a specimen would not necessarily mean that live, infectious viruses were still present.
That could only be determined by attempting to grow the virus from the sample, which takes weeks and is unreliable.


Much of Damaged Art At Society Is on Loan
LEAD: Dozens of severely deteriorated and damaged paintings that the New-York Historical Society is storing in a Manhattan warehouse are not owned by the society but are part of a collection on long-term loan from the New York Public Library.

The filing by the maker of Cabbage Patch dolls was accompanied by a management shakeup.

LEAD: Six Israeli policemen were wounded slightly this morning when dozens of Arabs attacked them in a crowded courthouse, the police said.
Two of the officers were stabbed.
Four Arabs were arrested.

Baseball Fever From Afar
LEAD: The All-Star Game is that once-a-year showcase where allegiances to one's hometown team are momentarily discarded in favor of reverence for the game itself.
But for many baseball fans, there are no allegiances to discard.
That's because they have no team.

LEAD: The First Boston Corporation said it would give one of its competitors, Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company, access to its computer system, a move that will help cover the system's cost and help pay for its future development.
First Boston developed its advanced global trading and clearance system in 1985.
It will allow the companies to do 24-hour trading, introduce new products more quickly and major costs.

Mount Desert Journal; Down East, the Traffic Is Way Up
LEAD: When Samuel de Champlain visited this New World island in 1604, he was struck by the rocky summits of the mountains that rise dramatically from the sea and dominate the sailor's view.
The French explorer named the place l'Isle des Monts-deserts, or the Isle of Bare Mountains.


Review/Television; Exploring the Frontiers of Medicine
LEAD: There once was the commercial, you may remember, in which a soap-opera actor proceeded to hawk a pharmaceutical product. ''I am not a doctor,'' he said, ''but I play one on television.'' The exploitation was so blatant that most viewers hooted.
Tonight at 10 o'clock on NBC, ''Modern Medical Breakthroughs'' is a touch more subtle.

LEAD: What a pleasure to have the Bartok Quartet in New York performing music by the man whose name it bears!

They were played by four splendid Hungarian compatriots.

Down and Out in Hollywood: That's Life
LEAD: Most people who live in Los Angeles, and certainly visitors to the city, probably have no real sense that there's a major strike going on here and that a group of writers has brought the entire show-business industry to its knees.
They may have read or heard about the strike in passing, or seen a few scattered picketers, but in a sprawling city like this one, a strike is almost invisible to the untrained eye.


Yukon Pacific
LEAD: The CSX Corporation said it had raised its stake in the Yukon Pacific Corporation of Anchorage to 54 percent, becoming Yukon's largest shareholder.
CSX already owned about 30 percent of the stock in Yukon Pacific, which has been actively lobbying for the construction of the Trans-Alaska Gas System, an 800-mile pipeline that would export natural gas from the state's North Slope to Pacific Rim countries.

James P. Argyropolous, chairman and chief executive of Cherokee, a women's clothing and shoe company based in Sunland, Calif., said the investor group was interested in friendly deal.

The Global Biotechnology Race
LEAD: Federal and private spending on biotechnology research and development exceeded $4.5 billion last year, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment reported yesterday.
The spending, coupled with industry sales that for the first time exceeded $1 billion last year, puts the United States well ahead in the international biotechnology race, industry experts said.

Jackets are the first item to be shed.

Marietta to Buy Gould Division
LEAD: As part of the continuing divestiture of its military businesses, Gould Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Ocean Systems division to the Martin Marietta Corporation, a major military contractor.
Terms of the sale were not disclosed.
The division, which makes underseas surveillance systems for use against submarines, posted revenues of about $100 million in 1987.

LEAD: In the latest skirmish in a simmering feud between the Guardian Angels and the New York City police, 11 Guardian Angels were arrested early yesterday after they surrounded two plainclothes officers in a Manhattan park.

LEAD: The board of Pier 1 Imports Inc. decided that the company should remain independent for the time being, a company spokesman said today.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: CASEMENT windows, which pivot open and shut on hinges, generally suffer fewer problems than double-hung windows, whose two sashes slide in channels.

LEAD: Azerbaijan has rejected an attempt by a predominantly Armenian enclave to secede and join Armenia, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture last Nov. 3, with articles about the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution, was published in error.
It was said to show the storming of the Winter Palace in Petrograd, but historical evidence, including publication of the picture in its original condition in a 1927 book on Bolshevism, indicates that it was taken in the 1920's at a dramatized re-enactment.

Tektronix Expects Loss Due to Taxes
LEAD: Tektronix Inc. said it expects to report a net loss for its fourth quarter and for its fiscal year because its taxes would exceed its pretax income.
The Beaverton, Ore., manufacturer of electronic equipment said it expects pretax income for the year ended May 28 to be $14 million to $16 million, but that its tax expense is expected to be $32 million, resulting in a net loss of $16 million to $18 million.

LEAD: A World War II bomb buried in a field in northern Libya blew up, killing a family of eight, the official Libyan press agency said today.

Review/Dance; New Cast In a 'Medea' From Spain
LEAD: The Royal Spanish National Ballet presented a number of dancers in new roles on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Most notable of these performances was that of Ana Gonzalez in the title role of Jose Granero's ''Medea,'' set to brooding music by Manolo Sanlucar, which takes place in a Spanish village and retells the classic tragedy in a blend of dance styles that includes well-timed outbursts of flamenco as well as ballet and modern dance.


U.S. Considers New Policy of Putting Nonmilitary Pressure on Sandinistas
LEAD: With little prospect for renewed weapons shipments to the Nicaraguan rebels, the Reagan Administration is being forced to consider a new policy aimed at applying political and diplomatic pressure on the Sandinistas, senior American and contra officials say.

LEAD:  Coming of Age in the Milky Way  By Timothy Ferris  Illustrated. 495 pages.
William Morrow &amp; Company. $19.95.


Paine Webber O-T-C System
LEAD: Paine Webber Inc., the large brokerage house, said yesterday that it had developed its own computer capability that allows customers to place stop and stop-limit orders on most over-the-counter stocks.


First Boston Reports Profit In 2d Quarter
LEAD: First Boston Inc. yesterday reported a sharp recovery in earnings for the second quarter in contrast to the corresponding period a year ago, when it had a loss.


Demand Cuts Louisiana Rate
LEAD: Interest rates on a $982 million bond issue of the Louisiana Recovery District were reduced by about a tenth of a percentage point because of strong investor demand, underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets said yesterday.


T.W.A. Hijacking Suspect Admits Sneaking Explosive Into Frankfurt
LEAD: Mohammed Ali Hamadei, accused of hijacking an American jetliner and killing an American Navy diver, admitted to a Frankfurt court today that he had smuggled explosives into West Germany.

Making Cameras Click
LEAD: ''THE biggest culprit of the photo industry is dirt,'' said Rick Rankin, who has been repairing cameras for 21 years. ''Eighty to 90 percent of the cameras brought in here aren't abused.
They're just plain dirty.''


Finance Plan for Seabrook
LEAD: One of the owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant said today that it would pay an extra $2 million in maintenance to keep the stalled project alive until Sept. 1 and gain more time to secure financing for another year.


Final Election Results Announced by Mexico
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission announced final returns late Wednesday in last week's presidential election, giving Carlos Salinas de Gortari of the Institutional Revolutionary Party 50.36 percent, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of National Democratic Front 31.12 percent, and Manuel J. Clouthier of the National Action Party 17.07 percent.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's program to monitor the use of American libraries by agents of the Soviet bloc is a relatively minor but necessary part of its counterintelligence effort, a top official told a House Judiciary subcommittee today.

LEAD: Many women, and men too, have a simple way to determine a desirable weight that permits them to go on wearing their golden oldies, and is measured not by a scale but by how quickly the zipper travels.

LEAD: Carter Brey, a young cellist who has been advancing rapidly on the chamber music and solo scene, gave a Town Hall recital with the pianist Barbara Weintraub on Sunday evening under the auspices of the First New York International Festival of the Arts.

Mahorn Has Surgery
LEAD: Rick Mahorn, the Detroit Pistons' forward, spent three and a half hours in surgery yesterday having a ruptured disk removed from his back.
Dr.
Ben Paolucci, the Pistons' team physician, said Mahorn should be released from William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich., in about three days and could begin therapy in 10 days.

Roy Nakayama, Expert on Chili, Dies at 64
LEAD: Prof.
Roy M. Nakayama, a horticulturist devoted to breeding chilis, died of lung cancer Monday at Memorial General Hospital in Las Cruces, N.M.
He was 64 years old and lived in Las Cruces, his native city.

Quotations of the Day
LEAD: ''Many people have a sense of indignation, a sense of insult, and certainly we must get the attention of our party, of its leadership and be a part of an equation, a partnership that takes us to victory.''  - The Rev.
Jesse Jackson.  ''Most people, I think, are very pleased, and we go forward from here, and both I and Senator Bentsen will be talking with Reverend Jackson and other key party leaders, working hard to unite our party and to go forward to victory in November.


Jacklin Jabs American Pros
LEAD: Tony Jacklin, who won the British Open at Royal Lytham and St.
Annes in 1969, added a rare element of nationalistic braggadocio to the 117th British Open, which starts tomorrow on the same 102-year-old links course.


Review/Pop; Jazz-Funk Hybrids Born In Brooklyn
LEAD: Graham Haynes, a trumpeter who led his band No Image at the Knitting Factory on Monday, is part of a Brooklyn-based musical movement, M-Base, that's creating up-to-the-minute jazz-funk hybrids.
No Image's early set offered the kind of smart, crackling pieces that make Mr.
Haynes one of the movement's strongest composers.


Needed: Pentagon Heart Surgery
LEAD: Once again, the United States defense industry has been rocked by a wide-ranging Federal investigation that has revealed possible bribery and fraud in Pentagon procurement, involving dozens and maybe hundreds of officials, consultants and industry executives.
Some charge that the Pentagon's troubles are the result of too little regulation.


Beverly Sills Plans Afternoon TV Show
LEAD: Beverly Sills, the director of the New York City Opera and the host of hundreds of operatic performances, charity benefit dinners and awards ceremonies in the last 10 years, plans to return to television with her own afternoon talk show.

Lilco Accord Faces Trouble In Legislature
LEAD: An agreement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant is encountering fierce opposition in the State Legislature, and many lawmakers and administration officials believe the accord might collapse.


House 376-45, Passes Revised Trade Bill
LEAD: The House of Representatives today passed a remodeled version of the trade legislation that President Reagan vetoed in May.
The bill, approved 376 to 45, would enable the United States to act more aggressively in rooting out unfair trade practices by other countries.


Fed Sees Stable Rates
LEAD: Alan Greenspan, of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate Banking Committee that a sharp increase in interest rates was not needed to head off inflation.
Page D1. (NYT/Michael Geissinger)

Snyder General in York Bid
LEAD: The Snyder General Corporation, a privately held air-conditioning equipment maker, has offered about $795 million to acquire the York International Corporation, York announced today.
The company had previously agreed to a $750 million buyout by an investment group led by Citicorp.


2 Firms Offer To Buy Micom
LEAD: Two New York investment firms today offered to acquire Micom Systems Inc. for $15.62 a share, or $291.5 million, while the communications equipment maker, based in Simi Valley, Calif., is considering bids from other parties.


Jackson Concedes Fight Over Bentsen Is Possible
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson today raised the specter of a fight over the Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination on the convention floor next week and defections from the party in the November election unless Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis embraces him and his supporters as central players in the party.


Digital Is Expected to Buy a Chip
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation is reported to be close to an agreement to use in its computers an advanced microprocessor chip designed by a Silicon Valley company.
Use of the chip would be a rare move away from Digital's own private hardware standard.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Cummins Engine Co., Columbus, Ind., named Peter B. Hamilton chief financial officer, effective Aug. 1.
He is succeeding John T. Hackett, who is taking early retirement.


Boat People and Compassion Fatigue
LEAD: Repression and poverty in Vietnam breed ever more boat people.
An appalling 1.5 million Vietnamese and other Indochinese have fled since 1975.
Each month, new thousands try to escape on flimsy vessels sailing pirate-infested coastal waters.
Now they face a fresh peril: compassion fatigue, an official euphemism that amounts to blaming victims for the cruelty of their jailers.


Kuwaiti to Seek Reversal of Missile Ban
LEAD: Kuwait's Prime Minister said today that he would seek to reverse a Senate vote against a missile sale to his country, calling the issue ''a barometer of friendship and cooperation'' between allies.

Review/Television; VCR Alert for Channel 13 Reruns
LEAD: A VCR alert would not be out of the question for the next three nights.
Channel 13 is rerunning some of the best programs ever made for television.
Of course, this being public television, the productions were made in Britain.
But quality is quality, and here is a windfall both for those who normally disdain television and for those of us who know better.


Toward a Smoke-Free New York
LEAD: If the State Public Health Council could regulate public smoking, a lot of New Yorkers would be breathing easier by now.
But that power, the Court of Appeals ruled last year, rests with the Legislature.
Having won its point, the Legislature now owes it to New Yorkers to do its job.

LEAD: A previously unknown group linked with Palestinians said today that it carried out the terrorist raid on a Greek cruise ship Monday.

Tax on Wealth Sought By French Government
LEAD: France's minority Government today approved plans to introduce a tax on wealth, setting the scene for Socialist Prime Minister Michel Rocard's first major battle in parliament.


Jail Term for Ex-Banker
LEAD: A former official of the Ka Wah Bank, Wong Ka-ning, was sentenced to two years in prison by the Hong Kong high court today for conspiring to defraud the bank.
Mr.
Wong, a 49-year-old Australian citizen, pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the bank with two of its directors between October 1984 and June 1986.


First Chicago Shows Profit
LEAD: The First Chicago Corporation reported today that its net income rose to $122.9 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $599.9 million in the corresponding period last year.


BRITISH BARRACKS STRUCK IN BOMBING
LEAD: Bomb explosions rocked a British Army barracks in West Germany early today, slightly wounding nine soldiers, the army said.
Gunmen believed to be the attackers opened fire on police officers while escaping, the police reported.

LEAD: No, Dave Johnson said, he isn't uneasy.
Yes, he is confident.
No, he isn't satisfied.
And he has no idea why the Mets keep asking for trouble as they open the second half of a season they were supposed to dominate.


Yields Post Strong Rise
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed more strength in the week ended yesterday than they have in more than a month.


Sorg President and Chief Resigns Both Positions
LEAD: Sorg Inc., a New York-based financial printing company struggling with its profitability, announced yesterday that its president and chief executive, Roy A. Cardia, had resigned.


Pitchers Tame Heavy Hitters
LEAD: On one inglorious evening, baseball's greatest hitters managed to produce all of 3 runs and 11 hits, 8 of which were singles.


Station for Sale In Connecticut
LEAD: Viacom International Inc. has put WVIT-TV, Channel 30, up for sale.
The station is the NBC affiliate in the Hartford-New Haven market.


F.D.A. Is Pessimistic on Drugs to Fight AIDS
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration said today that, based on experience in drug development, current experiments with dozens of possible AIDS treatments were not likely to yield more than one or two new drugs by 1991 that would be useful in fighting the disease.


Take Care When Releasing Hooked Fish
LEAD: THERE is a growing tendency among both marine and fresh water anglers to release many of the fish they catch, but this commendable act may be no more than a gesture if the fish is played to exhaustion or roughly handled while being set free.

LEAD: An agreement in principle has been reached for Robert E. Riordan's Family Media to acquire Venture magazine from Arthur Lipper 3d.

2 Beach Vials Are Tainted by Hepatitis
LEAD: Used syringes and other medical waste continued to wash up on Midland Beach on Staten Island yesterday as New York City officials announced that two vials found there earlier this week contained blood contaminated with the hepatitis B virus.


Go-Video Settles Suit With Toshiba
LEAD: Go-Video Inc. said it had settled a lawsuit with the Toshiba Corporation of Japan, as part of a broader legal battle to end what it contends is a boycott to keep dual-deck video cassette recorders from the United States market.
Go-Video, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., received a patent in June for its dual-deck video recorder, which permits a user to edit tape and copy television programs while they are airing.


U.S. and Iran in Angry Exchange, But Agree to Help Airbus Inquiry
LEAD: The United States and Iran exchanged recriminations today over the American downing of an Iranian jetliner but agreed to cooperate with an inquiry by the International Civil Aviation Organization.


Controversy in Rich Pace
LEAD: John Campbell, who is driving the second choice in the $1,039,000 Meadowlands Pace Friday night, is upset with the track for allowing more than 10 horses into the one-mile race for 3-year-olds.
Campbell's colt, Armbro Global, who handily won one of the three elimination races last Friday, drew post 11 in the second tier.

Amrep Corp., a real estate developer and book and magazine distributor, said its Kable News subsidiary had acquired the business of Publishers Aide, San Diego.


Soviet Hockey Star Remains Unsigned
LEAD: It was a summit of sorts.
The meeting had been long awaited, fastidiously planned and executed with the kind of cordiality and gravity that a month before had attended the more widely reported gathering a couple of blocks away at the Kremlin.


N.Y.U. Law School Picks New Dean
LEAD: A law professor who coached a girls' high school debating team to five national championships, was chairman of a college religion department and then served as law clerk to the Chief Justice of the United States was appointed yesterday as the new dean of the New York University Law School.


Piniella Grows Impatient Amid Yanks' Struggles
LEAD: The message Lou Piniella delivered yesterday hardly resembled the message he offered when he became the Yankees' manager for the second time late last month.
He stood under the warmth of the afternoon sun in the Bronx, stuffed his hands in his back pockets and assumed a firm, get-tough posture in the midst of yet another controversy.

LEAD: The director of the Drug Enforcement Administration said today that the Government would use the herbicide paraquat and two others in a stepped-up campaign to eradicate domestically grown marijuana.

LEAD: Metallgesellschaft A.G. is not a familiar company name in these parts.
Nevertheless the West German concern is one of the world's largest metal companies, and yesterday it announced a change to relatively youthful management.

Capitol Fresco's Restoration Finished
LEAD: Bernard Rabin, project conservator, standing under the newly restored fresco ''The Apotheosis of George Washington,'' inside the Capitol dome.
The fresco, painted by Constantino Brumidi in 1865, will be exposed to the public in stages as the scaffolding is removed. (NYT/Michael Geissinger)

Jesse Jackson's not being chosen as running mate for Michael S. Dukakis.


Foster to Try to Compete
LEAD: Greg Foster, the world champion in the 110-meter hurdles, will attempt to make the United States Olympic team despite a serious and complex arm injury.


Review/Dance; 3 New Works at American Festival
LEAD: The Young Choreographers and Composers in Residence project of the American Dance Festival annually brings dancers and musicians together to explore common artistic concerns and to collaborate on new works that are eventually presented at a public concert.
Judging from the dances shown Monday night at Reynolds Industries Theater on the Duke University campus, this year's young choreographers and composers had the jitters.


Soybeans and Corn Jump On Forecast of a Dry Spell
LEAD: Demand for corn and soybeans reached near-feverish levels yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as meteorologists predicted a return of hot, dry weather over the Farm Belt this weekend.


U.S. Plans New Envoys to Back Managua's Foes
LEAD: State Department officials said today that they hoped to send more diplomats to Nicaragua as soon as possible to show continued support for the political opponents of the Sandinista Government.


Senate Panel Clears Fed Nominee
LEAD: The Senate Banking Committee today approved President Reagan's nomination of John LaWare for a 14-year term on the Federal Reserve Board.
The action clears the way for a vote by the full Senate.


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: I REMEMBER being homesick, although I'd rather not.
It is one of those things you can't forget if you've experienced it, like sky diving or falling in love with the best-looking boy in the senior class when you are a freshman with bad skin and posture.
Except that being homesick is more horrible than either of these, and more resonant, too: that sense that if you were only in one specific ordinary place the nausea would disappear, and the misery, and the palpable sense of unhappiness and disaffection that keeps you only inches from tears except, of course, when you are actually crying.

NEW WORRIES ON SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASE
LEAD: Some major forms of venereal disease, such as syphilis and chlamidia, have increased dramatically in recent years, but other diseases, once extremely rare, are also on the rise.
Among them are chancroid, granuloma inguinale and lymphogranuloma venerium.
The estimates of annual new infections are from the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

Space Experts Unfazed by Power Unit Study
LEAD: A study by aerospace consultants has determined that the odds of catastrophic failure of a key power unit on the space shuttle are one in 70, but space agency officials say there is no need for alarm or for new engineering modifications.


Israeli and 3 Arabs Are Killed In a Clash in South Lebanon
LEAD: An Israeli soldier and three Arab guerrillas were killed in a short exchange of fire this afternoon when Israeli troops entered the southern Lebanese village of Libbaya on a search-and-destroy mission, the army said tonight.


CBS, Last in Ratings, Alters Its Management
LEAD: Coming off its worst prime-time ratings performance ever, CBS Inc. shuffled its executive ranks yesterday, naming Howard Stringer, currently president of CBS News, as president of its Broadcast Group.

Harper &amp; Row to Acquire Religious Books Publisher
LEAD: Harper &amp; Row, a growing presence in international book publishing, took an important step toward becoming a major publisher of religious books when it agreed yesterday to acquire the Zondervan Corporation for about $57 million.


Offer for Oakite
LEAD: An investment group led by Carlyle Investors V L.P. disclosed that it had discussed a possible leveraged buyout of Oakite Products Inc. with the management of the chemical concern based in Berkely Heights, N.J.
Oakite has 1.64 million shares outstanding.
With today's market close of $40.75 a share, up $1.75, a leveraged buyout would have a total value of $66.8 million.

American gardeners who travel eventually find their way to the Chelsea Flower Show in London and make pilgrimages, sometimes repeatedly, to Sissinghurst, Hidcote and other celebrated British gardens.

LEAD: For Mike Purvis, Joe Shearn, Marc Taglieri and young friends, life in the last two years has meant little but baseball.

Koch Rebuffs Vendors On Plan to Reduce Carts
LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday dismissed ''out of hand'' a compromise offered by food vendors that calls for reducing their number at least 25 percent, to ease sidewalk congestion in crowded areas.


Nuclear Plant to Close
LEAD: The world's first commercial nuclear power station, in southwest England, is to close next year following an economic review, the Central Electricity Board said today.
The Magnox plant at Berkeley, Gloucestershire, has been operating 26 years.


Two Park Officials Under Inquiry, But What Did They Do Wrong?
LEAD: Three years ago Loran Fraser, an official of the Interior Department's National Park Service, was temporarily assigned as deputy executive director of the President's Commission on Americans Outdoors, a panel appointed by President Reagan to make recommendations for long-range land and outdoor recreation policy.


Oil Imports Still Rising
LEAD: The United States petroleum industry said today that oil imports continued to rise in the first six months of 1988 and that foreign shipments now accounted for 41 percent of consumption.


Changing Times for Black Democrats
LEAD: Hollis Watkins attended his first Democratic National Convention in 1964, when blacks from Mississippi had to scrounge passes to get inside the hall and fight for seats in their state's delegation.


Review/Art; An Exhibition of Old Master Prints
LEAD: The season's most debonair skeleton can be seen in the 27th annual exhibition of Old Master prints at the Associated American Artists gallery.
Not even Fred Astaire himself could stand more nonchalantly, with legs elegantly crossed, head resting on the long thin fingers of the left hand, and a human skull held lightly in the long thin fingers of the right hand.


Probation Ordered for Man Who Set Fire to Yale Shanties
LEAD: A Yale alumnus who burned an anti-apartheid shantytown on the university's campus last month was granted special probation today after apologizing for setting the fire.


Vendors Agree to Limited Lottery
LEAD: After rejecting similar proposals for months, New York City food vendors agreed yesterday to a limited lottery for midtown Manhattan locations, a move urged by a councilwoman trying to break the standoff between the vendors and Mayor Koch.

The French-language film with English subtitles opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 1, Broadway and 63d Street.

LEAD: Prices of debt securities were little changed yesterday, but the credit markets remained unsettled about rising commodity prices and the possibility that the Federal Reserve will eventually push short-term rates higher.

LEAD: The best thing about ''A Fish Called Wanda'' is the anticipation of it.
