The Law; At the Bar
LEAD: One lawyer, describing the plan, conjured up Orwellian images of Big Brother.
Another lawyer said it smacked of the Soviet Union.
Many said it violated numerous clauses of the Constitution, including the ban on slavery.


Candelaria Wins 10th
LEAD: The same team that trudged quietly into the All-Star Game break -and then spent its time absorbing the verbal assault of George Steinbrenner - made something of a charge into the season's second half last night.
When they were done, the Yankees spoke of the need to forget their past and keep moving ahead.


Review/Opera; Holding on to the World With Music
LEAD: ''The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat'' is the title episode of a much-praised collection of neurological observations by Oliver Sacks.
It is not exactly a case study, since Dr.
Sacks's contact with the patient was limited to two encounters, but it makes a beguiling tale; the dramatis personae are affectionately drawn and their predicament is singular.


They May Love/Hate New York But Executives Give It Business
LEAD: Even though senior executives throughout the United States give the New York metropolitan region poor grades as a place to live and work, they plan to locate more new offices in the region than in any other urban area in the nation, according to a survey released yesterday.


Tour de France; Delgado Takes Overall Lead
LEAD: The folk wisdom of the Tour de France says that the bicycle race is not always won in the Alps, but is usually lost there.
And that may have been vindicated again today.


Tyson Decides to Fight
LEAD: Mike Tyson, who said three weeks ago he would not fight again, has decided to go ahead with his scheduled heavyweight title defense against Frank Bruno Sept. 3, Tyson's lawyer and his manager said yesterday.


Capital Plan Feared as a Burden on Banks
LEAD: Bank holding companies in the United States must raise billions more in new capital than their overseas counterparts under a Federal Reserve plan to increase capital requirements, according to calculations by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.


Prime Rate Up 1/2 Point, To 9 1/2%
LEAD: In response to the recent rise in interest rates, major American banks, led by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, raised their prime lending rate yesterday to 9 1/2 percent from 9 percent.
Other banking companies that quickly followed Chase included Citicorp, First Chicago, Chemical and J. P. Morgan.


For Children
LEAD:  Shows, Nature, Museums  WIDE-AWAKE JAKE, a play based on an English storybook of the same name by Helen Young, about a little boy who cannot fall asleep, performed by Tada and directed by Janine Nina Trevens, 1:30 P.M.
Friday through Monday; 11 A.M.
Friday and Monday, and 3 P.M.
Saturday and Sunday, at the group's new theater, 120 West 28th Street.


Aviation Unit Rebuffs Iran's Bid Against U.S.
LEAD: The International Civil Aviation Organization today rebuffed a bid by Iran for a condemnation of the United States for shooting down an Iranian airliner in the Persian Gulf.
It voted instead to issue a statement that ''deplored'' the use of weapons against a civilian aircraft but did not mention the United States.


Money Fund Assets Rise
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 443 money market mutual funds increased $1.39 billion, to $266.33 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 123 institutional funds decreased $147.1 million, to $69.52 billion.
Assets of the 220 general purpose funds were up $814.1 million, to $82.65 billion.


The Law; Legal Hired Gun: Have Computer, Will Detect
LEAD: When a California manufacturer of mobile homes found itself facing 13 lawsuits alleging unhealthy formaldehyde levels, the company's lawyers unleashed a new and powerful weapon in the legal arsenal: a private investigator with a computer.


JACKSON SUGGESTS CARTER MIGHT HEAL RIFT WITH DUKAKIS
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson took his smoldering dispute with Michael S. Dukakis in a new and striking direction today by saying someone else, former President Jimmy Carter, was needed to mediate it.


Racial Motive Investigated In Death of Kingston Woman
LEAD: The slaying of a 19-year-old woman whose body was found Tuesday morning near abandoned railroad tracks in Kingston, N.Y., may have been racially motivated, officials said yesterday.


U.S. Agent Indicted in Arrest of Pedestrian
LEAD: An agent for the Secret Service was indicted yesterday on charges that he made an unwaranted arrest of a Manhattan pedestrian who crossed paths with the motorcade of a Presidential candidate last spring.


Review/Theater; Kline and Danner In 'Much Ado' in Park
LEAD: Audiences will never stop rooting for Benedick and Beatrice - the Shakespearean antecedents of Tracy and Hepburn and the wittiest man and woman ever to be too busy exchanging insults to recognize that they are in love.
But the audience at the Central Park ''Much Ado About Nothing'' seems to be rooting for the couple's fusion harder than usual, extending its applause to the dull early exposition required to bring the merry warriors into harmony.

AIDS Survey Shows Course Of Infection
LEAD: Giving the clearest picture yet of current infection with the AIDS virus and thus the epidemic's likely future course, the State Health Department today released data on 141,000 anonymous tests for AIDS antibodies showing drastic contrasts by race, age, sex, residence and drug abuse.

Review/Film; The Police, Terrorists And a Captive Audience
LEAD: ''Die Hard,'' the movie that gambles a $5 million salary on Bruce Willis, has to be the most excessive film around.
It piles every known element of the action genre onto the flimsy story of a New York cop who rescues hostages from a Los Angeles office tower on Christmas Eve.
Partly an interracial buddy movie, partly the sentimental tale of a ruptured marriage, the film is largely a special-effects carnival full of machine-gun fire, roaring helicopters and an exploding tank.


Rangers Sign Center
LEAD: In an effort to strengthen themselves on face-offs, the Rangers yesterday signed Doug Wickenheiser, a free-agent center who has played with three teams since being the first player selected by the Montreal Canadiens in the 1980 entry draft.


Lawyer in Lee Insider Case Assails S.E.C.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission misrepresented a conversation its investigators had with the lawyer for the investor from Taiwan accused of insider trading, the lawyer asserted in an affidavit filed this week.


Redmen Lose Porter
LEAD: Michael Porter, the top scorer for St.
John's with a 13-point average last season, has been declared ineligible to play next season because of academic deficiencies.
Jim Ducey, an assistant to Jack Kaiser, the athletic director, confirmed yesterday that the transfer student from San Jacinto College in Texas, who has one remaining year of athletic eligibility, had failed to complete 30 credits and attain at least a 2.0 grade-point average, the minimum for varsity athletic participation at St.


Federal Judge Apologizes In Fight Over Use of 'Ms.'
LEAD: A Federal judge apologized today to a lawyer he scolded and threatened with jail when she insisted on using her maiden name and the honorific ''Ms.'' in court.

LEAD: The York International Corporation is considering additional potential antitrust issues regarding an unsolicited offer from the Snyder General Corporation.

Mandela Concert Prohibited
LEAD: The South African Government banned a rock concert that anti-apartheid campaigners had hoped would be the highlight of celebrations of Nelson Mandela's 70th birthday.
The Justice Ministry conveyed its decision in a letter to the organizing committee for the daylong concert, which had been scheduled to be held near Soweto on Sunday, the day before the birthday of the long-imprisoned African National Congress leader.

Japan on U.S. Trade
LEAD: Japan said today that its trade figures with the United States had improved strikingly in the last six months, and it predicted that the trend would continue for the rest of the year.
Over all, the trade surplus with the United States was down 14.9 percent during the period from January through June, compared with the period last year, according to statistics from the Foreign Ministry.

Stephen Reichard, 39; Started an AIDS Fund
LEAD: Stephen Reichard, an arts marketing consultant who helped to conceive and lead a major fund-raising campaign for AIDS research in the New York art world, died of cardiac arrest resulting from AIDS on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 39 years old.


Texas Gas Notes
LEAD: The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, a unit of the CSX Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent debentures due in 1992 at a price of 99.95, to yield 9.264 percent, through Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
Underwriters said the issue was noncallable and priced to yield about 63-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GOLF  Sauers Shoots a 62: Gene Sauers, playing with a new putter, shot a first-round tournament record of eight-under-par 62 yesterday at the $600,000 Hardee's Golf Classic in Coal Valley, Ill.
Sauers, a 25-year-old Georgian who won the 1986 Boston Classic, had an eagle, seven birdies and a bogey over the 6,606-yard Oakwood Country Club course.

Volleyball Team Basks in Anonymity
LEAD: When they travel to Japan, they provoke a response akin to the Beatlemania of the 1960's.
When they compete in South America, their prowess is so feared that they are spat upon by the legions of fans who come to watch them.
Only in the United States, not a volleyball hotbed despite being the sport's birthplace, does the Olympic men's volleyball squad, the defending gold medalist, go about its business virtually unnoticed.

Texas Cleans Up Oil Spill
LEAD: Cleanup crews worked today to contain 630,000 gallons of crude oil spilled into the harbor when a Singapore-owned tanker crashed into a mooring structure, the Coast Guard said.

Outdoor Sculptures Reflect Struggles Of Life in the City
LEAD: SOMETHING has happened to outdoor sculpture in New York.
There have always been works of substance, but they seemed isolated and often marginal, with little relation to issues about which most sculptors were concerned.
Each year, however, the outdoor season has become more of a forum in which large sculptural ideas and themes are developed and debated.

LEAD: One scene in tonight's edition of ''20/20'' sparks conflicting emotions that the rest of the program seems determined to douse.
The report at 10 o'clock on Channel 7 focuses on a 35-year-old woman named Vivian Shillander, who returned to Thailand last January in hopes of regaining custody of the four children left behind when she fled the country with her youngest, a baby, in 1984.

Restaurants
LEAD: Like upwardly mobile immigrants, Huberts restaurant has followed each surge of its success with a move to a better neighborhood.
Karen Hubert and her chef and husband, Len Allison, started in 1976 with a Victorian-style nook in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn.
In 1981, they crossed the East River and settled on East 22d Street, near Gramercy Park, where their ingenuous charm and ecumenical cooking continued to win followers.

LEAD: Demonstrating organizational strength, Philip F. Foglia yesterday filed nominating petitions with 31,667 signatures, considerably more than four other aspirants for the Democratic nomination for Bronx District Attorney - the most hotly contested primary in New York City this September.


Samurai Insurance
LEAD: Ohio dealers of the American Suzuki Motor Corporation will offer a $1 million accidental life insurance policy free for a year to those who buy or lease the company's Samurai model.
The effort begins Friday and ends Aug. 31, but it may be extended, said Robert Reichert, the president of the Kenwood Dealer Group.

Review/Film; Wartime Obsessions
LEAD: Set in World War II Germany, ''The Berlin Affair'' is the story of a married couple sexually obsessed with a total cipher named Mitsuko.
First Mitsuko seduces Louise, the brittle but beautiful hausfrau in her art class.
Louise's husband, Heinz, works as a Government minister for the Nazis, and is less upset by his wife's betrayal than by the threat it poses to his career.

LEAD: Local law-enforcement officials here have enlisted Federal agents and prosecutors to fight violent drug-dealing gangs that are moving into the Northwest.

LEAD: Raymond W. Goldsmith, an economist who for several decades was a leading authority on national income and wealth, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Whitney Center, a retirement community in Hamden, Conn.
He was 83 years old and had lived for many years in New Haven.

LEAD: Afghan rebels fired more than 20 missiles at the capital city of Kabul today, killing 20 people and wounding 34, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

Hungary Reform Plan
LEAD: Hungary's ruling Communist Party approved plans today for radical political and economic reforms and slashed the number of top jobs needing party approval.
A Central Committee meeting agreed overwhelmingly to work out details of a tough economic recovery plan for 1989 that would give free rein to market forces and but would be liable to increase unemployment.

Jess T. Adkins, Actor, 62
LEAD: Jess T. Adkins, the director of the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University and an actor best known for his work in daytime television series, died of cancer Wednesday at N.Y.U.
Medical Center.
He was 62 years old.
Mr.
Adkins was director of the National Theater Institute at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., from 1980 to 1983.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Major banks raised their prime lending rate to 9 1/2 percent, from 9 percent, confirming the recent trend toward higher rates.
The second increase in the prime this year brought it to its highest level since March 1986.
The increase may affect consumer spending but is unlikely to be a major drag on the economy.

LEAD: The transcript of radio calls between the downed Iran Air jetliner and air controllers appears to support Iran's assertion that the plane was sending out normal radar signals for a civilian aircraft and was climbing from 12,000 feet to its assigned altitude of 14,000 feet when it was shot down by the United States

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would continue to build the Mustang car at least into the early 1990's and would invest $200 million to modernize production and redesign its interior to hold an airbag on the driver's side.

Allied-Signal Stake
LEAD: Siemens A.G. of West Germany said it had agreed to buy at least 51 percent of the Bendix Electronics Group unit of Allied-Signal Inc., with an option to buy the rest of the subsidiary in three years.
The companies declined to specify the percentage of the equity now being transferred to Siemens, but an Allied-Signal spokesman said the company expected $200 million to $300 million from the sale.

Reagan, After Tour of Parched Farms, Prods Congress on Drought Relief
LEAD: After touring corn and soybean fields parched and stunted by weeks of searing heat, President Reagan urged today that Congress swiftly pass drought relief legislation being developed by the House and Senate Agriculture Committees.


A Break in the Angola Stalemate
LEAD: This week's secret talks in New York on Angola have produced tentative agreement on what Chester Crocker, the U.S. mediator, called the ''essential elements of a political settlement in southwestern Africa.'' This is far from a final agreement.
But if one can eventually be struck, it would be a major diplomatic triumph, ending South Africa's illegal rule in Namibia and removing Cuba's 45,000 troops from war-battered


Market Place; One-Price Stores Gain in Popularity
LEAD: WHETHER it's because of the inflation threat or a basic change in the nation's income distribution, stores that sell every item for the same price are beginning to take hold as the newest wrinkle in the discount-store phenomenon.


SPLIT IS REPORTED OVER ABM ACCORD
LEAD: Disagreeing with the civilian leadership of the Pentagon, the Joint Chiefs of Staff are resisting a move that would allow the United States to suspend some of its obligations under the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials say.


Last of Playboy Clubs In U.S. to Shut Down
LEAD: The last Playboy Club in the United States will close at the end of July, formally ending the era of buxom waitresses with bunny tails.

Two Bills on Drought Relief Advance in Congress
LEAD: Relief for drought-stricken farmers moved a big step closer to reality today as both the House and Senate Agriculture Committees approved separate legislation aimed at putting payments in farmers' hands by September.


50 Restored Movies at the Modern
LEAD: Without the restoration and preservation work done by film archives, we would never be able to see such artifacts as the first three-color Technicolor feature (Rouben Mamoulian's ''Becky Sharp,'' 1935), Ernst Lubitsch's ''One Hour With You'' (1932) in its original amber-and-blue tints, and two films that Laurel and Hardy made in Spanish (without subtitles).


Gannett Net Up 8.7% in 2d Quarter
LEAD: The Gannett Company yesterday reported net income for the second quarter of $97.5 million, or 60 cents a share, up 8.7 percent from $89.7 million, or 56 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago.


McNamara Dismissed
LEAD: The Boston Red Sox, struggling to keep pace in the American League East with a 43-42 record, abruptly dismissed Manager John McNamara today and named their third-base coach, Joe Morgan, as the interim manager.


New Scorsese Film Shown to Religious Leaders
LEAD: In an effort to defuse criticism by evangelical Protestants of Martin Scorsese's latest film, ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' Universal Pictures screened it for a group of religious leaders in New York City on Tuesday.


Iran Falls Short in Drive at U.N. To Condemn U.S. in Airbus Case
LEAD: Despite an impassioned speech by its Foreign Minister, Iran failed to win Security Council support today for a resolution condemning the United States for the downing of an Iranian airliner.
Diplomats said Teheran would have to settle for a less harshly worded statement.


Agency Moves to Revive Embryo Studies
LEAD: The Health and Human Services Department announced today that it would re-establish an ethics committee to rule on applications for funds for fertility research involving embryos.
The move is a first step in ending what amounted to a de facto ban on federally sponsored research on ''test tube'' babies.

Soviet Jew Reports Exit Visa
LEAD: A 50-year-old Jewish mathematician who has sought for nine years to leave the Soviet Union said Wednesday that he had been granted an exit visa and that he would fly to the United States on the private jet of Dr.
Armand N. Hammer, the industrialist.
The mathematician, Veniamin Charny, who had been denied emigration on the basis that he had access to space technology, said he planned to join his daughter, Anna Charny-Blank, 28, in Brookline, Mass.

Amoco Purchase
LEAD: A judge here has approved the $5.5 billion (Canadian), or $4.5 billion (United States), takeover of Dome Petroleum Ltd. by the Amoco Corporation.
The judge ruled that the deal was fair to Dome's creditors and shareholders.
Dome agreed to be acquired by the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company in 1987.
The company's dissident stockholders had asked the court to reopen the bidding.

About Real Estate; Utility's Land Sales Plan Stirs Connecticut Region
LEAD: A pastoral 134-acre wooded site in Easton, Conn., has become the first of an estimated 2,000 acres of excess land that the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company intends to sell over the next decade or so.
The Easton site, in the city's southeastern corner, will be developed with high-priced custom homes on three-acre lots.


Healthy Kids Magazine Will Publish 3 Editions
LEAD: The American Baby Group is taking on a very big project for the American Academy of Pediatrics.
And that is to publish a magazine three times a year called Healthy Kids, which will be distributed by pediatricians to parents.
It is expected eventually to have a circulation of 13.5 million.


Patti Page Looks Back On 40 Years
LEAD: How odd it seems in retrospect that Patti Page, a singer who has always exemplified wholesome pop-country conservatism, should have been a key figure in the evolution of pop-music technology.
Forty years ago, Miss Page - who opened her first New York engagement in 19 years at the Ballroom on Tuesday -became the first pop singer to have her voice overdubbed to sound like a duet or a group.

LEAD: QUITE early one morning, or was it quite late one night, the phone rang and I answered it from a deep dream of peace.

LEAD: Reacting cautiously to a reported agreement governing a Cuban withdrawal from Angola and a South African withdrawal from Namibia, South African officials said today that it was too early to interpret the progress made at three days of talks in New York.


Profit Declines At World Bank
LEAD: The World Bank earned $1 billion in the year ended June 30, despite a sharp increase in its provision for loan losses and the forgoing of interest on loans to eight countries.


Eastern-Machinists Talks Appear Stalled
LEAD: The management of Eastern Airlines and the machinists' union appear deadlocked in their contract talks, and the possibility of a strike appears to be increasing.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the Assembly session in Albany misidentified the Assemblyman with James R. Tallon Jr., the majority leader.
He was Frank J. Barbaro.


Why Not Run Twice in Texas?
LEAD: Thanks to Lyndon Johnson, Texas law allows Lloyd Bentsen to run for re-election as a Senator at the same time he's running for Vice President.
This leeway was written into the state's election code in 1959 for then-Senator Johnson, who had his eye on the 1960 Presidential nomination.
While it smacks of opportunism, it actually makes good sense.


Corrections
LEAD: The Letters column in The Living Section Wednesday gave an incorrect identification for the writer of a letter about hot dogs.
He is Michael F. Jacobson.

Acid Rain and Trees: In Clouds, an Answer?
LEAD: Rich MacDonald spends most of his time collecting clouds from the top of Whiteface Mountain.
Often the clouds carry part of the industrial Midwest to this scenic peak - pollution that will fall to the ground as acid rain.


New Hairdo, No Angst
LEAD: Women and especially men often shy away from a new hair style, color or permanent wave because they are afraid they will be stuck with it until it grows out.
Now there is a high-tech way to get a preview.
A California company, New Image Industries, has developed a computer system that superimposes hair styles on the video image of a salon client's face.

Design Faulted On the Aircraft That Blew Open
LEAD: The Boeing 737 accident in Hawaii in which a large section of the fuselage blew off in flight was probably caused by many tiny metal fatigue cracks that were suddenly ''zipped open'' by pressurization inside the cabin, a top Government expert testified Thursday.

Italy Loses Pasta Case
LEAD: The European Community's Court of Justice in Luxembourg ruled Thursday that Italy could not ban imports under its 1967 ''pasta purity'' law requiring that all pasta be made with durum wheat.
The case, dubbed ''Pasta Wars'' by the Italian press, was brought to the court by the West German pasta producer Drei Glocken.

GUIDEPOST: Melting Point
LEAD: High temperatures take their toll on the contents of handbags, beach bags and weekend totes.
Medications, cosmetics and other items will deteriorate if they are repeatedly left in a hot car or in the sun, because heat accelerates natural spoilage.
Most medications will not lose their potency for quite a while, but the coating on capsules can become gluey.

LEAD: An article yesterday about an ordinance requiring permits for people moving into or out of East Orange, N.J., incompletely described a lawyer representing a woman who is challenging the ordinance.
Although the lawyer, Marianne Tolomeo, is arguing the case on behalf of the American Civil Liberties Union, she is with the Newark law firm of Podvey, Sachs, Meanor &amp; Catenacci.

Masco Plans Operations Shift
LEAD: Masco Industries said it would transfer operations with annual sales of about $250 million, representing about 15 percent of its revenues, to a new company that it expects to form late in the fall.
John C. Nicolls Jr., the treasurer of Masco, said his company would exchange its military, gas cylinder, fastener and heat-treating operations for about half of the equity in the new company, which is to be called the Trimas Corporation.

Carter E. Talman Jr. of Richmond, and Scott Owen Corwin, a son of Dr. and Mrs.
Leonard J. Corwin of Short Hills, N.J., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents.
The Rev.
Frank J. Fagan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

Canada To Finance Oil Project
LEAD: The Canadian Government will announce next week that it plans to provide much of the financing necessary to begin a $5 billion oil project off the Newfoundland coast, oil industry executives said today.


Flying Tiger Files Japan Complaint
LEAD: The Flying Tiger Line Inc. said it had filed a complaint with the Transportation Department charging that Japan has unfairly restricted its proposed service between Tokyo and Frankfurt.
Since 1985, Flying Tiger, a Los Angeles air-cargo carrier, has sought new routes into Japan, but the country has historically restricted the operations of United


Wedtech Defendant Asserts Ignorance of Own Finances
LEAD: Prosecutors in the Wedtech racketeering trial yesterday talked John Mariotta, the company's co-founder, through millions of dollars of illicit transactions they assert he carried out with his wife to conceal their gains from an investigation into theft and fraud at the company.


To Many, Mexican Press Is Meek . . . But at One Paper, at Least, the Reporters Rake the Muck
LEAD: As part of its coverage of the Mexican elections, the newspaper El Norte infiltrated a reporter among the supporters of the ruling party who were stuffing ballot boxes.
Another reporter managed to attend a secret class on how to multiply the vote illegally.


Albany's Unfinished Schools Agenda
LEAD: For months, the State Legislature has been considering a bold agenda that could help revitalize New York City's ailing schools.
Now, with recess only days away, there is a chance that vital elements of that agenda may be deferred by the Senate.
Progress has been made in some areas, but little or none in others.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Abraham Pereira, Stockbroker, 76
LEAD: Abraham Pereira, a Wall Street stockbroker, died of cancer yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.
He was 76 years old and lived in the Bronx.


Biggest Union Reaches Accord at Pan Am
LEAD: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement with its largest union that would provide annual savings of $27 million a year.


Vietnam Saves 3 U.S. Fliers
LEAD: A Vietnamese ship rescued three United States Navy aviators shortly after their plane crashed into the South China Sea near the Spratly Islands three days ago, and the ship was taking them to Vietnam today.


Wiktor Weintraub, 80, Slavic Studies Scholar
LEAD: Dr.
Wiktor Weintraub, an educator and author who specialized in Slavic studies, died of cancer on Thursday at his home in Cambridge, Mass.
He was 80 years old.
Dr.
Weintraub held the Alfred Jurzykowski Chair of Slavic Studies at Harvard University from 1971 until his retirement in 1978.
He was a prolific writer in Polish and English, with more than 400 books, articles and essays.


Wood Chipper Murder Case Ends in Mistrial
LEAD: With a juror refusing to deliberate and to return to the courtroom after 17 days of deliberations, a judge today declared a mistrial in the case of an airline pilot accused of murdering his wife and putting her body through a wood chipper.

Today it helps to think like an insurance underwriter, or maybe a detective.


Bridgeport to Trim 'Model Housing' Complex
LEAD: Police Officer Herb T. Gullberg watching as youths relaxed at Father Panik Village in Bridgeport, Conn.
The 47-year-old, 40-acre complex, once hailed as a national model of public housing for the poor, has become a blight, according to city officials.
They plan to scale it down, demolish most of its buildings and rebuild it at about half its present size.

MacKinnon Stays On
LEAD: Bob MacKinnon, the Nets' assistant general manager, has signed a one-year extension of his contract, and he will remain with the team as a consultant and regional scout after the 1988-89 season.
In his current job, MacKinnon works closely with Harry Weltman, the general manager, evaluating talent and scouting teams.

LEAD: After more than 7 hours, 21 hits and 25 innings, the Jackson Mets and the San Antonio Missions of the Class AA Texas League were still locked in a scoreless tie at 2:30 A.M. today.
So the league president, Carl Sawatski, suspended the game for fear that players could be injured.

British Inflation Rate Up
LEAD: Britain's annual consumer inflation rate rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to 4.6 percent, in June from the previous month, the Government reported today.
The Department of Employment attributed the rise to higher prices for motor vehicles, non-seasonal foods, gasoline and clothing.

LEAD: Twenty years ago Andrew Young marched behind the mule-drawn wagon that carried the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. to his tomb.
Today, as Mayor of Atlanta, he presides over the political establishment of the city that will act as host to the 1988 Democratic National Convention.
It is an establishment that is mostly black.

744 Insurers Quit Lloyd's
LEAD: Hundreds of underwriting members have resigned from the insurance market of Lloyd's of London this year amid forecasts of possible losses from United States pollution and asbestos claims, a Lloyd's spokesman said today.


James Shanklin, 78, Led Kennedy Inquiry
LEAD: James Gordon Shanklin, a lawyer and former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who directed an exhaustive inquiry into the assassination of President Kennedy, died of cancer Monday at Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas.
He was 78 years old and lived in Dallas.

Volkswagen Plant Closes in Pennsylvania
LEAD: Paul Adams, a tool and die maker, sitting in the back of a truck with his tools as he left after his last shift at the Volkswagen plant in New Stanton.
About 1,725 workers were laid off after more than a million cars were made at the plant since 1978. (AP)


Bonne Stearns Weds Howard Wasserman
LEAD: The wedding of Bonne Marks Stearns to Howard Wasserman took place yesterday at the Cherry Hill Fountain in Central Park.
Justice Joseph A. Mazur of State Supreme Court in the Bronx performed the ceremony.


Taiwanese, for First Time, Hold Majority in Key Body
LEAD: Taiwan's ruling party has appointed several new leaders to its top policy-making body, and for the first time a majority of its members are natives of Taiwan.


Suzuki Sales Move
LEAD: The American Suzuki Motor Corporation said today that it was trying to reverse last month's 70 percent slump in sales of the company's Samurai sports-utility vehicle by giving dealers $2,000 for each unit they sell.
A spokeswoman for Suzuki, the United States unit of Suzuki Motor of Japan, said dealers might use the money, which is available from today through Sept.


Turner Is Hopeful on New Cable Network
LEAD: The Turner Broadcasting System's new cable entertainment network will sign on in October with nearly 10 million television households - well above the company's initial projection of seven million homes - the company's chairman, Ted Turner, said today.

Carlyle-Oakite
LEAD: Carlyle Investors Partnership V, L.P., a Washington-based investment firm, has offered to acquire Oakite Products Inc. for $44 a share in cash.
Oakite, a chemical concern based in Berkeley Heights, N.J., has 1.64 million shares outstanding, giving the proposal an estimated value of $72 million.
Carlyle made its offer in a letter Thursday to the Oakite board.

LEAD: Mexican voters had not even arrived at the polls on the morning of July 6 when the weekly magazine Impacto was beginning its press run with a surprising headline. Healing a Wound in Cambodia
LEAD: When America's eyes turned away from Indochina in 1975, Cambodia's misery had just begun.
The intervening years brought the infamous barbarities of the Khmer Rouge, then dreary occupation by Vietnam.
Now, however, a series of promising parallel forces are moving Cambodia's tragedy toward resolution.

LEAD:  International 2-6  The trade deficit was $10.9 billion in May, the Government reported.
The May figure fell about midway between the revised April deficit and the March deficit, suggesting that the deficit may be temporarily on a plateau.
Page 1  Ending trade barriers in West Euorpe by late 1992, once regarded as a utopian concept, is increasingly perceived as an unstoppable process.


At Loehmann's, Mystique Fades
LEAD: For generations of style-seeking women, Loehmann's has offered a kind of fashion salvation, selling top designer clothes, without the labels, at a discount.
But these days, women who once flocked to Loehmann's stores can find similar bargains elsewhere - at other discount houses, factory outlets and department stores that seem to offer perpetual markdowns.

Golden Fights Koch and Threats to His Political Power
LEAD: Howard Golden's expression turns dour when he speaks of Mayor Koch.

Rover Group Deal
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. will go ahead with its takeover of Rover Group P.L.C. despite conditions the European Community's Executive Commission has imposed on the deal, the Government said.
The commission on Wednesday approved the takeover on the condition that the British Government cut by $428 million the amount of cash the Government is to inject simultaneously into the state-owned auto maker.


Cuban Lists Conditions for Angola Troop Pullout
LEAD: Cuba will start to withdraw its troops from Angola only after South Africa begins to carry out a long-stalled United Nations plan for independence in neighboring Namibia, the chief Cuban negotiator in the talks on the Angolan conflict said here today.


Blaze at a Rocket Fuel Plant Is Attributed to Welding Job
LEAD: Fire officials have blame a welder's torch for the fire and a series of explosions that two months ago demolished a plant that produced a rocket fuel oxidizer.
Two people were killed in the accident, and 326 were injured.

Diggers, Eminent And Otherwise
LEAD: The article 'The Thieves Who Steal History in the Niht''  [ June 26 ]  has raised a firestorm.
The mischief such biased ''reporting'' has done in the past started with citizens calling the police everytime they saw someone with a metal detector looking for mercury dimes in an old ballfield or sifting the beach for quarters.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  TEMPERED ZEAL: A Columbia Law Professor's Year on the Streets With the New York City Police.
By H. Richard Uviller. (Contemporary, $19.95.) This book is a shrewd appraisal of how police officers handle criminal procedure: searches and seizures, arrests, lineups and interrogations.
H.
Richard Uviller, a onetime prosecutor who now teaches law at Columbia University, spent a sabbatical back on the front line of the criminal justice system - the crime-ridden Ninth Precinct in lower Manhattan.

Less Trading Means Calmer Markets
LEAD: AMONG the worries economists nag about these days is an apparent loss of liquidity in the stock market.
Much has been made of a report from Bridge Information Systems that in 1987 a purchase or sale of 155,000 shares was necessary to move the average stock 1 percent on the New York Stock Exchange, while in 1988 that number was down to 87,000 shares.

Tulane Picks Clark
LEAD: The basketball program at Tulane University, dropped in 1985 after a point-shaving scandal, is scheduled to be resumed in time for the 1989-90 season, and yesterday the school named Perry Clark as the new coach.
The 36-year-old Clark, currently an assistant to Coach Bobby Cremins at Georgia Tech, will become the first black head coach in any sport at Tulane.


The Emerging European Elite
LEAD: THE life of a corporate chief executive in Europe used to look something like this: offices stuffed with antiques and oils in a palatial headquarters building with half a dozen fountains adorning the grounds; butlers who trolleyed in tea at the appointed hour.
Beneath him were encrusted layers of upper and middle management whose main job seemed to be keeping dozens of chauffeurs and secretaries busy.

LEAD: Charles W. Lubin, founder of the Kitchens of Sara Lee, died Friday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, apparently after suffering a heart attack while driving.
He was 84 years old.
A Chicago native, Mr.
Lubin was apprenticed to a baker at the age of 14 in Decatur, Ill.
In 1949, he named his first special cheesecake for his 8-year-old daughter, Sara Lee.

Polluted Sound Needs Action, Not Study
LEAD: THE water was brutally cold.
Numbing as it touched the exposed parts of my body where the mask and hood made imperfect seals.
My temperature gauge read 51 degrees Fahrenheit, winter water with a summer sun overhead.
It wasn't quite summer yet, but it would be soon enough, and as soon as the water temperature rises with mid- and late-summer sunshine, another crisis will begin.

IDEAS &amp; TRENDS: Decoding Deconstruction; A Whole New Style of Thinking
LEAD: SINCE it is an article of deconstructionist faith that a text has no fixed, single meaning, it probably shouldn't be surprising that books and articles written by deconstructionists are all but impossible for most other people to comprehend.
Deconstruction is not just another philosophy, its champions proclaim, but a whole new style of thinking - and, to the consternation of the uninitiated, a way of using language that is based on the assumption that our words can never really say what we mean.

The very word was like a bell that tolled me back to childhood summers, to hour after hour (when time was not money) spent on the small concrete porches of our cabins at camp doing ''Cherry in the Basket,'' ''Flying Dutchman'' and ''Over the Fence.


High Tech to the Rescue
LEAD: In these days of high-tech-whoopee, one of the neater little tricks has no moving parts, no microchips, no plug-in jacks, no power source.
But it can start your car when there's no other way.

Saving the Threatened Piping Plover
LEAD: As the swallows return to Capistrano every spring, so do the piping plovers, small and shy shore birds, to the beaches on Long Island to nest and have their young.
But their habitat and nesting sites are shrinking every year, due to building and re-creation along their coastal habitat.

'Wanda': From Idea to Reality
LEAD: You could call ''A Fish Called Wanda'' an Ealing comedy that's been time-warped into a world recovering from the impact of Monty Python's Flying Circus.

Mr.
Cleese, who wrote the script and plays a main role, is, of course, a veteran of British television's most wickedly inventive comic series.


BERRIES JUBILEE
LEAD: THE FRAGILE BERRIES and fruits of summer are often best when eaten close to where they are picked.
I can remember bringing baskets of strawberries picked in the country one morning to serve in the city for dinner that evening.
I imagined placing them in little pastry shells set in a puddle of custard cream.

Provence
LEAD: To the Editor: We enjoyed the article about pizza in Provence by Patricia Wells (Travel, June 5), but your readers should know that they can satisfy their cravings for that thin crispy crust and super fresh ingredients here in the United States.
A pizza remarkably similar to the finest fare in Aix and Arles is made by Judie's European Baked Goods at 126 Shore Drive in the Short Beach section of Branford, Conn., a few miles east of New Haven.

There will be no immediate free agency for some 300 National Football League players, but the cheers or sighs of relief from 28 owners and their commissioner ought not to be too loud.

Treat the Causes, Not the Symptoms
LEAD: FRUSTRATION with our current welfare system runs deep.
Conservatives see it as a narcotic, encouraging illegitimacy and dependency.

Americans generally oppose its expansion.

A Retailing Resurrection?
LEAD: American women, in general, have held off buying new clothes for more than a year, producing the longest dry spell for women's apparel in more than four years.
Because sales of women's and girls' clothes represent about 60 percent of all clothing sales, this has severely affected the nation's retail sales.

Man Arrested in June Killing That Led to 911 Suspension
LEAD: A 26-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday for the June 21 murder of his ex-girlfriend, the police said.
The murder drew wide attention because a 911 dispatcher apparently delayed at least 20 minutes before sending a car to the scene, and the victim was shot while she was making a second desperate call to police.


Protection for Drought-Plagued Habitats
LEAD: The drought that has ravaged waterfowl nesting areas in Canada and the United States has produced habitat conditions described by some biologists as the worst they have ever seen.
Responding to this, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has already announced plans for more restrictive regulations during the 1988-1989 hunting seasons.

LEAD: AS part of the most complex interplanetary endeavor yet attempted by the Soviet Union, two probes have soared into space in the last two weeks to explore Mars and its moon Phobos.
While enthusiasts of detente were heralding the launchings as a prelude to a possible Soviet-American manned visit to the planet by 2010, some critics in the Reagan Administration were worried about military implications.

Paris Hotel Fire Kills 5
LEAD: A fire in a tourist hotel in central Paris overnight killed five people, the police said today.
The dead were two Belgians, a Swede, a Japanese and the French manager of the Saint Vincent de Paul hotel, near the Gare du Nord railroad station, they said.
At least two people were seriously injured and 19 others suffered slight injuries, the police said.

Correction
LEAD: A caption on page 17 in Television today incorrectly identifies the actors pictured.
They are Christopher Connelly and Jodie Foster, who starred in the ABC-TV series ''Paper Moon,'' based on the 1973 film of the same name.
The original film is to be broadcast today at noon and Friday at 2 P.M. on the Showtime cable channel.


Spy Ends Hunger Strike
LEAD: Jonathan Pollard, the former Navy intelligence analyst imprisoned last year for passing secrets to Israel, has ended a five-day hunger strike at the Federal prison at Marion, Ill., his father, Morris, said Friday.
Jonathan Pollard began his protest last Sunday, saying he and his wife, Anne, had been mistreated and their mail was censored.

Rome to Milan By Fast Train
LEAD: ITALY now offers a high-speed train to rival France's seven-year-old T.G.V. (Train a Grande Vitesse) and to compete with air traffic.
Service aboard the Pendolino, a red and cream, all-first-class train built by Fiat, started in May between Rome and Milan, the country's two largest cities, offering nonstop travel in about four hours twice a day.


As Ever, Democrats Would Prefer a Contest
LEAD: HUBERT H. HUMPHREY never tired of proclaiming Democratic dedication to ''the politics of joy.'' Fellow Democrats of various stripes have long insisted that, win or lose, love feast or fistfight, they have a lot more fun nominating their Presidential candidates than do the Republicans.
More noise, more disorder, more gleeful fratricide.

Part-Time Study For Graduate Students
LEAD: The article on opportunities in Connecticut for summertime study at the college and graduate level  [ ''New Season for Studying: The Summer,'' June 26 ]  was remiss in failing to take note of Wesleyan University's Graduate Liberal Studies Program.
Founded in 1953 and designed specifically for part-time adult learners, this program is the oldest and largest of its type in the United States.

Atlanta Up Close; A Journey Into Black History
LEAD: REMNANTS of the history of blacks in the South are largely hidden, apart from the well-documented heritage trails in main cities.
Atlanta, for example, is fairly well preserved: There is Auburn Avenue, a two-mile strip that Fortune magazine once called ''the richest Negro street in the world.'' There is the childhood home of Martin Luther King Jr., the church where he preached and his tomb.

Bruch and Analysis

Growing Pointers
LEAD: SOW fresh seed of biennials, either in pots or in nursery beds, where soil has been prepared; if sown directly in the ground, protect seed beds with chicken wire to keep rodents out.
Spray hemlocks for control of woolly adelgids.
Hedges are growing rampant; prune them back.
Snap off watersprouts (upright twigs) from dogwoods; prune or saw out all dead branches/twigs.

LEAD: SOMETIME this summer, K. Hovnanian Enterprises will complete its 30,000th home someplace along the East Coast between New Hampshire and Florida.
Like nearly all the others that have brought the Hovnanian company success as a home builder, it will be a town-house condominium in a growing outer suburb.

Steel and Glass Amid Greenery In La Villette
LEAD: LIKE a phoenix from the ashes, the hottest new attraction in Paris has risen on the site of the Fifth Republic's greatest financial scandal.
Where the city's stockyards and abattoirs stood in the 19th century, the de Gaulle government squandered a fortune to build new slaughterhouse facilities that were obsolete before the 1960's, when they were started.

Throwing Like a Girl
LEAD: To the Editor:


Partnership Study Makes a Case For Low-Rises
LEAD: WHEN government and private groups get together to build low-cost housing, one of the issues they face is what kind of housing makes the most economic sense.
The classic high-rise apartment building can put the most families on a given piece of land, but it costs more per unit, while the low-rise town home is cheaper but uses more land.


Joyner-Kersee Tops Herself, Again
LEAD: Jackie Joyner-Kersee completed her remarkable assault on another world record today in the heptathlon, finishing with 7,215 points at the United States track and field Olympic trials to become the first athlete to break 7,200 points, for her third world record in two years.


Headliners; At Odds
LEAD: The executive board of the teamsters' union picked William J. McCarthy as their new president last week, but it is uncertain how long Mr.
McCarthy will stay in the driver's seat.
The new head of the 1.7-million-member union defeated Weldon Mathis, the hand-picked successor to Jackie Presser, who died last weekend, in an election marked by rare - for the teamsters - open debate.

Mending Fence Posts
LEAD: Wobbly wooden fence posts are a nuisance and can lead to the loosening of additional fence parts.
Frequently, particularly if the fence is less than five years old, loose posts are the result of improper installation and can be corrected relatively easily.

LEAD: A 35-year-old Brooklyn woman walking home from work early yesterday morning was killed on a Manhattan sidewalk when she was struck on the head by a cinderblock that the police said they thought was thrown from the top of a two-story garage.

Optimism on Allison
LEAD: Doctors have told Bobby Allison's family that the stock-car driver should completely recover from injuries suffered in a June 19 crash, his brother-in-law, Donnie Johnson, said. ''It wouldn't surprise me if he sat down in one this year; I'm not saying to compete, but maybe to practice or start a race and then park it,'' Johnson told The Birmingham News.

Jet Lag
LEAD: To the Editor: In response to Practical Traveler of May 22 on jet lag, a phenomenon or myth, depending on one's view: It is the latter in my case.
I have made a fair number of trans-ocean flights and have never experienced it.


Romancing The Soul In the Bois
LEAD: WHEN I was 19 and full of romantic notions, I made the mistake of visiting the Bois de Boulogne in the warm sun of a summer afternoon.
This, I decided then and there, was how life was supposed to be.
This was Culture.
This was Civilization.
To my fevered, innocent eye, the Bois was the perfect embodiment of the dream picture I had painted in my mind of France.

LEAD: THE GLITTERY shades of eyeshadow, the scarlet bullets of lipstick, the clouds of pink blusher - all are mere frippery compared to loose powder. Hans Holbein: A Great Poet Of Equanimity
LEAD: Some exhibitions are born great and could hardly be improved upon.
One of them is the exhibition of drawings by Hans Holbein the younger that can be seen at the Kunstmuseum in Basel through Sept. 4.
What makes it unique is that for the first and quite probably the only time the two great surviving collections of portrait drawings by Holbein have been brought together under one roof.

Five years and who knows how much suffering later, the Reagan Administration is on its way out, power is shifting and the political climate has changed.

LEAD: If one didn't pay close attention, the new Mostly Mozart season's Thursday evening concert went amiably by.

The latter was by Vivaldi and Telemann, played by Christopher Hogwood and a small band of local musicians known as Music on Original Instruments.

THE REGION: On the Streets; Unlocking the Gridlock for Those Who Must Drive
LEAD: IN a city increasingly composed of rich and poor, New York's streets often seem like one of the last bastions of democracy, equalizing all in immobility and gridlock.
But with many of the city's arteries clogged most of the time, and with Federal air-quality standards looming that could mandate sharply reduced automobile emissions by the early 1990's, traffic officials are being forced to consider alternatives that could strike at the very heart of the cherished tradition of driving one's own car even in midtown Manhattan.

LEAD: OPTIMISM seems to have changed camps, leaving North America for Europe.
As the Reagan era glides bumpily to an end, America appears to be in an introspective and self-doubting mood, fretting about symptoms of decline.
But the Old Continent, both its capitalist and Communist halves, is palpably gripped by an unusual sense that momentous changes may be just over the horizon.

Major Patterns in the Festival Tapestry
LEAD: Some of the male and female partners in William Forsythe's ballet ''Love Songs'' - presented by the Frankfurt Ballet at the First New York International Festival of the Arts last month - got no closer to each other than the flashing of dirty looks.
And for those who did make contact, it was not by flinging themselves through the air with seeming abandon and then, in the nick of time, being spared a stay in an orthopedic bed by the fireman's catch of a muscular companion; contact was made with a vicious slap or a thrown fist.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  COGS IN THE WHEEL: The Formation of Soviet Man.
By Mikhail Heller. (Knopf, $22.95.) Mikhail Heller, a Soviet emigre and author who has lived in Paris since 1969, has produced a textbook for the school of thought that depicts the Soviet Union as a great machine.
Chapter by didactic chapter, he lays out the ideology and methods whereby, in his view, the Soviet citizen is denatured, beguiled, infantilized and frightened into becoming little more than a willing cog.

LEAD: Sometimes I wonder if I am, all unaware, living in one of those reverse-image universes that science-fiction writers assure us exist out there.
You know, the world in which large dogs and cats keep cute people as pets or the one where everyone dies at birth and then grows inexorably younger unto eternity.


LET SINGAPORE BE SINGAPORE
LEAD: Ian Buruma sees Singapore as a ''city of homeowners . . . a city without slums, where women can safely walk the streets at night, in many ways an ideal society,'' but suggests that the absence of Western-style democracy makes Singapore a ''city of fear'' (''Singapore,'' June 12).
Having years of exposure to Singapore (and a professional relationship with its Development Bank), we have a different perspective.

THE NATION: The Drought of '88; Candidates Gauge the Implications Of the Heartland's Dry Summer
LEAD: AT least twice before in this century, crop damage from drought has coincided with a Presidential election campaign.
In 1936 and 1956, drought became a national political issue, and, according to agricultural historians and students of the Presidency, 1988 looks no different.

The B-1 Comes Home to Roost
LEAD: President Reagan revived the B-1 bomber as the centerpiece of his strategic modernization program and deluged the Pentagon with money as a symbol of military resolve.

The Yucatan
LEAD: To the Editor: In reference to the letter by Prof.
Evon Z. Vogt Jr. (Travel, April 24), which recently came to my attention: The tendency to refer in English to the Yucatan is perfectly normal and correct.
Just as we say the Ukraine, the Bronx, the Yukon, we say the Yucatan.
Spanish usage has no bearing on it.

Soviets Decrease Use of Navy And Curb Overseas Exercises
LEAD: The Soviet Union has cut back on overseas naval deployments and has stopped carrying out ambitious naval exercises far from Soviet territory, according to top American and Soviet military officials.


Christa Ludwig Sings Schubert's 'Winterreise'
LEAD: A cautiously worded paragraph of justification in the program notes for Deutsche Grammophon's new ''Winterreise'' recording (423 366-2) reminds us that in recent decades it has been considered unusual or inappropriate for a female singer to perform this work.
Christa Ludwig is not the first woman to record Schubert's great cycle in the postwar era, but she is certainly the most celebrated, and hers is the first to be issued on a major label.

LEAD: Wobbly wooden fence posts are a nuisance and can lead to the loosening of additional fence parts.

Review/Concert; Victor Borge's Melange Of Relics and Inspiration
LEAD: Victor Borge, at 79, remains the Heifetz of the malapropism; he doesn't do badly with the piano, either, and he controls an audience with impressive virtuosity.
On Friday evening, at the second of his seven Carnegie Hall shows, the audience was a ticklish one that at first seemed to find Mr.
Borge's presence alone sufficient reason to giggle, and for a while he played along happily with the crowd's mood.

Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about military contractors incorrectly described the Pentagon's actions against a company linked to the investigation of procurement fraud.
The Pentagon suspended a single unit of Varian Associates Inc., the Continental Electronics Division, from future military contracting work.

Pina Bausch Adds Humor To Her Palette
LEAD: The second half of ''Victor,'' a dance-theater piece by Pina Bausch, begins with a woman making exactly the same arm-rotating gestures that William Forsythe uses in ''Steptext.'' Encouraging News On Trade, Inflation
LEAD: Encouraging economic reports sent the dollar soaring.
The U.S. trade deficit rose slightly in May, to $10.93 billion.
Although higher than the revised $10.3 billion of April, it was the second-smallest imbalance in almost three years.
Imports rose 3.4 percent, to $37.6 billion, while exports also increased 2.3 percent, to $26.6 billion.

LEAD: There is no airplane on the roof of the new office tower at 17 State Street in lower Manhattan, and there are no neon tubes in the lobby, or gigantic clocks, funny benches or umbrellas out front.

LEAD: James LeMoyne's article ''Testifying to Torture'' (June 5), includes testimony of a sergeant in the Honduran Army who reports having been trained by the Central Intelligence Agency in Texas in various forms of psychological torture: forcing prisoners to stand for prolonged periods, keeping them naked in isolated cells.

Berwick
LEAD: To the Editor: Anne Wilson's article notes that Lindisfarne Castle is ''16th-century'' without further comment.

VIDEO Sorting Out Camcorders
LEAD: Nearly all the tourists stepping off the bus at a prominent New England vacation spot on the Fourth of July carried cameras.
The surprise was that, by a rough count, about one in five was a video camcorder - clear evidence that do-it-yourself video has become a common aspect of American life.
The travel season naturally heightens interest in these hi-tech mini-marvels, and it is estimated that nearly two million camcorders will be sold in the United States this year.

LEAD: Henry Aaron retired as a major-league baseball player in 1976 after hitting 755 home runs, more than anyone else in the history of the game.
Now 54 yeras old, he maintains ties to the Atlanta Braves by serving as director of player development, a job that allows enough time at home to give him and his wife, Billye, the chance to sample restaurants all over the Atlanta area.


FICTION
LEAD:  AMBUSH AT OSIRAK.
By Herbert Crowder. (Presidio, $18.95.) Basically, ''Ambush at Osirak'' is about hardware, the kind of hardware that kills - offensive weapons with cute names like Sidewinder and good-neighbor names like SAM.

LEAD: Aliza Sass Rubin, who founded the West Side Jewish Community Nursery School 10 years ago and directed it until her retirement last year, died early yesterday at her daughter's home in Connecticut, following a brief illness.

Decisions After the Vote
LEAD: Short of some startling event, the prospects are that foreign policy won't be a significant issue in the campaign.
Major foreign governments, the Soviet Union as well as allies, are unusually relaxed this year as they anticipate a new U.S. administration.
Despite Republican emphasis on Michael Dukakis's lack of foreign policy experience, the impression is that main policy lines have been set and won't change drastically whoever wins.

MAINSTREAM JAZZ IS ALIVE AND WELL IN TWO SERIES
LEAD: In the days when Be-bop was the new thing in jazz, people who liked traditional jazz used to be called moldy figs.
There's probably another derogatory name now for people who like be-bop, cool, New Orleans or any other mainstream jazz, but if so, it would have to apply to a lot of people.
For, to judge by the number and amount of record sales of older jazz, there are plenty of lovers of mainstream jazz out there.


RECAST IN STONE
LEAD: JUAN MONTOYA WAS LOOKING FOR LAND when he happened on this 1939 stone house.
Set amid 110 wooded acres in the Hudson Valley, the dilapidated structure was simply a building waiting to be renovated.
And renovate he did, but over time. ''I left the property alone for a year in order to understand the terrain during each season,'' says the interior designer.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Newspapers Seek to Widen Their Antitrust Exemption
LEAD: EUGENE CERVI, a crusading weekly newspaper publisher from Denver, made himself very unpopular in publishing circles in the late 1960's by railing against the newspaper industry's efforts to win Federal exemption from antitrust laws.
He did not care much for railroads, mining companies or big banks, either, but he held a special place in his spleen for big-city newspapers, including his two hometown competitors.


Castro Urges Sugar Gain
LEAD: President Fidel Castro wants Cuba to increase its revenue with a bigger sugar harvest next year, according to the official daily newspaper Granma.
At a Communist Party meeting on Friday, it said, he called for an increase to 8 million metric tons, from this year's estimated 7.3 million tons.

LEAD: Australia plans to propose a set of principles Monday to establish free global trade in services, including banking, insurance and transport.

LEAD: The hot, heavy air finally wore down Ron Guidry.

Texas Oil Spill Kills Wildlife
LEAD: A spill of more than 600,000 gallons of crude oil in the harbor has killed a small number of crabs, birds and other wildlife, state officials said.
Volunteers sounded a propane cannon and air horns Saturday to scare birds away from an oily marsh.
The spill occurred Wednesday when a tanker carrying oil from Scotland rammed a dock near the marsh.

Iroquois Bid for Portec
LEAD: Iroquois Brands Ltd. said Friday that it had offered to acquire Portec Inc. in a stock swap under which one Iroquois common share would be exchanged for five Portec common shares.
Iroquois, a holding company based in Greenwich, Conn., , said the offer would be subject to the refinancing of a bank loan on which Portec defaulted and on a satisfactory agreement with Portec's management.

LEAD: The vacant lots on Andrews Avenue in the Bronx are littered with collapsed baby carriages and crushed bottles.

POMP is as vigorous as the tree that grows in an Andrews Avenue courtyard.

LEAD: Tiffany's is ready.
All its salespeople have been instructed in basic Japanese, including counting.
The Fifth Avenue jeweler has laid in a trove of medium-sized, 18-karat-gold Elsa Peretti heart necklaces, which, at $350 apiece, are the single most popular item among Japanese customers.


GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
China and the Soviet Union increased trade by nearly a third in the first half of this year, compared with the corresponding period last year.
The Xinhua News Agency said China sold the Soviets $670 million worth of goods and imported $627 million worth from January to June in the largely barter trade.

LEAD: After more than two days of toil, engineers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida yesterday pinpointed the source of a leak in a small, hard-to-reach space shuttle fuel tank and struggled to find a way to fix it.

LEAD: When NBC goes to Seoul, South Korea, this summer to televise the Summer Olympics, 488 of the 1,100 people in its entourage will be technicians - camera operators and video crews.

Competition Grows in Paperback Business
LEAD: Sales of mass-market paperback books have been flat for three years, unsold paperbacks are being returned in record numbers and the outlook for the next several years is equally bleak.
In theory, then, mass-market publishers should be cutting back on the number of books they publish, and other publishing houses should be thankful they are not in such a cutthroat end of the business.

The reading is sponsored by the Polish Theater Institute and the Cultural Center of Southampton. ''Karpilewski'' is a comedy about a struggling poet who dies and is given a second chance at life and his career.

The move was aimed at allowing Lord, Einstein to participate in the competition for the I.B.M.

AMEV Holdings Inc., the United States arm of N.V.
AMEV, a Netherlands-based multinational financial services company, elected as a director Robert J. Blendon, the chairman of the department of health policy and management at the Harvard School of Public Health.


Sports World Specials; Matchless Future?
LEAD: The words ''match race,'' immediately evoke a sense of sadness in the minds of people in the horse racing world.


Philadelphia Journal; Reunion of Clan Marks A Heritage of 300 Years
LEAD: There has almost never been a Philadelphia without a Rittenhouse.
The name calls forth images of old money and low-key gentility.


A Sunday in the Park, With Music and Dance
LEAD: The Larocque Bey Dance Company performing yesterday at the Harlem Meer in Central Park, at 110th Street and Lenox Avenue, as part of the ''Musica Para Hot Sundays'' series of free outdoor performances. (NYT/Chester Higgins, Jr.)


Boxing; Hopson Fails to Make Team
LEAD: Ed Hopson, a 5-foot-4-inch perpetual motion fighter from St.
Louis, lost his place on the United States Olympic team when he was beaten by Kelcie Banks of Chicago in an unpopular decision on the last day of the Olympic boxoffs at Caesars Palace.


Cuomo Sees Risk in Arrest Of Brawley
LEAD: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that several factors - the public safety, the independence of the police and Constitutional protections such as the First Amendment -had outweighed the state's desire to arrest Tawana Brawley's mother, Glenda, for contempt of court when she left a Brooklyn church Saturday.


Jersey Grapples With High Cost Of Insuring Cars
LEAD: Even as the State Legislature has struggled unsuccessfully to reduce automobile insurance rates, New Jersey motorists have been battered by a succession of increases in the premiums they must pay.


Nigeria to Ban Cigarette Advertising
LEAD: Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, plans to prohibit cigarette advertising by the end of this year.


Tensions Within OPEC Heighten Oil Price War
LEAD: A widely anticipated collapse of production restraint within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has combined with political discord to clear the way for what many oil industry officials describe as a free fall in oil prices.


In the New Soviet Psyche, A Place Is Made for Freud
LEAD: Sigmund Freud, long scorned by Soviet doctors as a quack and by Communist ideologists as a heretic, is now being hailed as a visionary as a small band of psychiatrists here tries to give a society in turmoil new ways to understand itself.


New Product Plans at G.M.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation plans to devote a larger part of its capital spending to developing new products and will share more of those costs with high-technology suppliers, the company's president, Robert C. Stempel, said today.


Laura Gardner Is Wed To Mitchell B. Briskin
LEAD: The marriage of Laura Gardner to Mitchell Bruce Briskin took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
Frederic J. Gardner, in West Falmouth, Mass.
Katherine Norton, a justice of the peace, officiated.


Coke Earnings Increase 13.8%
LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company has reported that its second-quarter profit rose 13.8 percent, to $303.1 million, reflecting brisk domestic and overseas soft-drink sales.


A Sad Chapter Ends
LEAD: The long-running debate over whether and how to compensate the Japanese-Americans who were interned in relocation camps in World War II is about to come to an end.
A House-Senate conference committee has reached agreement on a new bill, and President Reagan, who was earlier urged by the Justice Department to veto the measure, is now reported as all but certain to sign it.


May Stores Talks of Sale Of Mall Stake
LEAD: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it was holding discussions with several parties to sell 50 percent of its interest in 28 shopping centers across the country.


Music in Full Bloom At Union Square Park
LEAD: Free music and colorful flowers will be featured at the Second Union Square Park Full Bloom Festival, beginning today in the park, which is situated between 14th and 17th Streets, from Park Avenue South to Broadway.
The annual festival, sponsored by the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation, will run through July 29 and will include performances of jazz, country, rhythm-and-blues, new-wave and African-Caribbean music.


After Years of Soviet Chill, West Germans Warm to Gorbachev
LEAD: Across Western Europe, the vaunted ''new thinking'' of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, is stirring sympathy and softening perceptions of a Soviet military threat.
But perhaps nowhere is popular enthusiasm for Mr.
Gorbachev as strong as in West Germany.


Man Asserts AIDS Illness Was Revealed
LEAD: A man with AIDS-related complex has filed a formal complaint that his medical confidentiality was violated by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and the city Human Rights Commission.

LEAD:  Debt


4 G.I.'s Wounded in Honduras
LEAD: Four American soldiers were wounded early today when attackers opened fire and threw grenades at them as they left a discotheque in the northern Honduran city of San Pedro Sula, the police said.


China Warns On Price Abuse
LEAD: China's Prime Minister Li Peng warned that abuses of the country's price reform program could threaten social stability, the Government's news agency said today.

LEAD: Arthur Jamison is a highly successful criminal lawyer who would like to get rid of his wife.
Permanently.

The strategy at this confabulation of concealment is to hide the changes that the election of its nominees would bring.
Here are a few of the questions being evaded: 1.
Why does Jesse Jackson refuse to make clear what his constituency requires in return for its enthusiastic support?

Soviets Print the Works of a Dissident Poet
LEAD: A popular weekly printed poetry by the writer Yuli M. Daniel today, becoming the first Soviet publication in more than 20 years to publish the verse of a man who was jailed in one of the most celebrated trials of Soviet intellectuals in decades.

LEAD: After more than quarter of a century behind prison bars, Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela, a legend in his own lifetime, is sometimes portrayed as holding the Pretoria Government captive.


Gallant Elephant, 82, Is Dead in Sri Lanka
LEAD: White flags flew today over Kandy, the old Buddhist capital, as the nation mourned Raja, the elephant who was called the country's ''most venerated moving monument.''

LEAD: Those thirsting for renewed confrontation between Washington and Managua have got their wish.
The extremists on both sides are regaining the upper hand.
And while it seems too late to hope that the Reagan Administration would begin serious negotiations, it's far too early in the present turbulence to consider renewing military aid to the


Sandinistas' Rationale; They Say Crackdown Against Opposition Was Necessary to Derail Lethal Campaign
LEAD: As of a week ago, the contra guerrilla movement appeared to be in disarray.
Congress was not disposed to provide it with new aid, and the Administration was reduced to seeking diplomatic backing from Guatemala, Costa Rica and other Latin American countries that have made clear they will not provide it.


Man Shot Dead in Queens
LEAD: A 22-year-old man was shot to death last night during a dispute with a gang of Korean youths outside a bowling alley in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.
The victim, Veerakit Chisitichai, was from Thailand and was thought to have been studying in New York.
The police said Mr.
Chisitichai, of 42-19 Ketchum Street in Elmhurst, argued with the youths inside the Ace Bowling Alley, 82-02 45th Avenue.


Long-Term Dangers in Dollar Rise
LEAD: The continuing rally in the dollar has had short-term benefits, including making imports cheaper and reducing the prospect of higher inflation.
But it also hides real long-term dangers, including a slowdown in economic growth and a widening, rather than narrowing, United States trade deficit, according to three new economic studies.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hathaway to TBWA
LEAD: TBWA Advertising has been assigned the C. F. Hathaway Shirt Company by Warnaco Men's Apparel, Warnaco's president, Robert R. Lindley said.
He said no budget had been set.
Warnaco's seven-year relationship with Eric Mower &amp; Associates has ended, Mr.
Lindley added.


Hot and Cold, Then and Now
LEAD: Once, summer in New York City was the season for staying outdoors.
People who had fire escapes perched on the landings; people who didn't lounged in the parks.
At night, strollers moved slowly along streets still hot from the sun, staring somnolently into shop windows.
It was the era of the tangled sheet, the lukewarm shower and the long pause in front of the open refrigerator door.


Ex-Sailor, a Suspected Spy, Granted Asylum by Soviets
LEAD: A former Navy enlisted man who is the subject of an espionage investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been granted political asylum in the Soviet Union, the Soviet press reported today.


Blackmun Has Sharp Opinions Of Colleagues
LEAD: Justice Harry A. Blackmun singled out colleagues on the United States Supreme Court by name for personal criticism in a speech in which he expressed concern about bloc voting by President Reagan's judicial appointees.


Question Box
LEAD:  QUESTION: How long ago was the spitball made illegal in the major leagues?

LEAD: The venerable Mark Cross, supplier of leather goods for the well-to-do, is getting a new print ad campaign from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, with the theme line ''No wonder Americans have such style.
They have Mark Cross.'' To accompany this uplifting line, the agency has come up with black-and-white photographs against which new products, in color, will stand out.

LEAD: An Israeli soldier shot and killed a Palestinian who was reportedly trying to grab his rifle in the Israeli town of Petah Tiqva today, the police said.

LEAD: John R. May, the executive director of the San Francisco Foundation from 1948 to 1973, died of a heart attack July 13 while vacationing near Ketchum, Idaho.
He was 79 years old and lived in San Rafael, Calif, When Mr.
May was appointed the first director of the San Francisco Foundation in 1948, the philanthropy had assets of less than $1 million.

Harold Goodbody, 82, Who Led Wall Street Firm That Collapsed
LEAD: Harold P. Goodbody, who headed Wall Street's fifth-largest stock brokerage firm when it collapsed in a paper-work morass in 1970, died of brain cancer Sunday at the Sweetbrook Nursing Home in Williamstown, Mass.
He was 82 years old and for most of his career was a resident of Florham Park, N.J.

HELPED DEVELOP THE ATOMIC BOMB
LEAD: Dr.
Herbert Lawrence Anderson, a physicist who was a pioneer in the development of nuclear energy and the atomic bomb, died of berylliosis on Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M.
He was 74 years old and had contracted the lung disease in early nuclear experiments with radon and beryllium.

Prime Computer Adds to Series 50
LEAD: Prime Computer Inc. announced a midrange superminicomputer intended for use in offices and a more powerful machine for use in computer rooms.
It said the two new members of its series 50 family of computers, the midrange 4450 and the high-end 6150, would be available immediately.
Superminicomputers, very fast and powerful computers one step below mainframes, are most commonly used in specialized scientific or engineering applications.


PC Makers' Campaign in Schools
LEAD: In a classroom at Stevens Creek Elementary School in Cupertino, Calif., students in Barbara Bayha's class use personal computers for practically all their learning activities.
The second and third graders practice math, write and edit short stories, and solve tricky logic problems posed in the form of a game.


Japan Car Exports Fall
LEAD: Japanese vehicle exports fell 5.7 percent in June from a year earlier, to 479,127 units - 351,948 cars, down 3.9 percent, and 127,179 commercial vehicles, down 10.2 percent.
The export total was down from 482,638 in May.

LEAD: Carl Lewis made the United States Olympic team tonight in his second event by winning a marvelous long jump battle from Larry Myricks.

Diane Dixon of Brooklyn, a gold medalist in 1984, made the team again.

How to Help Mozambique's Refugees
LEAD: One of the world's little-noticed tragedies plays out in Mozambique.
Torn by 13 years of civil war, this southern African nation has produced more refugees than any country today except Afghanistan.
Starvation threatens a far greater proportion of Mozambicans than Ethiopians, whose despair is more widely known.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about insurance rates in New Jersey incorrectly described insurance agents' compensation for writing automobile policies.
The agents receive 9 percent of the annual premium, but must return part of the commission if a motorist drops the policy in less than a year.

LEAD: With an eye to eventual admission into the European Community, Turkey has taken steps in recent years to dismantle its apparatus of official repression.

Censorship forbids publicizing ''racialist'' statements or offending Turkish nationalism.

Major 'Greenhouse' Impact is Unavoidable, Experts Say
LEAD: Momentum toward a global warming caused by the greenhouse effect is now so great that there is no way to avoid a significant rise in temperature in the coming century, many scientists around the world now agree.

LEAD: The newborn found abandoned in the restroom of a jetliner will remain in the care of San Mateo County at least until Friday, a juvenile court commissioner ruled today in rejecting the father's effort to obtain custody.

LEAD: The Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum producer, yesterday reported second-quarter net income of $237.6 million, or $2.69 a share, in contrast to a $91.2 million loss in the period last year.

LEAD: Frank Gullino, a violinist, died of bladder cancer yesterday at his home in Lido Beach, L.I.

LEAD: Two New York helicopter companies voluntarily agreed yesterday to ground their aircraft while the Federal Aviation Administration investigates the operations of each company and inspects each helicopter.


Utility Net Up In Midwest
LEAD: The American Electric Power Company yesterday reported earnings of $118.8 million for the second quarter, which ended June 30, up 1.3 percent, from $117.3 million in the second quarter last year.
Earnings per share remained at 61 cents, the same as last year.
Operating revenue for the Columbus, Ohio, holding company dipped to $1.1 billion, a decrease of 3.6 percent from the quarter last year.

LEAD: The International Herald Tribune yesterday transferred its American printing site from Miami to Long Island City, Queens, in an effort to improve distribution of the newspaper in the biggest cities in the United States.

Portec Rejects Bid
LEAD: Portec Inc. said it had rejected a bid from Iroquois Brands Ltd., a holding company based in Greenwich, Conn.
Iroquois had offered to acquire Portec, a manufacturer of construction and materials-handling equipment, in a stock swap with an indicated value of about $12.6 million.
Iroquois offered to exchange one share of its common stock for every five shares of Portec's approximately 2.8 million shares of common stock outstanding.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  COMPANIES  The I.R.S. has billed ARCO for more than $1.1 billion in back taxes and interest.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about growth in the Atlanta metropolitan area misstated the political plans of Michael Lomax, the Fulton County Commission chairman.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about remarks in St.

LEAD: A group of murals thought to be the first and among the most important abstract wall paintings in the United States, and long believed lost or destroyed, have been found and are being restored under the supervision of the New York City Housing Authority, which owns them.


3 Indicted In Swindle On Properties
LEAD: Three Brooklyn residents have been indicted on charges that they forged deeds on buildings and attempted to sell them in a scheme that officials said involved 38 properties valued at more than $3.7 million.
