Japanese Company Acquires 9.6% of USG
LEAD: The Settsu Corporation, Japan's largest paper board producer, said today that it had acquired a 9.6 percent stake in the USG Corporation for ''investment purposes only.''


3 Guardian Angels Arrested in Attack on Trainee
LEAD: Three Guardian Angels were arrested Monday night after a trainee in the red-bereted civilian patrol group complained to the police that he had been assaulted by other Guardian Angels with fists and a sneaker.


Leonard Seeks Title
LEAD: The World Boxing Council has approved a possible fight between Sugar Ray Leonard and Don Lalonde of Canada for the new supermiddleweight crown. ''The executive committee of the W.B.C. has voted in favor of the fight, requiring, of course, as the organization's regulation provides, an exhaustive medical examination before giving the definitive authorization,'' the statement said yesterday.


Pacific Bell Seeking Change
LEAD: Pacific Bell, breaking from tradition, has proposed to give up its monopoly on local toll calls in exchange for reduced state regulation.
The telephone company called its proposal ''the most significant change since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984.''

Market for Swaps Totaled $1.1 Trillion at End of 1987
LEAD: The market for interest-rate and currency swaps totaled about $1.1 trillion at the end of 1987, remaining one of the fastest-growing sectors of the financial markets, according to a recent survey by the International Swap Dealers Association.


Honeywell Profits Drop
LEAD: Honeywell Inc. today posted a 41.8 percent drop in its second-quarter profit, mainly because of $43 million in one-time charges and accounting changes.
Honeywell said its net income fell to $31.6 million, or 75 cents a share, from $54.3 million, or $1.21 a share, in second quarter 1987.
Sales rose 11.5 percent, to $1.75 billion, from $1.57 billion in the 1987 quarter.


MOSCOW PROPOSES TO REMOVE RADAR CRITICIZED BY U.S.
LEAD: The Soviet Union said today that it would dismantle a disputed radar complex in Siberia if Washington and Moscow resolve their differences at the Geneva arms talks over the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.


MELANGE OF POP, ROCK AND SOUL
LEAD: Toure Kunda, a nine-member, Paris-based band led by three Senegalese brothers, has become one of Europe's most popular African bands by annexing bits of American, British and Caribbean rock.
At a packed Sounds of Brazil last Tuesday, Toure Kunda relied on its most internationalized repertory for an early set that was enjoyable but slightly bland.


North Seeks Trial Delay
LEAD: A lawyer for Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North, retired, of the Marine Corps, said today that he would seek a delay in Mr.
North's trial in the Iran-contra case, now set to begin on Sept. 20.


Giants' Rookie Is Versatile
LEAD: The numbers have not been kind to Danta Whitaker.
During his senior year at Mississippi Valley State College, the tight end caught just one pass.
His team won only 1 of 11 games.

Milton Krims, 84, Dies; Wrote for Film and TV
LEAD: Milton Krims, a screenwriter, died of pneumonia on July 11 at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif.
He was 84 years old and had suffered from Parkinson's disease for many years.


Japan's Banks: Top 10 in Deposits
LEAD: The world's 10 largest banks, based on deposits, are now all Japanese, according to a survey published today by the American Banker.


Steroid Directive
LEAD: In a 15-page directive sent to all 28 National Football League teams, Commissioner Pete Rozelle warns that any player who tests positive for steroids for a second time will be subject to discipline by the commissioner. ''Each instance this year of a second positive test will be handled on a case-by-case basis,'' according to the memo.

Soccer Crisis Over
LEAD: The Major Indoor Soccer League, saying that its latest crisis is over, will now concentrate on regular league matters such as scheduling and ticket sales, Commisssioner Bill Kentling said yesterday.
The comments came a day after the M.I.S.L. and the players association agreed to further cuts in the salary cap deemed necessary for survival by some owners.

Solving a Quality Control Problem
LEAD: Trying to find the cause of defects in the paint on an mini-van hood, engineers identified seven possible causes.
In a traditional approach, bottom, extensive experiments in which each possibility is investigated one by one would be conducted, involving as many as 500 different hoods.
Using the Taguchi method, top, a brainstorming session is followed by a few experiments with about 40 hoods in which several factors are changed simultaneously, their selection based on statistical techniques.

At the end of the 1932 Chicago meeting that first nominated Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Mr.

Christian Town in Lebanon Besieged
LEAD: Moslem gunmen have attacked a Christian town in northern Lebanon, near the border with Syria, the local Christian radio reported today.


No Sign of Slowing Down for Moses
LEAD: He has won every Olympic gold medal and every world championship he has tried for.
He has broken the world record four times and has held it for 12 years.
For a span of 9 years 9 months 9 days, he went 122 races (107 of them finals) in his event without a loss.
He has become an American folk hero, a man of regal dignity.


U.S. SAYS TEHERAN WILL HONOR TRUCE
LEAD: American officials said today that they believed Iran would soon observe a cease-fire in its war with Iraq despite a new outbreak of fighting between the two countries.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled in Manhattan yesterday that Nicaragua could not obtain almost $900,000 held in the United States for a Nicaraguan steel company that was confiscated by the Sandinista Government.


Slight Vindication for Mr. Meese
LEAD: The long-awaited independent counsel's report on Edwin Meese says two things about the departing Attorney General: He should not be criminally prosecuted, but his actions were highly questionable.
The report gives fresh evidence that the nation's top law enforcement officer was inattentive to the ethics of his trade.


A Portrait Of Tastes In Wine
LEAD: DESPITE a 1 percent reduction in wine consumption nationwide last year and a continuing decline of grape acreage in California, the volume of chardonnay planted there reached an all-time high in 1987, a leading California-oriented trade publication reports.

LEAD: The Los Angeles office of D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles has chalked up its third big victory for 1988.

LEAD: HEADING south toward Montgomery, Ala., from his home in Richmond, Jack Van Brockle decided, for old times' sake, to stop off in Atlanta for a chili dog and an ''F.O.'' -a frosted orange - at the Varsity drive-in.

LEAD: Frank E. Basil, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Frank E. Basil Inc., an engineering and architectural firm based in Washington, died of a heart attack Sunday while sailing off the coast of Sardinia.
He was 75 years old and lived in Washington.

Edelman Reduces Stake in Payless
LEAD: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, has decreased his stake in Payless Cashways Inc. to 4.8 percent from 6.1 percent.

Edelman had been thinking of trying to take over.


Palestinian Slain While Biking in Jerusalem
LEAD: A Palestinian youth died today after he was shot in the chest while riding a bicycle, the authorities said.
Arabs said the youth was shot by soldiers, but the army said it was not involved in the killing.


Gastineau Gets Some Encouragement
LEAD: When Mark Gastineau strolled into a Jets film session Monday night, Wally Chambers was among the first to greet him.
When Gastineau arrived for his first day of training camp this morning at Hofstra University - four days before the veterans were scheduled to report - Chambers was there, too, with open arms.

Dorothy C. Finkelhor, College Founder, 86
LEAD: Dorothy Cimberg Finkelhor, founder and first president of Point Park College in Pittsburgh, died Tuesday at her home in Ocean Ridge, Fla., the college announced.
She was 86 years old.

Jorge Lozano and Christo Van Rensburg, seeded players who had been having problems on Monday night when rain interrupted play, rallied for victory yesterday.

LEAD: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it was undertaking several ''corrective'' actions in response to a Government investigation of the company's military contracting practices.


Police Officers Facing Charges On Co-op Forms
LEAD: Thirty-seven New York City police officers falsified or misreported their incomes in order to be able to live in a subsidized Queens apartment complex, a senior police official said yesterday.

LEAD: A stable-like smell sours the air in the basement room of the Massachusetts Correctional Institution at Concord, a former office that now houses 24 men who share one toilet and one window.

LEAD: HIS silent partner never stopped talking.
His telephone never stopped ringing.
His waiters never sat down.
And by the end of the night, more than 100 people had bid him ''Buona sera,'' with vows to return.


U.N. Council Asks End To Hostilities in the Gulf
LEAD: The Security Council called on Iraq and Iran to ''exercise maximum restraint'' after stepped-up Iraqi air raids today on Iranian industrial installations.
The Iraqi attacks came a day after Teheran said it had accepted a United Nations cease-fire resolution in the Persian Gulf war.


Texas Bank's New Loss
LEAD: The First Republicbank Corporation, which is in the midst of a bailout by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, declared a loss of $758 million for the second quarter of 1988, the company said today.
The company recorded a loss of $1.5 billion in the first quarter of this year and a loss of $313.2 million in the second quarter of 1987.

LEAD: Prosecutors cross-examining the final witness in the Wedtech racketeering trial yesterday dealt a blow to efforts by Representative Mario Biaggi and his son, Richard, to show that a transfer of Wedtech stock from son to father was a gift.

Stores Plan Fall Strategy To Woo Buyers
LEAD: THE American fashion world has been in turmoil for nearly a year.
The decline of the dollar, coupled with diminishing supplies of silk and wool yarns, caused prices to rise.
Retail sales of women's apparel plummeted.
Large companies engaged in a frenzy of mergers and acquisitions, which placed diverse stores under the control of a few huge corporations and put thousands of executives out of work.

LEAD: When Administrations change, United States ambassadors around the world routinely submit their resignations for the new President to accept or reject.

LEAD: Alain Chevrier, who started last season as the No. 1 goaltender for the Devils, will be starting this one with the Winnipeg Jets.

Tom Goldstein Named Journalism School Dean
LEAD: Tom Goldstein, a former reporter for The New York Times and New York Newsday and press secretary to Mayor Koch, has been named dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California in Berkeley, it was announced yesterday.
He succeeds Ben Bagdikian, a Pulitzer Prize-winning media commentator who has headed the school since 1985 and who will return to teaching after a sabbatical year.

LEAD: A 4-year-old girl missing for six weeks before she was found hidden in a pit beneath a church was reported in good condition today.


Man Held in Baby's Slaying
LEAD: A 34-year-old Newburgh man was arrested today in the fatal stabbing Thursday of a North Albany baby and a sexual attack on the infant' 5-year-old sister, the police said.
The man, Alfred Hardy, who, the police said, was the boyfriend of the baby's mother, Sandra Bosh, was charged with plunging a knife into the head of the babv, 10-month-old Samuel Gist, and assaulting his sister, Sannetta Stallings.

15 Hurt in French Crash
LEAD: A train moving at 30 miles an hour hit another train stopped with mechanical problems today and 15 people were reported wounded.
The state-run train authority said the conductor of the moving train had failed to heed a yellow warning signal to slow down.

LEAD: Consumer prices jumped 19 percent in the last year, the Government announced today, acknowledging the biggest such rise since China introduced market reforms a decade ago.

With the encouragement of a ranking Florida Congressman on a military spending subcommittee, they chose to locate their plant in his district.

Vehicle Sales Seen Rising
LEAD: The Commerce Department expects total sales of cars and trucks in the United States to rise steadily in the next few years, from 15.5 million in 1988 to 16.6 million in 1991, the director of the department's motor vehicle division said today.
Albert Warner, speaking to the Automotive News World Congress, also predicted that the Japanese share of the United States market would rise to 33 percent in 1991, from about 26 percent in 1987.


Delegate Collapses and Dies
LEAD: An Ohio member of the Rules Committee of the Democratic National Convention collapsed on a dance floor at his hotel Monday and died shortly afterward of a heart attack, party officials said.


Interco Shares Up In Heavy Trading
LEAD: The stock price of Interco Inc. rose yesterday despite generally lower prices on the New York Stock Exchange, after a Wall Street analyst estimated the value of the company's planned restructuring at $2.35 billion.

Excerpts From Jackson's Speech: Pushing Party to Find Common Ground
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of the speech by Jesse Jackson to the Democratic Convention last night, as recorded by The New York Times:


Company Logos, Signifying Nothing
LEAD: One of the mysterious compulsions of modern corporate life is the recurrent itch to convert familiar company logotypes into lifeless blobs.
Since the companies are willing to pay upward of six figures for this, they obviously don't do it casually.
But to the untrained eye, the reasoning - and sometimes the results - are hard to grasp.


WINE TALK
LEAD: SHOULD American wine makers emulate the French?


SUMMERTIME BRINGS FRESH RASPBERRIES IN PINTS AND PIES
LEAD: IT'S the season for fresh raspberries.
Half pints are $2.50 at farm stands and green markets in and around New York; fancy groceries sell them for $3.98.


Bastia Journal; In Napoleon's Homeland, a Rare Summer of Peace
LEAD: The violent few who want Corsica to secede from France have laid down their guns for the summer, permitting tourists to splash in the glistening Mediterranean or wander in the craggy mountains without being reminded of political grievances.


Yanks Get Caught In Ranger Deluge
LEAD: The Yankees' only real ally last night was the rain.
But even though it poured for more than two hours -and even though most in the crowd of 27,456 were chased home by the fifth inning - the two separate showers were no help.

LEAD: Sinkholes were discovered in the outfield at Riverfront Stadium before tonight's game, sending the grounds people scrambling with spades and scissors and buckets of sand.

Philip Morris Profit Up 31.7%
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies, the cigarette, beer and food concern, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 31.7 percent, to $627 million, or $2.68 a share, from $476 million, or $2 a share, a year earlier.
Revenues rose 10 percent, to $7.8 billion from $7.1 billion.


Canada and Iran to Restore Full Relations After 8 Years
LEAD: Canada and Iran have agreed to resume full diplomatic relations after eight years, the Canadian Government announced Monday.

LEAD: Italy, the home of macaroni since the days of Marco Polo, is bracing for what purists say will be an invasion of rubbery ravioli, squishy spaghetti and, heaven forbid, limp linguine.

About New York; A Hard Choice Between Lunch And Eviction
LEAD: It has been a long, mean food fight for the few old residents of St.
Margaret's House who have refused to take a mandatory daily meal in the cafeteria these last years, and the other day the management served notices to terminate their tenancies.
These people are fairly poor, and they find the prospect of losing their shelter breathtaking, but they say they'll not, under any circumstances, give in and come to supper.

LEAD: The Beacon Theater, that dazzling movie palace on Broadway and 75th Street, has been saved from conversion into a disco.
How can it best be used in the future?

The company easily filled the cavernous stage and theater, which was packed with cheering fans and bemused newcomers.

LEAD: Once again the British and the Americans are teaming up to revive Clifford Odets.

A couple of years ago, public television's ''American Playhouse'' and John Jacobs, producing and directing for England's HTV, worked together on ''Rocket to the Moon'' starring John Malkovich and Judy Davis.

Samuel Ruben, 88, an Inventor Noted for Electrochemical Work
LEAD: Samuel Ruben, a scientist who had no formal education beyond high school but whose inventions led to more than 300 patents, including the alkaline battery now in wide use, died Saturday in Milwaukie, Ore., where he lived in retirement.
He was 88 years old and was a longtime resident of New Rochelle, N.Y., before moving to the West Coast three years ago.

Shearson to Buy First Capital Stake
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. said it had agreed to acquire a 42 to 44 percent equity interest in the First Capital Holdings Corporation, a Los Angeles-based financial services concern, which provides some of Shearson's customers with insurance products.
First Capital bought E. F. Hutton's life insurance unit in May 1986.


Argentine Trade Surplus
LEAD: Rising exports and falling imports helped Argentina's trade surplus increase 67.5 percent in the first four months of 1988, according to official figures published today.
The National Statistics Institute said exports rose to $2.13 billion - 7.7 percent above the corresponding period in 1987 - while imports fell 5 percent, to $1.55 billion.


More Medical Waste Shuts 2 Beaches on S.I.
LEAD: Two Staten Island beaches were closed for the seventh straight day yesterday after more medical waste washed up with the tide, a spokesman for the New York City Health Department said.

Milk Forecast Reduced
LEAD: Milk output may not rise this year as much as expected, according to the Agriculture Department. ''For all of 1988, milk production probably will total about 1 percent more than 1987's 142.5 billion pounds,'' the department's Economic Research Service said Tuesday.

F.C.C. Approves 2 Settlements by Gencorp
LEAD: In a decision that may provide the model for resolving the highest-stakes licensing dispute in broadcasting history, the Federal Communications Commission approved settlement agreements today that clear the way for Gencorp Inc. to sell a Los Angeles television station and a Memphis radio station for about $217.5 million.


Dr. Geoffrey Bourne, Anatomist; Primate Expert a Prolific Writer
LEAD: Dr.
Geoffrey H. Bourne, an anatomist and expert on primates, died of heart failure Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan.
He was 78 years old and maintained homes in Atlanta and on the island of Grenada.

LEAD: Some rock went batty in the late 1970's, and leather-winged insectivores are still circling the belfry of Pere Ubu.

LEAD: A Federal prosecutor said today that eight men had been charged with pro-Libyan activities in the United States and that one suspect had been involved in an assassination plot aimed at a ''high Government official.''


American Soldiers in Panama Exchange Fire With Intruders
LEAD: American soldiers exchanged gunfire with unidentified intruders spotted twice at a United States military installation near the Panama Canal, the United States Southern Command reported today.

LEAD: The State Health Department received complaints about conditions in what it called an unlicensed nursing home in Harlem more than a year ago and sent inspectors to the site, but the department did not shut it down until Tuesday, officials said, because of confusion.

But hunger isn't one of them.
The United States has shown it knows how to feed its poor.

'20/20' Staff Reported Seething Over Changes
LEAD: Last spring, as some producers of the ABC prime-time news magazine ''20/20'' were preparing a 10th-anniversary broadcast, half the 25 producers on the program were quietly looking for work elsewhere, notably at CBS News, members of the ''20/ 20'' staff said yesterday.


Tour de France; Leader Fails His Drug Test
LEAD: The leader of the Tour de France, the world's major bicycle race, was officially notified this morning that he tested positive for drugs last Friday.


Milton Krasner, Cinematographer, 84
LEAD: Milton Krasner, a cinematographer whose work on the 1954 film ''Three Coins in the Fountain'' earned him an Academy Award, died of heart failure Saturday.
He was 84 years old.
The films on which Mr.
Krasner worked included ''The Invisible Man,'' ''An Affair to Remember,'' ''All About Eve,'' ''The Seven Year Itch,'' ''Bells Are Ringing,'' ''The Sandpiper'' and ''How the West Was Won.


Dun &amp; Bradstreet Profit Rises 3.9%
LEAD: The Dun &amp; Bradstreet Corporation, a leading marketer of business information, yesterday reported a slight increase in its second-quarter profit but said its earnings were depressed by the cost of a a recent acquisition.


The Democrats in Atlanta; Atlanta Fire Officials Close Coliseum Again
LEAD: As Democrats prepared to nominate Michael S. Dukakis tonight, city fire officials closed the overcrowded Omni Coliseum for the second straight night.


Pakistani Is Criticized Over Date for Elections
LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan today ordered national elections to be held Nov. 16, but was quickly attacked by critics for delaying the voting beyond a deadline set by the Constitution.


Sandinistas Say 11 Contras And 7 Civilians Died in Raids
LEAD: The Defense Ministry said today that 11 rebels and seven civilians were killed in attacks this week that violated a cease-fire between the contras and the Sandinista Government.


Miriam Gurko, Author, 73
LEAD: Miriam Gurko, an author of books for young adults, died of pneumonia July 3 at Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital.
She was 78 years old.

Corrections
LEAD: A film review of ''Midnight Run'' yesterday misidentified the director of ''Beverly Hills Cop II.'' He is Tony Scott, not Martin Brest.

LEAD: Teddy bears are the newest tool of the police in metropolitan Miami, who plan to stock two of them in each patrol car.


Head of Hoover Center To Quit Post Next Year
LEAD: W. Glenn Campbell, who for nearly three decades has led the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, a font of conservative ideas and leaders in the Reagan Administration, says he will step down next year.


Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: THE temperaments of parents and children move together and apart like the melodic lines of a fugue, sometimes creating harmony, sometimes dissonance.
As with music, the tension developed during one stage can make the resolution and passage to the next stage all the sweeter.

LEAD: Q. The grout between the floor slates in my kitchen and entry hall is dirty and stained.
I want to clean the grout, or have it replaced if that's the only way.
How can this be done?

Chairman and Chief Resigns at Foxmeyer
LEAD: William Y. Tauscher has resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Foxmeyer Corporation, a big drug distributor that he co-founded and sold to National Intergroup Inc. in 1986 for $343.3 million.


MEDICAL WASTES FOUND ON NEW ENGLAND BEACHES
LEAD: Medical wastes similar to those that have fouled beaches in the New York area have begun to appear on beaches in Rhode Island and Massachusetts.
Governor Edward D. DiPrete of Rhode Island said today that his state would immediately begin an investigation to determine the source of the waste.

LEAD: Chris Sabo, who enjoyed the age's standard 15 minutes of fame on prime-time television last week, says it now takes him about 20 just to wade his way into his locker every afternoon.

LEAD: Some Central Park visitors were unprepared for the rain (more than an inch) that fell on New York City yesterday.
Among those who took cover under a canopy at the Bandshell were tourists from Florida and the Caribbean as well as a downhearted young man from Scotland, who said, ''I could have stayed home for weather like this.

Reviews/Music; Concert Moves Inside
LEAD: New York's outdoor summer concerts are sometimes described, however hyperbolically, as moveable feasts, but the Washington Square Music Festival took the cliche literally in its opening concert on Tuesday evening.
The performance began in Washington Square Park, as scheduled.
When the sky darkened and a thunderstorm drew near, the concert was transported, between movements of a Mozart work, to the Loeb Student Center of New York

LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed in very sluggish, technically based trading yesterday, as market participants awaited upcoming reports on inflation and the economy.


Mountbatten Slayer Fires
LEAD: A man serving a life sentence for the Irish guerrilla murder of Lord Mountbatten whipped out a pistol and opened fire in a Dublin court cell today in an unsuccessful escape attempt, the police said.
Thomas McMahon, who designed and planted the bomb that killed the uncle of Prince Philip in 1979, was quickly overpowered by police officers.

LEAD: Twelve years ago, the Democratic Party nominated for President a man whose entire political career had been spent at the state level, an outsider in the eyes of the Washington crowd, a man without real experience in foreign policy, an understated man of simple tastes.
Tonight it did the same thing.

LEAD: The crash of two Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains that killed an engineer and injured five other workers in April was caused by failures of observation and communication between train and tower crews, a state investigative agency said yesterday.

LEAD: A riot broke out today in the penitentiary of the central Mexican state of Michoacan, and officials said that at least 10 people were dead and 15 injured before it was brought under control.
A preliminary report by the state government described the violence at the prison, in Morelia, the state capital, as ''an attempt at a mass breakout.

His group, Goodman Fielder Wattie Ltd., Australia's largest baked-goods and flour company, already owns 29.9 percent of the British company.

LEAD: The grain and soybean markets came under renewed selling pressure yesterday as the July futures contracts expired.

Life in the 30's
LEAD: THE worst job I ever had was as a waitress at a rest stop on the New Jersey Turnpike the summer I was 18.
Everyone who passed through the place wanted their food NOW, and many of them seemed to think that tipping was a nice idea in theory but not in practice.
The pace was manic, and I had to wear a hairnet and white oxfords.

Graduate Education Faces Tax Code Crisis

An Update on the Drought
LEAD: Maps, comparing moisture in the top layer of the soil, show gradual shift of dry conditions over the growing season.
Recent rains have alleviated some of the worst short-term drought conditions in the Plains, but dryness has developed farther east in recent weeks.
In areas shown as extremely dry, many crops have been ruined; in severely dry areas, potential crop yields are severely cut.


Corrections
LEAD: A table yesterday with an article about the number of New York City residents believed to be infected with the AIDS virus carried reversed column headings in some copies.
The old estimates were on the left and the new estimates on the right.


Yields Are Set On Citicorp Notes
LEAD: Citicorp is issuing $250 million of 9 1/2 percent notes priced at par and due in 1993 through managers led by the First Boston Corporation The issue yields 81 basis points over similar Treasury securities.
The issue, which is rated A-1 by Moody's and AA by Standard &amp; Poor's, is noncallable for three years.


Metro Datelines; 3 Posing as Guards Steal $50,000 in Cash
LEAD: Three men posing as guards of an armored car company fled with $50,000 in cash and another $950,000 in nonnegotiable checks from a Pan American World Airways counter at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.


Home Improvement
LEAD: BRICKLAYING with sand instead of mortar requires very little skill and is an easy way to create handsome walkways, patios and even driveways.
The bricks are arranged close together on a bed of packed sand surrounded by a border.
After they are laid in place, additional sand is swept into the crevices to prevent shifting.

Review/Television; Finally, Human Faces Fill the Screen
LEAD: Last night, finally, television gave the nation what first radio and then television taught us to recognize as an authentic political convention.
Not long after the networks took to the air, the nominations for the Presidency began.
No surprises in store, little spontaneity permitted.
Yet gradually the delegates took over from the leaders, and the screen drew a little life from the inklings of individuality.

8-Year Study Finds 2 Sides to Teen-Age Drug Use
LEAD: The small minority of teen-agers who become heavy users of hard drugs and alcohol in high school are put on a life trajectory that leads to serious problems in young adulthood regardless of whether they continue taking drugs, according to a study released today by the University of California at Los Angeles.

Warner-Lambert Buys Candy Maker
LEAD: The Warner-Lambert Company, the pharmaceutical concern, has agreed to buy the French candy maker Nouvelle des Pastilles de Vichy from the Perrier Group.
Terms were not disclosed.
Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, said the purchase would help it enter the $5 billion French confectionery market.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported slightly lower earnings for the second quarter, while the GTE Corporation said its net income rose 34.1 percent in the period, helped by a special item.

Rover to Close 2 Plants
LEAD: The British auto maker Rover Group P.L.C. said this week that it plans to close two plants in the next few years, cutting 3,400 jobs.
The company, which currently employs 46,400 people, said it would phase out its car assembly plant in Cowley South, Oxford, by the early 1990's and would shut its pressings factory in Llanelli, Wales, in two years.


Dusting Off Berlin
LEAD: The nation's attic, as the Smithsonian Institution is affectionately known, is unpacking some treasures to mark the 100th birthday of Irving Berlin.


Yields Show Rise in Week
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday.


Soviets Expel Armenian Dissident, Signaling Tough Policy on Unrest
LEAD: Soviet authorities ordered Armenia's best-known dissident stripped of his citizenship today and expelled from the country, signaling a tough new official position on the threat of renewed Armenian unrest.

Columbo Yogurt
LEAD: The Columbo yogurt business, formerly handled by the Boston office of Della Femina McNamee WCRS, has returned to Jordan, McGrath, Case &amp; Taylor, which had the business for about two years before losing it six years ago.
The brand's distribution is largely in the Northeast.
Billings are about $3 million.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief account by The Associated Press on Saturday about a report to the University of California regents on drug trafficking at the Lawrence Livermore laboratory misstated a location of drug deliveries.
Drugs were not delivered in a restricted plutonium building; the laboratory director, John Nuckolls, said he misunderstood a reporter's question.

FOR PEOPLE PRONE TO DEPRESSION, DANGER SIGNALS ON BAD MOODS
LEAD: Even when they are simply in a bad mood, people who are prone to serious depression are especially susceptible to irrationally pessimistic thoughts about themselves and the world, new research suggests.
And these distorted thoughts can all too easily knock the person into an emotional tailspin, transforming an ordinary bad mood into a full-blown clinical depression requiring medical intervention, psychologists say.

Georgia Power
LEAD: The Georgia Power Company sold $150 million worth of 10 3/4 percent 30-year bonds at competitive bid yesterday.
A syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company won the bonds, which were priced at 99.65, to yield 10.79 percent, or 1.46 percentage points over the yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity.

Britain's Water Industry
LEAD: The British Government said today that it intends to privatize the country's water industry in a stock offering expected to raise the equivalent of $8.6 billion.
Shares in Britain's 10 regional water authorities will be offered to the public in a single $:5 billion sale at the end of 1989, Nicholas Ridley, the Government's environment secretary, said.

LEAD: Political nominating conventions lost their middle name 20 years ago.
Primaries and caucuses have drained away the suspense.

U.S. Welcomes Soviet Radar Proposal
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today welcomed a Soviet proposal to dismantle a disputed radar complex in Siberia as a ''positive step.'' China Quality Bureau
LEAD: China has set up a new state bureau to oversee efforts to reduce the number of shoddy, substandard goods on the market and make Chinese products more competitive on world markets, an official daily said today.
In announcing creation of the State Bureau of Technical Supervision, the state councilor, Song Jian, said substandard products remain a serious problem, The China Daily said.

Sailboat Haven Groans as Motors Growl
LEAD: Out of the noonday glare on the Connecticut River comes a sound wild, loud and ragged.
It is the deep gear-burning scream of a cigarette boat, long and sleek and fast, bouncing through a wake as she barrels full-bore past the harbor.
Vrrrrummmm!
Whooosh.
Vrrrrummmm!
Whooosh.
Vrrrrummmm!
Whooosh.  ''That's a small one,'' said Clayton Firman, a marine-patrol officer of the State Department of Environmental Protection.

Waltzing Round Krasnoyarsk
LEAD: Among the more serious embarrassments Mikhail Gorbachev inherited from his predecessors is a 30-story, phased array radar near the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk.
The massive device is a hefty contravention of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, and Mr.
Gorbachev seems properly eager to find a face-saving way of scrapping it.


Awnings for Esthetics And Summer Shade
LEAD: AWNINGS are making a comeback.
They are practical: they add shade to terraces and protect draperies, upholstery, rugs and paintings from fading caused by sunlight.
And according to the Industrial Fabrics Association International in St.
Paul, awnings conserve energy in the summer by lowering indoor temperatures 8 to 15 degrees.

Poland Signs Debt Pact
LEAD: Poland and its Western creditor banks signed a rescheduling agreement Wednesday covering almost all of the nation's Western commercial debt.
A spokesman for the bank group said the deal, signed nine months behind schedule, would restructure about $9.4 billion of Poland's debt due between 1988 and 1993.

George R. Hickey Commodore, 84
LEAD: George R. Hickey, who retired as commodore of the Farrell Lines shipping company in 1968, died Tuesday at the Dell Manor Nursing Home in Rockland, Mass., where he lived.
He was 84 years old.


Foster's Dream Intact Despite Fracture
LEAD: Greg Foster knows the risks.
Doctors have told him that if he falls while hurdling Friday night, and his broken left arm gets the worst of it, he could crack the bones where each of 12 screws are in place or, even lose partial use of the arm.

LEAD: A joint $292 million acquisition proposal for Micom Systems Inc. from two New York investment firms has expired without an agreement or extention, the company said today.

Jake Lindsey, World War II Hero Honored by Congress, Dies at 67
LEAD: Jake W. Lindsey, a combat hero of World War II who received the Medal of Honor at a special Congressional ceremony, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Waynesboro, Miss.
He was 67 years old.
Mr.
Lindsey, then a technical sergeant, was the 100th infantryman awarded the Medal of Honor in World War II.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about a Soviet proposal to dismantle a radar installation misstated the Soviet interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.
Moscow no longer insists on an end to ''Star Wars'' research, but says that the treaty strictly limits the scope of anti-missile tests in space.

Iran-Iraq War: Eight Brutal Years
LEAD:  1980  Sept. 7: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq cancels 1975 treaty with Iran and claims sovereignty over the Shatt al Arab, the waterway that forms part of the southern border between the countries.
Iran rejects the claim.
Minor border clashes follow.
Sept. 22: Iraqi forces invade Iran.

Review/Theater; School as a Symbol Of a Society's Decline
LEAD: The setting of ''The Film Society,'' a new play by Jon Robin Baitz at the Second Stage, is the sort of rotting private school for boys beloved by chroniclers of the English Empire's decline and fall.
The time is 1970, and signs of decay are everywhere.
The school elders are ill.
The building is disintegrating.


Market Place; A Short-Sale Plan That Backfired
LEAD: A STRATEGY based on an expectation of a decline in the Japanese stock market has backfired for some aggressive New York money managers.
A number of these so-called hedge fund managers are said to have sold short the American depository receipts of some large Japanese stocks.


Colombian Politician Freed
LEAD: Leftist guerrillas freed Alvaro Gomez Hurtado, a former presidential candidate, Wednesday night 53 days after kidnapping him.
He said he was unharmed.
Mr.
Gomez Hurtado, 69 years old, a former Ambassador to the United States, was kidnapped May 29 by armed men.
His bodyguard was killed.
The guerrilla group M-19 claimed responsibility.

Deftly Crashing the Gates of the Rich
''Mr.
North'' is a comic fable about Theophilus North (Anthony Edwards), a clean-cut Yale graduate who has the self-assurance of a crackpot saint.
At the height of the 1926 summer season, Theophilus makes his way through the social maze of Newport, R.I., with the aplomb and springy step of a very young, very American Mr.
Hulot.
He tutors the children of the rich, teaches them tennis, and reads to the elderly in English, French, German, Italian and Hebrew.
He doesn't actually speak Hebrew, but he offers to bone up on it when a client resists his estimate of six weeks to read the Bible in English.
Theophilus says that since Hebrew has no vowels, the reading time could be reduced by one third.


Sports People; Rice Suspended
LEAD: The Boston Red Sox suspended Jim Rice without pay for three days yesterday as a result of an altercation Wednesday night with Manager Joe Morgan after Rice was replaced by a pinch-hitter against the Minnesota Twins.
The suspension, which became effective before the start of a four-game series with the Chicago White Sox, was announced by General Manager Lou Gorman, who said, ''You can't allow any player on the club to question the manager's judgment in any situation during the ball game.

The scars remain.

Review/Pop; Three Mustaphas Three
LEAD: Three Mustaphas Three, the fez-topped band that performed Tuesday at S.O.B.'s, could be the Monty Python of world-beat pop.
It's a six-man British band (all claiming the last name Mustapha) with a female singer, Lavra Tima Daviz M., that plays a wildly non-authentic melange of regional styles.

Company News; American Medical Holders Drop Plan
LEAD: A group of Texas investors who hold a 7 percent stake in American Medical International Inc. said that they had abandoned a proposal calling for board representation and the establishment of a committee to examine a possible sale of the Beverly Hills, Calif., concern.


Company Briefs
LEAD: ABI American Business Phones Inc., Irvine, Calif., said the company had received an extension until July 29 on the expiration date of the unsolicited $11-a-share merger proposal from a company director, Jean R. Stiegemeier.


Business People; New Treasurer For Times Co.
LEAD: David L. Gorham, a senior vice president and chief financial officer of The New York Times Company, has assumed the additional title of treasurer.

LEAD: Iraq came under increasing pressure in the United Nations today after raising a new obstacle to an early cease-fire in the eight-year-old Persian Gulf war.

3 Gun Concerns Indicted by Jury In Bronx Sales
LEAD: In an action that the Bronx District Attorney hopes will slow the flow of illegal guns into New York City, a Bronx grand jury has indicted three out-of-state weapons companies for selling at least 1,000 handguns to a man who did not have a New York City gun permit.


Company News; Bank in West Says Profit Improved
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation today reported improved earnings and a steep decline in loan losses for the second quarter of 1988, further signs that the once-troubled banking company is on the mend.

44% OF HEART BYPASS SURGERY IS UNNEEDED, STUDY SUGGESTS
LEAD: Nearly half the patients who had heart bypass operations in three hospitals either should not have had them or might have done as well without them, a new study says.

Reynolds drove in three runs tonight, two on a tie-breaking double in the sixth inning, as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, for their 12th victory in 13 games.


American Brands Gains
LEAD: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit climbed 43.9 percent, to $154.6 million, or $1.57 a share, from $107.4 million, or 94 cents a share, in the period a year ago.

2 Palestinians Die as West Bank Violence Flares
LEAD: Two Palestinians died today in unrest in the West Bank that was among the most violent in two months, while the police and protesters clashed in unusually violent disturbances in East Jerusalem.


New Orleans Journal; Hope Buds Where Oaks Once Grew
LEAD: North Claiborne Avenue was once one of the city's most graceful boulevards, running through a neighborhood just north of the French Quarter, its lanes divided by a wide grassy median with an arcade of oak trees.

Bolivian Drug Lord Is Captured
LEAD: The Bolivian police have seized Roberto Suarez Gomez, considered one of the top cocaine traffickers in South America, after trekking through jungles all night to surprise him at his ranch, the Interior Ministry reported today.


The Media Business; Thompson and Bertolli End Their Relationship
LEAD: J. Walter Thompson/New York and Bertolli U.S.A., an olive oil importer based in Secaucus, N.J., have ended their client-agency relationship, which began in the spring of 1987.
The reasons given were ''mutual differences in marketing approach and future direction.'' Billings are about $3 million.

LEAD: A 30-year-old single man who works at a copy center and lives in a boxy house in suburban New Jersey can't be blamed for saying, as the main character in ''Home Remedy'' does, ''Life is boring and then you die.'' New York Officials Disagree Over Beach Debris
LEAD: Amid an almost tangible sense of frustration at their inability to explain the source of medical waste on beaches in the region this month, New York City and State officials yesterday began disagreeing with each other over theories about the origin of the trash.


American Express in Black
LEAD: The American Express Company yesterday reported a strong second-quarter profit, in contrast to a large loss a year ago, when the American Express Bank joined major banks in raising its loan-loss provision to reflect problem third-world loans.

LEAD: There was no way to explain the loss this time, no way to sort it out and examine it in small, manageable pieces.
It simply happened, and then it was over.


Keynote Letter Writer 'Embarrassed a Little'
LEAD: Donna Alexander's previous letters to politicians had always brought replies by form letter.


Company News; Catalyst Agrees To Be Acquired
LEAD: The Catalyst Energy Corporation, an independent power-producing company that owns and leases generators, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Merrimac Corporation for $11.25 a share in cash, or more than $202 million.
Merrimac was recently formed by Thomas B. Pickens 3d of Dallas, the son of the corporate raider T.


Levin Parents Sue Chambers For $25 Million in Damages
LEAD: The parents of Jennifer Levin sued Robert E. Chambers Jr., the confessed killer of their daughter, for $25 million yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.


Bentsen: A Private Man in Public Life
LEAD: After 40 years in and out of public life, Lloyd Millard Bentsen Jr. remains an enigma and a contradiction.


Company News; Spanish Airline Buys Boeing Jets
LEAD: Hispania Lineas Aereas has purchased four advanced-technology 737-500 aircraft, valued at more than $105 million, from Boeing Commercial Airplanes, Boeing announced.
The airline, based in Palma de Mallorca, Spain, will take delivery of the 130-passenger airplanes between June and August 1991.

BankAmerica Corp. filed for a proposed shelf offering of up to $1 billion of debt and up to $50 million of currency warrants.

Surrender Baby At Birth, Judge Tells a Woman
LEAD: A pregnant woman has been ordered by a judge to surrender the baby at birth because she has abused or neglected seven previous children.


Company News; Lufthansa to Buy Four Airbus Jets
LEAD: The West German airline Lufthansa said it would buy four Airbus jets for a total of about $270 million.
Three of the planes are A300-310's and one is a larger A300-600.
Each type can carry about 200 passengers.


Iran Action Linked to Anti-War Mood
LEAD: Iran decided to call off its war with Iraq because there was growing opposition to it among Iranians and because Iran's leaders saw a cease-fire as the only way to insure survival of their revolution, in the view of State Department officials and other experts on the region.


Economic Scene; Democrats Seek Big Issue for 1988
LEAD: WHAT is the main economic issue on which the Democrats will fight the 1988 Presidential campaign?
In Atlanta this week, Jesse Jackson sought to make that issue the unequal distribution of income and opportunities in the United States.
He made his own life the symbol of the issue - and of hope that others could follow his example in making it.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  FRIDAY  DINOSAURS ON DISPLAY


The Law: At the Bar
LEAD: Samuel C. Klagsbrun's psychiatric training consisted in part of studying how human beings behaved in an oppressive, stressful environment, sealed off from the real world, separated from friends and family.
Among other things, he examined how bright young people coped with the arbitrary and at times irrational orders of elders, and what traits helped them inch their own way up the organizational ladder.


Iraq Honors Heroes
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein giving bravery medals to Iraqi military commanders.
He defended his nation's call for direct talks with Iran.
Page A6. (AP)


Ask Not, Only Weep
LEAD: So moved was the speaker of Iran's Parliament that he wept when he heard Ayatollah Khomeini give his personal endorsement to an end to the war with Iraq.
But don't ask questions, pleaded Speaker Hashemi Rafsanjani: ''We should not ask why and how, not create more problems for the society.'' The war has claimed a million lives, smashed as many limbs, and yet Iranians are told not to ask the reason why.


Naval Forces in Gulf Have Civil Flight Data; Electronic Mirages
LEAD: To the Editor:


Hepatitis Up Among Drug Users; U.S. Vaccination Strategy Hinted
LEAD: Federal health officials expressed concern today about an increase in hepatitis among intravenous drug abusers, suggesting that a national strategy might be needed to vaccinate them.


A Month of Rain, All in Three Days
LEAD: Homeowners who are happy because they have not had to water the lawn for the past three days can consider how delighted Ed Toth and his colleagues are at the Queens Botanical Garden.


Maxwell Is Joining Fight for Macmillan
LEAD: In his latest effort to gain a large publishing foothold in the United States, Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, yesterday offered to buy Macmillan Inc. for $80 a share, or about $2.06 billion.

Anne Frank Letter to Iowa Pen Pal to Be Sold
LEAD: Pen-pal letters sent by Anne Frank and her sister to two girls in Iowa in 1940, just before the German invasion of the Netherlands sealed the Frank family's doom, have come to light as the result of a decision to auction them in New York in October.


A Revived U.N. Needs U.S. Cash
LEAD: If an end to the Persian Gulf war at last seems possible, that is thanks in part to the United Nations.
The U.N. has also helped bring Soviet occupation of Afghanistan to a close, and may soon play peacemaker in Indochina and southern Africa.
When the great powers start to see a common interest in resolving conflicts, they find this unwieldy international forum indispensable.


Rexene Purchasers Near a Windfall
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. may have its troubles with the insider trading investigation of the firm, but it also has plenty to cheer about these days thanks to an obscure petrochemicals company, the Rexene Corporation.


New Times Supplement
LEAD: The first issue of New York, New York, a twice-a-year Part 2 supplement to The New York Times Magazine, will be published Nov. 20.
It will be the newspaper's first magazine section with circulation limited to greater New York.
It will replace The World of New York, a nationally distributed supplement.

LEAD: Because of a production error, page 52 in some copies on Saturday was blank.
The page should have carried articles about the new president of the teamsters union, including the continuation of a front-page article; about a fuel leak in the space shuttle, and about the screenwriters' strike; and answers to the News Quiz.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis, no longer an aspirant but the Democratic Presidential nominee, sought tonight to put his imprint firmly on his party, on a convention that until he addressed it had seen little of him and on a nation that still scarcely knows him.


Armenian Capital Residents Are Said to Ignore Strike Call
LEAD: Residents of Armenia's capital ignored calls for a strike today, residents and the state-run press reported.
The strike had been called to protest Moscow's rejection of their demand to annex a region in neighboring Azerbaijan.

LEAD: The last thing the Mets need, according to Dave Johnson, is team meetings.
In fact, the manager was so convinced of it, he called a team meeting to say so.

LEAD: The mannered style of ''Pascali's Island'' perfectly suits its tale of political and emotional intrigue hiding behind a crumbling facade of stability.
On a Greek island in 1908, in the fading years of the Ottoman Empire, Greek rebels, Turkish spies and foreign mercenaries mingle in shady hotel bars and winding streets overlooking the sea.

It was telephone-line problems, not computer problems at The Associated Press.

Naval Forces in Gulf Have Civil Flight Data; Policy Traced to Carter
LEAD: To the Editor:


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 443 money market mutual funds increased by $276.2 million, to $266.61 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 123 institutional funds decreased by $310.5 million, to $69.21 billion.
The assets of the 220 general-purpose funds were up by $284.2 million, to $82.93 billion.


Reviews/Art; Bringing Light and Color to Gray City Spaces
LEAD: On paper, Artists in the Gardens is one of the most promising art projects in the city.
It was conceived in 1984.
It is part of Operation Greenthumb, the city's community gardening program inaugurated in 1978 as part of the Department of General Services.
So far, Artists in the Gardens has enabled around 20 artists to create work in collaboration with inner-city residents.


H.U.D. Offering
LEAD: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said it would offer $300 million in securities backed by public-facility loans.
Underwriters will be led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company, which will price the notes by the end of July.
The Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae, will administer the sale.


BALLOON ON THIN TUBE IS SEEN AS SOLUTION TO SHUTTLE'S LEAK
LEAD: Taking a cue from heart surgeons, engineers are considering using a thin tube with an expandable balloon on the end to plug a leak that could cause a long delay of the next space shuttle mission.


Tour de France; Leader Wins Drug Appeal
LEAD: Although the result of his second drug test was positive, Pedro Delgado escaped a time penalty and kept his lead in the Tour de France, the organizers of the bicycle race announced tonight.

Sundberg, a six-time Gold Glove winner, was released by the Chicago Cubs last Friday. . . .
Jerry Butler, the third-leading receiver in Buffalo Bills' history, was waived at his request after failing a team physical.

Research Suggests Virus Link to Alzheimer's Disease
LEAD: Research at Yale University has raised the possibility that some cases of Alzheimer's disease may be caused by infection with an unidentified, slow-acting virus.


Jones and Ruiz
LEAD: Elvin Jones, a drummer, and Hilton Ruiz, a pianist, are leading jazz groups in a double bill tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592).
Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. with a 1:30 A.M. show tonight.
There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables or a $10 charge at the bar.

LEAD: A 76-year-old Bronx man, who had been in a feud with his neighbor, was shot yesterday during an argument, the police reported.

Corrections
LEAD: A Company News report in Business Day on July 14 about the Toshiba Corporation and Go-Video Inc. misstated the terms of a settlement between the two companies.
Toshiba agreed to refrain from interfering with a possible business transaction between Go-Video and its potential manufacturing partner.

Control Data Sets One-Week Closing
LEAD: TheControl Data Corporation will close five of its computer systems plants for one week in August as a result of disappointing computer sales.
The company said about 2,500 people would be affected by the shutdowns of of the plants in Minneapolis and in Kansas City, Kan., and Sunnyvale, Calif.

Former Minister Is Jailed
LEAD: A defrocked Lutheran minister has been jailed on a contempt charge after an angry exchange with a judge.
The former minister, Daniel Solberg, the leader of a group rebelling against the church's positions, was placed in the Allegheny County Jail on Thursday after County Judge David Cercone found him in contempt of court for refusing to participate in jury selection.

Everyday Objects Are History at the Smithsonian
LEAD: A wooden spinning wheel, a pewter goblet and a cast-iron plow stand in seemingly curious juxtaposition to a baby-blue Maytag washing machine, Tupperware dishes and a medley of kaleidoscopically colored radios, credit cards and hundreds of other more or less familiar objects in a new, permanent exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History.

Racing's Newest Sure Thing?
LEAD: Horse racing has always been a game of windfall profits.
Last month at Belmont, a groom bet $96 in the Pick-Six and four hours later won $500,000.
John Henry was bought for $25,000 and he earned more than $6 million.
Conquistador Cielo was auctioned for $150,000 as a yearling and was syndicated as a stallion for $36 million.


Chief of Municipal Finance At Bear, Stearns Resigns
LEAD: Three months after a management shake-up relieved him of his administrative duties, Joseph M. Giglio Jr. resigned yesterday as head of public finance at Bear, Stearns &amp; Company, the firm said.

LEAD: Most crop futures prices moved lower yesterday in a lackluster session dominated by profit taking and uncertainty about the Farm Belt weather outlook.

'As You Like It'
LEAD: The Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival will present Shakespeare's ''As You Like It'' tonight and tomorrow outdoors at Boscobel Restoration.
The site opens at 6 P.M. for picnickers (no barbecue grills allowed), and performances begin at 8.
Boscobel, a museum of Federal period decorative arts, is on Route 9D in Garrison, N.Y., eight miles north of the Bear Mountain Bridge.

Carson Pirie Stake
LEAD: An investor group that includes Arnhold and S. Bleichroeder Inc., New York, investment bankers, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had reduced its stake in Carson Pirie Scott Inc. to 641,749 shares, or 4.7 percent of the outstanding common stock.
The group, which had previously held 5.7 percent, said it sold 139,300 shares of the Chicago retail company in open-market transactions between June 1 and July 18 at $12.50 to $14.50 a share.

LEAD: An international theater complex on a 22-acre site alongside the Moscow River, within view of the Kremlin, is being planned as a joint venture of the Soviet Union of Theater Workers and the Seabeco Group, a Toronto-based company that specializes in business development in the Soviet Union, representatives of both groups announced yesterday in New York.


Fanfares for Michael Dukakis
LEAD: No one played ''Happy Days Are Here Again'' at the Democratic Convention Thursday night; too dated, probably.
Besides, the Democrats had new songs to sing.
John Williams had composed a ''Fanfare for Michael Dukakis'' and the nominee's own father-in-law conducted it.
And then the candidate, once a trumpeter in the Brookline High School band, took the podium and performed his own Fanfare for the Common

LEAD: The champagne was flowing recently as an elegant party of movie stars, business leaders and politicians inaugurated a new restaurant here.

Review/Theater; A Rock Musical Explores the Low Life of Berlin
LEAD: New York City doesn't have a resident company quite like Grips Theater, the West Berlin children's ensemble whose successful rock musical ''Line 1'' opened a nine-performance engagement Wednesday at the Pepsico Summerfare arts festival in Purchase, N.Y.
Between 1969 and 1985, the company had premieres of 34 plays with a left-of-center political agenda that looked at social problems through the eyes of young people.


Corrections
LEAD: A news analysis article on Wednesday, about the image of the Democratic Party, characterized Garrison Keillor's appearance at the Democratic National Convention incorrectly.
Mr.
Keillor accepted the invitation of party officials to lead the singing of the national anthem; he was not paid for his appearance.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the greenhouse effect misstated the amount of carbon dioxide being released to the atmosphere by human activity.
About 20 billion tons, containing 5.5 billion tons of carbon, is currently being released annually.


Bulgarian Party Chief Ousts A Key Proponent of Change
LEAD: Todor Zhivkov, the Communist Party chief of Bulgaria, has bolstered his position by ousting a proponent of changes similar to those of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, Western diplomats said today.


GUIDEPOST: Keeping Bills at Bay
LEAD: Letting bills sit during an extended vacation is risky.
Some creditors now impose penalties after 30 days, especially if there is a history of erratic payments.
Figure out what bills you'll miss by taking a list of billing-cycle dates for your regular payments; you might also include your account numbers and the addresses and customer-service telephone numbers of the creditors.

'Fresh Water' Economists Gain
LEAD: To tinker or not to tinker?
For decades most politicians and professors of economics have taken it for granted that the Government must adjust the engines of the economy to avoid recessions and create jobs.
But lately, a long-belittled school of skeptics who think the Government usually just gums things up is gaining attention and influence.

Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch, broke oral agreements with a public relations man by identifying him as the source of an article after promising him confidentiality, and it awarded him $700,000.

Schools Drop Plan to Install Metal Detectors
LEAD: A pilot program to equip some New York City schools with walk-through metal detectors similar to those used in airports has been abandoned because of cost, city officials said.

LEAD: If there is anything distinctive about political theater today, it is not in the actors who occupy the center stage.

Instead, almost everything is conceptualized in terms of winning and losing elections.

2 Queens Men Held in Killing Of 82-Year-Old
LEAD: Two men have been arrested and charged in the slaying of an 82-year-old woman who was hit on the head with a large rock Sunday during a robbery as she walked to church in Queens, the police said yesterday.


David Chertok, 66; Amassed an Archive Of Rare Jazz Films
LEAD: David Chertok, a leading collector of jazz on film, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 66 years old.


Murdoch Seeks Listing
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch's Australia-based media empire, the News Corporation, will seek a listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, a local newspaper owned by the company reported today.
The News Corporation's shares are already traded in Australia, New Zealand, New York, London, Paris and Amsterdam.
The shares are expected to start trading on the Hong Kong exchange in October.


Consumer Prices Rise 0.3%, Easing Inflation Fear
LEAD: In a report that allayed some fears about a resurgence of inflation, the Labor Department said today that the Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the same as in May and less than the rises in March and April.

LEAD: CSR, an Australian building materials and sugar conglomerate, has agreed to buy the Rinker Materials Corporation, a maker of concrete and building materials, for $515 million.

Preventing The 'Brain Drain'
LEAD: Dr.
Norma Foreman Glasgow, the State Commissioner of Higher Education, has called attention to a problem which has begun to worry employers and government and community leaders - the migration of Connecticut college-bound youth.  [ For College Students, the Grass May Be Greener at Home, June19 ]  Statewide the figure is 53 percent; however, Fairfield County loses over 60 percent of its students to outofstate institutions of higher learning.


Griffith Joyner Takes The 200
LEAD: The United States Olympic track and field trials ended today as Florence Griffith Joyner turned in another outstanding performance and a few surprise athletes made the team along with a bunch of familiar faces.


TO THE FANS, HE'S STILL NO. 1
LEAD: What was that boy's name?
You remember him, Ted, the one the Dodgers picked up in the 22d round in 1965 and we signed the next year.
You didn't even own the Braves then, but we thought he'd put us on the map and rewrite National League history.


GARDENING MEANS WAR
LEAD: Michael Pollan's article ''Gardening Means War'' (June 19) was a direct hit.
I sat reading it, and laughed until I nearly cried, while, outside, a mother woodchuck was training her three youngsters in guerrilla tactics in my garden.
We have put the garden in a new spot this year.
Last year, after we jammed boulders into the gaping holes surrounding our vegetable patch, the resident woodchuck set up new underground quarters - with its main entrance in the middle of the snap beans.


FOCUS: Toronto; Economic Growth Foreseen Into 1990's
LEAD: WITH its reputation as a center of manufacturing and finance as well as its proximity to major United States cities, Toronto has emerged as one of Canada's economic bright spots.
Last year there was record demand for office space, and as a trade agreeement with the United States nears approval, the business community is geared up for continued economic growth in the 1990's.


And Then the Grass Grows Some More
LEAD: ''NO, I won't be needing the gardener this year,'' I declared in December, full of resolve.
I pushed up the sleeves of my sweater and anticipated the coming of summer.
Snow covered the ground outside my window as I wrote a note explaining my change of plans to the landscape gardener.


In Lakeville, Comfort of Past Era
LEAD: WAKE ROBIN INN'S current reincarnation may be its finest.
This large, comfortable hilltop property in Lakeville began life as a girls' school in 1898, but has been an inn for decades, with ownership and dining room changing almost as frequently as New England weather.

LEAD: Looking as fit as a Hall of Fame center fielder should, Joe DiMaggio was discharged yesterday from the Miami Beach hospital where he underwent surgery 10 days earlier. ''His prognosis is excellent; the reason he recovered so well is that he's in excellent physical condition,'' said Dr.
Manuel Sivina, a vascular surgeon.

Avoiding a Sunburn With Pills and Patches
LEAD: TOO busy to pack sun lotion?
You could wear a pliable plastic bracelet that snaps open to dispense an ounce of waterproof suntan oil.
Called Handy Tan - and available in four colors at some convenience stores and health food outlets - the item can be strapped onto the wrist or ankle or worn in the hair.


Correction
LEAD: The Bridge column in the Pastimes page July 17th had an incorrect bidding with South bidding double.
The final double was by East and not by South.

LEAD: Both China and the Soviet Union have given assurances that they are willing to help resolve the war in Cambodia, the Indonesian Foreign Minister said today.


Italy to Take Back Waste
LEAD: Two Italian ships will be sent to retrieve several tons of unspecified toxic waste left in Koko, a Nigerian port that has been the site of a controversy over the dumping of toxic waste in West Africa, Civil Defense Minister Vito Lattanzio said Friday.
The announcement was expected to ease tensions between Italy and Nigeria and lead to the release of the Italian freighter Piave, which was seized by Nigeria pending a resolution of the waste issue.

LEAD: Most of the people of the vast desert state of Sonora have always regarded the Mexican Government's war against the drug trade as something that has little to do with them and their daily lives.

LEAD:  THE DECLINE AND CRASH OF THE AMERICAN ECONOMY  By Joel Kurtzman.  224 pp.

Correction
LEAD: A chart on third world missile deployment in The Week in Review on July 3 was incorrectly labeled.
The headline should have said that the chart listed only ''nuclear capable'' missiles (defined as those with a range of greater than 190 miles and a payload of greater than 1,100 pounds), and the footnote should have said that countries listed with question marks were reported to be seeking the missiles indicated, not that they already had them.

LEAD: You can still see them in the more-depressed industrial cities of northern England: huddled rows of tiny, grimy red-brick houses in the terminal stages of decay. ''And on the very edge of town, almost sliding off, there's always one street where all the losers and roughs and ne'er-do-wells seem to end up,'' says Jim Cartwright.

Disney Group Puts Polaroid Into Play
LEAD: Polaroid is in play.
After months of speculation that the photography company was a takeover target, Roy Disney announced that his Shamrock Holdings held 8 percent of Polaroid's stock and was willing to buy the rest for $2.3 billion, or $40 a share.
Polaroid had been selling for about $30 a share in February before the first takeover rumors began.

Reviews/Music; Leppard and Mozart
LEAD: There was a disheartening incongruity between what was seen and what was heard at Friday evening's Mostly Mozart concert, at Avery Fisher Hall.
In the opening work, Mozart's Symphony No.25 in G minor, Raymond Leppard's conducting gestures were full of detail: phrases and their components were drawn vividly in the air, and the signals for entries and cutoffs were crisp and unequivocal.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. When we decided to close our house for the winter while we were away, we got conflicting advice.
One school of thought recommended leaving the heat on at a low setting because otherwise the woodwork, furniture and even the latex paint could be damaged by cold and dampness inside the house.
The other school of thought said that dmage, if any, would be negligible, and the worst would be offset by the savings in fuel bills.

Simpler Views From Islands Off Wisconsin
LEAD: BAYFIELD PENINSULA is a forest-covered finger of Wisconsin that juts into the awesome, chilly drink of Lake Superior.
Its easterly shore helps to shelter and embrace Chequamegon Bay, and clustered around the tip of this digit are the lovely, low-lying Apostle Islands.
There are 22 of them, of odd shapes and varying sizes, and they lie hunkering about the peninsula like the bushy pates of a submerged race of giants.

LEAD: DESSERTS are easy in the summer.

I rarely let a summer go by without making it.

Public Enemy: Rap With a Fist in the Air
LEAD: In the last decade, rap has become as much a symbol as a musical style.
For those who revel in it as well as for those who can't stand it, rap holds all the tensions of urban life - tensions between sexes, generations, races and classes.
Its electronic crunch and sonic collages, its jolts and shouts, echo an urban streetscape that some city dwellers want to flaunt or exorcise, others to escape.

The Busiest Time to Keep Plants Growing
LEAD: GROOM petunias, geraniums, snapdragons and salvias by cutting off or snapping off old flowers to prevent seed pods and prolong bloom; if there is time, remove faded roses and day lilies.
Sow ripe columbine seed promptly where it is to grow.
Prune hedges to keep them in line, especially if they block street and drive views or hinder foot traffic.

Make Money. Have Fun. Be Ethical.
LEAD: LATELY I've done a lot of thinking about ethics in business.
This might be because my job is very competitive.
I'm in charge of getting new clients for my firm, a medium-sized advertising agency with a reputation for memorable commercials.
Trying to win an advertising account in a contest with other agencies has to be one of the most intense forms of business competition.


GARDENING MEANS WAR
LEAD: We experienced the woodchuck invasion last summer and we had a fence.
Nothing deterred them.
Wildlife experts advised us to set humane traps, then drive to some distant, wooded area and release them.
Somehow, transporting woodchucks in the back of my new car appealed to me less than giving up my garden-fresh produce.


A Family Defends Its Dynasty
LEAD: IT is one of the great family dynasties in corporate America.
McGraw-Hill Inc., the publishing giant founded in 1909, has had a McGraw at the helm through two world wars, the Depression and into the electronic era.


Barbecue
LEAD: To the Editor: The articles about the debate over barbecue (Travel, July 3) certainly hit home - in fact, two homes.
My North Carolinian husband, after a dozen years in New Jersey, still refuses to call a cookout a barbecue.
It is certainly true that we Jerseyans call the act of cooking any meat on a grill, with or without sauce, a barbecue.

Fancies Flow in a Quiet Garden As Californians Experiment With Outdoor Chairs
LEAD: What does the word ''chair'' suggest?
Lots of different things, no doubt: anything from a folding chair to a fauteuil, from Chippendale to Charles Eames.
As for ''the chair,'' it can equally well conjure up a symbol of authority - the chair that a chairman takes - and the electric chair.

With Friends
LEAD: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article reminded me of a technique I've used with groups even as small as two.
Each of the possible companions prepares for the others two short lists: Things I Can't Do Without and Things I Can't Stand.
If one party refuses to miss the glories of sunrise and another can't bear to get up before 10, best to know it early on.

The Long and the Short of Museum Loans
LEAD: Woven into the fabric of every major museum there are two kinds of thread.
Both are important.
Both are invisible to the casual eye.
One is the thread of the long loan - the work of art that is by now so much at home in the museum that we forget that it belongs to someone else and can be withdrawn at any time.

A Summer Dessert of Berries
LEAD: DESSERTS are easy in the summer.
As berries become cheaper they can be made into tarts and pies - and summer pudding, my favorite of all.
This English dessert, made with raspberries, blackberries and red currants, is a beautiful ruby-red dome that tastes as wonderful as it looks.
I rarely let a summer go by without making it.

LEAD: Dave Righetti could break the record book in many categories if he became a starting pitcher again, but I know he would go crazy waiting every fifth day to pitch.

As long as he is happy putting out the fire, I am for the relief role.
HOLLY S.

The anti-Nazi group known as the White Rose consisted of a small circle of students and a teacher at the University of Munich who in May 1942, when Hitler was still triumphant in the war, secretly began to distribute leaflets denouncing the Nazi regime.

Reviews/Dance; Leads Change in 'Onegin'
LEAD: The National Ballet of Canada gave a polished account of John Cranko's ''Onegin'' on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.
The dancing was smooth and clear, and the performance revealed that this is a very carefully trained company.
But it also revealed how great an artistic distance there can be between studio and stage, for despite their technical competence, several leading dancers failed to be dramatically convincing.

LEAD: A United States Navy veteran who worked for naval intelligence and mysteriously disappeared over two years ago has surfaced in the Soviet Union, where he has been granted political asylum.

Repertorio Espanol Goes on With el Espectaculo
LEAD: Repertorio Espanol is 20 years old this summer, a milestone the company is too busy to observe and one that is unlikely to seize the attention of New York's mainstream theater world.
Repertorio, which remains adamantly Castilian in tongue, tone and tune, is one of the more venerable professional repertory groups in the nation, and offers a profusion of plays, dance and musicals that would, in its native land, be at center stage in the cultural scene.


An Exponent Of Order And Control
LEAD: Name the greatest prodigy in the history of music.
Mozart?
Mendelssohn?
Korngold?
Wrong.
He was Charles Camille Saint-Saens, who was composing at the age of 3 1/2.
If you find this hard to believe, go to the Conservatoire in Paris where the manuscript is on display.
The child was playing the standard repertory with mature violinists before he was 7.

Knight-Ridder Profit Rises
LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc.'s net earnings rose 4.4 percent, to $44.9 million in the second quarter, from $43 million a year earlier, despite weakness in newspaper advertising, the big media company reported Friday.
The company's pretax profit, however, declined to $74.8 million from $78.9 million.
Revenues rose 3.3 percent to $544.6 million from $526.9 million.

Issue for SSC Holdings
LEAD: The SSC Holdings Corporation is issuing $500 million of debt in three tranches through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
The first tranche of 13 percent senior subordinated extendible notes is priced at par and due in 1998.
Due in 2000 will be $125 million of 12 1/2 percent notes and $175 million of 13 1/4 percent notes.


Ambush in Bangladesh
LEAD: Buddhist rebels shot and killed five Moslem settlers and wounded three others in an ambush Saturday on a ferry in southern Bangladesh, the police said today.
The rebels opposed a Government program resettling Moslems from the plains to hilly land.
They attacked a boat ferrying 50 settlers near the hill town of Rangamati, about 120 miles southeast of Dhaka, a police officer said.

Fashion Channel Filing
LEAD: The Fashion Channel Network Inc., which sells clothes through cable television, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

Runway Accident in India
LEAD: An Air France Boeing 747 jet carrying 275 people swerved off a runway at New Delhi's airport and crashed into a field today after the pilot aborted takeoff because he thought an engine was on fire, airport officials said.
No one was seriously injured in the accident, the Airport Authority said.
Indian news agencies said several passengers on the flight, which had been bound for Paris, were treated for minor cuts and bruises after evacuating the plane through emergency chutes.

'Cosby' Reruns Give Stations An Intimidating Weapon
LEAD: IN the last four years, one program, ''The Cosby Show,'' has essentially rearranged the network television business.
The show brought NBC from last to first, its enormous popularity cannily exploited to build an empire of hits and to ruin the strategies of the opposition.
Producers lucky enough to have shows proximate to ''Cosby'' on the NBC schedule are now Hollywood moguls.

Copper Price Forecast
LEAD: Higher world copper output next year is likely to end a run of price increases that began about a year ago, Shearson Lehman Hutton predicted Friday in its quarterly report.
Shearson said copper prices, which earlier hit spot highs of $1.50 a pound, had not regained these levels.
Shearson said the current year's surplus would be 65,000 metric tons, against a previous estimate of 130,000 metric tons.

Bridge
LEAD: For 60 years, since the dawn of contract bridge, the most difficult events to win in New York City have been the knockout team championships, scheduled two or three times a year at regional tournaments.

Kathie Wei, Judi Radin, Karen McCallum and Kitty Bethe, all of Manhattan; Carol Simon, of Summit, N.J., and Susan Green, of Alexandria, Va., won their semifinal match with some help from the diagramed deal.

LEAD: River currents have ruptured the main petroleum pipeline in eastern Colombia, spilling thousands of barrels of oil and halting operations at a pumping station, the state-owned oil company Ecopetrol said today.

The cause was under investigation.

Scientists Discover Formula Describing Coiling of DNA
LEAD: TO fit into a cell, the genetic material DNA must twist and coil upon itself until it has been reduced to one ten-thousandth of its original size.
Now, researchers have discovered a mathematical formulation describing how the helical structure of the DNA molecule determines its ability to twist and coil.

LEAD: Trader Publications of Clearwater, Fla., publishes 50 magazines, and all of them consist of classified ads with accompanying photographs in such product categories as cars, trucks and boats and variations of each.
It has been acquired by Cox Enterprises of Atlanta and will continue to operate under its founder, Stuart Arnold, and under its old name.

LEAD: APPLICATIONS to enter graduate schools of business administration have dropped since the stock market collapsed last October.
But some academic leaders think the overall effect on M.B.A. programs, especially the better ones, has been slight - perhaps even helpful.
Good graduate business schools among the 700 in the nation now must scramble a little harder to attract high-caliber students.
