Steel Production Dips
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.905 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 2.2 percent from the previous week's 1.947 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 89.3 percent of capacity in the week, compared with 91.3 percent in the previous week.


Business and Health; Costly Procedures Under Scrutiny
LEAD: CONGRESSIONAL experts and private insurers are taking a hard look at new studies indicating that questionable or unnecessary medical and surgical procedures ordered by physicians may be adding significantly to health care costs.


Israelis Release Token Group of Palestinians
LEAD: Palestinians being greeted by friends and relatives as they arrived by bus yesterday in Gaza City from a prison in the Negev Desert.
They were part of a group of 148 prisoners released as a good-will gesture.
Military officials say that there are 6,400 Palestinians currently being held.
Meanwhile, Arabs clashed with Israeli soldiers in the occupied territories.


Profits Rise At 7 Big Oil Companies
LEAD: Seven oil companies yesterday reported sharply higher earnings in the second quarter, reflecting strong profits in oil refining and marketing operations, as well as higher returns from chemical operations.


Mercedes Inquiry Is Enlarged
LEAD: Federal regulators have expanded their investigation of unintended acceleration in Mercedes-Benz automobiles to include 309,000 vehicles made from 1984 through 1988, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

LEAD: A man described by United States officials as one of the biggest international drug traffickers has been indicted on narcotics charges here, along with 21 other people.


Deputy Mayor Links Ambulance Problems to Heat
LEAD: Acknowledging that New York City's ambulances do not adequately cover the city, First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff yesterday attributed much of the problem to this summer's exceptionally high temperatures and mounting demand.

LEAD: Michael Exner, president of the Skylink Corporation of Boulder, Colo., is seeing his dream of a mobile communications system based on a satellite link, taking another step closer to fruition.

Sports People; Twin Wrestlers
LEAD: Two of the 10 freestyle wrestlers who will represent the United States in the Olympic Games at Seoul, South Korea, began competing at age 9 on the living room floor of their parents' home in Mobridge, S.D.
Jim and Bill Scherr, identical twins, eventually moved their ragtag grappling on the rug to more orderly matches downstairs in the basement where their father served as referee and their grandfather as timer.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia says it is lowering its goal for economic growth next year by one-third.

Confidence Index Rises
LEAD: Business leaders have grown more confident about the economy, although they remain worried about a recession, according to a new survey.
The Conference Board, a business-financed research group, said its business confidence index had risen to 58 during the second quarter, from 51 during the first three months of the year and 47 in the quarter of the stock market collapse.

Science Watch; Genetic Puzzle
LEAD: Friedreich's ataxia, a rare and puzzling disease of the nervous system has long been known to be hereditary, but it has never been clear whether it resulted from one gene defect or any of several.
No one has known which of the 23 pairs of human chromosomes harbor the defect or what chemical abnormality produces its symptoms.

Q&amp;A

Review/Television; Music Shows Returning To Lean, No-Frills Form
LEAD: No-frills music is making a comeback on television.
Now that music videos have developed their own elaborate cliches, there are an increasing number of music specials reverting to a simplicity that is undeniably refreshing.
In most cases, the performers are taped in performance.
The focus is kept on the music, not on special effects or pointless scenarios.


Kentucky Under Inquiry
LEAD: The Kentucky basketball program is being investigated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association over allegations that a package sent by an assistant coach to a recruit's father contained $1,000.


Washington Talk: Briefing; The Nina Issue
LEAD: For years Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank has been a fan of Al Hirschfeld, the show business caricaturist.
And when Mr.
Frank took office last March, he was delighted to learn that the Citizens Stamp Advisory Committee had already commissioned and received three Hirschfeld drawings of Laurel and Hardy, Mary Pickford and Rosa Ponselle for a series of 25-cent stamps commemorating great entertainers.


Olympic Notebook; 16 Who Got Money Fail to Make Team
LEAD: Early in the track and field season, The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field, established a financial assistance program, Operation Seoul, for 44 athletes judged to be medal contenders in the Olympics.


Champions of the Rhododendron Press the Cause
LEAD: JUST back from China, source of most of the world's rhododendrons, Richard Piacentini has brought home to the Pacific Northwest a botanical dream.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on May 27 about a proposed automatic driverless trolley line in Los Angeles misstated the novelty of the system.

Anacomp Reduces Xidex Buyout Bid

Anacomp, a leading supplier of micrographics products, had previously said it would pay $10 for each of Xidex's 41.5 million outstanding shares.

Peripherals; Call of the Dogfight Beckons Armchair Pilots
LEAD: PROGRAMS like Sublogic's Flight Simulator II and Microsoft's Flight Simulator put you behind control panels so realistic that you actually do have to learn how a plane is flown and what its many instruments do.
Mastering one of these programs amounts to committing yourself to a whole new hobby, and they are known to be popular not only with armchair aviators but also with occasional or even professional pilots.

LEAD: James W. Silver, a professor of American history at the University of Mississippi for more than 30 years whose outspokenly liberal views on racial equality stirred controversy throughout that state, died of complications from emphysema yesterday in Tampa, Fla.
He was 81 years old.

LEAD: OF all the touchy moments on the job, an exchange of criticism ranks high on the list.

LEAD: A star with the Czechoslovak national hockey team is defecting in order to play for the Islanders, the office of the player's agent, Rich Winters, said yesterday from Edmonton, Alberta.
David Volek, a forward, reportedly was to arrive in Edmonton last night from Frankfurt, West Germany.

Fleet-NorstaR To Acquire Banks
LEAD: Fleet-Norstar Financial Group said it had agreed to acquire Indian Head Banks Inc., a New Hampshire bank holding company, in an exchange of stock valued at about $240 million.
The deal calls for Fleet-Norstar to exchange 1.775 common shares for each of Indian Head's shares.
The exchange ratio represents a price of about $44.375 for each Indian Head share, based on Fleet-Norstar's closing price of $25 a share on Friday.


Boatyard Strikers Gain Senator's Support
LEAD: Metal Trades Council members marching in Groton, Conn., in support of striking Electric Boat workers.
The 25-day-old strike, to demand improved wages and benefits, has also gained the support of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who said it was for ''a good cause.'' (AP)

LEAD: A 2,700-acre forest fire in Yellowstone National Park burned to within eight miles of Old Faithful yesterday, but officials were optimistic that the flames would bypass the famed geyser.

Chrysler to Raise Its Fleet Prices
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had told its auto dealers that prices for fleets of 1989-model cars would increase between 3 percent and 5 percent.
But these tentative increases may not have a bearing on the final retail prices, which are expected to be announced in August along with final fleet prices, the company said.

Gunman Slays Guard At a Hospital in Bronx
LEAD: An unarmed guard manning a metal detector at a Bronx hospital was fatally shot yesterday when he tried to detain two men, one of whom was carrying a gun, the police said.

Mellon Set To Shift Bad Loans
LEAD: In a bold move intended to sweep its bad loans from its balance sheet, the Mellon Bank Corporation announced yesterday that it would transfer about $1 billion of its $1.6 billion in bad loans to a newly created entity.
Mellon's move will result in a one-time loss of about $200 million in the third quarter.

At Fireman's Fund, a Profit
LEAD: The Fireman's Fund Corporation, an insurance company based in Novato, Calif., yesterday reported second-quarter net income of $51 million, or $1.05 share, in contrast to a $116 million net loss a year before.
In the 1987 period the company set aside a large amount for reserves against losses and adjustments.

LEAD: Reasserting its status as the provider of the most powerful commercial data processing computers, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced 10 mainframe computers and said it had begun shipping a new operating system that would increase the performance of those machines and its other most powerful computers.

LEAD: The head of a small city police department in Florida was appointed Chief of Police in the nation's seventh largest city today.

Castro Foresees Accord Ending War in Angola
LEAD: President Fidel Castro declared tonight that ''we are now on the threshold of a political solution'' to the 13-year-long civil war in Angola.
It was the strongest statement so far by a national leader that an end to the war was in sight.


Review/Music; The Hardy And Fragile Offenbach
LEAD: As a transplant to America, the operettas of Offenbach are at once hardy and fragile.
The tunes are delicious and the sheer verve of the scores is irresistible.
Musically they are close to the level of the Johann Strauss and Gilbert and Sullivan works that are their contemporaries in comic opera's richest era after Rossini.

Credit Markets; Bond Prices in a Narrow Range
LEAD: The bond market largely shrugged off a stunning surge in the June durable goods index, reported yesterday, because many participants viewed the 8.8 percent rise as an aberration.


Marcos Says He Seeks a Deal For a Return to the Philippines
LEAD: Facing the possibility of indictment in the United States, Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he was negotiating with the Philippine Government on conditions under which he might return to his homeland.


Poland Debt Postponed
LEAD: The Soviet Union has agreed to postpone for 10 years the repayment of $1.5 billion in hard-currency debts owed by Poland, a Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said today.
The announcement follows an agreement reached on July 20 under which Western banks also rescheduled the repayment of $9 billion in debt.


Panel Votes for a Rise in Milk Prices
LEAD: Ignoring warnings by some Democrats and Republicans alike about the possibility of a consumer backlash, the House Agriculture Committee voted to raise milk support prices starting in October as part of a legislative proposal it approved today to aid farmers hurt financially by the drought.

LEAD: Cadwell Davis Partners, a Saatchi &amp; Saatchi company, is acting as the agency to help the Control Data Corporation's Ticketron initiate itself into the travel business with Ticketron Trip.


Adult Broadcasting Opposed
LEAD: The Senate tonight approved an amendment by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, to end a Federal Communications Commission policy that allows radio stations to air sexually explicit adult broadcasts between midnight and 6 A.M.
By voice vote, the Senate attached the amendment to an appropriations bill that will be sent to a conference with the House.


Iranian Meets U.N. Chief on Gulf War
LEAD: Peace negotiations aimed at ending the nearly eight-year-old Persian Gulf war began here today as Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar held two rounds of talks with the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati.

LEAD: A selection of sports and outdoor magazines, automobile buff magazines and handyman magazines - in other words the kind of publications that attract guys who maintain their own cars - will run ads October through December that will carry checks that will not only give interested consumers an instant $2 rebate for the purchase of six or more quarts of Valvoline motor oil but will also carry numbers that might make them winners of $100,000.

LEAD: Boston's 12-game winning streak under Manager Joe Morgan came to an end tonight as Ruben Sierra's two-run homer in the seventh inning gave the Texas Rangers a 9-8 victory over the Red Sox.

Sheldon T. Mills, 83, A Former Ambassador
LEAD: Sheldon Tibbetts Mills, a former United States ambassador to Ecuador, Afghanistan and Jordan, died of heart failure last Wednesday at the Valle Verde Retirement Community complex where he lived with his wife.
He was 83 years old.
Mr.
Mills was appointed a United States Foreign Service officer in 1927, launching a diplomatic career that spanned more than 32 years.He was stationed in places like La Paz, Bolivia; Santiago, Chile; New Delhi, and Rio de

LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods advanced in June at their fastest pace in 42 months, an 8.8 percent increase that was propelled by heavy demand for new commercial aircraft.

The Media Business: Advertising; A Magazine for Chefs
LEAD: Michael and Ariane Batterberry, who founded Food &amp; Wine magazine in 1978, now published by American Express, will start a trade magazine for chefs and other food preparation professionals named Food Arts.
It will have a controlled circulation of 50,000 and will be issued six times a year.
A black-and-white ad page will sell for $5,600 and a four-color page for $7,400.


Tyson Settles Rift With His Manager
LEAD: Mike Tyson settled his emotional and sometimes bitter dispute with Bill Cayton yesterday, and the champion announced that he was ''running the show now.''

SmithKline Division Loses Its President
LEAD: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation's slump in earnings as a result of slower sales for its two major prescription drugs took a victim yesterday.
James H. Cavanaugh resigned as president of Smith Kline &amp; French Laboratories, the company's domestic pharmaceutical division.


Company News; Chrysler Reports Low '88 Inventory
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation is running out of its 1988 cars and trucks and may reduce its incentive programs further, the company's chief sales analyst said.
Steve Torok, the director of sales operations planning, said the automobile maker's inventory of cars was down to 57 days, and its supply of trucks was down to 48 days.

LEAD: Fazlur Rahman, an author and leading scholar in Islamic studies, died of complications after heart surgery yesterday in Chicago.
He was 68 years old and lived in Naperville, Ill.

Bibby has also coached for the last three seasons in the United States Basketball League.(

Bill to Combat Hunger Clears Senate, 89 to 7
LEAD: The Senate today approved a bill to combat hunger by expanding the food stamp program and rejuvenating Government distribution of surplus milk, cheese and other commodities to the poor.


Fires Rage in Yellowstone Park
LEAD: Forest Service workers monitoring the progress of one of several fires burning in the national park in Wyoming.
One blaze has covered 5,500 acres.
Yesterday it threatened Old Faithful, and helicopters were dispatched in an effort to protect the area around the geyser.
About 1,000 firefighters were assembled in the area, but officials had not decided whether to actively fight the fire.

Executive Changes
LEAD: Alitalia, the Italian airline whose parent company is Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, appointed Carlo Verri director and chairman.
He is replacing Umberto Nordio, who resigned last week after a public dispute over management strategy.


Wasserstein Stake Sold
LEAD: Nomura Securities Ltd., Japan's largest investment company, announced today that it would join forces with the Wall Street firm of Wasserstein, Perella &amp; Company to work on mergers and acquisitions.


Study Finds 31% Rate of Miscarriage
LEAD: Thirty-one percent of all conceptions end in miscarriage, usually in the early months of pregnancy and often before women even know they are pregnant, according to a new study.
But most of the women who have miscarriages are normally fertile and subsequently become pregnant again and have babies, the study reported.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''You get a flavor of what life was like in the Department of Justice.
It was a world of 'Alice in Wonderland' - a world of illusion and allusion: a world in which up was down and down was up, in was out and out was in, happy was sad and sad was happy.''  - Arnold I. Burns, former Deputy Attorney General.

LEAD: DISAPPOINTING earnings reports have made the last two weeks miserable for investors in technology stocks.
Companies that published earnings lower than what Wall Street analysts had expected, like Seagate Technology, Tandem Computers and Apollo Computer, have seen their stock prices fall as much as 30 to 50 percent.

LEAD: A quotation in the Q&amp;A column of Science Times yesterday, in the answer to a question about Earth's atmosphere, characterized the temperature of Venus incorrectly.
It is a hot planet.

LEAD: Wang Laboratories Inc. has introduced its VS 5000 series of four low-cost minicomputers designed for small businesses, corporate departments and offices in large corporations.

LEAD: EVERY utility regulator who stayed awake through Econ 101 knows that standard cost-plus-a-guaranteed-profit regulation is a sure ticket to mediocre performance.
But few are as determined as Dennis Patrick, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to find a way to keep a lid on telephone profits without deadening incentives to innovate and cut waste.

Marietta Net Rises 14%
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit had risen 14 percent on a revenue increase of 3.6 percent.
The aerospace contractor reported earnings of $81.4 million, or $1.53 a share, compared with $71.6 million, or $1.31 a share, in the second quarter of 1987.
Sales for the second quarter rose to $1.44 billion from $1.39 billion a year ago.

Suspect Placed in Athens on Eve of Hijacking
LEAD: Mohammed Ali Hamadei, who is on trial in Frankfurt on charges of air piracy and killing an American hostage, was in Athens on the eve of the hijacking there of a Trans World Airlines jetliner in June 1985, the court was told today.


Fashion Isn't All Diapers, You Know
LEAD: IT'S a hard life, being toted around in Mom's or Dad's arms, trying to look cool and stylish among the fashionable crowd at a charity event.
Still, someone has to do it.
Take the young guests seen recently at an auction in Bellport Village, L.I., that benefited AIDS research.
With bonnets and bows at the ready, these youngsters proved that the diaper set could stay dapper in the heat for a good cause.


Political Frustration Spawns a Brazilian Party
LEAD: The formation of a new Brazilian political party seems unlikely to stir interest in a country that already has 30 parties, 11 of which are represented in Congress and all of which have gained legal status in the last six years.


The Media Business: Advertising
LEAD:  Addendum


The Media Business: Advertising; Thompson U.S.A. Wins $10 Million in Business
LEAD: J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. has won two accounts, one in Los Angeles and another in Detroit, totaling more than $10 million in business.


Settlements in Insider Case
LEAD: Geoffrey W. Collier, the former head of stock trading for Morgan Grenfell Securities Ltd., today settled Federal civil charges that in 1986 he illegally bought stock in two companies that he knew were likely to receive takeover bids from investment banking clients of the London-based brokerage firm.


At the Nation's Table
LEAD: RESIDENTS of Sheboygan, 50 miles north of Milwaukee, are proud of their city, proud of their German heritage and proud of their bratwurst.
And on Bratwurst Day - Saturday, Aug. 6 this year -the citizens turn out to show that pride.


11 Carriers Charged With Discarding the Mail
LEAD: Eleven United States Postal Service letter carriers in Brooklyn - a quarter of the carriers at the New Lots post office - were charged yesterday with throwing away thousands of pieces of mail.


Astoria Journal; A Radio Station Returns to Its Roots
LEAD: By day, Barbara Freeman runs the Parnassus Bookstore near the south bank of the Columbia River.
By evening, several times each month, she selects a few books from the shelves and reads bedtime stories over radio station KMUN-FM to the 10,000 residents of this old city in northwestern Oregon where the Columbia empties into the


Review/Television; A Briton With a Flair For French Cooking
LEAD: And now for something refreshingly different in television's approach to food and cooking.
It is being whipped up by Keith Floyd, whose BBC series ''Floyd on France'' can be seen Wednesdays at 8:30 P.M on Channel 13.


House Panel Recommends Impeachment of Judge
LEAD: The House Judiciary Committee, by a vote of 32 to 1, recommended today that Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami be impeached on 17 counts of misconduct despite his acquittal at a bribery trial in 1983.





Business Technology; A Race to Make an Old Power-Plant Idea Work
LEAD: An international race is on to commercialize a highly efficient form of electricity generation that uses gas or molten metal as a conductor instead of the copper wire used in conventional generators.


Texas Bank Loses Capital
LEAD: Texas American Bancshares Inc., which expects to be acquired soon by Carl R. Pohlad, the Minnesota investor, said today that most of its capital base had been eliminated by its second-quarter loss of $135.3 million.


Greeks Say Arms Used in Terror Raid on Ship Are Traced to Libya
LEAD: The Greek authorities have determined that the weapons used in the terrorist attack this month on a Greek excursion vessel were of Libyan origin, senior Greek police officials say.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Hungary, Communist?
LEAD: Facing interrogation in an alien tongue, not to mention an alien culture, would seem to be a formidable challenge.
But Hungary's Prime Minister Karoly Grosz, who is also General Secretary of the ruling Communist Party, carried it off with aplomb yesterday before a large audience at the National Press Club.


Former Aides Assail Meese's Leadership
LEAD: The former chief deputy to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told Congress today that under Mr.
Meese, the Justice Department had become ''a world of Alice in Wonderland - a world of illusion.''

U.S. Said to Study Boesky-Drexel Deals for Tax Violations
LEAD: Federal investigators are examining evidence that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. may have aided Ivan F. Boesky in a scheme to violate Federal tax laws, people with knowledge of the investigation said yesterday.


Company News; Alltel Makes Offer For CP National
LEAD: The Alltel Corporation has offered to acquire the CP National Corporation in a stock swap that values the telephone utility company at about $280 million.
Under the offer, which was made Monday, Alltel, a Hudson-based telephone utility holding company, would exchange 1.1 shares of its common stock for each outstanding common share of CP National, which is based in Walnut Creek, Calif., and is also involved in energy services.


U.S. Planning New Covert Acts Against Noriega
LEAD: President Reagan has ordered the Central Intelligence Agency to pursue additional covert actions aimed at ousting the Panamanian leader, General Manuel Antonio Noriega, a Government official said tonight.


REAGAN IS PRESSED ON PLANT CLOSINGS
LEAD: Senators Bob Dole and Alan K. Simpson, citing potential damage to Republican candidates this fall, said today that they had strongly urged President Reagan not to veto a bill requiring companies to provide 60 days' notice of factory closings or large-scale layoffs.


Revived Righetti Saves Yankees
LEAD: Jack Clark played a strange position last night, one he hadn't played in nearly 12 years.
Dave Righetti played his usual position, one his manager said is becoming comfortable to him once again.


A Woman Learning to Drive Kills Her Child in an Accident
LEAD: A woman who was learning to drive in a stolen car accidentally killed her daughter tonight when she drove into a concrete wall, causing it to fall and crush the 7-year-old, the police said.


Corrections
LEAD: The Peripherals column in Science Times yesterday misstated the availability of Jet, a flight-simulation program, and gave an incorrect address for the manufacturer, the Sublogic Corporation.
The program is not yet available for the Macintosh line of computers.
Sublogic's new address is 501 Kenyon Road, Champaign, Ill.

Company News; Florida Steel Backs Sweetened Offer
LEAD: The Florida Steel Corporation has agreed to a sweetened leveraged buyout offer from a management group that is valued at nearly $306 million.
Florida Steel would receive $50 a share for up to 85 percent of its 6.01 million common shares, or $50 a share for 5.1 million shares, with the unpurchased stock being converted into a new series of preferred stock.


Santucci Office To Fight Voiding Of Bribery Case
LEAD: The Queens District Attorney's office will fight a ruling that overturned a bribe-solicitation conviction in a case stemming from the awarding of cable-television franchises.

A. &amp; Q. in the Wright Case
LEAD: Finally, and wisely, the House Ethics Committee has answered an urgent question about its inquiry into the finances of Speaker Jim Wright: Would it ask an outside counsel to supervise the investigation?
By hiring Richard Phelan, a Chicago lawyer, the committee gives an affirmative answer.
Even so, a question remains about the committee's determination to investigate credibly.

LEAD: California's Education Superintendent has told schools in this state not to give information about their students to three publishing companies that he said had duped parents into paying for an essentially worthless service.

PANEL UNANIMOUS ON WRIGHT INQUIRER
LEAD: The House ethics committee today formally selected Richard J. Phelan, the head of a Chicago law firm, to lead its investigation of Speaker Jim Wright, the nation's highest-ranking elected Democrat.


Critic's Notebook; Opera in Brooklyn: A Preliminary Bravo
LEAD: The recently announced decision of the Metropolitan Opera to mount experimental productions at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1991 is part of a larger plan for performances at the academy that may be the most promising operatic venture New York has seen in decades.


The California Work Ethic: Be Beautiful
LEAD: The reigning Miss California, Marlise Ricardos, is a 26-year-old, 5-foot-9, impressively slender Latin beauty who frosts her hair and sometimes wears blue contact lenses when she competes.
She's the ultimate self-made competitor, a chemically ''sun streaked'' miss who rid herself of both pounds and ethnic identity to please pageant judges.


21 HELD IN JERSEY CONSTRUCTION INQUIRY
LEAD: Twenty-one people were arrested today in a state police investigation into corruption in the construction industry.


For Schools in Los Angeles, A Blueprint for Progress
LEAD: The Los Angeles School District has been given an outline for what administrators call its most far-reaching education reform effort: a report with 612 recommendations to improve the city's schools.


The Next Big Crisis
LEAD: The cold war isn't over.
But even as the political climate is warming, so is the world's physical climate.
There are many signs that the next general international crisis is going to be about the environment.
It can become as abrasive, dangerous and costly as the arms race.


Free Brass Concert
LEAD: The Canadian Brass will give a free concert today at 1 P.M. at the Lincoln Center fountain.
The five musicians - Frederick Mills and Ronald Romm on trumpets, Eugene Watts on trombone, David Ohanian on French horn and Chuck Daellenbach on tuba - will play Christmas music as a gesture against the summer heat.


IRAN OFFERS HELP TO FREE HOSTAGES IN DEAL WITH U.S.
LEAD: A senior Iranian leader said today that Iran would help obtain the release of American hostages in Lebanon if the United States returned Iranian assets frozen in this country.


Firehouse Help for Medical Emergencies
LEAD: New York City is home to many of the world's best hospitals and physicians.
But in an emergency, their ability to help may depend entirely on how rapidly city ambulances respond.
Deaths caused by ambulance delays are intolerable - the more so because firefighters are already deployed and ready to help.

Extradition Policy Is Politics in Another Guise
LEAD: To the Editor:


Japanese Defense Force Mourns Victims of Boat Collision
LEAD: Members of the Japanese Defense Forces, in white uniforms, bowing to a hearse carrying the bodies of victims killed in a collision between a Defense Force submarine and a small pleasure craft.
Twenty-nine people have been confirmed as dead in the accident, and one is still missing. (Reuters)


NBC Names Gartner as News Chief
LEAD: NBC has reached outside of broadcasting and chosen a newspaper executive, Michael G. Gartner, to be the new president of NBC News.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Brighter Trips
LEAD: Painters on Capitol Hill have been doing their bit to spruce up the working environment for the Senate.
The result is a new midnight blue tint on one of the four subway cars that shuttle lawmakers between their offices and the Senate chamber.


2d Mistrial Declared in Gotti Case After Jury Impasse
LEAD: A Federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the drug and racketeering case against Gene Gotti and two others after jurors said they could not reach a verdict.
It was the second mistrial in the case.


NEW EFFORT IN THE U.S. BY PEUGEOT
LEAD: FRANCE'S reviving automotive giant, the PSA Group, maker of Peugeot, Citroen and Talbot, is preparing to introduce its Peugeot 405 to the United States consumer market.
Consequently, Peugeot Motors of America is increasing its advertising budget fivefold, its president, Pascal H. Henault, said.

Silverman said.

Ralph Daniel Junker, Surgeon, 65
LEAD: Dr.
Ralph Daniel Junker, a surgeon, died of a heart attack last Thursday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital, where he had been a member of the staff from 1958 to 1978.
He was 65 years old and lived in Tryon, N.C.

LEAD: Sil Campusano, Jesse Barfield and Fred McGriff hit bases-empty home runs today as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Minnesota Twins, 4-1, and ended Frank Viola's 19-game regular-season winning streak in the Metrodome.

Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: DINAH Daniels never expected to take over the family business.

Crisis in Emergency Rooms: More Symptoms Than Cures
LEAD: It was only 6 o'clock on a recent Saturday night when the busiest emergency room in downtown Los Angeles, at the California Medical Center, ordered all ambulances diverted to other hospitals.
The 13 beds were already filled: a woman delivering a baby, a boy with an asthmatic attack, a 6-year-old girl bleeding from apparent sexual abuse, a young man hurt in a car accident and, the last straw, a 48-year-old man in full cardiac arrest.

Review/Music; Haydn and Mozart On Original Instruments
LEAD: How strange it is to realize that the Haydn Cello Concerto in C, an understandably popular work with cellists, was discovered only 26 years ago among the uncatalogued holdings of the Prague National Museum!
Christopher Hogwood offered the work, with Anner Bylsma as the soloist, as the centerpiece of his second Mostly Mozart ''Music on Original Instruments'' program, Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

Technology for Korea
LEAD: South Korea's imports of advanced technology for machinery and other projects rose 49 percent in the first half of this year from a year earlier, Government officials said today.
Japan was the largest supplier of technology, with 181 imports, followed by the United States with 90 and European nations with 46.

Inquiry Is Ordered on Conduct of a Top State Judge in Bronx
LEAD: The chief administrative judge for New York State said yesterday that he had authorized an inquiry into allegations that a top judge in the Bronx improperly directed business to an insurance company run by a friend.


Ex-Sergeant Tells of Davis Shootout
LEAD: A retired police sergeant choked back tears yesterday as he described a gun battle between Larry Davis and police officers and the wounding of a fellow officer.


China's Harvest Plans
LEAD: China issued a nationwide order today to spare no effort to bring in the autumn crop after announcing a decline in the summer grain harvest.
The People's Daily published on its front page an order from the State Council stating that China would have to rely on the autumn crop to reach its grain target for the year, but adding that this would be difficult because of drought, floods and typhoons.

LEAD: Santa Barbara Savings and Loan, a subsidiary of the Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara, is offering $310 million of participation certificates through a real estate mortgage investment conduit managed by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
The issue is the first such offering backed by fixed-rate mortgages with rates based on the Cost Of Funds index rather than the London interbank offered rate.

LEAD: CEILING fans turn slowly in the heat above a table set for lunch.

Farther along in the 60-foot-long greenhouse, comfortable rattan furniture is arranged as a whimsical sitting room.
Fanciful metal topiary frames stand empty.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Cypriot to Visit
LEAD: The president of Cyprus, George Vassiliou, arrives in Washington today for an official visit that may involve him and his country in Presidential politics in the United States as well as focus attention on the long controversy over Turkish occupation of nearly half the Mediterranean island.


NBC Appoints President for Its New Cable-TV Division
LEAD: The National Broadcasting Company yesterday announced the creation of a division - NBC Cable - and named Thomas S. Rogers as its president.


Currents; A Fresh Line of Furniture
LEAD: WHEN the shoppers began to disappear from Broome Street and headed north to Prince Street, Peri Wolfman, co-owner of Wolfman Gold &amp; Good, a housewares store, went with them.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''By golly, there's something unusual going on here.
Generally, fish don't attack people.''  - Weldon E. Jones of the California Department of Fish and Game.  [ A16:1. ]


Talking Deals; Mellon's Spinoff Of Shaky Loans
LEAD: DREXEL BURNHAM LAMBERT ostensibly called the news conference Tuesday to explain how it was helping restore the health of the Mellon Bank Corporation with an innovative plan to spin off most of its bad loans.
But, it soon became clear, Drexel viewed this as a chance to spread the word that the same approach could be applied to the loan portfolios of many other banks.


International Paper Settles Federal Allegations
LEAD: The International Paper Company said today that it had agreed to pay the Federal Government $873,220 to settle hundreds of allegations of safety violations at its paper mill in Jay, Me.


Sports People; Forfeits by Temple
LEAD: Temple University has reacted sternly after Paul Palmer, the 1986 all-America running back and Heisman Trophy runnerup, admitted last week that he had violated his eligibility by signing a contract with Norby Walters, a professional agent.
Palmer also admitted he accepted an interest-free loan of $5,000 and payments of several hundred dollars a month during his final season.

LEAD: After spending 28 years around harness tracks, George Berkner now has the favorite in the richest race on harness racing's richest night.

LEAD: Randall Cunningham, the Eagles' quarterback, ended his holdout yesterday by signing a three-year contract believed to be the richest in the history of the Philadelphia franchise.

Santa Fe Stake Sold By Henley
LEAD: Michael D. Dingman, chairman of the Henley Group, yesterday gave up his two-and-a-half-year battle for control of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.


McCartney May Tour Soviet Union
LEAD: Paul McCartney, a former member of the Beatles, will tour the Soviet Union later this year or in the spring of 1989, according to a report in Moscow News, a Soviet weekly.


Foreign Policy Paradox
LEAD: By the ordinary logic of politics, foreign policy should help George Bush in this election campaign.
The United States is at peace, the perception of Soviet menace diminished, the Ayatollah Khomeini in retreat.
When threats abroad subside, those in power expect to benefit politically.


A McKesson Promotion
LEAD: The McKesson Corporation said today that Thomas W. Field, its president and chief executive, had been named chairman.
Mr.
Field, 54 years old, succeeds Neil E. Harlan, 67, who will remain a director.


Castro Faults Soviet Tactics in War in Angola
LEAD: In an annual speech that has become a kind of report to the Cuban nation, Fidel Castro asserted that Soviet military tactics in Angola almost caused a disaster for Angolan soldiers, who had to be saved by a large-scale infusion of additional Cuban troops.


John McCook Roots, Journalist, 84
LEAD: John McCook Roots, a foreign correspondent and author, died Tuesday at Mackinac Straits Hospital in St.
Ignace, Mich.
He was 84 years old.


Acquitted in 'Pizza Connection' Trial, Man Remains in Prison
LEAD: More than four years after he was arrested in the ''pizza connection'' drug case and more than a year after he became the only defendant acquitted in the record trial that followed, the son of a Sicilian Mafia boss remains in jail in a convoluted immigration case.

Hefner Says Playing Days Are Over
LEAD: Hugh M. Hefner, for decades one of the world's most eligible and determined bachelors, the man who keeps a Latin plaque at his front door saying ''If you don't swing, don't ring,'' is no longer eligible.


Forstmann's Pullman Bid
LEAD: The Pullman Company of Princeton, N.J., announced late yesterday that it had received a buyout offer of $9.25 a share from Forstmann Little &amp; Company.

Should Cocaine Cost More? Less?
LEAD: Does the American public want cocaine prices to go up - or down?
Present anti-drug policies are so muddled that America cannot answer so clear a question.

LEAD: Since the Pentagon investigation of possible military-procurement fraud and bribery began to unfold six weeks ago, Secretary Defense Frank C. Carlucci has imposed a series of interim measures modifying acquisition practices within the $150 billion-a-year military-procurement system.

Finance/New Issues; Farm Credit Banks Agency Sets Rates on Three Issues
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday set interest rates on three issues of Federal Farm Credit Bank consolidated systemwide bonds totaling $2.633 billion.


Getty Buys Ancient Greek Wonder
LEAD: The J. Paul Getty Museum has acquired for an undisclosed price an over-lifesize Greek cult statue, believed to represent Aphrodite, the goddess of love.
Probably dated around 420 B.C., the statue stands 90 inches high and is remarkable for the power and monumentality of the huge heavy limbs, the lightness and delicacy of the windblown draperies and the majestic serenity of the head.


Remnant of L.I. Prairie to Be Saved
LEAD: Here in the heartland of suburban Nassau County, the last remnant of a once vast prairie is being saved.


Foreigners' Holdings Up
LEAD: Direct holdings in the United States by foreign investors have more than tripled since 1980, with increases likely to continue through the end of the century, according to a private study released today.


Company News; Offer by Emigrant For Home Savings
LEAD: The Emigrant Savings Bank of New York has made an unsolicited offer to acquire the Home Savings Bank of Brooklyn.
Emigrant said that it already owned 9.9 percent of Home Savings' shares and was willing to pay $20 each for the remaining shares outstanding.
The $20 offer, which represents a 28 percent premium over Home Savings' closing price on Monday, puts the value of the deal at at least $217 million.


Finance/New Issues; Kidder Offering
LEAD: Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company is issuing $200 million of collateralized mortgage obligations backed by Government National Mortgage Association certificates.
Coupon rates range from 7.70 percent in 1997 to 9.43 percent in 2016.
The issue, which is being offered through Kidder, Peabody Mortgage Assets Trust Eighteen, is in 11 classes of bonds, including fixed-rate, floating-rate and planned amortization class bonds.


ANOTHER ENDURES
LEAD: Ending months of investigation and uncertainty, two college students who vanished here in April surfaced in San Diego and called their parents Tuesday, the police said today.


Shell Profit Drops 1.1%
LEAD: The Shell Oil Company's profits fell to $263 million in the second quarter, from $266 million a year earlier, a decline of 1.1 percent, the company said yesterday.
Revenue rose to $5.43 billion from $5.18 billion, an increase of 4.8 percent.


Doctor Cleared of Weapons Charge
LEAD: A weapons charge against a prominent Manhattan neurologist who shot and wounded a cane-wielding patient who attacked him in his Fifth Avenue office was dismissed yesterday at the request of the Manhattan District Attorney.

The Roofs Are Alive, With Alpine Plants
LEAD: CITY rooftops may lack the scenic splendor of the Alps, but hidden among the concrete crannies, alpine and rock garden plants are starting to sprout.
Once grown by only a select few, these diminutive species are gaining in popularity, according to the American Rock Garden Society, which noted more than a 10 percent rise in membership since 1986, for a total of more than 4,000 members.


Samuel Huntington, Executive for Utility
LEAD: Samuel Huntington, a lawyer and electric utility executive, was killed by lightning Tuesday in Aspen, Colo., while hiking.
He was 49 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.


Two Connecticut Men Killed In a Crash of a Small Plane
LEAD: The bodies of two Greenwich, Conn., men were found today in the wreckage of a small airplane that crashed in a remote area after distress signals were detected by the Coast Guard, the authorities said.


Seoul to Accept North's Offer of Talks on Olympics
LEAD: South Korea will reportedly accept North Korea's proposal for joint parliamentary talks that will include discussion of how the North could take part in the Olympic Games.

Ruling for N.F.L. Players
LEAD: A Federal judge has ruled that National Football League team owners owe the players' pension fund more than $19 million in overdue payments.


Yves Saint Laurent Reasserts His Mastery of Line and Color
LEAD: Yves Saint Laurent, looking racy in a green linen jacket, white pants and a red plaid tie, strode confidently down the long runway at the Hotel Inter-Continental this morning.
He carried a bouquet of white lilies, which he presented to the model wearing the wedding dress.
The audience - including Daniele Mitterrand, Blaine Trump, Lamia Khashoggi, Liza Minnelli, Paloma Picasso and Judith Taubman - had risen to its feet and applauded his progress.


Jury Is Told Meese Planned Wedtech Graft
LEAD: In a summation laced with indignation and vitriol, the lawyer for Representative Mario Biaggi charged that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d orchestrated corruption at the Wedtech Corporation and asserted that prosecutors had allowed Government witnesses to conceal millions of dollars in their haste to convict his client.


Seeking a Satellite Dish Esthetic
LEAD: THE American lawn has a rich esthetic tradition.
From the garage-door basketball hoop to the barbecue grill, it is a splendiferous outdoor sanctuary, a haven for pink flamingos, twirling plastic daisies, metal butterflies perched on windowsills and other ersatz flora and fauna.


Senate Votes to Expand Financing for Abortions
LEAD: The Senate tonight approved a measure that would permit Medicaid to pay for abortions in cases of rape or incest.
It is the first time since 1981 that either house of Congress has approved a measure to expand the use of Federal money for abortions.

Birth of Israel: A History Is Revisited
LEAD: Revisionist studies by Israeli scholars, published recently here and in Britain, have been reinterpreting many of the events surrounding the creation of the state of Israel in the years 1947 to 1949.
In general, the new books tend to place greater blame on Israel for the Palestinian problem - as well as for the turmoil, the human cost and the continued political impasse in the Middle East - than have most earlier

LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, further confirming its return to profitability, said yesterday that its net income more than tripled in the second quarter as steel prices and demand increased.

The Editorial Notebook; The Virtue of Impeachment
LEAD: When Congress removed Harry Claiborne from the Federal bench in Nevada two years ago, it was the first full use of the impeachment power in five decades.
Two more judges are now targets of impeachment proceedings.
The House Judiciary Committee yesterday recommended the impeachment of Judge Alcee Hastings of Florida.

BURMA'S NEW CHIEF CHOSEN PRESIDENT
LEAD: A former army general, U Sein Lwin, was elected President today, one day after being named party leader, and all but 2 of 22 posts in his Cabinet were filled by active or retired military officers.


Finance/New Issues; Chrysler Financial Issuing Notes
LEAD: The Chrysler Financial Corporation., a unit of the Chrysler Corporation, is issuing $300 million of extension notes due in 2008 through Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.
The notes are priced at par and have a 9.65 percent coupon rate, yielding 96 basis points more than five-year Treasury notes.


Company News; Travelers Expects Loss
LEAD: The Travelers Corporation said today that it expected to report a loss of $337 million in the second quarter after adding $415 million to its reserves for losses in its real estate business.


Consumer Rates; 6th Increase For Yields
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, the sixth consecutive strong performance in as many weeks.


Belgrade Sentences 4 For Revealing Secrets
LEAD: Three prominent Slovenian journalists and a noncommissioned officer were sentenced by a military court in Ljubljana today on charges of revealing a military secret.


Stamp Recalls Ratification Of Constitution - Again
LEAD: A new stamp that commemorates the 200th anniversary of New York's ratification of the United States Constitution and statehood was issued - again - at Federal Hall in lower Manhattan.

Health; Personal Health
LEAD: Several years ago a new disease dubbed chronic Epstein-Barr virus syndrome was described as causing severe, persistent fatigue and other perplexing symptoms among hundreds of patients throughout the country.
For the afflicted, the diagnosis was a relief, assigning a name and physical cause to an ailment that even many physicians had come to think of as an emotional disorder.

LEAD: ''We have an immense musical vocabulary available to us,'' the electric guitarist and composer Rhys Chatham said. ''Since the turn of the century, we've been looking for different directions.
Arnold Schoenberg suggested one.
John Cage suggested another.

Company News; Net at Digital Rose by 6.3% In Quarter
LEAD: Pointing to increasing demand for its computer work stations, the Digital Equipment Corporation shook off rumors of slowing sales yesterday by reporting stronger quarterly and annual earnings.
The company said that net income had risen 6.3 percent for the fourth quarter and 15 percent for the year.

LEAD: Iraq's Foreign Minister joined the Persian Gulf peace talks here today and took a hard line, demanding direct negotiations with Iran as proof that it is sincere in wanting peace.

LEAD: A growing number of countries are enacting discriminatory laws and travel restrictions to fight the spread of AIDS, according to a Harvard study.


Company News; 2 Phone Concerns Plan Joint Venture
LEAD: Two fast-growing regional long-distance telephone companies announced the creation of a new holding company they said would be the nation's fourth-largest long-distance carrier.
Atlanta-based Southernnet Inc. and the Teleconnect Company of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, said they had signed a letter of intent to create a yet-to-be-named holding company, forming a carrier serving about 400,000 customers, with revenues of more than $400 million annually.

Courses Are Safe, Navy Says
LEAD: In the wake of the drowning death of a recruit, the Navy has reviewed its training programs and concluded that there are no major problems, a top service official said today.


Reagan and Hungarian Chief Discuss Trade
LEAD: President Reagan met today with Prime Minister Karoly Grosz of Hungary and discussed closer economic ties between the two countries.


Market Place; Disparate Results In Holder Surveys
LEAD: POLLSTERS continuing to try to sort out the effect of last October's stock market crash are coming up these days with results as confusing as the recent performance of stocks themselves.
For example, a survey released today that was sponsored by the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. found that more than half of all people who have stock holdings expect to buy stock in the next 12 months.


Brussels Journal; European With Mission: A More Perfect Union
LEAD: When Jacques Delors sets off on his vacation this summer, he plans to take with him history books explaining how 13 squabbling colonies became the United States of America.
Like a chess player, the president of the European Community's commission advances one piece at a time, but beneath a cool and even shy exterior lurks a passionate visionary.


Bonds Retreat in Confused Trading
LEAD: Bond prices dropped and yields climbed in confused trading yesterday as the Federal Reserve moved boldly and unexpectedly to tighten credit.


Health; Health Insurer Is Selecting Hospitals for Transplants
LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said today that it would require policyholders needing heart, kidney or liver transplants to have them at select hospitals it considers to have the best survival rates.

LEAD: Doug Lewis, the top downhill race on the United States Ski Team the last four years, has retired from World Cup racing, the team announced yesterday.

Home Improvement
LEAD: PLASTIC plumbing pipe has many advantages over metal varieties.
Not only is plastic pipe less expensive, lighter and easier to handle, it also does not rust or corrode.
It also provides some insulation, preventing condensation from forming on pipes carrying cold water and reducing heat loss through pipes carrying hot water.

Jersey Insurance Up Again
LEAD: Nearly all New Jersey motorists will pay an average increase of $73 per car for insurance under a surcharge approved today by State Insurance Commissioner Kenneth Merin.
He said that the charge, the third insurance increase he has granted this year, is needed to bail out the deficit-ridden Joint Underwriting Association and that another surcharge probably would be imposed in January.

LEAD: Beazer P.L.C., which struck a deal last month to acquire the Koppers Company, is expected to announce, perhaps as soon as today, that a preliminary agreement to sell Koppers's chemical unit to a management-led group has fallen through, people familiar with the deal said yesterday.

Some Beaches Stay Closed
LEAD: New deposits of medical waste washed up on several New York beaches yesterday, preventing authorities from reopening three public bathing areas.
Some beaches in New Jersey also remained closed.


Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: Kurt Rambis, a free-agent forward who played seven years with the Los Angeles Lakers, has agreed to a four-year, $2.4 million contract with the expansion Charlotte Hornets.
Rambis averaged 4 points and 12 minutes a game for the Lakers last season. . . .
Ken Griffey, the 38-year-old outfielder, has been released outright by the Atlanta Braves, who called up another veteran outfielder, Lonnie Smith, from their Richmond farm team.

Review/Film; Identity Crisis: My Monkey, My Self
LEAD: George A. Romero's ''Monkey Shines: An Experiment in Fear'' has more coincidences than a Sidney Sheldon mini-series, more cliches than a Jackie Collins potboiler, and one thing they don't have - Ella, the killer monkey.
A cute little organ-grinder's monkey, Ella dusts furniture, does windows, and has been injected with an experimental serum made from freeze-dried human brain cells.


Guinness Loses Appeal to Court
LEAD: Britain's Court of Appeal today rejected Guinness P.L.C.'s appeal to overturn a ruling that the brewing giant had violated takeover rules when it acquired the Distillers Company in 1986.
The decision could eventually force Guinness to pay up to $:70 million, or about $121 million, to former shareholders of Distillers, the Scotch whisky maker.


A Balance for Bush
LEAD: With the moment for his first big decision fast approaching, George Bush needs to balance his ticket - not so much regionally or ideologically or to counter women's supposed disaffection but to strike hard at the ''silly image'' from which Jimmy Carter recently observed the Vice President to be suffering.


Debate Over a Military Bill Divides G.O.P. Lawmakers
LEAD: With President Reagan listening quietly, Republican Congressional leaders and Administration officials today heatedly debated whether the President should try to score political points against the Democrats by vetoing a $299 billion military programs bill.


FEDERAL JUDGE CHALLENGES HIMSELF ON U.S. CASES
LEAD: A Federal judge in Birmingham, Ala., has invited Government lawyers to appear before him next month and consider an extraordinary question: should he remove himself from hearing all cases in which the Federal Government is a party?


Lansing Journal; Another Lost Species: U.S. Playboy Bunny
LEAD: Hugh Hefner first proclaimed his notion of the good life in 1953 when he founded Playboy magazine.
Seven years later in Chicago, the Playboy Club was born, and it was a commercial formula perfectly suited for the first stirrings of the sexual revolution.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  International A2-7


Sports People; Contract for Wilkens
LEAD: The Cleveland Cavaliers have extended the contract of Coach Lenny Wilkens for two years, through the 1990-91 season.
It was to have expired after the upcoming season.
Two assistant coaches, Dick Helm and Brian Winters, were rehired through the 1989-90 season.


Pentagon's New Rule Troubles a Contractor
LEAD: A United Technologies Corporation executive said the company could not possibly comply with a new Pentagon directive requiring contractors to certify that they have not improperly obtained confidential inside information when bidding on contracts.


Suits Filed by 2 Unions On Cutbacks at Eastern
LEAD: The pilots' and machinists' unions at Eastern Air Lines Inc. each filed lawsuits today, seeking to block the carrier's plans to eliminate 4,000 jobs and sharply reduce its flight schedule.

A Needless Threat to Eastern Airlines
LEAD: Hemorrhaging cash and preoccupied with a fierce labor dispute, Eastern Airlines is eliminating service to 14 cities and laying off 12 percent of its employees.


Library to Receive Preservation Grants
LEAD: The New York Public Library will receive grants totaling $150,000 from the National Endowment of the Humanities to microfilm and catalogue 1,800 volumes of periodicals published in the Soviet Union between 1917 and 1940.
The grants will aid the library in preserving nearly half of its collection of titles from that period, works that are too deteriorated to allow further use by researchers.

Northrop Contract
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said it had received a new $730 million contract from the Boeing Company to build more main fuselage sections for its new 747-400 jetliner.
Northrop, which has built 720 of the 153-foot-long sections since 1966, expects to add another 300 employees this year to the program, which already has a 2,100-member work force.

Horse Racing Notebook; A High-Priced Colt Proves His Worth
LEAD: At the yearling sales last summer, five colts were sold for more than $2 million.
Three of them, purchased by Arabs, were sent to race in Europe.
The other two made their debuts in the fourth race Wednesday at Belmont Park.


Panel Urges Bigger Role For Principals
LEAD: Proposals to give New York City school principals greater authority and make them more accountable for their students' performance have been made by a panel established by the State Board of Regents.


Kennedy Spars With Justice Appointee
LEAD: The lawyer nominated for the second-ranking post in the Justice Department acknowledged at his Senate confirmation hearing today that he had not tried to find out, and still did not know, why his predecessor resigned in protest last spring.

Teamsters and Mobster Linked
LEAD: The new president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, William J. McCarthy, said in 1984 that he needed permission from a reputed organized crime boss before he could advance in the union, The Los Angeles Times reported today.


Treasury Prices Continue to Fall
LEAD: Treasury bond prices continued to decline yesterday as new evidence of a strengthening economy unsettled investors.
The Government reported that personal income rose a stronger-than-expected seven-tenths of 1 percent in June and that personal spending jumped by 1 percent.


The Law: At the Bar
LEAD: Woody Allen once wrote that some people think of sex all of the time, some people think of sex some of the time and some people never think about sex: they become lawyers.


New York Folk Arts Are in Free Exhibition
LEAD: The folk art and craft traditions of New York's many ethnic groups are the focus of an exhibition at the Paine Webber Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (near 51st Street), through Sept. 9. ''City Folk: Ethnic Traditions in the Metropolitan Area'' includes more than 100 objects dealing with national and religious holidays, cultural rites of passage and the immigrant experience.

Computers to Reshape Air Control Job in 90's
LEAD: Sometime in the early 1990's storm clouds will be displayed in a blue pattern on an air traffic controller's computer screen.
Then, with a few keyboard strokes, the controller will punch a new route into the computer, which will change the flight plans for all planes on a particular track so they can skirt the weather.


In a Retraction, Pakistan Denies Moscow Added to Afghan Force
LEAD: The Pakistani Foreign Minister today retracted his Government's charge that the Soviet Union was reinforcing its forces in Afghanistan.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article on June 29 about a Soviet newspaper's publication of a plea for legal vindication of Trotsky briefly described Trotsky's politics.
The article said Trotsky opposed Lenin's New Economic Policy.
As some scholars have written to point out, Trotsky did not oppose the policy when it was introduced in 1921, but in later years he differed sharply with other Soviet leaders over its management.


Housing Commissioner Resigns Amid Review of Cuomo Housing Policies
LEAD: The Cuomo administration, whose housing programs have drawn sharp criticism, announced today that its Housing Commissioner had resigned and said that it was reviewing its entire housing policy.


His Remarks on Trip May Cost Key Support
LEAD: Mayor Koch, once a master at commanding beneficial publicity (beneficial to him, anyway), has managed to top his bellicose performance in New York's Democratic primary by upsetting a constituency still considered pro-Koch - Irish New Yorkers.
Capping a trip to Ireland with


Corrections
LEAD: A front-page article in some editions yesterday about publicly owned sewer systems' record in meeting pollution standards misstated the amount of sewage treated by plants each day in the United States.
It is 35 billion gallons, not 35 million.

Orders for Boeing Worth $790 Million
LEAD: The Boeing Company announced that it had received orders for 12 commercial jets, with a total value estimated at up to $790 million, from a Canadian and an Australian airline.


Manila to Seek Loans
LEAD: The Philippines plans to approach its creditor banks and the International Monetary Fund for loans this autumn, the central bank governor, Jose B. Fernandez, said today.
The nation received $925 million in loans in May 1985.
The country's foreign debt stood at $28.4 billion at the end of January.

JERSEY MEDICAL COMPANY ACCUSED IN DUMPING
LEAD: A medical testing laboratory was accused today of dumping 2,000 vials of blood, some tainted with the AIDS antibody and hepatitis B virus, in a vacant lot in Woodbridge, behind an apartment building in Old Bridge and in Perth Amboy, 100 feet from the Arthur Kill.

New Zealand Budget
LEAD: New Zealand's Labor Party Government introduced a budget today that envisages major sales of state-owned assets to produce a surplus to reduce the national debt.
Finance Minister Roger Douglas also said the Government remained committed to cutting personal income taxes on Oct. 1.

New Yorkers Growing Angry Over Aggressive Panhandlers

Comical 'Family Viewing'
''Family Viewing'' was shown as part of the recent ''New Directors/ New Film'' series.
Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 23.
The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema 1, at La Guardia Place.
Video cameras and monitors watch over the characters in Atom Egoyan's ''Family Viewing'' with the patience and passivity of vultures, but without the enthusiasm.
The advent of this modern technology seems to have drained all vitality out of the participants in Mr.
Egoyan's very peculiar black comedy, and it's their listlessness that makes them so funny and sad.

Black-Jewish Hostility Rouses Leaders in Chicago to Action
LEAD: Hostility between blacks and Jews in Chicago has become so intense that a group of community leaders today called for meetings in churches and synagogues aimed at easing relations.


Bregman Rejects Multifoods Offer
LEAD: Bregman Partners, a Canadian investment concern, said it had rejected an offer of ''greenmail'' by Multifoods International for Bregman's 11.95 percent holding in the company.
Greenmail is the practice of companies paying a premium to buy their stock to stave off takovers.
Bregman said that the Minneapolis foods products company had offered $32 a share for the stake.

Sports People; Weight Lifter Dropped
LEAD: Karl-Heinz Radschinsky of West Germany, who won the gold medal in the middleweight weightlifting class at the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, has been dropped from his country's Olympic squad because he was convicted two years ago of dealing in performance-enhancing anabolic steroids.

Baby Dies; Mother Charged
LEAD: A 19-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged yesterday in the death of her infant daughter, who died Tuesday after being in a coma for 12 days, the police said.
The woman, Sandra Jenkins, of 198 Bond Street in the Gowanus Houses, a housing project in the Boerum Hill section, was charged with second-degree murder in the death of her 8-month-old daughter, Charmaine, whose skull had been fractured.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 443 money market mutual funds decreased by $330.2 million, to $266.35 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 124 institutional funds decreased by $540.3 million, to $68.74 billion.
The assets of the 220 general purpose funds were up by $278.3 million, to $83.21 billion.

LEAD:  The Economy


Dollar Ends the Day Higher After a Sluggish Beginning
LEAD: The dollar rose against major currencies yesterday, led by a strong demand in Europe and bolstered by comments by the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan.


Revco Drugstore Chain In Bankruptcy Filing
LEAD: Unable to restructure its heavy debt load and hampered by increasingly reluctant suppliers, Revco D.S.
Inc., one of the nation's largest drugstore chains, filed today for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

Restaurants
LEAD: Late July may not be the most opportune time to talk about a steakhouse - as the temperature soars, thoughts often turn to salads and seafood -but Brandywine is a special place, and the summer menu there is varied enough to offer something for all tastes.


Review/Film; Childish Tricks and Facial Tics
LEAD: While it would be impossible to prove scientifically that ''The New Adventures of Pippi Longstocking'' is the longest children's film ever made or Pippi herself the most irritating of characters, it would be difficult to persuade any audience otherwise.
Pippi is the freckle-faced, irrepressible heroine with the braids that stick out parallel to her shoulders, and one of the film's only points of interest is the star's hairdo.

LEAD: Divided by religion, social class and even geography, the Hanna family of the elegant town of Hillsborough and Brendan Davison of the bleak Markets area of South Belfast were linked in death today as they never were in life.


Yukon Dust Revives Gold Dreams
LEAD: Nearly a century after the Yukon gold rush, the family of Len and Rona Millar spends 10 hours every summer day down on Gold Bottom Creek, participating in the biggest gold-mining revival here since World War I. From a wooden home that is all that remains of a thriving gold rush town 20 miles east of Dawson, the Millars run what has become a typical Yukon mining operation.

He refused to disclose the companies that might bid, but said two or three are based outside the United States.

The double bill of neglected Richard Strauss works that John Crosby's Santa Fe Opera presented last evening offered both disappointment and revelation in roughly equal measure, which is better than par for this kind of course.

Brig.
Gen.

Celebrating Comics, Punsters and Aunt Sheila
LEAD: ONLY a handful of young comedians have created characters as finely observed as Billy Crystal's gallery of alter egos.

Crystal's creations are so affectionately observed that we see the world through their eyes even as we laugh at their foibles and pretensions.

White House Forecasts a Deficit Of $140 Billion Next Budget Year
LEAD: The Reagan Administration estimated today that the Federal deficit for the next budget year would be $140.1 billion, $5.9 billion under the level that, by law, would force automatic across-the-board spending reductions.


Alter the Catholic Church's Tax Status?
LEAD: In 1979, lawyers working with the National Abortion Rights Action League began presenting the Internal Revenue Service with scores of anti-abortion documents that had been distributed by groups connected with the Roman Catholic Church.
The lawyers contended that these newsletters, leaflets, questionnaires, reports and articles proved that the church had systematically violated the law forbidding tax exempt institutions from participating in campaigns for elective office or devoting a substantial amount of their activities to influencing legislation.

The company said the latest 6-month results reflect the acquisition of certain assets and the business of the Measurement Systems division of Page-Wilson Corp., effective March 29, 1987.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about economic growth misattributed a statement about inflation in some editions.
It was Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers - not Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board - who said, ''Prices have temporarily picked up as a result of higher food prices and higher prices for imported goods and services.

Layoffs at Tonka
LEAD: The Tonka Corporation said it had laid off 110 employees in a restructuring of its Kenner Products and Tonka toy divisions.
In cutting the 87 full-time and 23 part-time employees Wednesday, Tonka cited disappointing sales of its once hot Pound Puppies line and other Tonka products as well as a need to eliminate overlapping responsibilities with Kenner Parker Toys, which it recently acquired.

LEAD: The Snyder General Corporation withdrew its offer to acquire the York International Corporation in a letter delivered this morning, a York spokesman said.

Record Price for Seat
LEAD: A seat on the International Monetary Market was sold today for $417,000, surpassing Thursday's record sale of $399,500.
A seat on the I.M.M., the main market for foreign currency futures, allows a holder to trade all futures and options on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, except for agricultural products.

Sutter Sidelined SPORTS PEOPLE; Horner Ailing SPORTS PEOPLE; Campanis Uproar
LEAD: The long road back that Bruce Sutter appeared to have completed this season has reached a sudden detour.
After having overcome a shoulder injury that sidelined him for most of the last two seasons, Sutter, an Atlanta Braves reliever, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with Bell's palsy, an affliction that has paralyzed the right side of his face and caused severe headaches.

Canadian Airbus Order
LEAD: Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, said today that Canadian Airlines International had ordered 17 of its A320 short-to-medium-range airliners and placed options on 17 more.
An Airbus spokesman also said Canadian Airlines had expressed interest in 17 more A320's, over and above those on option.

Horner Ailing
LEAD: Bob Horner, the St.
Louis Cardinals' first baseman, may miss the remainder of the season with continuing shoulder problems, according to Manager Whitey Herzog.
Horner underwent arthroscopic surgery in June after his left shoulder, injured 10 years ago, began to bother him. (AP)

Agassi, the top-ranked American in the world at No. 5, will face 12th-seeded Dan Goldie in a semifinal today.

Your Money; Comparing Costs Of Mutual Funds
LEAD: Mutual fund investors have often found it difficult to determine the cost of their investments.

Savings Unit Is Closed
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had closed the insolvent American Federal Savings and Loan Association of Anadarko, Okla., and shifted its insured deposits to the Midfirst Savings and Loan in Oklahoma City.
The board said depositors with less than $100,000 in their accounts would have access to their funds on Monday.


U.S. WILL PROVIDE BILLIONS TO RESCUE AILING TEXAS BANK
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tonight announced a bailout of the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas, one of the nation's largest and most troubled banking companies.


Reuters Profit Up by 26.2%
LEAD: Reuters, the news and financial information organization, this week reported a 26.2 percent rise in its pretax profit for the first half of 1988.
This was despite a sharp fall in revenue from trading room systems after last October's stock market collapse.

LEAD: Mike Conley, the silver medalist in the triple jump during the 1984 Olympic Games at Los Angeles, failed to make the United States team for the Seoul Games in the trials last week.
But the nine-time National Collegiate indoor and outdoor, long- and triple jump champion from the University of Arkansas said he has evidence that his final jump was measured inaccurately.

LEAD: New York City's mounting panhandling deluge has given new meaning to the question: to give or not to give?

Reviews/Music; Lively Music of Cambodia
LEAD: We hear a good deal of third-world music in New York, but while the sounds of certain countries are heard regularly enough to have acquired a certain familiarity, every now and then a concert is presented that reminds us how diverse the musical universe is.
The New York Open Center offered one such reminder last Saturday evening with a program called ''Traditional Music of Cambodia,'' performed by a quintet led by Sam-Ang Sam, a young doctoral candidate at Wesleyan University whose specialty is the music of the Khmer civilization.

Pearson Unit Sold To Amerada Hess
LEAD: Pearson P.L.C., the British conglomerate that publishes The Financial Times, said it had sold its British oil subsidiary, Whitehall Petroleum Ltd., to Amerada Hess Ltd. for $162 million in cash.
Lord Blakenham, chairman and chief executive of Pearson, said that Whitehall's oil interests had potential but that Pearson would have to make a substantial capital investment and wait for years before it would make a significant contribution to the conglomerate's profit.

Gunmen Raid Bus, Kill Driver
LEAD: Four men boarded a bus at a downtown stop early today and sprayed it with semiautomatic gunfire, killing the driver and wounding four passengers.


Bridge
LEAD: For 3,000 bridge enthusiasts who have converged here, today is a beginning.
But for a handful, it is also an ending.
The American Contract Bridge League Summer Nationals began 10 days of play this afternoon.

An Expectant Mother
LEAD: Ling-Ling, a giant panda, at Washington's National Zoo, where she is expected to give birth sometime next week.

Ellin Berlin, 85, a Novelist, Dies; The Songwriter's Wife of 62 Years
LEAD: Ellin Berlin, the novelist wife of the songwriter Irving Berlin, died early yesterday at Doctors Hospital, to which she had been taken from her Beekman Place town house after the last of a series of strokes.
She was 85 years old.


Good Trade-In
LEAD: Steve McGlothin, New Mexico State's starting center the last two basketball seasons, has said he would not trade anything for his last year of eligibility, not even his first car.
So the 6-8 McGlothin agreed to give up the 1988 automobile he won at a World Basketball League game July 13.

New Effort Takes Surplus Produce From Market to New York's Hungry
LEAD: Amid the bustle of deliverymen, forklifts, handcarts, trucks and crates at the Hunts Point Produce Market, a team of New York City workers is rescuing fresh produce and delivering it to the poor.


Patents; New Computer Chip Is Aid to Video Work
LEAD: Adrianus Ligtenberg, an electrical engineer with Bell Laboratories in Murray Hills, N.J., has developed a computer chip that permits easier manipulation of video images at computer work stations.
The inventor said the new chip would allow a desktop computer to read a compact disk and manipulate pictures and sound as well as printed text.

Du Pont Chemical Alternatives Due
LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company, a producer of chemicals that are depleting the earth's protective ozone shield, said it plans to begin producing alternatives to the chemicals by this fall.
The company will modify an existing plant in Montague, Mich., to produce alternatives to fully halogenated chlorofluorocarbons by as early as October.

Ambulances a Target for Koch Rivals
LEAD: Few would dispute that fast reliable ambulances are among the most essential of New York City's essential services.
So the failures of the Emergency Medical Service, which have been documented with distressing regularity and led yesterday to the resignation of James Kerr as executive director, seemed to shock Mayor Koch and put his administration on the defensive.

Reagan Says Ties to Hanoi Hinge on Issue of the Missing
LEAD: Speaking to the families of soldiers still unaccounted for in the Vietnam War, President Reagan warned today that the ''deep pain'' felt by the American people will continue to poison relations between Washington and Vietnam until Hanoi helps to resolve all questions concerning the men. ''It is in the interests of Hanoi,'' he said, ''to position itself for a new era and to help bring this to pass.

Grain and Soybeans Climb; Plunge in Cattle Prices Seen
LEAD: Grain and soybean futures scored their first major advance in more than two weeks yesterday, and many other commodity markets followed suit, reversing a trend of generally falling prices.


Honduran Admits Drug Link
LEAD: The former Honduran Ambassador to Panama faces a possible life sentence after pleading guilty to charges of trying to smuggle 26 pounds of cocaine hidden in coffee bags in his luggage.
Rigoberto Regalado Lara, 49 years old, was arrested May 15 at Miami International Airport and stripped of his diplomatic immunity by Honduran officials.

Treasury Bonds Turn Upward
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds rose for the first time in four sessions yesterday.
Dealers attributed part of the recovery to the usual pre-weekend portfolio balancing and an overnight improvement in market sentiment.

Firefighters Gain the Upper Hand in South Dakota
LEAD: A forest fire burning at the outskirts of Rapid City on Thursday.
Officials reported yesterday that the fire had been 90 percent contained and that they hoped to have it under control by Sunday.
The fire, which has been called the work of an arsonist, has been burning since Tuesday and has consumed about 3,000 acres of timber and destroyed 15 homes on the western edge of the city.

6 Held in Melee Set Off By Arrests of 2 Youths
LEAD: An arrest of two people for underage drinking triggered a disturbance in which 50 young people marched on the police station, breaking windows and taking a flag from its pole, the police said today.


Columnist Who Shot Trespasser To Face Gun Possession Charges
LEAD: Carl T. Rowan, the syndicated columnist who shot and wounded an unarmed trespasser in the backyard of his Washington home last month, was charged in District of Columbia Superior Court Wednesday with possession of an unregistered gun and unregistered ammunition.


SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 50.


Patents; Birth-Control Compound For Males
LEAD: A Canadian zoologist has developed a chemical contraceptive for males that he contends is ''safe, simple and cheap.'' The compound, which has been tested in rats, rabbits and monkeys, appears to stop sperm production without diminishing sex drive or causing unwanted side effects.


Guidepost: Phones With Flexibility
LEAD:  Cordless telephones - many are now on sale - are a convenience when the backyard or terrace becomes your summer living room.
Models and features vary widely depending on price.
Some contain answering machines, intercom systems and automatic dialers capable of storing up to 20 numbers.
Some can be used in a swimming pool and some allow both the base and the handset to be used as individual phones.

Review/Dance; Exploring the Eloquence of the Smaller Gestures
LEAD: Even the least connotative of gestures tend to have an inherent expressive quality.
And Victoria Marks explored that potential for expression in three dances she presented on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, in a concert shared with Rhys Chatham in the Serious Fun festival.


Singer Divestment
LEAD: The Singer Company, in the latest move in its divestment program, agreed to sell its American Meter division to West Germany's Ruhrgas A.G. for about $132 million.
Since the investor Paul A. Bilzerian bought Singer in January, the Stamford, Conn., company has pursued a policy of divestment, so far concluding seven sales agreements with a total value of about $1.7 billion.


JONES BEACH ALTERNATIVE: GIANT POOL
LEAD: A few hundred feet from the Atlantic Ocean at Jones Beach is the West Bathhouse Pool.
Why a pool so near an endless amount of water?
Well, not everyone likes the ocean.
