Long Island's Quick Garbage Fix
LEAD: Nassau County is considering a ban on plastic containers, like the law Suffolk County passed last spring.
The intent is to have them replaced by biodegradable forms of plastic or paper that will reduce the volume of waste in landfills.
But it's based, at least in part, on a misconception.

Campanis Uproar
LEAD: The Seattle chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has threatened to pickett or boycott Mariners' games if the team hires Al Campanis.
Campanis, 71 years old, was dismissed by the Los Angeles Dodgers last season following televised remarks in which he suggested that blacks lack ''the necessities'' to hold front-office jobs in baseball.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a civil rights suit brought against the state judiciary by Alton H. Maddox Jr. and an indigent murder suspect whom the lawyer had sought to defend at public expense.


Few Are Jobless in Japan

The Talk of Saratoga Springs; Suddenly, the Pounding of Hooves, a Whirl of Parties
LEAD: In August, Saratoga becomes the world capital of thoroughbred horse racing, for 24 days a glittering show with filled-to-capacity hotels and motels, crowded restaurants, balls, private parties in fashionable homes on the outskirts and traffic jams.


Hunt for Antidote Leads to the Spa
LEAD: The horseplayers of Belmont Park, never exactly a cheerful lot, are even more sour than usual these days.
With particular urgency, they are counting the hours until Saratoga opens Wednesday.
The Belmont meeting, now in its 70th of 72 days, has been with them too long.

Slayer of Youth Sentenced
LEAD: A professor convicted of killing and dismembering a teen-age male prostitute with a chain saw was sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison.
The 58-year-old defendant, Max Bernard Franc, taught political science at Fresno State University until his arrest last August.
His secret life as a homosexual voyeur was disclosed at his trial for the killing of Tracy Leroy Nute, 18, a runaway from Kansas City, Mo.


Review/Theater; Australians Adrift in a World of Kewpie Dolls
LEAD: It is with good reason that ''Summer of the Seventeenth Doll,'' a rawboned 1950's drama by Ray Lawler, is regarded in the playwright's homeland as a cornerstone of modern Australian drama.
The play, which depicts the middle-aged awakening of two Queensland sugar-cane cutters spending their New Year's holidays in a Melbourne suburb, is more than the story of people facing inevitable changes.


Coleco Receives New Financing
LEAD: Coleco Industries, which filed for bankruptcy protection less than three weeks ago, said it had found $50 million in new capital and ended its relationship with a crisis management team brought in to help run the company.

LEAD: Marco Baldi, the 6-foot 11-inch backup center from Italy who played three seasons with St.

B.A.T. Industries
LEAD: B.A.T.
Industries P.L.C., after successive setbacks in California and Oregon in its bid to buy Farmers Group Inc., said that the Arizona Department of Insurance had upheld its approval for it to take over the United States insurance company.
B.A.T., through its Louisville-based Batus Inc. subsidiary, said the Arizona Department of Insurance had denied a Farmers Group request for a rehearing on the company's proposed $4.5 billion takeover of the large insurer.

Manville's Novel Plan: Profits for Claimants
LEAD: The Manville Corporation is expected to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of this year as the first company run to generate money primarily for people injured by one of its products.
Both Manville and Wall Street are still trying to figure out the ramifications for the company, which sought bankruptcy protection in 1982 so it could deal with claims from people injured by asbestos.

Red Sox Win 18th Straight at Fenway
LEAD: Todd Benzinger hit a two-run homer in the third inning and then broke a tie with an r.b.i. single in the eighth tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-4, to sweep a doubleheader and win their 18th straight game at Fenway Park.


New Interest Seen In Zondervan
LEAD: The Zondervan Corporation said it had received an indication that a third party might be interested in a deal for the Bible publisher ''on terms substantially more favorable'' than the $57 million bid Zondervan has accepted from Harper &amp; Row Publishers Inc..


Welfare Steps Forward
LEAD: Before the year is out, President Reagan is likely to sign the first major revision of welfare since the creation of Aid to Families With Dependent Children in 1935.
That would represent a well-deserved personal triumph for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York.
It also represents a rare social policy step forward in the

Court Rejects an F.C.C. Curb On 'Indecency' in Broadcasts
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled today that a Federal Communications Commission ban on the broadcasting of ''indecent'' language during evening hours violated the rights of free speech.


Shuttle Test Firing Delayed Again After New Malfunctions Surface
LEAD: A critical test firing of the space shuttle Discovery's main engines was set back another three days today, until next Thursday, as engineers grappled with two new malfunctions - a mysterious hydrogen leak on the launching platform and a balky oxygen pump at some distance from the launching platform.

Elster's Homer Lifts Mets
LEAD: The second he hit it, Kevin Elster flipped his bat and began his home-run trot.
He would either look cocky or silly, he wasn't sure which.
One thing was certain: He had hit John Smiley's changeup as far as he could.


New Scheme Of a Schemer Fails in Court
LEAD: An apparent attempt by a confidence woman to trick a judge into giving her a lesser prison sentence on a forgery and grand larceny conviction backfired yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.


Leontine Ruth Young, Educator, 78
LEAD: Dr.
Leontine Ruth Young, an educator, social worker and author of books on child abuse, died of lung cancer Thursday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center.
She was 78 years old and lived in Cranbury, N.J.

The Decline Of A.K.A.
LEAD: This column cavalierly stripped the late Adm.
Arleigh Burke of one of his knots the other day by referring to him as ''Thirty-Knot Burke.'' His correct sobriquet (''a fanciful appellation,'' according to Webster's Third) was of course ''Thirty-One-Knot Burke.''

LEAD: Michael Fay of New Zealand reached a compromise yesterday with Doug Alford, commodore of the San Diego Yacht Club, to begin the America's Cup races Sept. 7.


Guyana Signs Oil Pact
LEAD: The Government of Guyana has signed an accord with British and Australian companies, allowing them to explore for oil about 60 miles off its shores in the Atlantic Ocean.
The agreement was signed Thursday between the state-owned Guyana Natural Resources Agency and London and Scottish Marine Oil P.L.C., based in London, and Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd.

LEAD: Burma for decades tried to find safety and prosperity by shutting out the world, but without success.

Though blessed with resources and a lively, friendly people, Burma has sunk to the world's 10-poorest list.

'Cry Freedom' Seized by South African Police
LEAD: The film ''Cry Freedom'' opened in more than 30 South African theaters today with censors' approval, but the police said it threatened public safety and seized copies of the film seven hours later.

Hurrying to Find Housing in Jersey
LEAD: Like 500 other welfare families who have exhausted their emergency shelter benefits, Sheila Gonzalez and her two sons have begun to pack their belongings and prepare to leave the Brookside Motel on Monday.


Couch Potatoes Arise; It's Time to Interact
LEAD: THE next phase in the development of the compact disk is interactive compact disks or CD-I.
These disks, which are still in the developmental stages, allow the user to, in essence, ''talk back'' to a television set to get information.
Philips and Sony are among the companies working on making CD-I available for the mass-market; they hope to have their products in stores as early as next summer.

LEAD: Executives of the financially ailing Atlantis Casino Hotel say their bet on plastic tokens for slot machines appears to be a winner.

Hospitals to Share Costly Equipment
LEAD: HOSPITALS around the state, which alone cannot handle the expense of buying some of the most modern, and expensive, health-care equipment, are forming partnerships to buy or lease the material jointly.
Purchasing such advanced equipment can cost about $2 million an item.
A pact has been announced for the first lithotripter in the state.

When Networking is Play
LEAD: NEARLY everyone knows about networking.
There are old-boy networks and professional women's networks, all devoted to helping their members achieve success in the get-ahead, stay ahead world of business.
Less publicized - but just as critical - is the network that exists amonth mothers who are home full time raising their children.


Inflation Redux?
LEAD: Last quarter, the gross national product grew by 3.1 percent, down from recent quarters but still fairly healthy.
Strong growth combined with high levels of capacity utilization and low unemployment is the classic formula for inflation.
But commodity prices have recently begun to fall due to a stronger dollar and the return of rain to the Middle West.

Teacher Traces Ebb and Flow of Education Over 6 Decades
LEAD: Since entering first grade in 1930 until my recent retirement as a professor of English, I have twirled about in six decades of education fads.
Some of these hoola hoops were productive, some regrettable, some destructive - but all were well-intentioned.
And in each decade the educators were absolutely certain that they at last had the correct philosophy.

Question Of the Week; Are You Following The Leadup To the Olympics?
LEAD: Yes, but only with some difficulty.
Trying to keep abreast of the selection of this year's United States Olympic team (much less other countries) through the media is strictly a hit-or-miss affair.
The parochial nature of United States sports means that domestic sports such as baseball overshadow international competitions such as track and field.


By Thinking Small, Investors Thrive
LEAD: RENT regulation extends a broad hand over New York City housing, determining to a great degree how much residents in more than one million apartments will pay in rent each month.
Even so, more than half a million apartments spread throughout the five boroughs are unfettered by government strings and rent for what the market will bear.

LEAD: As a professional woman and (formerly) the first national coordinator for women's health of the National Organization for Women, I have to agree, sadly though, with Mary Anne Dolan's observations of women today in the marketplace.

LEAD: THOSE WISHING TO find His Majesty Mohammad Zahir Shah must negotiate a series of country lanes in a wedge of suburban Rome that is still mostly pasture and forest.
Since he was overthrown in 1973, the former King of Afghanistan has accepted the genteel irrelevance of a deposed monarch - living quietly in Rome, confining his plotting to the bright red display of his electronic chess game.

Tosh and Ms.
Mowatt mixed Rastafarian songs with pop tunes; the contradictions between the asceticism of the religious compositions and the unabashed desire to entertain bothered neither the musicians nor the packed audience.

Venice Inside and Out
LEAD: Inside Venice, for us, was located only two brisk turns behind San Marco, ''the central building of the world,'' in the city that in certain moods looks as if it might still, for coherent beauty, rank as the central city of the world.
In 1987, when we were looking for a pied-a-terre in Venice, we were unexpectedly offered one, gratis, by a learned and charming Bolognese doctor, at that time unknown to us, who happens to agree with Ruskin about San Marco and the esthetic perfections of La Serenissima - the most Serene, an old name for Venezia.

Slayer of Youth Sentenced
LEAD: A professor convicted of killing and dismembering a teen-age male prostitute with a chain saw was sentenced Friday to 25 years to life in prison.
The 58-year-old defendant, Max Bernard Franc, taught political science at Fresno State University until his arrest last August.
His secret life as a homosexual voyeur was disclosed at his trial for the killing of Tracy Leroy Nute, 18.

B.
H., Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

POSTING: N.J. Conversions; Union City Blooms
LEAD: Not so long ago, Union City, N.J., was the only community between the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels that had not seen a great deal of residential construction and conversion.
While nearby cities like Weehawken and Hoboken have sprouted new condominiums and cooperatives whose marketing is directed at New York City across the harbor, landlocked Union City seemed to remain insular, concentrating on its own commercial districts along Bergenline Avenue and Kennedy Boulevard.

Where Freshness Is Foremost
LEAD: NOT every restaurant makes its own desserts and salad dressings.
Bruce's in Wainscott does.
Still fewer bake bread, churn ice cream and roll fresh pasta.
Bruce's does all five, plus makes sausages; smokes fish; sun-dries tomatoes; cooks up batches of jam, jelly and chutney and even ketchup.

Headliners; Back to Earth
LEAD: Elegant in the clinging draperies of her period, but looking sturdy enough to have pulled a plow back home on Mount Olympus, a 2,400-year-old goddess believed to be Aphrodite has been causing a stir in the world of classical art.
The J. Paul Getty Museum announced last week that it had acquired the marble-and-limestone statue of the goddess, seven and a half feet tall, for an undisclosed price.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  SKULLDUGGERY, by Peter Marks. (Carroll &amp; Graf, $4.50.) For years amateur historians have tried to discover who perpetrated the hoax of the Piltdown man by planting the bones that tricked anthropologists into believing they had found the missing link.
Last year, our reviewer, Patrick McGrath, said the imaginary solution offered in this novel was unconvincing but that Peter Marks ''displays a masterly grasp of the scientific subtleties  [ and ]  an extensive familiarity with the lives and works of the famous men who grace his pages.

Peru Holds an Arab Tied to Airport Raids In Rome and Vienna

Going From Music-Lovers to Mass Market
LEAD: IF there is a silvery glint in the eyes of music sellers and listeners, it is the reflection of millions of compact disks being popped into compact disk players.
About seven million compact disk players have been sold since 1983, the year they were introduced.
Over the past five years they have been selling better than video cassette recorders, of which 1.1 million were sold from 1983 through 1987, according to Link Resources, a New York-based market research group.


On Martha's Vineyard, A Drive Against Mopeds
LEAD: Several times this year a group of residents here on Martha's Vineyard have been driven through town on a flatbed truck, some of them dressed in bandages made to look bloody.
It is not a pretty sight.
But then, some residents said, neither is the plethora of accidents on motor-driven bicycles, or mopeds, that prompted the display and a campaign to ban moped rentals.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Agassi to Face Annacone: Second-seeded Andre Agassi advanced to the final of the Volvo International tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt., yesterday, using his powerful forehand and a looping topspin to beat 12th-seeded Dan Goldie, 6-3, 6-3.
Agassi's opponent today will be 13th-seeded Paul Annacone, who returned to his chip-and-charge game to defeat ninth-seeded Darren Cahill, 6-4, 6-3.

Now, a Way to Put Big Books Into Little Computers
LEAD: A NEW match is being made of compact disks and computers.
It's called CD-ROM, for ''compact disk-read only memory'' and it can drastically increase the storage capacity of a computer.
A CD-ROM is a 5 1/4-inch laser disk that contains the same amount of information as 1,200 floppy disks.

American Express Goes High-Tech
LEAD: IN recent months, holders of the American Express card have seen a change in their billing statements.
In the past, the bills came with a bulky packet of paper receipts of purchases.
Today those slips have been supplanted by neat laser-printed sheets containing as many as eight reduced images of the original receipts on a single page.

Sports of The Times; Night Games at Wrigley Field: Some Call It Progress
LEAD: A glossy black-and-white photograph came across the desk showing an aerial view of Wrigley Field in its new nighttime garb.
A longtime Wrigley Field fan and a keeper of the flame for old-time virtues looked at it. ''I hate it,'' he said. ''It looks beautiful.'' Indeed it did.
There was the flush of light on the ball field and this was set against the black velvet background of the surrounding city streets with their own diamond-sprinkle of lights.

No More Identity Crisis In Canada
LEAD: What is the National Ballet of Canada?
For nearly three decades it seemed to model itself after Britain's Royal Ballet; then suddenly, a few years ago, it began to resemble American Ballet Theater.
Nowadays, it looks, believe it or not, like the National Ballet of Canada - a company that has finally found its true identity.

PUSHING CIGARETTES OVERSEAS
LEAD: The thrust of Peter Schmeisser's article on American cigarette exports was predictable from its title, ''Pushing Cigarettes Overseas'' (July 10).
However, whether one likes or dislikes a product is a matter quite apart from whether or not it should be treated equitably in world trade.
Some people think we would be better off without televisions and motorcycles, but the existence of those products worldwide is a matter of everyday reality.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  IMPROVISATION: Music From the Inside Out.
By Mildred Portney Chase. (Creative Arts, Paper, $7.95.) Improvisation, as we are often reminded, is concert music's lost art.
Two hundred years ago, cadenzas in concerto movements served to launch the individual performer's flights of fancy; cadenzas today are simply repetitions of what someone else has already written out.

LEAD: KEEP after weeds and pull them out; use mulches so the soil stays moist and smothers additional weed growth.

Check gerberas, petunias, geraniums, fuchsias, ageratums and other border favorites for white flies; control, if found.

LEAD: BY chance I visited three doctors in one day recently - one for a mammography, one to examine a lump on my first rib, and one to X-ray that lump.
That meant that I had the opportunity to wear three types of hospital gowns in one day, making me realize that no major changes had occurred in gown design in recent years, despite great progress in so many other areas affecting women.

The Defense Speaks for Mark Belanger
LEAD: IT may well be that nothing funny happened to Willie Stargell on his way to induction today into the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, but something passing strange seems to have affected at least a few of the people whose votes helped put him there.
I should know.
I was one of them.


In London This Summer, Masses of Old Masters
LEAD: Old master paintings have been at home in London for close on 400 years, but right now there is what might be called a new nonchalance in the way in which they come into view.
It is not that they are taken for granted - how could they be, when so many of them have been made new for us by recent cleaning?


Question Of the Week; Are You Following The Leadup To the Olympics?
LEAD: Yes.
But for objective media coverage I have to turn to sources other than the home press and television.
The domestic media continue to report on the Olympics with a parochial fervor that borders on arrogance.


Is Modern Recycling Really Progress?
LEAD: As a believer in the conservation of our natural resources, I have always been enthusiastic about the benefits of recycling empty bottles and cans.
So it was a sad day recently when I nearly gave in to the temptation to simply throw away my returns rather than go through what was turning out to be an exasperating procedure for a cleaner environment.


Ethics and Fetal Research: Government Begins to Move
LEAD: FOR years, scientists who wanted to do research involving human embryos and fetuses have found themselves in a Catch-22 situation.
They could do their work with impunity, and receive Federal funds for it, so long as an ethics advisory board approved their proposals.
The catch is that the board does not exist, and has not for nearly a decade.

Not Moving
LEAD: THE owner of the Seattle Mariners announced that he would not take immediate advantage of an escape clause in his lease with the Kingdome that would allow him to move the team to another city next season.
The statement by George Argyros came after considerable speculation in Seattle that he would invoke a provision of the lease that allows him to seek a new site for the team if attendance fails to average 1.4 million for two consecutive seasons, an average the Mariners failed to acheive.

LEAD: THEIR mothers and grandmothers - according to the famous advertisements that ran from the late 1940's into the 60's - dreamed of showing up at the poshest of places clad in their Maidenform bras.

CLASIC bLACK
LEAD: In the contemporary design world, black conjures up images of sleek, high-tech objects and stark spaces.
But countless old-fashioned decorative accessories are black, too.
Indeed, black can be as romantic and alluring as it can be gloomy, perhaps because it is an earth pigment that in the color spectrum expresses violet.


Olympic Athlete Jackie Joyner-Kersee
LEAD: TOWARD THE end of a steamy afternoon at the United States Olympic track and field trials in Indianapolis two weeks ago, Jackie Joyner-Kersee listened intently as her coach and husband, Bob Kersee, talked about the 200-meter sprint, her next task in the seven-event, two-day heptathlon.
Run the curve as if it were the straightaway, her coach told her, and the straightaway will take care of itself.

BUSINESS FORUM: EMPLOYEE BENEFITS FOR THE 1990's; Business Needs a Family Policy
LEAD: EFFECTIVE July 1, all permanent Connecticut state employees are entitled to 24 weeks of family leave within any two-year period, upon the birth or adoption of a child or the serious illness of a child, spouse or parent of the employee.
A medical leave of absence of 24 weeks is also permissible if the employee should become seriously ill.

3 Museums That Tell Venice's Story
LEAD: Venice offers such extraordinary works of art in diverse settings that even the most ambitious sightseer must make choices.
For those who appreciate viewing art in the context of history, three museums will provide insight into the development of this island city.
These are the Correr Museum in the Piazza San Marco, the Museum of the Venetian 18th Century in Ca' Rezzonico on the Grand Canal, and the Naval Museum near the Arsenal, at the eastern end of the city.

Soviet Union
LEAD: To the Editor: Ray Warners's letter (Travel, May 29) expressing disappointment due to unfufilled promises from Intourist during a Soviet tour is no surprise to anyone who has been there.
The Intourist attitude is arrogant and often misleading.


Giants' Old Pro Is Mellow
LEAD: This is his 13th National Football League season, and he will be 35 years old before it ends.
He has been voted to the Pro Bowl nine times in the last 10 years.
His skills may have diminished somewhat and he may no longer be the game's best inside linebacker, but he is certainly among the wisest and the best.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  SALAMANDER: The Story of the Mormon Forgery Murders.
By Linda Sillitoe and Allen D. Roberts with a forensic analysis by George J. Throckmorton. (Signature, $17.95.) Mark Hofmann, a premed student, decided at age 25 to become a professional forger of old documents.
For several years in the early 1980's he had outstanding success as he turned the Mormon world upside down while he picked its pockets and cast doubt on some of its fundamental beliefs.

So does Michael Dukakis.

IN THE WHIRL AND MUDDLE OF WAR
LEAD: Sometime in the late 1920's, Horace Pippin, a black American veteran of World War I, began to write his memories of his war.
It must have been difficult: Pippin was not a writer and was not very well educated.
Even the physical act of writing was hard for him, for his right hand and arm had been crippled by a sniper's bullet and he could scarcely hold a pen.

The Second Time Around
LEAD: They say that love is sweeter the second time around.
I wouldn't know: I'm still enjoying the first tour.
But I do know that, when it comes to foreign travel as opposed to domestic affairs, attempts to maintain sentimental relationships born of impetuousness are not always easy.
They are fraught with unanticipated frustrations that play havoc with the emotions.

LEAD: The play is about two couples who rent a two-family house in the suburbs of Detroit.
The first has been married for 45 years.
Frank, a World War II veteran, has never matched his military achievements in postwar civilian America, but is without question the man of his household.
Mattie, his wife, has been the rock of the relationship.

Lucille Thompson, 66, Professor

Corrections
LEAD: A table last week with an article about McGraw-Hill Inc. mislabeled the company's second-quarter results for 1988 and 1987.
For the 1988 quarter, revenues were $443.8 million, net income was $44.8 million and earnings per share were 92 cents.
For the 1987 quarter, revenues were $425.9 million, net income was $40 million and earnings per share were 79 cents.


High Tide, Fat Fish: Story for a Sunday Afternoon
LEAD: IT was high tide on a Sunday afternoon and the fishermen were lined up along Bayville's beach.
The swimming season had not yet begun, and out-of-towners were still welcome.
There is something reassuring about a group of men standing or sitting quietly at the waterfront, attending to their fishing rods with calm, deliberate motions, ignoring the passage of time.

For Sid Fernandez, it is not the standard spelling of his name.
It is, though, an increasingly common way of summarizing his game.

Maine Coast
LEAD: As you drive up the coast from Portland to Bar Harbor, rocky, evergreen-lined bluffs taper into sandy shores.
Spartan fishing villages give way to towns with boutiques, restaurants and galleries.
Simplicity and sophistication coexist along this 161-mile stretch that is Maine's midcoast region.
The best way to get a feel for the terrain is by car, a trip that can take a few hours or a few days, preferably accompanied by DeLorme's Maine

The Legacy Of Widowhood
LEAD: ONE OCTOBER EVENING 21 months ago, my husband and I went out to dinner and to see ''La Traviata'' at the Metropolitan.
We ate at a favorite restaurant and he said that I looked beautiful in my new wool suit.
Since my outfit was a decade old, I smiled and thanked him for his compliment: we'd been married for 21 years.

Bookshelf
LEAD: TOPSY TURVY.
Written and illustrated by Monika Beisner.
Farrar, Straus &amp; Giroux. $12.95. (All ages) The rich and witty illustrations that accompany this collection of short verses, adapted from the German by Daniel Huws, are full of topsy-turvy incongruities.
A little girl sits on the lap of her wooden doll, kites dance on the ground while children fly in the sky, a cuckoo hatches kittens from her eggs.
